A bit conflicted on this one. Is Birdman a good movie? Absolutely. Is it an Academy Award best picture movie? That I'm not so sure of. The first half was a fairly generic, slightly pretentious theater drama. The second half (when it really starts to focus on the Riggan Thomson character) is when the movie gets really good. Michael Keaton gives the best performance of his career. It's a great performance and watching the character struggle with his ego and come to terms accepting that maybe he just isn't very good is both funny and sad. I really enjoyed this movie for Michael Keaton (which it really is all about), but when he's not on camera and there's a shift in focus to other characters the movie loses a bit of its luster. Not to say there weren't some memorable or funny moments early on in the movie, it just wasn't as good as what was to come.

Of course a lot of people will enjoy this movie, but it's about getting through that first act. Must see.

Tuve cierta reticencia para con esta película, si hay algo que de verdad aborrezco son las películas hollywoodienses de super-heroes modernas tipo Iron Man, The avengers, Los 4 fantásticos, etcétera.  Ojo, con esto no estoy reparando en las películas clásicas de este género, véase Batman o incluso Superman por citar dos ejemplos por todos conocidos.  
El nombre "Birdman"  me sugería que la película estaría basada en aquella caricatura  que pasaban por Cartoon Network hace décadas. Resulto ser todo lo contrario, "Birdman" es la antítesis de estas super-producciones, creo que la filmaron en una toma, los efectos especiales son esporádicos, incluso la banda sonora es jocosa, ya que la interpreta un baterista que incluso llega a aparecer en una toma. 
Birdman es una  critica muy ácida al mundillo de los blockbusters , llega enhorabuena, ya que últimamente no parecen existir películas decentes, todo lo producido es meramente diseñado para entretener a la mayor cantidad de consumidores posibles, sirviendo quizás únicamente para vender muñequitos de cera coleccionables y cajitas felices en los Mcdonals.  , 
Resulta paradójico ver a Keaton  interpretando el papel de Birdman, pareciera ser un reflejo de su vida misma, ya que fue el quien alguna vez interpreto al caballero de la noche. En el transcurso de la película, destaca la lucha de este para no ceder ante  o que damos por sentado hoy en día. Es decir, medir nuestra popularidad por el número de seguidores o likes en el mundo virtual. 
Existe una mofa muy bien intencionada, que incluso se llega a confundir con pretensión, no obstante esto no es atribuible a la película en sí, es mas bien una sensación que se da mientras uno la ve. 
En fin, me alegró ver una película así, una que me inspire a escribir incluso una breve reseña. La recomiendo mucho.

In Birdman: Or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance), Michael Keaton plays Riggan Thomson, a nearly washed-up actor best known for playing a Hollywood super-hero called Birdman (not unlike Batman whom Keaton famously played in the first two films of that franchise in 1989 and 1992 directed by Tim Burton). Riggan is desperate to escape the shadow of the role that made him famous and he puts everything he's got on the line (financially, emotionally, mentally) to direct and star in a dramatic play based on a short story by Raymond Carver that he desperately hopes will salvage his reputation if not resurrect his career. Along the way, Riggan battles with everyone around him (his co-stars, his lover, his daughter) and with Birdman himself, who appears like a specter or perhaps more accurately like one of those little devils floating above cartoon characters' heads whispering evil encouragements, here life-size and with huge menacing wings. All the while, Emmanuel Lubezki's camera literally follows Riggen, mostly through the dark interiors of the St. James Theater where the film is set in extremely long shots edited together as if in one long take, creating a powerful sense of propulsion and urgency.

Keaton gives a committed performance, ironically playing down his usual squinty-eyed disapproval of everyone and everything around him, portraying a man who is put-upon by the world and trying to do just one good and worthy thing. Naomi Watts and Zach Galifianakis turn in typically strong performances while Emma Stone as Riggan's daughter Sam leaves little room for shades of gray in her exaggerated role as a druggie pessimist. The plot is as contained as the set and some scenes feel forced or even unnecessary. To what purpose other than titillation do we see Naomi Watts and Andrea Riseborough lock lips? And the casualness with which Riggan finishes a joint he finds on Sam after ripping into her for still using drugs feels like a weak attempt at portraying hypocrisy. Yet just as often there are remarkable scenes, such as when Keaton and Ed Norton as Riggan's co-star in the play run through a scene in rehearsal, Norton's infamous bad-boy stage actor Mike flashing his acting chops to a fiery yet receptive Riggan.

Through it all runs a magical realism that finds Riggan floating in the air and moving objects with his mind. The effects are outstanding, particularly a scene where Riggan literally flies over New York City. This reflection of Riggan's Birdman, both the character and the inner demon, is potentially undercut by the film's final scene in which Emma Stone's Sam is seen staring out a window breaking into a smile apparently observing Riggan floating in the air. The impossibility of that occurring in real life can perhaps best be explained as being imagined images flashing through Riggan's mind as he lay dying on stage after shooting himself in the head. Or perhaps he died earlier, jumping off the roof in the afore-memtioned scene that feels so real it's shocking until Riggan re-appears soaring over the city street. The director himself has been mum on explaining the film's ending except to say that it replaced an earlier "bad" ending. One has to wonder if that earlier ending was the more expected if not predictably satisfying one in which Sam, in a rare display of affection, lays her head on Riggan's chest in the hospital where he lay recuperating from that gunshot wound that turned out to be a minor injury. Though even that defies logic as the way the gunshot is filmed, it seems clear Riggan is holding the gun directly to his head; in the hospital he's told he shot his nose off but when he removes the bandage all we really see is a huge bruise. The ending will surely divide its audience and that's not a bad thing as ultimately Birdman: Or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance), infused with questions about the value of art and the power of criticism, certainly gives viewers much to chew on.

I loved and understood every weird minute of it.  Often, I think a lot about the fine line between exerting one's ego and having lasting, meaningful influence over people. Especially as someone that is super extroverted and works in a field where I am essentially "on stage" all day.  I think about the difference between charisma and attention-seeking. This movie thinks about those issues really deeply.  I related to it very much. So by being able to connect to the essential questiosn in the film, does that make me a huge egoist? The term 'Oscar bait' is an interesting little concept.  If you've been living under a movie nerd rock, this essentially means that some films are made simply for the chance to get a lot of Oscar nominations.  They do this by pandering to what the Academy likes.  Whether it be stories of perseverance in the face of extreme adversity or subversiveness and/or satire of the business these people find themselves in.  These films are strategically marketed in order to be fresh in the minds of Oscar voters, which is why a lot of them are released in November/December prior to the Oscars.  While I agree that there is some thing as Oscar bait, in the sense that some films are made strictly for that purpose, at the same time, does that mean that the final edit of the film is any less because of it?  If the film is great then isn't that what should matter in the long run?  The Oscars are self-serving as it stands.  I guess this is brought on due to the fact that the film's main character Riggan Thomson is an alcoholic, schizophrenic on the verge of losing his mind due to the mounting stress of putting on a play that, from all accounts, seems like it's gonna be a disaster.  That's the type of shit the Academy loves, right?  Well I found this movie to be excellent, maybe not Best Movie material, though I reserve the right to change my mind as I write out this review.  First things first, Michael Keaton is absolutely incredible here.  I don't mean to suggest that Keaton is a washed up actor or anything of the sort, but the character of Riggan Thomson is in, many ways, much like Keaton's career himself after he stopped playing the Batman character.  So maybe because of that, Keaton felt an attachment to the script and to the role itself.  It doesn't mirror Keaton's career exactly, but it's close enough to the real thing where Keaton pulls it off in a incredibly believable manner.  You can just see this man, obsessed with putting on a perfect play in order to prove to the world that he can, outside of putting on a costume to play a superhero, playing to the lowest common denominator, produce meaningful and worthwhile art.  Of course, on the way to putting on the perfect play he faces his own ego, a method actor, Shiner played by the always great Edward Norton, who seemingly tries to sabotage Riggan's play at every turn, his own struggles with his family and his attempts to make everything right after being such a fuck-up, a theater critic that wants Riggan's play to fail at any cost so she'll write a negative review about it regardless, Birdman's voice continually mocking him and his attempts at being taken seriously as an artist when he could, just as easily, be making billions on a film franchise.  He's also facing the complete disdain from the theater crowd, who just sees him as a talentless hack.  All of these things, particularly with Riggan's mental state, has filled him with such stress and insecurity that you almost exactly know how everything's gonna turn out and it's not a happy ending, which we'll get to later.  This is really a satire of theater snobbery, summer blockbusters, Hollywood pretentiousness (from Riggan's point of view, at least).  Here's this guy who's been known only for his Birdman series taking a very serious undertaking in the form of a Broadway play when he has absolutely no experience on the stage.  The film's tagline, The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance, also the title of the theater critic's review in the film, very obviously applies to Riggan's attempts to put on this play.  Riggan's pretentiousness clearly got the better of him.  His attempts to remain relevant in an ever-changing world has done a number on him.  He wants to be famous again, but he wants to be famous on his own terms, he wants to be appreciated for his art, not for a character where you barely got to see his face behind the mask.  It is pretty excellent character development if you ask me and the cast is replete.  The film is very funny, which makes the eventuality of Riggan's path all the more powerful.  Which brings us to the ending, or part of it  There will be ****MASSIVE SPOILERS**** so skip ahead.  Riggan finally loses his mind, or what was left of it, when he gets into an argument with the theater critic the day before his play premieres, there have been several previews prior to this that have been disastrous.  Essentially, the critic will give Riggan's play a bad review regardless of what happens on-stage, because she hates Riggan's kind, the Hollywood type, who think they can come in and take over their chosen field of profession, or what they review in her case.  This is also a satire of the nature of some film criticism where people make up their mind based on preconceived notions rather than giving the film a fair shot.  Riggan then proceeds to get drunk off his ass and falls asleep on an apartment's steps.  He's woken up by Birdman, mocking him yet again, and telling him to get over himself and to stop this pretentious bullshit and give the audience what they want, which is action, blood, death, etc.  Riggan finally agrees with Birdman on something, after trying to get rid of him all throughout the film, and he decides to give the audience something that they will never forget.  All the while explosions and giant bird robots destroy New York City (all in Riggan's mind).  You can guess where this is going to lead.  By this point, Riggan has already plotted ahead how his own journey will end in his mind.  Keep that in mind.  The play culminates with Riggan's character killing himself at his lowest point.  So Riggan, wanting to give the audience something they'll never forget, actually shoots himself on stage at the climax of the play.  You believe that he's dead, only for the next scene to be at the hospital where, it is revealed, that Riggan only shot his nose off and how he got a new one.  His play is a success, they got a great review from that theater critic, he's relevant again and, most importantly, his family is back together again.  Sounds a little odd, does it not?  I think the biggest hint that something is off here is that, when Riggan reveals his new nose, there are no stitches around it.  Assuming this took place a day after Riggan shot his nose off, there would HAVE to be stitches.  You could say that this was just an oversight, a tiny mistake.  But, watching this film, and its attention to detail, and how impeccably edited it was, this isn't accident.  Every shot is calculated and measured.  This is what Alejandro Gonzales Iñárritu and his team of editors wanted you to see.  It's a very obvious clue as to what's going on here.  Everything is just too perfectly resolved.  My theory is, and this seems to be the popular theory, is that what you saw at the end was a construct of Riggan's own self-conscious.  This was the way he would've wanted to see his life end.  He's beloved by his family, beloved by the people, and beloved by the critics.  These are some things that few people ever manage to achieve separately, much less at the same time.  Riggan wanted to die at his 'peak', if you will.  So people would talk about him for ages and ages.  Of course, the theory changes a bit because I believe that Riggan DID shoot himself in the head, rather than shooting his nose clean off, and he's in a coma nearing death.  The final shot of the film, with Sam looking up and seeing her father's powers, was symbolic because this was the moment where Riggan died.  That's my opinion.  It's very possible that the ending actually did happen, but I happen to doubt that very much.  You know, reviewing this film, I've come to the realization that my score of 4 stars is simply too low.  I'll bump that up to 4.5 stars.  I think there's simply too much greatness here for the film to be anything less than 4.5.  The writing is absolutely fabulous, the editing is perfection, makes every scene look like it's one long take.  The acting from the cast is excellent, with Keaton being absolutely incredible here.  And I think this is a film that will reward repeat viewings.  There's a lot of subtext here that I probably missed, repeat viewings will definitely tear that down.  This is an excellent film, one that's more of an acquired taste than you'd think, but one that's worth watching nonetheless.  I realize this means that, to some people who hated the film, this makes me an idiot, but I honestly don't give a shit.  I thought the film was great and I think I've done a decent job as to explaining why.  If you don't like it, then I'm sorry, that's why they are called OPINIONS.  There's no right or wrong.  This is surreal, but it's an excellent movie.

Despite a phenomenal performance from Michael Keaton, "Birdman" is a frustrating, polarizing and ultimately disappointing film that fails to live up to the hype. While far from a total failure- given that this is the film that took home the Oscar for Best Picture- it could have been so much more. On the one hand, I definitely admire aspects to this film from the brilliant performances to the marvelous cinematography. Yet, regardless of these superior qualities, it's a film that leaves the viewer conflicted. To start with the positive first, the acting is absolutely amazing. Each and every star is at the top of their game, particularly Michael Keaton who delivers the finest performance of his career. Edward Norton is also a joy to watch; charismatic, charming and full of life. Even Emma Stone steps out of her comfort zone to deliver what may be the best performance of her career to date. Did I even mention Zach Galifianikis? Apart from the acting, the writing is truly breathtaking. Putting the audience into the head of a conflicted movie-star, it is filled with sharp, funny and often thought-provoking dialogue that raises questions about the movie-making business. Then there' s the intense one-shot cinematography, which is unlike anything I've ever seen before in a movie. However, it's ultimately not enough to make up for a film that's paced poorly. While the first-half of the film is incredibly exciting to watch unfold, it loses steam towards the end. To elaborate, the movie takes ridiculous twists and turns that seem to go nowhere. The ending, though, is a major disappointment. Nonsensical, confusing and leaving important questions unanswered, it left me more irritated than awe-struck. Taking everything into account, "Birdman" is a film that definitely needs to be seen more than once to be fully understood. It provides interesting insights into movie-business, critics and the pressures of being an actor in today's media-driven world. However, in the bigger picture, it only offers glimpses of genius. I definitely admire the film for it's risky choices, ambition and originality, but in the end it fell short of my expectations. Whether you like it or not, will ultimately depend on your patience as a viewer. Regardless, if there's one reason why it's worth watching, it's for Michael Keaton's timeless performance that will long be remembered in the years to come.

Birdman: ¿González Iñárritu vuela o cae?

Por Rafael R. Deustúa

El director mexicano González Iñárritu derrocha talento técnico en su nueva película, "Birdman o la inesperada virtud de la ignorancia", con una oscura y densa narración que bien puede ser el peso que le impida volar. Cada espectador lo decidirá.

Hace casi 30 años Riggan Thompson era "Birdman", gran superhéroe de la taquilla, pero renunció al papel aunque el personaje nunca lo dejó a él. Hoy día gastó todo su dinero en una obra teatral de Broadway que él protagoniza, dirige, produce y escribe con la idea de recuperar su propio orgullo como actor y persona, fuera del dinero y fama "fáciles" del cine.

Intensidad es la palabra clave para todo salvo para el libreto. El guión es directo al retratar la crisis de su protagonista y su lucha personal por sobrevivir a sí mismo, aunque al mismo tiempo abusa del realismo mágico para no comprometerse con un final y éste sería el gran defecto/virtud de una película ambigüa.

González Iñárritu produce, escribe y dirige ésta cinta apoyado de un gran equipo técnico al mando de su compatriota Emmanuel Lubezki. Tal como Riggan tiene su alterego y competencia en Birdman, el director lo tiene en su cinematógrafo pues viendo la película es difícil sabe a quien atribuir sus méritos.

Técnicamente ésta película es más compleja que cualquiera de efectos especiales de éste año. La cámara sigue a los actores en una aparente toma continua en un delirio y pesadilla de coordinación. La táctica nos contagia de la intensidad narrativa que, además, es en algunas secuencias musicalizada con una batería de jazz que parece improvisar (coordinar eso es otro mérito, pues en algunas tomas vemos al baterista). Aún así se mantiene una estética visual extraordinaria, un impecable manejo de enfoque y luces, para retratar la miseria detrás de bambalinas.

Michael Keaton, Edward Norton, Naomi Watts, Zach Galifianakis, Lindsay Duncan, Andrea Risenborough y Emma Stone se lucen en las interpretaciones, el guión honra a los actores y ellos a sus personajes, aún cuando sus historias queden inconclusas.

Los méritos de "Birdman", como su intensidad, serán motivo de que algunos la rechacen: El filme es pesado y duro de digerir, por ello algunos lo alabarán y otros no. A medio camino entre el arte y lo comercial, se anota como candidato a candidaturas del Oscar.

Excelente como película de arte, pésima película comercial.
Con anterioridad he comprobado que los Oscares son una forma de hacer comerciales las películas de arte y Birdman no es la excepción. Es una excelente película porque está filmada de manera que no se notan mucho los cortes de edición como si fuera una sola secuencia, salvo dos cortes y transiciones que sí tiene. Pareciera que es un solo tiempo cuando la misma trama nos va revelando que las transiciones están hechas por la misma secuencia de la cámara. Es una excelente cinta, sin duda, para los cineastas, por eso no me extrañó que los frikis y otras personas no muy allegadas al cine la vieran como aburrida o que los fanboys del cine la vieran de tal o cual forma sin fijarse en qué era lo que en realidad simbolizaba la película.
Al igual como comentaron con la película de la vida de Hawkings, esta tampoco se escapa de un checklist obligatorio para hacerla ganadora. Uno de estos elementos es el retomar propuestas cinematográficas de diferentes directores como David Lynch, Gaspar Noé, Christopher Nolan, Woody Allen (en las partes de la comedia, porque es una especie de humor negro), David Fincher y otros tantos más que se me escapan.
Hay tantos matices en Birdman que es muy difícil que se puedan englobar en un solo artículo de una crítica. Es por eso que mejor me voy a saltar toda la paja y decir que si no se le entendió a Birdman o se le encasilló solo como una crítica al teatro, como una crítica a la crítica del cine y del teatro, como una crítica a Hollywood o como simplemente una propuesta más de cine, entonces no se entendió Birdman. Birdman son muchas historias en una sola. Son muchos elementos que se deben admirar y al mismo tiempo aburren al cinéfilo. No es una película hecha para cualquier público pero eso no quita que no se le de una buena calificación. Cualquiera que sabe de cine, al menos un poco, como este humilde servidor podrá detectar por qué le gustó tanto a la academia al grado de darle los premios que se ganó. Y sin duda, eso merece un gran aplauso de pie para Iñarritu.

The cast of "Birdman" is excellent, but the strongest and most impressive performances in the film come in the form of Emma Stone, Zach Galifianakis, and Lindsay Duncan, with Michael Keaton playing the lead and his notorious alter ego, Birdman -- you've got to hand it to a man who can not only openly satirize his own role in the old, Tim Burton "Batman" movies, but also simultaneously be confident enough to walk down Times Square, through the sea of people, wearing nothing but a pair of socks and some whitey-tighty underwear -- and Edward Norton's performance is deceptively and despicably brilliant: you can never quite tell whether Norton's character is simply assuming the role of the pretentious method actor in order to get on the other actors' nerves or whether he's genuinely one of the most self-absorbed jackass stage actors to ever live.

Birdman is absolutely fantastic from start to finish.  Aesthetically it feels like you're watching a production because everything is go, go, go, go, go 100% of the time and I love that it's almost like a revolving door.  We get to see characters here and there talking with one another in standout selections and then its right back into the chaos.  Michael Keaton's performance is wonderful:  tragic, funny, likeable Keaton pulls out all of the stops for this performance.  The surrounding cast is also fantastic whether it's Emma Stone playing the drug addict daughter with the foul mouth but has the heart of gold, or Edward Norton as the asshole actor who is the "real" actor not the "fake" actor like people in movies.  The music is also wonderful, I loved the jazz soundtrack, it kept the film moving at a break neck pace the entire time.  With all of that said, I can see why Hollywood chose it as Best Movie of the Year because it fits in line with what they were trying to say at this years Oscars.  Those big budget movies with special effects galore and explosions...aren't movies.  They're not filled with actors they're filled with celebrities.  It's a very pretentious statement to make but they made it loud and clear and Birdman symbolizes that.  Keaton's character only wants to be taken seriously as an actor, he wants to put on this stage production, he's trying to change who he is in the face of the public which ultmately is why people don't like him because it's not as much about the work that he's doing, because no matter how serious he is about doing something...it's always about his image.  He is the star, he is the director, and he wants to be known for something other than Birdman.  The film makes a lot of statements about the industry and its awesome that they got Keaton to play the part because it adds a whole other meta layer to the film that it might not have had, had it gotten someone else to play the part which in itself is kind of ironic seeing as how the film is about people who normally wouldn't get the part because of someone with celebrity status like Keaton getting the part.  Birdman is an awesome film--funny, smart, fast, and ultimately tragic.  I highly recommend it.

Birdman is a technical masterpiece which has been crafted with real flair by innaritu and it has some excellent performances driving it's dream like state from Michael Keaton, Ed Norton and Emma stone.  this would be five stars if it weren't for the fact it relies on its technical flair just a little too much for me.

A movie with striking reviews, a hoard of awards, an A-list cast, and yet a complete waste of time.  I really wanted to like this movie, I convinced myself if I sat through it a little longer, it would get better...that never happened.  The movie tries too hard to be everything it's not.  I hated the over-indulged storyline, the filming, the constant camera movements, the closeups on the faces of the actors... annoying and distracting.  While the movie features some of the best actors in the industry, at times, their over-acting was off-putting and comical.  I think this movie had potential, but entirely missed the mark. How this movie won any award or earned any positive reviews mystifies me.  Likely just a case of trying to keep up with undeserved hype by jumping on the bandwagon of desperation.  This movie is crap.  Plain and simple.

Birdman was my most highly anticipated movie in month and in many ways it delivered. But while I loved the existential quandary on life, moments frequently grew too artsy to watch... Things were metaphorical for the sake of metaphor -- with no other purpose than to make it seem whimsical. Quick dialogue and an anticlimactic ending left more to be desired...  But there are few movies that'll beat this.

Pretentious and boring with the stupid constantly moving camera work that makes me feel carsick.  Highly overrated movie.  Birdman's only redeeming feature is its impressive cast doing what comes naturally.  I was so looking forward to Michael Keaton's comeback role.  Too bad I hate the movie.

With a concept and its direction as ambitious as this, Birdman or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance) more than delivers, with outstanding performances by all of its ensemble cast, great cinematography and the best directing I have seen from 2014.  I should also add that it is also the kind of film to get a laugh out of, and it excels at that with its exceptional writing.
Just an ok movie, don't understand the hype..

This one some awards, and I can see why.  The acting was really good.  It's really a bizarre movie, though.  A guy who used to act as a superhero hears/sees the alter-ego.  He's directing a play and it gets wacky after that.  The play is sort of based off his life and at times you can't tell what's real or not.  The real life blends into the play and then the play blends into the real life.  At times you think they're acting and then they go backstage and it's real and they're fighting... well made.

We have no right to speak for the human race, we cannot speak for the characters that crawl into broadway success, we cannot even speak for Riggan, he already struggles with that by himself. But Riggan speaking with the Birdman? Now that has it's own agenda in mind for laughs, for breakdowns, for tireless whining of the lesser beings, and the piss-street walk of shame under the influence of an unrelenting hangover..........and we'll make of that what we will.

About as good as film gets,  the kind of film that reminds me of why I love cinema and film. Technically,  this is a breathtaking exercise with the camera moving around in seemgly impossible ways. Add to this a superb cast,  Norton has not been this good in years, ditto for Watts and Stone.  Ultimately, this is Keaton and Alejandro's show.  Keaton is just brilliant with a layered performance that highlights insecurities and ambition in ways that just blew me away.  Simply put,  I haven't seen a film like this before and it grabs me each time I see it....

One of the worst movies I attempted to watch, I walked out after a while. How do such terrible movies get financed, let alone win undeserved awards? There were many far better movies this year that deserved an Oscar for Best Picture. The only reason I can come up with for this award is that the movie mostly took place backstage in a theater which most Academy members are familiar with. But to non-actors I would say, avoid this film, there are plenty of better films out there to watch.

I liked the concept of an actor trying to live down his past as an action hero and prove that he could do theatre, Michael Keaton was terrific and I thought the direction was superb as it seamlessly melded scenes together.  Yet, when it was all over, I felt a bit let down; I would've preferred if it had ended 10 minutes earlier (and I don't want to give away spoilers, but there's a place where it could've easily ended).  Overall, it was a really good movie, but I think Boyhood was more deserving of the Oscar!
The acting is first class and the "continuous" shot is impressive,  but I think you have to be in th world of acting to be truly in on the joke

Birdman, more than most, seems a film that deserves a second viewing, not only to admire the work of Keaton and his co-stars, but to delve into its many layers. Alejandro takes advantage of every facet of Keaton's talent, from his knack for absurdist comedy to his seemingly effortless ability to tap into graceful profundity without making a big show of it.The Father-Daughter ( portrayed by beautiful and talented Emma Stone ) gives a perfect microscopic view of a modern dysfunctional family relationship. Ed Norton, Zach and Naomi Watts each contribute well to their characters. At last all praises goes to Alejandro González Iñárritu for creating such a unique film.

Aun asi, no es una pelicula con una historia fuerte y tampoco envolvente, lo dicho, mas una obra interpretativa que una pieza coleccionable. En mi opinion, otro error de la academia.

It's easy to see why the Academy liked this movie: it's a story about struggling actors that is big on style. It's also easy to see why this is one of the lowest-grossing best pictures ever: it's complicated, vulgar, and hard to understand. The actors each turn in first rate performances, but the whole thing is so odd that it's ultimately unsatisfying.

One of the best and most original movies I've seen in a longÃ¢Â¦ long time! 

   Birdman is a thought provoking, beautiful piece of satire that is destined to be classic. Michael Keaton gives the best performance of his career and this is some of the best  work Edward Norton has done in a while. Birdman is about manyÃ¢Â¦ many things. Actors, Broadway, good for nothing kids, you name it. Films that are about many different things usually lose their focus. However Birdman keeps its focus and strives for greatnessÃ¢Â¦ and achieves. 
   Alejandro G. IÃÂ±ÃÂ¡rritu continues to improve as a director and puts all of his talents to work here. The ensemble is incredible Keaton, Norton, Galifinakis, etc. all give great performances. This is also a very good looking film with excellent cinematography from Emanuel Lebezki (hope that's correct). And the score is fantastic as well. 
   Overall Birdman is a bold and original film with greatness all over the board including acting, directing, cinematography, and more. However Birdman is not for everyone, but if you love movies Birdman is for you!

Here is a movie that not only does not contain car chase scenes or gratuitous violence or excessive special effects, it actually mocks those that do. There are so many moving parts to this plot that interweave reality and the film it is hard to list them, or indeed perceive them.

Two characters, Riggan, played by Michael Keaton, and Mike played by Edward Norton, carry the film from beginning to end. You might be tempted to see Keaton as a man trying to regain his former glory by pulling this serious play off; but in fact he is a man who views his prior roles as Birdman as a sell out for easy money. Faced with the choice of recreating his earlier Birdman role, or showing the world that he can create and perform something that is indeed both serious and witty, he chooses the latter. Riggan sums it all up in one line: "I want to matter". Mike is both his last minute only hope to pull it all off, and his constant pain-in-the-ass, any second catastrophic failure figure.

If you like constant action with car chase scenes, real bullets flying, and bare breasts bouncing with intermittent sobbing from broken hearted women, then this is not the movie for you.

On the other hand, if you want to see a movie with a real plot, edgy directing and sharp dialog, then see it - - and pay attention! Not for the masses of today's audiences, and for a change a great movie without sub-titles.
Waste of time and money

Very impactful and serious, but still has enough going for it to make it hilarious. The acting is superb and the film never has a dull moment. Everything adds to character and plot, which is what lots of modern films are lacking and just think they can make a story with characters that aren't ever extended upon. The style of the film is also very unique to itself. The way that a majority of the film feels like one consecutive shot is a masterful art, and definitely adds to the experience of the film. And that is what this film is. An experience for the ages. This is definitely one film that will go down in history.

A movie for film students, actors, and Oscar fiends, Birdman does everything "right." Perhaps, too right. It's cinematographically pleasing, meaningfully layered (to the point where every little word or prop in a scene is related to some sort of symbolism and not the necessarily the good kind where you have to search for it or only discover it after watching the film), and iconically written, and well acted. It's a painting hung in the Museum of Film but you aren't allowed to touch it or interact with it. It should make you feel inspired but you only feel depressed. With so many fakeouts, loose-ends, and new-age film school techniques, I walked away unsatisfied but understanding of the movie's reclaim.

Truly one of the most brilliant films of all time. I simply am at a loss for words. I've seen it twice on the best big screens in my area, and I was completely blown away. And THAT is the purpose of film, to be moved. There is no better film this year. The direction and "one take" photography was ingenious beyond all belief. My jaw will remain dropped for the rest of my life at the mere thought of this colossal masterpiece. It is a must see for anyone interested in the film art. Iñárritu is a freak genius, making so many celebrated directors pale before him. The entire film and all involved were miraculous. Michael Keaton was pretty much robbed of an Oscar. I've never seen a more moving and riveting performance. Real tears just drop from his eyes; not those fake drops or fake tearless sobs. I feel honored to have met him 5 years ago at a funeral in Los Angeles. I never realized I was in the presence of such a great actor. What an extraordinary and beautiful film for him to throw himself into. If you haven't yet seen this film, you must see it. Do NOT heed a single negative audience review. They are wrong. This is a perfect film from beginning to end, with the most unique script and style possible. Thank the gods Boyhood did not win the Oscar over this because I would have died of shock. I would run to see the next Iñárritu film. I've always been a fan, but this was just the limit. I am humbled.

 Bringing so many award nominations that if it doesn't win something will quite literally brake; it is Birdman! So I suppose the reel question is, will this... I don't know what it is really, a drama? A thriller? Comedy? Some kind of psychological warfare?.... Let's just start the review...

Pretentious, that's a word that is used far to lightly now a days, you can be pretentious for almost anything, but no matter what you think about Birdman it is pretentious, and I kind a think the film knows it. As if the entire idea is some kind of massive joke that the audience isn't part of but everyone else is. Birdman feels like a joke that starts off strong, like a one liner but never quite gets round to delivering the punchline.

 I'll admit it here and now Birdman is not an easy film to watch, or to enjoy. You have to really put the effort in to love it and it's so easy to fall by the wayside. Here are just a few of the really obvious issues you have to get over to enjoy Birdman properly. The shooting style, is it at best bewildering and worst totally unwatchable, as is the musical score which seems to take the format of unorganized drum solo's (As if Rick Allen has gone off on one), the way most of the characters are played can be either phenomenal or grinding, and actually the entire premise of the movie and sureness of the story with both one foot in reality and one foot in fantasy leaves us with many, many elements never explained. Actually that could be the biggest setback of al;, it's own self. But, if can get past all that, something really quite amazing happens.

 If you can get past all of Alejandro González Iñárritu ( the writer and director) obstacles you discover one of the greatest pieces of cinema possibly ever made. Birdman is unique in just about every way that matters, every single member of the cast give career defining performances (even the lesser roles make the effort), and each twist and turn the plot takes gives us a deeper understanding of the pure insanity that is locked within Riggen's head. 

 Birdman isn't really a film at all; Birdman is a moving work of art. That's the truth of it. You can take any one single character or element of the film and justify it as art. I'll prove it by doing just that. The score for the film is irratic but it's timing is perfect, it throws us out of the context of the film like a signpost to the inner rhythm of Riggen's brain. Lets all consider that for a moment. Alejandro González Iñárritu has created a film that is so close to a characters thinking we can literally hear the beat of his brain. We know the film is set inside Riggen's head because he is the only inner monologue voice we hear for the duration of the movie. 

 The entire film comes together for one single sequence when Riggen gets locked out of the theatre that he is appearing in. That sequence is pure art, from start to finish it is a perfectly observed and presented piece of art, every element and thread of the movie comes together for that sequence and then it all starts to disintegrate again. Pure genius.

 To comment on Birdman now is almost unfair of me to do, I feel like it's too soon. Birdman is the sort of film you need to look at 20 or 30 years from now and see how much it has impacted the further films after it. It's THAT kind of movie.

 The directing for Birdman is so bold that it can barely be described, technically the film is a masterpiece without doubt. The entire movie is in one shot and instead of getting cuts we just follow different characters as they enter and leave scenes, but the amount of space that is shown is at times incredible. 

 I feel like I'm stating the obvious if I say anything at all about the cast here, but it feels like this is the role Michael Keaton has been waiting his entire life to play. His voice is like silk blended with gravel. In honesty I could write an entire new review on Keaton's performance alone. 

 Birdman is as close a study into insanity as I have ever witnessed, it's a film that is about everything at once, and is directed within an inch of it's own life, it's a love it or hate it movie and I don't hate it.
Astonishingly brilliant!

Birdman was released in 2014 to almost universal acclaim, giving Michael Keaton's career a serious boost and director Alejandro González Iñárritu one of his most well-received and widely-seen films. To say that this film is a masterpiece goes beyond how I feel about it. It's one of the most compelling and perfect films that has come out in the last twenty years. Of Alejandro González Iñárritu's previous work, I had only seen Babel, which I didn't care that much for. So when it was announced that he was making a film with Michael Keaton, I didn't give it much thought, despite how much I like Michael Keaton as an actor, Batman films aside. Once I started hearing the rumblings about Birdman and how it was going to change Michael Keaton's life around, I knew it was a film that I was just going to have to see, and now that I have, I wish I had seen it sooner. In my mind, Birdman is perfect. There's just no other way to describe it than that. It's not a gimmick movie, it's not a pretentious or philosophical movie, nor is it a special effects movie. It's none of those things. It doesn't merely tell the story of a washed-up actor trying to make it in the theater because he has nothing else left. It's also about all of the people working in show business and how their lives can become affected over time, in the good and the bad. It's a father/daughter story, a jilted lover story, a lost friend story, a disappointing life story... it's a lot of things. It also never gets overly melodramatic. It has the perfect blend of humor and pathos. But above all else, Michael Keaton is 100% amazing in it. If nothing else, see it for his performance and be reminded of what an amazing actor he is and always has been.

One theme of Birdman is the accentuation of a human condition: the struggle to achieve recognition and affirmation. Accompanied by the main character of his box office film series, Michael Keaton desperately grapples with his need for importance and relevance in society by transforming from an action packed, slow-fastball-down-the-middle, easy home run type actor to a multi-dimensional, emotionally complex broadway performer. Underlying this desire to further prove his worth to society, and more importantly, himself, are the fruits of his past: a detached daughter, a broken love, and an intense anger problem. 

Bursts of satirical comedy accompanied by Keaton's battle with the human desire for approval yields a great story that has the capability to trigger a real emotional response.

It is a film that truly plays at a psyche of former actor Riggan Thompson, which is played coincidentally and well by former Batman star Michael Keaton, as the movie brings you into the madness of the star, the scenes from the play, and the movie itself. If there are two complaints that I have with this movie, it's the following:

1) Edward Norton's performance. While it is hard to tell if he's acting or not, he is made into a frustrating character who can barely keep it in his pants in some scenes. However, he does improve.
2) The fact that 'not a whole lot happens'. My parents blamed this film for that, and I still can't get over the fact they consider it a bad movie.

To be fair, the central figure of Riggan, the film being made as if it were in one shot, and the fact that it actually can sum up a Michael Bay film in only a few minutes. It is a black comedy that is executed much better than expected, with only two minor errors that don't really affect the movie at all.
Stellar performance from Keaton, that, on its own carries the film, but the story, directing and it's theme makes it a film to deeply appreciate.

Riggan Thomson (Michael Keaton) is a washed-up Hollywood actor famous for playing the superhero Birdman in blockbuster movies decades earlier. Riggan is tormented by the voice of Birdman, who mercilessly criticizes him, and he sees himself performing feats of levitation and telekinesis. Riggan hopes to reinvent his career by writing, directing, and starring in a Broadway adaptation of Raymond Carver's short story "What We Talk About When We Talk About Love". The play is produced by Riggan's best friend and lawyer Jake (Zach Galifianakis), and also stars Riggan's girlfriend Laura (Andrea Riseborough) and first-time Broadway actress Lesley (Naomi Watts). Riggan's daughter Sam (Emma Stone), a recovering addict, serves as his assistant. During rehearsals, a light fixture falls onto Ralph, an actor Riggan and Jake agree is terrible; Riggan tells Jake he caused the light to fall so he could replace Ralph. Through a connection with Lesley, Riggan replaces Ralph with the brilliant but volatile method actor Mike (Edward Norton), refinancing his house to fund his contract. The first previews go disastrously: Mike breaks character over the replacement of his gin with water, and attempts to rape Lesley during a sex scene. Riggan reads early press coverage and is incensed that Mike has stolen the attention, but Jake encourages him to continue. Riggan needs to find a way to keep the play together and himself as well...

Aside from a few shots near the beginning and end, Birdman appears to be filmed in a single shot (The concept of shooting a feature-length film in one, continuous take was actually accomplished twelve years before Birdman's release in the film "Russian Ark" (2002), which was shot in a single 96-minute Steadicam sequence.), an idea the director had since the film's conception. This required an atypical production approach, with many elements of post-production needing to be considered before principal photography. As a result the script took two years to write, the cast went through several weeks of meticulous rehearsals, and during shooting takes were cut for the slightest mishaps. The film was written using a dramatic device similar to Magical Realism - Magic realism or magical realism is a genre where magical or unreal elements play a natural part in an otherwise realistic (often mundane) environment. Although it is most commonly used as a literary genre (mostly during the Latin American "boom" generation, which includes Gabriel García Márquez and Carlos Fuentes amongst many others), magic realism also applies to film and the visual arts.It was filmed in New York City during the spring of 2013 with a budget of $16.5 million, jointly financed by New Regency and Fox Searchlight Pictures. The film premiered the following year in August where it opened the 71st Venice International Film Festival. "Birdman" was given a limited theatrical release in the United States on October 17, 2014, followed by a wide release on November 14. The film has grossed more than $86 million worldwide. It has garnered critical acclaim, with praise particularly directed to the cast's performances, Iñárritu's direction, editing, screenplay, and cinematography. It is widely considered to be one of the best films of 2014, and has received multiple awards and nominations. Birdman won the Academy Award for Best Picture, along with Best Director for Iñárritu, Best Original Screenplay, and Best Cinematography, and also receiving five additional nominations, tying it with The Grand Budapest Hotel for the most awards and nominations at the year's ceremony. It also won the Outstanding Cast in a Motion Picture at the 21st Screen Actors Guild Awards, as well as Best Screenplay and Best Actor at the 72nd Golden Globe Awards. Alejandro González Iñárritu is a great director with some truly fantastic films on his CV and I reckon we all raised an eyebrow when he took upon himself to do the project "Birdman: Or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance)" as this is pretty far from his usual style and art form. First of all I love the camera work which depicts most of the film as one continuous take and I can only imagine how difficult that is to make that happen so it looks good and believable. The idea of having a self aware showbiz satire as the foundation is not new, but it´s how you actually handle the topic that makes it interesting. And Iñárritu puts everything in it. I have been a fan of Michael Keaton since "Beetlejuice" and I love that he gets to show his full range yet again in a movie that will propel him into the industry yet again with good roles at hand. And I reckon you can´t get away from   the fact that the role is close to his own life and his stint as Batman. He is magnificent as Riggan Thomson in "Birdman" and I do think he should´ve won the Oscar for this role. I´m on your side Michael. Edward Norton is great as well together with Naomi Watts, Zach Galifianakis and the lovely Emma Stone. In the midst of all the black comedy and pointed fingers at what it means to be a celebrity with the good sides and the bad sides that comes with it, my personal problem with "Birdman: Or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance)" is the feeling of this being an "invite only" show for the people on the inside and not for us outside of the entertainment industry. I didn´t feel invited by Iñárritu while he was dissecting all the ugly sides of the industry in his personal laboratory making the movie also feeling a bit self-important and pompous on the side. This does however not drag down the movie and the experience.

You know how you assume an academy award winning movie ... especially "best picture" will be good so when you see it it's like, "Yeah it was good... but no surprise."  Well this movie was surprisingly effective and moving despite the fact that I knew it would be good. The surreal moments in it were perfect and the dramatic acting and single shot camera work just upped the ante without seeming forced or corny. The gimmicks the film used (including the drums) were either unassuming or amusing. But the important thing is that the film showed a real story and a real experience. And the ending? It was literally and figuratively transformative...

Before I say anything, I just want to say that all film is subjective and there is no right or wrong answer. So before you all start screaming at me or/and threaten to unfriend me on Facebook, please note that everyone is entitled to their own opinions. With that being said... I know a lot of people will hate me for saying this... I thought Birdman was overrated. Yes the whole one-shot thing was extremely well done and yes the acting is good, but best picture worthy? First off, Michael Keaton DID do a good job as Riggan Thompson. He had some funny lines and he gave a good performance. What I didn't understand was why Edward Norton got so much praise. He's a good actor and I have nothing against the guy personally, I just didn't see what was so great about his performance. Yeah sure, he got butt naked in front of Naomi Watts and Emma Stone, big deal. I guess just after hearing so many times from friends that Edward Norton should have gotten Best Supporting Actor, I was a bit too overhyped. The one part of the movie that I loved was Zach Galifianakis. Although he wasn't in the film for long, he stole every scene he was in. I did like the "Birdman" voice talking to Riggan throughout the film. I liked those scenes the best. Plus the dream sequence where the Birdman starts following him in the street and where Riggan flies around the city was a pretty neat scene. Overall, I liked the movie. I just didn't see a masterpiece like some other people did. If you love this movie, that's great! More power to you! But out of the other Best Picture nominees, I preferred American Sniper, Boyhood, The Imitation Game, Selma, & Whiplash.

Birdman has some of the best directing I have seen in a long time.  Acting was great throughout (although I'm not convinced entirely about Galifianakis).  Keaton's performance was superb and in a year when he wasn't up against Redmayne's Hawking, I have no doubt he would have won an Academy Award.  Wonderful film editing and great effects.  Spectacularly edgy soundtrack.  The film is quirky, funny, profound and moving.  The only reason I can find that someone might not to like this film is that it would be strange and confusing if you view the film literally rather than understanding that some of it depicts internal events rather than external ones.  It won the Academy Award for best picture and director... and it definitely deserved it even in a year with so many quality films.

Just saw Birdman yesterday,  and it was brilliant.  I was enthralled from start to finish, because of these characters,  because of the themes,  because of the acting,  because of the cinematography, because of the script.  It was,  in my opinion 100% perfect.  I do not consider myself a critic,  I'm just some nerd who likes movies, so I'm not the type of person to sit down and care about nothing but the character development, and themes,  but this movie did both so well I did care about both.  All of the characters have layers and layers on them,  Emma Stone isn't just some dumb teen,  she plays a teen struggling to connect with her Dad,  she has addiction problems,  she wants to be relevant,  she wants to help others,  but struggles to help herself.  Edward Norton is not just some jerk who only cares about his preformance, he is also struggling to find a way to feel alive,  to live life,  but life won't give him a break.  They are all real characters,  and the movie expects you to know that.  It never spoonfeeds you info,  you have to make your own connections,  you have to figure out what is happening,  why people are the way they are in the movie,  so it kind of pisses me off when someone puts a review saying that it made no sense,  because it's not the movies fault that you can't put 2 and 2 together,  that's your fault for being too dumb to be able too.

If you know going in it's going to be pretty odd, I think it turns out to be a pretty enjoyable experience. Was surprised to notice myself laughing out loud as often as I did. Definitely was not enjoyed by all and uncomfortable for several but I think that just relates to expectations.

This is a film primarily about Hollywood's action-film excesses, and what is or isn't real to the audience and the actors. If that were the extent of it, then I'd probably love the film. But, unfortunately, that worthy theme is mixed with a very sad tale of mental illness, and it's all laced with some very funny comedy too, including a drum beat in the background that seems to be there for comic relief. It all makes for a very odd cocktail and it left me scratching my head.
Likes: Keaton, Norton, and many other very fine performers; an effective motif of continuity; some *extremely* clever editing tricks, e.g. on several occasions, the camera seems to somehow squeeze through the bars of a window; and a very snappy, tight script that is expertly delivered by all.
Dislikes: obviously, my biggest dislike is the rather casual treatment of mental illness... is it really okay to mix laugh-out-loud humor with a plot that traces the predictable breakdown of a schizophrenic? This tale is way more serious than, for example, the film about Walter Mitty, who came across as whimsical. Here, Keaton's character is in rapid decline You know it right from the start, and you probably guess the ending right from the start too (I did). Surely the entire audience anticipates what Keaton's character will do when it's all "for real"... and on several occasions we're actually surprised that it goes on a bit longer.
Fellow photogeeks will note that on several occasions, the movie reverts from film to digital. E.g. when Norton joins a female supporting character on a balcony, the film quality is completely lost and the scene looks like it's shot on a handy cam. Why? I found that very disruptive to the story line...it broke the implied continuity. Maybe that was the intention? Odd.
On the whole, I do recommend seeing this, but it's *definitely* not for kids- don't mistake the overarching action-hero theme as light entertainment. It's an adult film. And, fair warning: if you know anything about mental illness then it may not sit well with you at all.

I tried watching this movie. It does have some redeeming artistic virtues but, at the end of the day, it is about a dysfunctional has-been trying to make a comeback. I found it extremely boring and pointless.

Other than the achievement of the single shot (or at least appearance of it) for most of the film, I wasn't that impressed, and I'm a Michael Keaton fan. Yes, they are all good actors but, honestly, I wasn't caught up in the story; the play within the play has been done much better - and not just by Shakespeare. I could have done without Riggan's psychosis about his super-hero status. And, we get it, actors and actresses are prima donnas who like to bask in their faults. Also, maybe this is just me, but too much yelling and psychological pain. I was grateful whenever his ex-wife was in a scene because she was the only character I liked in the whole movie (and, arguably, though not a  household name, Amy Ryan may be the most versatile actor of the star-studded cast). I realize that we were not supposed to like them, but, there's a way to make even the seemingly unlikeable likeable. One more thing - I don't care what they say, this was not a black comedy. It was just a dark movie in which I'm not sure I laughed once. Laugh at what - that he got caught outside in his underwear - it was sad, not funny? The third star is for the technical work.

I honestly do not see how this movie managed to win Best Anything.

Some of the best ways to describe the film come from it's own lines.

You're doing a play based on a book that was written 60 years ago, for a thousand rich old white people whose only real concern is gonna be where they go to have their cake and coffee when it's over. And let's face it, Dad, it's not for the sake of art. It's because you want to feel relevant again. Well, there's a whole world out there where people fight to be relevant every day. And you act like it doesn't even exist! Things are happening in a place that you willfully ignore, a place that has already forgotten you. I mean, who are you? You hate bloggers. You make fun of Twitter. You don't even have a Facebook page. You're the one who doesn't exist. You're doing this because you're scared to death, like the rest of us, that you don't matter. And you know what? You're right. You don't. It's not important. You're not important. Get used to it."

The characters are all flat, there is no depth or growth for any of them. Instead of showing us qualities about the characters, or leading us to have perceptions of them, the film flat out tells us what each character is, and then proceeds to repeat that message over and over. We are flat out told that the daughter is "big, strong, and all the attitude and booze and weed will never cover it", but at no point do we ever see that. All we ever see is a petulant child who has no real contribution to the film at all that couldn't have just as easily been done by any of the other characters that actually did contribute.

"You're telling me the same thing four times. Just tell cut it down to once and make it work", another good line to describe this movie. It just retreads the same ground with at most minuscule advancements. Mike is a jerkass, we get it, we don't need a half dozen scenes to explain this to us over and over again.

By the time we got to the point where our lead character is having discussions with his split personality hallucination, I found myself agreeing more with his Birdman persona than with him. How I wish I had been watching the movie with that fabulous costumed hero in it, instead of this washed up nobody with severe mental problems. Which is especially odd considering the fact that the mental instability (which mainly gets displayed through a "Wait, does he actually have super powers, or is this all just him being delusional?" moments) plays virtually no part in the narrative what-so-ever. Its as if the scenes were included for no other reason than to be put into a trailer to intentionally mislead audiences, every last one of them could be cut or replaced with something more mundane and not only would the movie have lost nothing, I think it would have enhanced it. Honestly, the scenes where he uses his "powers" is jarring because they completely do not fit the tone of the rest of the film, and they suddenly take the user out of the flow as you suddenly realize "Wait, why is the movie doing this again? Oh, its supposed to be him being unstable, okay, really clunky but I get it."

If this was a "thrilling leap forwards" for the director, I shudder to think what kind of drek he must have been putting out to this point.

This movie hid completely off my radar until very recently when it took home the oscar for best picture. I was stunned to read that news, and not have seen the film, so I figured the academy usually is at least a little right in their decisions, so I went out and bought a copy, which is not something I usually do.  Anyway, this was a good movie, borderlining on great. Its a tad hard to express emotion about it. Things I liked were the single sort of unedited one shot style, I thought that was extremely impressive because not enough movies even attempt to make that happen. As a musician and primarily a drummer, I appreciated the use of the free range jazzy drum beats for a majority of the interlude music. I also like the plot, how you see pieces of this play here and there in that single shot style and have Michael Keaton battling his inner voice of Birdman, and that they leave the thought of him having actual powers ambiguous until the very end of the film, and you never really find out.  Edward Norton and Zach G. and Emma Stone were all pretty fantastic in their roles. There were a few pieces of dry plot here and there, but ultimately entertaining and weird. So I guess I can say, money well spent. 4/5

The Oscar-winning Best Picture of the year Birdman is worth seeing if only for its clever camera work and acting performances by its star-studded cast alone. It's reminiscent of Black Swan, dark, quirky, humorous at times, tragic at others. But what was the best part for me was to see Michael Keaton in action again in a leading role, hopefully we'll see him in more films to come! It may not be the best movie of the year in my book, but it's a great movie regardless and worth seeing.
Too slow. A total snoozer!

It's masterful on a technical scale strictly for its well-executed ambition. And it's tailored by excellent performances from Keaton, Norton, and Watts. Its message and symbolism and material are not straight forward, and it's not an easy watch. Unfortunately, this dooms 'Birdman' to join the likes of 'The Artist' as a best picture that doesn't quite feel "best," but nonetheless should be studied and analyzed as such.
The single take style is truly impressive and so are the performances.

I am wondering if this wasn't written specifically for Michael Keaton.  The story about him and George Clooney on the plane and his alter ego voice captures what may have happened if Keaton himself just had Batman under his belt.  Slightly confusing at first but once you get it with the continuous shots and the elapse of time it is like watching a dream.  In a dream you go from one situation to another without cuts or subtitles telling you elapsed time.  Following Riggan we can see how he battles himself to be a respected actor.  Knowing the West/East coast battles of Broadway and Hollywood adds tension to the story.  I haven't seen an entire film that is like one continuous shot since that Russian film that I can't remember.  Everyone is at their best.  Keaton is good in anything so his versatility is well established, Edward Norton is always good, if anyone remembers his first film with Richard Gere where he was nominated for best supporting actor, this is no surprise.  The big surprise for me was Zach Galifinakis, he wasn't a weird funny type guy in this which is his bread and butter.  He played a human being very well.  I am happy to say that the Academy got it's head out of it's own Butt and actually gave the Oscar to the best picture of the year with this one.  Hopefully they will keep their heads out for a few years.
the surrealism/satire of the film is sort of like an act of kindness, inviting the viewer to think past the non-stop flurry of psychological breakdowns and crisis behavior.
Technically excellent with great performances. Otherwise overbearing and insufferable.

Its a film made by actors for actors.  Thus, it can feel very much like an insiders film, and not for everyone. I think fans of Michael Keaton will enjoy it, but mainstream audiences are likely to feel let down due to so much hype. Its not bad, its not great, and its definitely not for everyone.
Superhero flick meets art-house drama in this compelling masterpiece. With a unique visual style and talented actors all bringing their A-Game, this is one of the greats.

What we have here is a movie pretending to be far more clever than it actually is.  The script is simplistic and holds almost no surprises.  What makes it stand out are the performances and the unique way it's shot (it looks like one long take, but those familiar with editing will spot the cuts).  Michael Keaton gets full credit for holding the entire thing together and fully deserves every award he wins for his performance.  Birdman takes plenty of shots at the superhero genre, and Hollywood in general, but none of it would work without Keaton's meta-casting.  The supporting cast is impressive, but none of the characters get much development or resolution.  Birdman also gets in the bad habit of playing the "is it real, or in his imagination?" card one too many times.  Leaving it up to the audience's imagination is a great thing for filmmakers to do, but here it kinda comes off as lazy writing and doesn't add much to the movie.  Aside from Keaton's performance and some impressive camerawork, there's just not much here.  Good, but far from great.
Gave me a new respect for Emma Stone, for sure. She should have taken that Oscar for this.

Everyone fears being forgotten. This is the one thing that Birdman  puts right in the forefront of the story and ensures that it keeps reminding the audience that it is a fear held by everyone. Michael Keaton plays Riggan, a lost soul who can't shake his past as an action movie hero. Staging a Broadway play seems to be his last ditch effort to feel remembered and relevant again but it seems to come with a cost. The cost being a combination of colliding egos (both within and outside of himself), a daughter who loathes him and the risks one must take to stay in the lime light just long enough to feel famous again. Birman gives the audience a rare glimpse inside the world of the theatre while maintaining the illusion that we are part of it just by watching.
I want my money back.
Blah...  Decent movie, but not what it was hyped to be.  It's a movie worth seeing once.  Would never have a need to watch it again.

The actors were fantastic.  The interaction between Stone and Norton was especially good.  Otherwise, this got quite boring rather quickly.  It seems like a movie that would be better the second time around but I'm not sure when I'll be motivated enough to try it on again.

This was decent.  I know alot of people were crazy about this movie but it was only pretty good. Michael Keaton definitely out did himself in this one.

So refreshingly original. Well deserving of the Oscar. Great performances. Wonderful soundtrack - the drumming is amazing. The play within the play. Such a great device. Plus a bit of a Shakespearean soliloquy thrown in. Love love love it.

It seems that all you have to do these days is make a film about the "craft" of acting and all the seriously pretentious critics will rave about it.  Maybe they missed the point as it clearly sends up critics and "ignorant" audiences alike. Is Birdman the best movie of 2014? I'd say no, but I do say it's a fully enjoyable movie that's rather fun and heartfield. The main thing that brings it over the top is the camerawork: With few exceptions, the movie is designed to look like it was shot all in one take. One scene flawlessly segues into the next by the camera following characters who only briefly appear in the previous scene. It's quite a ballet.

How's the actual story though? It's pretty good. It's about an aging actor trying to perform a theater play to make his comeback. The ensemble cast really makes this-specifically Emma Stone and Naomi Wattts. I wasn't really so much struck by Keaton's story but the ensemble cast carries it. The latter half suffers a bit because it focuses mostly on Keaton and forgets a lot of the supporting characters, but most threads do wrap up nicely. It's a good movie.

Pour toute l'originalité technique et l'image remarquable de Birdman, qui parvient à faire évoluer le réel et le fantasmagorique dans la même séquence, le film d'Alejandro Inarritu mérite toutes les louanges qu'on lui a versées. C'est dommage que la matière scénaristique du film soit en revanche un peu moins intéressante et tourne franchement en rond, pour ne pas dire à vide, dans la dernière demi-heure. Birdman est pourtant souvent grinçant, parfois hilarant et surtout porté par une interprétation hallucinante de Michael Keaton et d'Edward Norton. Les autres acteurs, hormis Zach Galifianakis bien trop rare, sont moins bons. Birdman est aussi franchement desservi par un score omniprésent et horriblement monotone composée uniquement de percussions. A n'en pas douter, le film d'Inarritu aurait gagné à durer un petit quart d'heure de moins.

Birdman is the confirmation of just how cuckoo society but in particular Hollywood has become.  While the movies are often a reflection of where we are headed, it is also supposed to be a form of escapism from reality.  This cynical, f'd up piece of garbage is the reason viewership is down.  While industry insiders hail this movie and voted it Best Picture, it confirms my belief in how corrupt and sarcastic the film biz really is.   If you have a healthy mindset and can make it more than 30mins into this movie, I'd be amazed.   I'm sure there's an audience for this, but I pay for movies wanting to leave, exhilarated, joyous, happy, thoughtful and amazed. I walked out of this one pissed off wanting my money back.

Words used to describe 'BIRDMAN or The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance' has been odd, strange, distributing-all are extremely correct but other words that could be used to describe 'BIRDMAN or The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance' after viewing the film is odd, strange distributing but I would say that these descriptions should not be seen as negative points but more along the lines of that in 'BIRDMAN or The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance' the audience is witnessing something very different than shall we say what is the 'normal' movie experience. 

The overall film is extremely well acted with everyone producing very genuine emotions and the audience is let into the world where Michael Keaton is determined to change his image and leave behind his alter-ego of Birdman to become relent as a director and actor in a Broadway play. Keaton as Riggan hires Mike played by Edward Norton in the hope of getting the play off the ground, but with Mike being an actor in the theater and Riggan coming from Hollywood-egos quickly clash between the two and to make matters worse, Riggan runs into a theater critic from the New York Times who simply will not give Riggan credit for risking what he was into what he wants to be. This leads to the back and forth battle between Riggan and 'The Birdman'-of whom he can only see. On top of all of this, Riggan is attempting to get back in the good graces with his daughter played wonderfully with passion by Emma Stone.

The takeaway from this movie is still a question and not really sure that by the end of ''BIRDMAN or The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance' that anything was resolved but that might actually be the genus (or madness) of this movie. 'BIRDMAN or The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance' won the Oscar for Best Movie of the Year and can be debated but love it, hate it, like it, or unsure what to think of it-'BIRDMAN or The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance' is a movie that has its place in movie lure and under all of the oddness and yep, I'll say it, like a drug trip with Keaton talking to himself and trashing his dressing room with a flick of his hand-'BIRDMAN or The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance' invites the audience to take a ride with Riggan as he attempts to find himself and comes to terms with who he is.
Disappointing, every1 so hyped bout this but I was really disappointed. Still good just not as good as every1 says it is.

did the Oscar people lose it??? 2nd year of great winning movie? 
wonderful in so many ways (except for the horrible Whiplash score)

As we dive deep into the mind of yet another conceited self-wallowing self-absorbed psychotic main character in this years winner for best picture, I find myself dumbfounded in what is considered art in todays society. Although I did enjoy the film it rattles me to the core what is considered a great film in the eyes of people in this generation. I sense a message coming from this movie that says todays big Hollywood hits, mainly comic book superhero films, are nothing more then big flashy expensive productions that is not real art, and does not represent good creativity in the movie making industry. At times to me it bathes in its own self-righteousness all while maintaining its central theme of suicide. I swear that this movie couldn't go ten minutes without referencing suicide in some way shape or form. At some points you actually start to believe that Keaton's character will abandon his selfish desires for the betterment of his families needs, but in the end chooses to end his own life in an attempt to show everyone that he is in fact "somebody" and not just a washed up Superhero actor. It even tries to convince us that in this act he is taking some sort of admirable approach to his dying career. Going out with a bang fashion. It upsets me that they mock films that inspire us to do good, and try to show us morals even when we doubt ourselves. Films that teach us real courage and sacrifice for the better of mankind, such as the Dark Knight trilogy, are considered less creative, and not deemed real art while films that teach us to ignore loved ones for selfish desires, and that suicide is a reasonable and honorable approach to failure are widely and critically acclaimed. My opinion of what true art is seeing something that you did not think was possible coming to life in front of your eyes. I get that from films such as the Avengers or Man of Steel. Those movies are the reason I go to the theatre, to see something spectacular come to life that I have never seen before. This movie is nothing more to me then a carbon copy of all other films that show us the inside of a mentally unstable characters mind, and we get to witness his depressing fall into madness only to try to shock us and disgust us with what actions this madness makes them do. Making people try to guess what atrocious horrible action this character is going to next approach to film making is not art to me. It is my hope that great films like the ones Marvel studios puts out, and hopefully DC soon, will get the same recognition and awards that these films about crazy people doing crazy things do. Unfortunately I don't see this happening anytime soon. It was a good movie, but deserving Best Picture of the year I do not agree at all.
Flawless direction, hilarious dark comedy, brilliant performances, and layers of intelligence make this quirky film a must see. Absolutely deserving of its Best Picture award.

We watched this before the Oscars to live the hype. Hype. It's a good movie don't get me wrong, but the Best Picture? Meh. 

Cinematography was absolutely amazing and well conceived for the unique feel of a continuous shot. Keaton was great, but how hard is it to play basically yourself? Still a good performance. Norton was also really good. It was also nice to see Zach in a different role, although used very little.

By winning Best Picture, Hollywood only helped solidify the narrative that nobody loves Hollywood, as much as Hollywood. It's a business movie and they love movies about them.
It was good, the acting was great and the cinematography had some nice shots. Very funny at moments too.

For me it lacked character development and featured needless high budget cgi which was unnecessary and jarred with the documentary style. Still impressive and great to see such a film in a conventional cinema, hopefully the start of things to come.

Good film with some outstanding performances. Yet I can see why this film wouldn't be everyone's cup of tea, if your looking for action then don't look here; but if you are looking for character driven and art house style films then look no further.

Alejandro directed the hell out of this movie, finally we have brought back art house films into the big blockbusters. A film that has huge amounts of philosophy and hidden symbolism. The direction on this film really reminds me of Four Rooms. (If you haven't seen it do it now!)

I feel this will be a film they talk about in media studies or English classes in a few years. Kinda like what Donnie Darko did when I was at school.

An overly 'clever' art house style load of rubbish with ridiculously annoying drum noises all the way through it. The fact this film scores 93% while 'The Birdman of Alcatraz' only got 82%on the TOMATOMETER must mean either people are idiots or the rating system is not working.
Should be subtitled "Whatever happened to Batman".  Unique and entertaining.  This film will be studied in film and culture classes for years to come.

A very funny, ambitious film that targets several references to the ignorance of today's show business.  The continuous shot is the highlight of the piece. The writing is superb and the directing is definitely a force to be reckon with.  One of my favorite movies of 2014 and probably one of my favorites films of all time. This can't be missed.
