Birdman's cinematography is an incredible achievement in its own right. Combined with its stellar acting and stabbing take on the theater, it's easily one of the best films of the year. However, the weirdness of it all--and the constant "we get it!" references to modern social media--will roll some eyes.
The cinematography and acting were superb, but the movie itself was a little boring, long, and a little confusing/weird sometimes.

Hated this movie and I'm a big fan of Michael Keaton.  It was  absolutely ridiculous amd hard to follow. We walked out after 50 minutes because of the sheer nonsense and over abundance of A.D.D. content.  Very disappointing,  I cannot believe this was the big winner on Oscar night.

Interesting... very interesting. Birdman does not exactly fall under my "cup of tea" however as a movie fan I had to watch it and see what the hype was about. Wow. It's hard to describe because it is a highly peculiar movie. What I'll say first is that I am not in the club of people who praise this film as one of the best ever, however there are plenty of attributes that deserve applause. For starters, who's ever idea it was to blend and edit all the shots in the movie to make it look like one consecutive take is brilliant. It added an entirely new spin to the movie that is something I've never seen before and makes me appreciate the movie more than I would have otherwise. Another aspect of the film worth recognition is the spectacular script that is carried perfectly by the actors. The dialogue is quick witted and always ahead of the audience which also adds to the play-like dynamic of the film. The surrealism is a large part of the movie and almost feels out of place although it manages to work. It factors into the protagonists' struggles and morals as he decides who he is and his meaning toward society. Without going into detail and avoiding spoilers, there is a "Christopher Nolan" type cliffhanger ending that lets the audience speculate which direction the director wants this story to end. In my opinion, this movie is not that type of movie and almost seems like it was thrown in there for the hell of it. I would have preferred  a more complete and finalizing ending for this movie and protagonist.
Should not have won the Oscar. Love the actors, but this film was not Oscar worthy (with maybe exception to cinematographer)

Ljudi vole akciju a ne pricu i depresivno filozofsko preseravanje. Da, daaaas. Birdman  dobitnik Oscara u kategoriji najboljeg filma i rezije.Michael Keaton cija je karijera obiljezena filmovima o Batmanu. Odlican isto tako Edward Norton i Emma Stone. Zaboravite bljestavilo, raskos, modu, crvene tepihe, lijepe haljinice, Birdman prikazuje glumacki, umjetnicki krv, znoj, suze, uz obilan dodatak alkohola. Da, da izazovi modernog doba, ima I o drustvenim mrezama, promocija kulturnog dogadaja, samopromocija. Film se poigrava I sa filmskim kritikama, recenzijama koje utjecu na uspjeh filma ili kazalisne predstave. Odlicna, zabavna, crnohumorna, edukativna I to moram reci prica o (ne)uspjehu. Film za razmisljanje, mislim da se u danasnje vrijeme in ne isplati razmisljati mozda je dovoljno biti super heroj. Pa tko ovo sada cita a siguran sam da ce procitati znati ce o cemu govorim. Bolje spasitelj super heroj nego  jebeni umjetnik, neka se zadovolji masa. Amen.
very good and watchable BUT  best picture of the year-nah not for me.

Probably closer to being "full of sound and fury [while] signifying nothing", than to some profound character study; yet quite creatively and enjoyably so.  A few too many "you're an asshole"s and random slaps, but ultimately enjoyable nonetheless.

This film is what I would classify as "an Actors film"; A movie in which people who are enthralled by "the craft which is Acting" will enjoy immensely.  Moreover, which made the movie Birdman a shoe-in for the Oscar.  
Without question, the performances of each and every member of the cast is brilliant and the message of the film (i.e the narcissism of one man, and shallow tastes of the masses) is a unique and interesting subject.  
Nevertheless, watching the movie felt as if I were watching a dog chase his own tail.  And the more I wanted to enjoy the movie, the more frustrated and irritated I became.  
The inclusion of so many eccentric, self-absorbed characters ranting at one another constantly, juxtaposed with crashing jazz music and visual assaults was disquieting.  
I understand why the movie was nominated for the Oscar, and why many people would truly enjoy the film ...great acting, interesting commentary on American's taste in entertainment, one man's crushing reflection on how he chose to live his life etc.  But the intense manner in which the Director captured his vision was, for me, so physically unpleasant, I found the film both boring and irritating...Definitely not a film I would recommend for most people.

Worst  movie I saw this year, and and I saw all major Academy contenders. Not only my opinion, but also that of everyone else I know who saw it. The standard reaction is, "why did I just waste any timewatching this!."

hate hate hated this movie. the plot was terrible the music was worse...a constant poem reading drum background that was overwhelmingly loud. wasted my money and time not even if you're bored should you watch this. this movie will drive you to insanity.  lol

ever heard of the emperors new clothes? this is one of those movies: if you dont say you thought it was amazing, you are considered a moron. well you know what, this movie f***ing sucked. absolute garbage

This movie was a big "Eff You" to just about everyone. Critics, Hollywood, news media, the public, and more. You can't say you loved it or hated it without that statement defining exactly how the movie pinpointed who YOU are. The acting was spectacular. The story had a good base, with too much surrealism thrown in to be satisfying. The narcissistic focus of all the characters made me sick, but that was exactly the intention. With all its good qualities, I came close to turning the movie off several times, thanks to the ridiculous surrealist twists. I wanted a movie based in reality, and every time something REAL was about to happen, Birdman would spread and would steal that from me. Also, the music was a good fit for the movie, but in the middle of a deep conversation, the drum beat would kick up and bring you out of the moment enough that the impact of the interaction was then totally lost.
Excellent movie.  Loved how it was shot.
It was creative but not worth best picture just like the Artist in my eyes not entertaining or touching,  parts of the movie kept me interested others were just weird

Birdman is a emotionally thrilling, delivering powerful message in self-worth. a story layered with levels of love, comedy and accompanied by the outstanding performances of the entire cast. Director Alejandro Gonzales shows the all real side of the curtain and the struggles of self-acceptance and the sides of what it means to be a actors. and the manifestations of  your inner demons. The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance is a magnificent and important film that deserves all its praises. Highly deserving of their merit's. From the performances and cinematography to the editing and the screenplay.

The ending of this film is based on your own interpretation... What a great movie... Deserve to be the winner of Academy Awards 2015...
PS: this is not an action or superhero movie.. :p

Birdman is full of interesting ideas and performances that don't add up to an interesting film. I do recommend it for either:
1) Actors who believe what they're doing is incredibly brave and important...or should be. 
2) People who've always dreamed of watching Ed Norton and Michael Keaton girl-fight in their undies.

A film that has so many consistently outstanding performances which, on their own make this film worth watching. Every actor has their moments to shine and they all pull it off wonderfully. 

But on top of the performances, you have amazing cinematography, an intriguing story which gets the viewer completely invested, a very minimalistic yet organic score and sharp, poignant and occasionally hilarious dialogue.

This is a film that could've just as easily fallen under the weight of its own ambition, but all the pieces fit together perfectly in the end thanks to Alejandro González Iñárritu's masterful direction.

This is the worst movie ever, depressing , boring and the music is so irritating you want to turn the sound off. I don't know where these movie critics come from but it is not from this planet. What a waste of time and money !!!!!!!!!

- Beautiful and impressive cinematography giving an impression of continuous shot.
- Surreal, trippy and original art house story of an actor struggling to prove his worth in a Broadway theatre and to himself of what he is.
On a technical level, "Birdman" is fantastic. The continuous takes alone make the movie stand-out on a whole new level. The acting is also exceptional, but the film does drag a little at times.

Loved this film! Loved everything about it! Takes you on a behind the scenes tour of Broadway, acting, and showbiz. Going head to head with Boyhood for the Best Picture Oscar, this quirky meta-dramedy about a washed-up movie star attempting redemption on Broadway has generated much applause from critics around the world. It's not hard to see why, what with director Alejandro González Iñárritu's ambitious technical achievements, the razor sharp satirical screenplay and a bunch of soul-bearing performances. Presenting the story as one long continuous take, Iñárritu employs all the tricks of the trade in search of something unique and it largely pays off; his ever-flowing camera segues between scenes creating a dreamlike atmosphere. Finding where the shots have been joined, however, can at times distract from the emotional journey crafted by Iñárritu and his team of writers, in a script full of dark humour and irony. Unfortunately there's also a hint of pretension and self-satisfaction in Iñárritu's work - intentional and otherwise - that comes across as smug and, therefore, annoying. As Riggan Thomson, the former A-lister seeking professional rejuvenation on the stage, Michael Keaton gets a long- awaited opportunity to shine in a lead role and attacks it, for better and worse, with unbridled gusto. Ed Norton hogs the spotlight though, with a comedic turn as a supercilious stage actor looking for the "truth" in even the tiniest of things, whilst Emma Stone, Naomi Watts, Zach Galifianakis, Andrea Riseborough and Amy Ryan round out the impressive cast. Birdman is clever, enterprising and admirably distinct, if occasionally laborious and inaccessible; it's not for everyone, but lovers of film and/or theatre should seek it out.

Birdman: After finally seeing this film (I previously resisted because it just looked boring), I can now see why it won the Best Picture Oscar. It is a self-indulgent tribute to the self-absorbed profession of acting. It stars Michael Keaton (ironically, as the former star of the fictional "Birdman" comic book movies), who's now desperately trying to revive his stalled career on Broadway. There is much about this movie that is loathesome - its pretentiousness, its over-acting and its recurring bait-and-switch phoniness; but ultimately, all that awfulness results in a pretty innovative film about our obsession with celebrity. Birdman is not the best film of 2014 but it is thought provoking and unique, which earns it a B+

Birdman is an insightful and intelligent drama which brings incredible acting from its stars, thought - provoking satire, and an incredibly ambitious filmmaking technique to the table. 

What really stood out were the heavy performances by Michael Keaton, Edward Norton and Emma Stone as the leading triumverate. Their honesty and raw emotion set the tone and pace beautifully. Norton, in particular, brought an electric energy to the picture. 

The film is layered in every way, ambitiously taking on themes such as: what is art? What are the risks of an artist? How does Hollywood really compare to the stage? What is the nature of reality? How do you escape past success to redefine who you are? Who does that really matter to? And many, many more. 

Birdman is unabashed in its answers to these questions, running the gauntlet of emotion to delve every ounce of meaning from every frame on screen. The cinematography and editing were both masterworks, boasting a nearly seamless long shot of the entire 2 hour film. 

Adding to the layers, the film often goes completely meta, with things like being able to see the source of the music in the film and Keaton's character acting as both director of his play and, at times, his life. Despite the seeming lack of cuts, there's still plenty of highly stylized moments which often raise more questions than they answer. 

Birdman, overall, was a thinking movie with great acting that had great ambitions. Though, its worst sin is that it didn't go far enough in any of its many directions to truly create a masterpiece. 

Still, watching it try is a great ride.

Well if this just isn't one of the best movies I've ever seen. Spectacular performances. Really intricate camerawork that makes the passage of time and transitions feel so fluid. Interesting paradoxes that constantly interrupt your expectation (i.e. the pounding of agony is actually a high school drumline on the street). At every turn, Birdman is taking chances and changing the game. As for the movie's end, I cannot think of a better way to wrap together the two realms that we are presented with throughout the film (the actual, and the supernatural). With Riggan's success in finally achieving what he wants in life (a nod to the opening card), his daughter looks down in horror, then up in delight--acknowledgment that he has left Birdman behind and is finally a person of self-significance and worth. Is he dead or is he flying? The answer is simply no. Audiences who crave concrete answers will be frustrated by the movie's metaphysical end. But the metaphor is just so beautiful.

I just fail to see why the critics have gone so nuts over this. The frantic drumming and fast pace of the opening shots suggest inner turmoil in michael keaton's character. The recurrence of the drumming - including various shots of a drummer in action - all smack of a film trying to pretend it's an arthouse movie without the least idea of what this means. Much has been made of the technical accomplishment of long sequences filmed without obvious cuts - but so what? what does this add to what the film is trying to say? what is it trying to say exactly? it seems very confused about this. early on we are given the impression that the birdman really has supernatural powers - to move objects for instance. Then we learn that these are probably in his mind, Then a CGI sequence persuades us that he can fly. Then it appears he can't because having landed he has to pay the taxi driver. Then he;s in hospital and fantasises about flying with the birds. Then his daughter arrives and thinks he's jumped and fallen to his death - and then she looks up in wonderment. So - can he fly? Who knows? Do we care? Absolutely not? And what is the point? Not a fucking clue. On the plus side Emma Stone is terrific as the daughter. The one truly believable character in  the whole film.

It's hard to follow a movie like Birdman as an editor. I was so distracted by the continuous shot gag that most of the story was obscured. I did feel that the performances were pretty solid and the plot, while not earth shattering, held up pretty well. Hollywood seems to be grasping for the next big trend in filmmaking. This has the unfortunate consequence of giving praise to films in categories that are not warranted. Too many people fail to ask the most important question about this movie. Would it be as good if it were shot and edited in the traditional style?

Writer/Director Alejandro González Iñárritu has crafted a jazzy, hilarious, mesmerizing, innovative, and indulgent movie about an sixty-something actor confronting himself perhaps for the first time. Michael Keaton as Riggan provides not just the the meta reference to his own career but a worthy character study. The supporting cast is equally as impressive, from the bluntness of Emily Stone as Riggan's daughter Sam to Edward Norton as the very funny and very destructive actor Mike.

The movie plays with time in interesting ways. It is edited as if it was all filmed as one shot, but the seams are there to see, and calls attention to the theme of constructed realities that the movie sometimes references. Time, sound, and editing also create elements of magical realism and reflect the mind of Riggan.

There are a couple things I did not appreciate very much, including sexism that is played for humor and a titillating kiss that doesn't make much sense to me and adds to the undercurrent of sexism. Are these elements there on purpose, or do they reflect some unexamined prejudices?

Birdman tells the story of seasoned actor Riggan Thomson (Michael Keaton) who is preparing for the opening night of his first Broadway play. He's best known for his starring role of superhero Birdman decades earlier and is in quite a bit of a personal crisis. He wants nothing but recognition for his professional accomplishments and he wants his new project to be a success.

In Birdman, we're dropped right into the backstage drama leading up to the play's opening night. We see several people connected to the play as well as Thomson's daughter/assistant Sam (Emma Stone). We also get the idea that the Birdman character invaded Thomson's psyche and the tragic lead of this story doesn't experience reality in is head as we observe it.

Possibly interesting only to theatre production people, the drama is quite dull and predictable, giving the audience time to pay attention to the fact that director Alejandro González Iñárritu is playing games with time and space in this movie. Those games are executed to a T, with props going to Emmanuel Lubezki, the cinematographer, and Douglas Crise and Stephen Mirrione for their superb job at editing these scenes.

These technical accomplishments of making the movie look like it's one long take instead of connected scenes overshadow the actual story and acting here. Sure, Keaton does a good job with the troubled Thomson. And when Edward Norton enters as co-star Mike, the intensity sure picks up a bit. But after almost two hours of this story, I am left feeling a bit underwhelmed by the actual content of the narrative and characters. And annoyed by the pseudo-artsy-fartsy drum soundtrack. If you'd look up 'style over substance' in a 2015 illustrated dictionary, you'd find this movie.

Don't be fooled by reviews claiming it to be the greatest work of art in filmmaking in decades. There's quite a few people jumping on the chance to showcase their love and admiration for this film in an online movie review. I get the feeling most critics do it so as to not lose face with their peers. There's even a hint of "let's write this is the best movie ever made, because if I don't, I'll be considered a neanderthal who doesn't understand art."

Let's get one thing straight: the production value is excellent. Unfortunately, the story and characters are severely underwhelming. If this takes 'best picture' at the Academy Awards, it will be a crying shame.

Pros: Great production value, excellent editing and OK performances
Cons: Style over substance at every level

Verdict: Meh

This film is so frustrating!

I am both ecstatic and contemptuous, amazed and bored, interested and confused, but ultimately unfulfilled. I don't care about Riggan's past or future - the single-take shot scenes anchor you so supremely in his present moment yet the majority of the conflict in the film is propelled by events you never witness. And so we're invited to attach a popular meta-narrative of other films and real life personas too (perhaps it would have been better to go the whole Being John Malkovich route and just reference Batman directly). 

Edward Norton is fantastic and then squandered upon cliché.

My favourite scene is when Norton first comes on stage to workshop a scene. The anatomy of this is really basic: 1) Riggan commits a basic writing crime (redundant dialogue), 2) Mike fixes this error; but the execution is so perfect. Too bad nothing really tops this exchange making many subsequent scenes just appear as self-parodies. 

The personal conflict does not motivate the best sequences, instead the mere accident of locking oneself outside a one-way door is the trigger and so the resolution of this conflict fails to really connect with anything deeper - while being wildly entertaining.

The end is crap. At least in Ghostworld, when the main character departs the reality or world of the film, this potential had long been foreshadowed and built up - here it's just confusing. Why doesn't Riggan want the magical success he's just been granted? Why was his surgery so neat? Was the performance really so good it could change the spiteful critic's bias against him? What happens to everyone else? Birdman just derails.

However, at times, I really couldn't grasp some of the dialogue since it seemed a little out of touch. Nevertheless, "Birdman" is a one-of-a-kind film that I would like to watch when I have the chance &, in its own right, is one of the best films of 2014.

Birdman is a conceited, insular commentary on the life of an actor with a seriously unchecked mental illness making it big who later has to find ways to cope with the realities of mortality and legacy.  I had high hopes for this film as a fan of much of the cast's and director's previous work.  A serious disappointment for me as a filmgoer and a tremendous shock for me when this film won Best Picture at the Oscars.  In a way, I'm probably feeding into the main points of the film about the nature of criticizing someone's Art.  But, I'm only a consumer and I like what I like. Best Cinematography for Birdman? Birdman não é um filme fácil. Escondido por detrás da premissa envolvendo um ator outrora famoso por viver um super-herói, no caso o 'homem-pássaro' do título, que sofre para se manter relevante após não fazer a sequência do longa há 20 anos atrás, o filme parece ser mais 'normal' do que realmente é.

Mergulhado em um diferente conceito de ser filmado para dar a impressão de que foi feito sem cortes, o que evidentemente não passa de uma simulação, dado o fato de ser uma produção cinematográfica de algumas horas de duração, e complementado por uma trilha sonora composta, em sua maior parte, apenas por uma bateria, Birdman demora um pouco para nos fazer adentrar em sua trama.

Uma vez imersos, entretanto, o filme se torna um maravilhoso ode ao teatro. O filme se passa nos bastidores de uma produção teatral, nos apresentando de forma curiosa às suas mais variadas vertentes. Há acidentes, saídas de roteiro, pessoas à beira de uma crise de nervos, visitas da imprensa, e até mesmo desentendimentos entre os atores, tudo envolto neste conceito de que há alguém perseguindo os personagens o tempo todo pelos palcos, corredores e até pelas ruas.

O filme todo se desenvolve basicamente no mesmo cenário, um teatro de Nova Iorque, o que igualmente ajuda a dar aquela característica ainda mais teatral ao projeto. E como uma boa peça, o componente essencial é a atuação dos atores, e não deleites visuais que distraiam da história e seus personagens.

Assim, Michael Keaton brilha como o atormentado Riggan Thomson, atuando basicamente como si mesmo. E a ironia de que Keaton igualmente fez fama há 20 anos quando viveu o personagem Batman nas telonas, apenas reforça o efeito metalinguístico. Ao contrário de seus colegas indicados ao Oscar de Melhor Ator, que ou interpretam pessoas reais, ou contam com artifícios como dramas exagerados, Keaton foca sua atuação dentro da alma do próprio personagem, salientando que tudo se passa dentro da própria perspectiva de Riggan. As angústias, dúvidas, e alegrias do personagem são meramente naturais, e conferem um peso muito maior à sua atuação.

Edward Norton, então, se sai extraordinariamente bem, no que talvez seja seu melhor papel em anos. Emma Stone, com seus grandes olhos, sempre se sai encantadora. E até mesmo Zach Galifianakis, nitidamente mais magro, consegue nos surpreender em um papel mais sério. Eu não acreditava que ele fosse capaz de fazer qualquer coisa sem encarnar a aura amalucada do Alan de Se Beber Não Case.

Trazendo ainda uma história que pode gerar entendimentos ambíguos, Birdman honra a si mesmo com efeitos especiais divertidos e pouco usuais em momentos chaves, deixando os espectadores ainda mais surpresos quando a trama larga um pouco o teatro para focar quase que exclusivamente em Riggan.

Sem dúvida, Birdman talvez seja o filme que mais divide opiniões dentre os vários indicados ao Oscar de Melhor Filme de 2015. E gerar debates nunca é ruim. Principalmente para o cinema, que vem optando por escolhas cada vez mais fáceis e certeiras nos últimos anos, adaptando livros popularescos e histórias em quadrinhos como se fossem requisitos infalíveis para se arrastar multidões às salas de cinema. E até isto é debatido em Birdman, numa amalgama metalinguagem extremamente perspicaz. 

Talvez não ser fácil seja uma qualidade, afinal de contas.

And the folks who make their living going to auditions and trying to make their living in live theater do not cotton to this.  The movie did flesh this out quite well.  But the wierd elements fantasizing Keaton's journey was a little "over the top" to put it mildly.  Good film.....C+.

Birdman is different. Its skeleton is pretty basic but there is just so much meaning. Birdman mirrors, pokes fun at and symbolizes hollywood and its stars. It starts with the Birdman gimmick which is inflating hollywood. Michael Keaton's character played Birdman in Hollywood and is now trying to redeam himself as a serious actor. On his journey of redemption he tries to escape his past, stay releveant and not be remembered as being Birdman. On the journey we see parallels with the real film industry: the critics being the only option that matters, celebrities who feel loved but in reality are admired, not being able to separate reality with acting and one actors fame causing him to overstep others. In the end which can be interpreted many ways, Keaton realizes he cannot escape Birdman and just accepts it. Just like Christian Bale will always be Batman and Robert Downey Jr will be Ironman.

Basic: So, Birdman or the unexpected virtue of ignorance, Riggan Thompson (played by Micheal Keaton) is a washed-up actor, he's been famous for playing the character, Birdman, and now he's trying to redeem himself by doing an adaptation of a novel, by not in a movie, but in a play. He's also trying to get his family back together. Amy Ryan's character wants Micheal Keaton's character, Riggan to spend more time with her daughter, Sam (played by Emma Stone), after she got back from rehab for all the drugs she's been doing. Well, in fact, she worked with Riggan on his play he's doing as his as. Zach Galifianakis plays Riggan's agent. Edward Norton, Naomi Watts, and Andrea Riseborough are all playing the actors, who are in Riggan's play he's doing. Just an absolute A- level cast there.

What's the deal: Let me just start off to say about Alejandro Gonzales Inarritu, and his films he had done. In 2001, he directed Amorres Perros, a very bleak and a very strong film, which had great performances, and considered it to be a classic for a lot of people out there. Then, in 2003, he did 21 grams, (his first English film), that somehow may not be as great as Amorres Perros, but it was good for a lot of critics. In 2006, he made Babel, a movie that went down a little, but it did earn a lot of Academy Awards Nominations including best picture. In 2010, he goes back on making another foreign film, Biutiful, starring Javier Bardem, and that does marked the least film that he has done due to its graphic images. Now, he makes Birdman, a dark comedy, which really does take a very thrilling leap forward by Alejandro Gonzales Inarritu. After watching many times of the trailer, I really thought the film was going to be a lot like Silver Linings Playbook. The fact, that these two movies have different genres, but it does have that same subject that the main character is trying to fix his problems, and also trying to get his life back as he wanted to be. Now, when I watched the film, it felt different of what I experienced. That it's not like Silver Linings Playbook at all. It was an absolute darkly comedy, that I was quite amused by it, and the filmmaking was pretty ballsy.
 
The nominations: The film is nominated of nine academy award nominations, including best director, best actor, and best picture. Everybody has been talking a lot about Michael Keaton's performance, and I think he does a great job as playing a washed-up actor, who's going into this reality and fantasy world of his. I do think he's going to win the Oscar for best actor in a leading role, but I'm not 100% sure of it, because people do talked about another actor in another movie, Eddie Redmayne in The Theory of Everything, which I had not yet saw the movie. Of course, Michael Keaton's recent films: Robocop (remake), and Need for Speed has been disappointed. In fact, I haven't seen the remake of Robocop. I really detested Need for Speed, though. But, anyway, I do think his performance carried a lot of great strength in the film. As for the rest of the cast, I do think they did a solid job in the film, especially Edward Norton, and Emma Stone, who are nominated this year.  Emmanuel Luebezki's cinematography (better known for winning an Oscar for Gravity) is very beautiful to look at. The direction by Alejandro Gonzales Inarritu is pretty ballsy, and the reason why I'm saying that because almost the entire movie is done with this one long shot, and the camera angles were moving around in places, when we see these characters of where they're going, and what they're doing. It reminded me of something that Sam Raimi had done that with The Evil Dead trilogy, except he was only doing it to make it scary. Now, my only question I have with this movie is why Birdman won best screenplay at the Golden Globes?  I mean, I do see the fact that the screenplay is very well written, and it does have some creativity, but I really do think The Grand Budapest Hotel deserved to win best screenplay because it had so much creativity, and it is just so wonderfully written, that it was so hard for me to resist. The screenplay to this film is still well-written, though.

My full opinion: I wouldn't say that Birdman is a perfect film for me, because some of the visuals in the film really does warned me down, but for the most part, I was actually quite amused by this absolute ballsy dark comedy, that Alejandro Gonzales Inarritu had just created. 8.6/10

Birdman is the story of an actor who used to play a superhero in big blockbuster films but decided to quit after a few movies to pursue a deeper acting career. So this movie opens on him preparing a show on Broadway that he is writing, directing, and starring in. Of course if you've heard anything about this film it's not the plot, but the fact that it is intended to appear as one entirely continuous take. It's a fun artistic choice, however I did struggle with it at times because without breaks I sometimes had difficulty figuring out how much time had passed in the moment it took them to sweep the camera from one end of the room to another. However, the rapid-fire way they moved from one scene to the next without cuts made the whole thing feel very theatrical. In fact, the stuff that was happening to the characters backstage sometimes felt as scripted as the stuff we see them doing on stage. I don't mean this as an insult because a number of the speeches and monologues that characters have in this film are simply wonderful. It all flows very nicely and even caused me to question what was actually a line in the play and when someone was bringing their personal life on stage.

The true brilliance of Birdman is in the cast. I could walk through every single actor on the list and talk about how awesome they were, but it would get repetitive after awhile. I could not ask for more from their performances, and it seemed almost every person had their one scene to shine which they nailed. Instead of gushing endlessly about the cast I think I'll get to the couple of things that I didn't love in Birdman. First of all, this movie continuously inserted some magical elements into the story. I thought it did a nice job of straddling the line and making the viewer question whether these things were happening in reality or only in the main character's unstable mind. However, towards the end it feels like we are given a definitive answer, and then a little while later we are given a contradictory definitive answer. I just would like the movie to either leave it ambiguous or make up its mind. The only other problem I had with Birdman was the way it seemed to take a number of stands on things but it was never solidly decided on one stance. For instance, is it villainizing superhero films or glorifying them? It was beautifully presented, perfectly acted, and had a lot of excellent scenes but it didn't really have anything to say. There were several moments where I was asking myself "Why is this scene even in the movie? Is there an overall point to all this?" I guess I didn't totally understand the film, but I'd gladly watch it again to attempt to figure it out.

My husband and I wanted to walk out of the theater.  I wish we had.  What is the attraction of this nihilistic, weird, dark, non-funny movie?  Why do audiences put up with films filled with gratuitous F-words every other minute?

I loved it. Dark comedy that examines the struggles and insecurities of actors, particularly, one known for the single role of Batman/Birdman. Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu's masterful direction and Emmanuel Lubezki's stunning cinematography creates a single take that dances like a play while critiquing the entire industry. Michael Keaton gives the best performance of the year.

The technical achievement present in the film, one that is made to look as if the entire thing is one continuous shot, is enough to be at least intrigued by "Birdman". However, the directorial technique is far more than a gimmick. Inarritu uses this method to enhance his storytelling, giving the movie a far more fluid and immediate energy as we follow the turbulent story of Keaton's emotionally damaged character. Michael Keaton does in fact give his best performance to date, and the rest of the cast deliver equally as funny and dramatic performances. Perhaps the film's most admirable achievement, however, is its excellent combination of insanely dark humor with significant dramatic heft.
I love visually interesting movies, but it's not just pretty, it's all around done well. Meta levels were particularly fun.

Semi-biographical of it's star, and essentially a commentary that tries to separate entertainment from art, while intelligently criticizing the pursuit of celebrity and fame, "Birdman" is an immensely well-made film in almost every aspect. Michael Keaton, Edward Norton, and Emma Stone are fantastic -- Norton's performance being my particular favorite in this film. The story, which follows a former Hollywood star (Keaton) who tries to write, direct, and act in a broadway play to prove himself an artist, seems like it might be deriving aspects of Keaton's real career. The plot is very well structured, but it loses a bit of its balance in the final act. Director Alejandro González Iñárritu's coolest superpower in "Birdman" is how the film appears to be all one take. This gives the film a dreamy vibe which is accentuated in several surrealist scenes that are scattered across the film. Furthermore, the single-take style gives somewhat of a broadway feel to the film itself, while maintaining incredible filmic staging. The director's intent is clear throughout "Birdman" and it makes the film a wonderful, wholesome, and energetic experience.

An unexpected view that turns out to be quite rewarding. The cast rocks the Broadway stage with a splendid and unforgettable performance. Using the theatre as the primary setting for the movie is just perfect and the fact that the camera follows the people of interest wherever they go, it kind of feels like the living souls of these performers lies within the very walls of the theatre itself. Add BIRDMAN to your bucket list now as it's very WELL DONE!

More mess-terpiece than masterpiece, and does not improve upon reflection. There are things to like here - some snazzy dialogue, that brilliant flight scene - but I struggle to understand why there's so much hype about a movie where: 

1. Two major subplots disappear - one involving Michael Keaton's daughter falling in love with Edward Norton (not too long after he greets her by complimenting her ass, which I'm pretty sure would be a dealkiller for most people); the other involving a lesbian kiss for Naomi Watts's astonishingly flat character.

2. The one-shot gimmick (EVERYTHING FLOWS TOGETHER) reveals absolutely nothing.

3. In every single scene something Extremely Dramatic happens - two characters scream at each other, have a fistfight or share a fateful kiss.

4. Half the punchlines involve genitals.

Michael Keaton has been hiding in plain sight acting in forgettable movies to the point that I thought he was semi-retired.  I looked at his filmography and he's been busy cashing paychecks, but in nothing I have seen since 2002's Live From Baghdad, an HBO movie, which itself was billed as a sort of comeback.   What Keaton does in this movie is what all the great movie stars have done before him, he is both himself and the character at the same time.  The material is that of a Neill Simon satire of Hollywood and Broadway minus the comedy.  Those of us that remember how good Michael Keaton he was in the 1980s have probably wondered why he stopped getting the A-list roles.  Maybe it was Batman, but he was also occupying the same real estate as Tom Hanks and Robin Williams.  He had the problem that Joel McRae faced with Gary Cooper or Randolph Scott had with Jimmy Stewart, winning actors that find themselves with the rejected scripts of bigger stars.  
This movie trades the comedy normal in satire for a bit of art house pretension that works better in European movies but fits right in with this material.  Keaton's alter ego is BIRDMAN, the character that had made him rich and famous 20 years prior.  Birdman is constantly getting into his head and the audience gets to see Keaton's super powers when he gets angry.  I don't think I have read Raymond Carver since around the time Keaton was making Batman movies, but the play is based on his work.   It's a great choice for an actor of fluff that is looking for something he takes to be depth and the script also gives Keaton a personal connection back to Carver.  Overall the movie is realism splashed with dreamlike moments, but on reflection the movie only makes sense as a dream or a delusion.  I appreciated the nuance and the ambiguity.
It has some notable co-stars, including a deglamorized Emma Stone, a youthful looking Naomi Watts, Edward Norton channeling that pipsqueak Brando thing he does, along with Amy Ryan as the ex-wife and Zach Galifianakis as the best friend and producer.  
This is one of the better films of 2014 and I look forward to the director's commentary when it comes out on DVD.   We can only hope that this time Keaton is back for good giving us some meaty performances over the next ten years.   If I had to place a wager I think this would be most likely to win Best Picture by process of elimination.

The story of Birdman is for the most part compelling, the characters engaging. Director Inarritu creativity infuses the plot with a captivating rhythm and feel. The the camera follows just behind actors' shoulders as they turn tight corners backstage, a jazz drummer brings an infectious energy to conflict, and scenes melt into each other appealingly. Outside of style and characters, the film is worthwhile in how it invites the viewer to ask if the Broadway crowd is right in its abhorrence of Reegan and "all he represents". It seemed to me only partially true. 

Reegan may not be a very likable character, but the complicated feelings he inspires is what makes one return to the film later. His manic delusions are grotesque and pitiful, and the lack of love his self-absorption leaves his daughter and lover are hateful. At the same time, his courage in putting his career on the line inspires admiration, as do his soliloquies of great pathos. 

If you are looking for a movie both enjoyable and light, and difficult and thought-provoking, Birdman is a safe bet.

Every year there are films that come along and try to be so different and "cool" in the way a film is made that they fail and the film is an utter mess - THIS IS NOT ONE OF THOSE FILMS! 

BIRDMAN is an absolute gem of a film in every way that it is made - from the superb directing to the simple yet stylistic score, to the amazing writing, and spot on acting - this film is as REAL as it gets; now I'm not saying that every film should be made in the fashion of BIRDMAN (because it wouldn't work for anything else) but I hope this film inspires all filmmakers and movie goers to understand how a moving picture can go outside the lines and be a real life piece of art that is memorable...besides the run time this is almost (almost) a 5 star film!

Birdman is a film within a theater play, and Michael Keaton is its harried writer, director and producer.  When actors get tired of acting, they become directors: Keaton
is attempting both.  He's naked (walking around in his jockey briefs)and fallible before the world: he's no genius but he keeps the ball rolling as the theater production looks like a train going across a rickety bridge.  What I like about the film is that the characters are vulnerable, hurt, bewildered, confused, but they carry their confusion with a certain dignity.  After all, life is just a stage; the cinematography looks like a guy with a camera following the actors around and never quite knowing what the actors will do next. 
The female parts show surprising kindness and vulnerability--which empowers them.  The all- too -powerful theatre critic is brassy and tangles  with Keaton; he needs a good review: they both stick up for their rights: she to be a critic and he an artist.  After all, it's not the result that is all important, but its all important that he try.  Keaton shows about every emotion in the acting book and his nomination for a best actor Oscar is timely.

This was a really interesting watch. I will say, I think you need to be in a certain mood to watch it. But, I really enjoyed it. The continuous long takes were fascinating. There was a lot of creativity and ingenuity to make those work and flow the way they did. Michael Keaton is absolutely fantastic. You essentially watch him fall to pieces over the course of a few weeks. (Going back to the long takes, using those made weeks feel like one long day, which was a brilliant move). Edward Norton is also really interesting as a super method actor (and one wonders how much of that was acting...) and Emma Stone also does a good job as Keaton's daughter. Overall, this is a compelling, thought provoking movie that inspires a lot of discussion, which I think was the point.

A movie so meta you'll lose its multiple threads if you look away, Birdman (Or: The Virtue of Whatever) ultimately failed in leaving me satisfied but proved to be a riveting movie to watch and disseminate. At points self-parody ( Birdman IS Batman IS Michael Keaton IS Riggan Thomson, get it?), at others a treatise on the nature of art and artistic worth, and sometimes a fable of "magical realism", it's the rare movie that challenges its viewers to really read between the lines. This movie works on so many levels, it's  amazing Iñarritu didn´t buckle under all that weight. Add to that the illusion of the movie being one big long uninterrupted shot, and you have a gem that any self-respecting cinephile should see. Micheal Keaton at its best!

Alejandro González Iñárritu has thrown himself into the Oscar ballet with his critically acclaimed film Birdman, but is it really has good as the hype says it is? The story revolves around Riggan Thomson (Michael Keaton) a down on his luck actor who is better known for his portrayal of the super hero Birdman. He attempts to make people remember the man behind the mask by producing, directing, and staring in a broadway play, but he keeps hitting walls at every turn, sometimes real and sometimes in his own mind.

This film was beloved during it's limited release I personally left the theater enjoying what i saw but also confused at what it was. Birdman is a good movie, but it is by no means perfect and some elements are just plain bad. It's biggest strength is in it's cinematography with long uncut tracking shots following characters in and out of rooms, conveying that you're watching a play more then a movie. It also plays around with diegetic and non-diegetic sounds to convey a sense of frustration and instability. However while the film falls flat when it comes to the plot, it starts out strong and pulls the audience in quickly, but during the second act the film seems like it forgot what it's trying to say and goes all over place. Certain scenes that would be large plot points are just forgotten by the third act and gives us an ending that just seems forced and cliched. 

The best performance of the entire film goes to Michael Keaton, while he was not actually in Alejandro's mind when we wrote Birdman he was still the perfect choice. He does wall at conveying an actor who isn't a good person but makes you root for him. We may not see Keaton as much as we used to but after this film it's should be obvious people will want to see him more. Edward Norton nearly stole the show as a antisocial overly realistic method actor. He can sometimes become over the top in his performance, but brings it down at the right moments for him to be taken seriously. Emma Stone plays Keaton's post-rehab daughter, who's always been a great actress but in this role she's a mixed bag. When she tries to convey an angsty depressed Lindsey Lohan type girl, it comes across as simply forced, but she really shines in the more sincere moments especially with Keaton, doing well to convey a loving relationship. The most disappointing performance in the whole movie has to be Zach Galifanakis, while he looks good he just doesn't stand out among the herd of other great actors. Anytime he wasn't on screen I would totally forget he was even in the movie.

All in all the film started strong but ran out of breath near the end. I am not dissapointed i saw it at all, but i'm happy to have only seen it once. While I highly doubt it will win best picture hopefully this will mean Keaton being brought in for leading rolls.

This utterly baffling film is riding on a sea of awards hype, fueled in large part, I think, by an army of people thinking "Michael Keaton? I remember him! He's great! He was Batman! I love Batman! And he's in a new film! Brilliant!"

Through Keaton-coloured glasses, Birdman is viewed as a sort of homecoming party, and I can't help but fast forward a few years to wonder how time will treat it. We start out with an engaging little ensemble drama set on Broadway, and we finish with a maddeningly self-indulgent, freewheeling "exploration" which upends most of our established feelings about Keaton's Riggan Thomson, renders nearly everything we've seen happen prior to be either meaningless or nonsensical, and leaves us on a note which is "open to interpretation" in as much as you're choosing between thinking "what the fuck was that?" or yawning.

It's problematic.

But, it is undoubtedly a technical marvel - if you've any interest in cinematography, this is a no-brainer. It is extremely meticulously put together, and it looks fantastic. And everyone in it is good. And it really is a good film for the first hour or so - infuriatingly so, as it turns out. As it ran out of steam somewhere into the second hour, the film that leapt to mind by way of comparison was Darren Aronofsky's howlingly pretentious Black Swan. Both films have an annoyingly loose grasp on what I was demanding from them: structure and meaning. Indeed, in a moment here which is supposed to be self-referential and clever, Keaton literally walks past a character using Macbeth to describe the film he's in: "It is a tale. Told by an idiot, full of sound and fury, Signifying nothing." - I couldn't help but think to myself, "yup!"

La historia de Birdman tiene quizás el problema de tener el enfoque del mundo del cine/teatro, lo que seguramente para gran parte del público sonará como algo distante con lo que no puede sentirse identificado, pero realmente su mensaje puede ir más allá de eso.

Puede que lo más llamativo de la cinta sea el "cómo": una soberbia realización de cámara y montaje que nos engaña a todos con un falso plano secuencia durante prácticamente todo el metraje y que no debería caer en saco roto ya que no solo ayuda mucho al ritmo de la trama y a esa sensación de angustia que sufre el protagonista, sino que también es todo un alarde cinematográfico. Un aplauso al señor Iñarritu, ESO es hacer.

Birdman Movie? is a story about an actor Riggan (Michael Keaton?) who is past his peak days. In his peak he used to play a superhero, Bridman. Now in his later years he regrets that he didn't validated himself as a true actor. To right his wrongs he acts in and directs a Broadway show. So the whole film revolves around that show, it feels more like a play than a film. It is a satirical commentary on the bombardment of superhero films in our age. Keaton's performance was outstanding, along with brilliant performances by Emma Stone? and Edward Norton? as supporting cast. The cinematography was fabulous given there are very few visible cuts. But even more so because of the long takes, which would reach upto 15 pages of dialogue at a time! The music score is also worth mentioning which is performed solely on drums.
Not my kind of movie. Wasn't enjoyable.

Per capire quando il regista ha interrotto le scene del pianosequenza (per poi unirle con il montaggio) basta vedere quando la telecamera inquadra un muro/uno spazio senza persone e roba simile. Spesso la telecamera insegue un attore nei corridoi e spesso si vede l'attore girare l'angolo mentre la telecamera rimane per meno di un secondo leggermente indietro e per un attimo inquadra la parete del corridoio: ecco, quello probabilmente è il momento in cui il regista ha spezzato la registrazione per poi riprenderla in un secondo momento ripartendo proprio inquadrando quel muro.

One of the most unique movies I have seen in quite some time. Michael Keaton was great and is my pick for best actor, and not simply because of the meta angle of him playing a former superhero actor trying to revive his career. I hate Edward Norton, but he did a good job (I'd give the supporting nod to JK Simmons though). 

My biggest gripe about the movie is that it is too self-aware, but in many ways that is what makes the movie. You combine it with the uneasy camera angles and the annoying music (which was probably produced by JK Simmons' conservatory after throwing some cymbals at his drummer's head), and it created a strange dizzying sensation that matched the plight of the Birdman. I loved the ending and think this movie is the dark horse to win it all since the historical/true story movies will split votes and people will wake up and realize that beyond the gimmick of filming it over 12 years, Boyhood wasn't a very good movie. When all is said and done, though, Birdman's most lasting contribution will be that it inspired two artists to create a new style called "extreme realism."

 Honestly I really don't understand why I ended up liking Birdman so much. The story feels as much ignorant as the alternate title.To begin with I truly was not able to stick myself with plausibility of the events shown in the film. Although I was quite able to relate to it metaphorically but the ending left me pretty much hanging. The story has a multi-layered point of view and the writers have done splendid job working on small little details which many casual viewers miss. Birdman is a kind of movie where you will spot something new on multiple viewings that you might have missed earlier.

 The story revolves around Riggan (played masterfully by Micahel Keaton) who was once a famous superstar for playing superhero Birdman in blockbuster movies. Now past his middle age, Riggan seems to have lost his path in the film industry but his mind is not a phase to accept it. He is working on Broadway play which he himself is directing and writing apart from acting in it to showcase his talents. We get see his internal struggle countering with his alter-ego "Birdman" who makes him feel he is still a superstar and shouldn't waste his time on Broadway plays. Also he is facing family problems with distances between him and his daughter Sam (Emma Stone) constantly increasing. Starring in his play is a hardcore actor Mike (Edward Norton) whose dedications have no limit while he is acting and two more actress Leasley(Naomi Watts) and Laura(Andrea Riseborough) who have relatively smaller role. The entire star-studded cast was absolutely brilliant to watch and each of their characters is given ample amount of depth.

 The cinematography is excellent and the entire film is edited to make it look like a one continuous shot (except once in the climax). The background score comprising mostly drums was also splendid. The multi-layered screenplay was very interesting and there were also many laugh-out-loud moments which was a really surprising considering the theme was more of dark comedy. I am not very clear about what rating to give right now, will have stronger opinion after re-watching it few times. Still with its stellar cast, weirdly intelligent script I must admit Birdman is one the finest films I have seen this year.

Mexican director Alejandro GonzÃ¡lez IÃ±Ã¡rritu is not normally known for his jeu d'esprit and has seemed more comfortable while dealing with heavily pessimistic and sombre themes. His previous films Amores Perros, 21 Grams, Babel and Biutiful are all excellent works but they require serious commitment to get yourself through their excruciatingly downbeat material. With that in mind, it's no surprise that his latest effort in Birdman is ultimately about the fractured and fragile psyche of a man on a seemingly downward spiral. However, Birdman shows another side to IÃ±Ã¡rritu's talents; black it may be but he now surprisingly  displays a great talent for comedy.

Riggan Thomson (Michael Keaton) was once a massive Hollywood star that made his reputation playing the superhero Birdman. However, his career faded after the third instalment of the franchise and he now finds himself working on the Broadway stage. He's determined to prove his worth as a real actor and director by adapting a Raymond Carver play but problems with his cast, his family and his own fragile mental state threaten to sink his ambitions.

Films within films have often been a theme throughout filmmaking. To become self-referential is a bold move. Robert Altman's The Player, Spike Jonze's Adaptation or the surreal work of David Lynch's Mulholland Drive are notable works that have toyed with the life imitating art imitating life structure. It can be hard to pull off but these films are just some  examples of when it's done right and IÃ±Ã¡rritu's latest can now consider itself to be on the same level.

On previous evidence, IÃ±Ã¡rritu has proven to be a very clever director. He has always had a grasp on his material and delivered their fractured structures and timeframes with deftness and consummate skill. His work on Birdman is as impressive as he's ever been but it's the handling of comedy that's impresses most. Not only is he able to capture the absurdity and quirks in human behaviour but he also utilises these behaviours to create an inventive and original farce.
Employing the likes of Emmanuel Lubezki as director of photography is also a genius stroke. In a short space of time, Lubezki has become one of the most respected cinematographer's in the business and if you look at his work on Gravity last year or his work here, you can easily see why. He manages to keep the camera constantly moving throughout the films entirety; one minute we're focused, up close and personal, on the actors before sweeping through claustrophobic corridors, upstairs and down to find another dramatic moment. The film wasn't shot as one continuous take but it's miraculously made to look like it and credit must go to editors Douglas Crise and Stephen Mirrione for their seamless work on Lubezki's constantly mobile camerawork.

As the long, seemingly  continuous shots grab your attention, though, so too do the performances. Across the board, everyone delivers. Amy Ryan and Andrea Riseborough are given small roles but they're by no means ineffective. Naomi Watts produces the emotional quality she always does and Emma Stone really sinks her teeth into the conflicted and tortured daughter role. Again, Zach Galifiniakas is given a small role where he only sporadically appears throughout the story but whenever he does, he commands a surprising range of emotions. I was very impressed with his dramatic work when he's normally considered a comedy actor. From the supporting players, though, it's Ed Norton who shines brightest. It's been a while since Norton has had a role that he's able to reaffirm his talents but he finds it here. Again, self-referential, Norton sends himself up. He has a reputation for being difficult to work with but bravely embraces a character that similarly reflects his acting methods. As a big admirer of Norton, I can only hope that this sees him back where he belongs. Which brings me to the leading man; I've never really been too kind or retrained on my dislike for Michael Keaton. I've often found him to be quite a self-conscious actor and could never shake off the feeling that most of his work is nothing more than a performance. He never allowed me to suspend my disbelief and for any actor that is a major demerit and (to be brutally honest) unforgivable. That being said, as Riggan Thompson, Keaton wonderfully parodies himself and I have to hold my hands up here... he's absolutely outstanding in Birdman. It's by far his finest work to date and a role that's tailor made for him. Having successfully donned the Batsuit in Tim Burton's take on the dark knight, Keaton never really reached those heights again. He had the occasional role that provided him with reasonable supporting hits but, for the most part, Keaton had had his day. This is the film that will, no doubt, bring him more work where his fans will rejoice in seeing his solid return.

I was honestly one for passing Birdman by. I do enjoy the works of Norton and IÃ±Ã¡rritu but when I heard about Michael Keaton headlining a film, I considered giving it a wide berth. However, the buzz surrounding it left me with no choice but to check it out. I'm glad I did as it's an accomplished piece of work that explores the weighty themes of the human ego, past successes and the inability to come to terms with failure. Meanwhile, it satirises showbiz, and in particular, the superhero hero genre. Everyone from Woody Harrelson in The Hunger Games to Robert Downey, Jr in his "tin-man get up" takes a dig but ultimately the film is one big in-joke that manages to tread a fine line between fantasy and reality.

I loved the artistic style of this movie, and felt that its cinematography was a few notches above its contemporaries. Watching the plot unfold, I felt like I was really a part of the backstage crew to a major theatre production. While not without a couple of gratuitous scenes and plotlines that amounted to nothing, I felt that the coyness of this story was very unique. The acting was exquisite across the board, and the tongue-in-cheek premise of Michael Keaton as a washed-up former movie superhero was explored exceptionally well. Riggan Thomson (Keaton's character) noted that the role he was playing on a Broadway stage felt like a microcosm of his character's life, and I can't help but wonder how much Keaton felt Thomson was a microcosm of his actual life.

At one point in the film, Thomson decries a critics' review as nothing more than a mere "label." Well, here's a label for Birdman: phenomenal.

I'm pained to say that I didn't love Birdman, as the single-shot cinematography was executed fluidly and delightfully. It's ambitious. Even Gravity had a few cuts littered throughout the film on occasion. Birdman, from the introduction of Michael Keaton as washed-up actor Riggan (formerly titular star of superhero film 'Birdman'; great casting) meditating in the air to the intense on-stage climax, has no cuts. This condition certainly limits director Alejandro Gonzalez in reward for unique results. Admirable, too, considering how costume and makeup changes had to be at Broadway level for certain transitions to work. I doubt that Gonzalez would cheat via editing. The music feels like New York and Broadway, switching between familiar classical movements and the showmanship of a sole jazz drummer. We become familiar with the layout of the Broadway theater that the movie takes place in, and the streets around the theater. On the subject of familiarity, since this film centers around Keaton's play production, we also become familiar with certain scenes of the play, and each repetition feels drastically different. As an actor, I empathized with those in the production, in fear of the show fucking up at any moment, or at the worst moment.

Strangely, what happens on stage or in public was far more interesting than the exposition behind the curtain. Besides Michael Keaton, the other stage actors are hardcore method acting and controlling-in-compensation-for-flaccid-penis Edward Norton, the sexually unsatisfied Naomi Watts, and emotionally unsatisfied Andrea Riseborough. Keaton's character has a daughter, played by Emma Stone, who got out of rehab and blames Keaton for the err of her ways. What's unfortunate about the cinematography is that Gonzalez limited himself to focusing on one or two characters for an extended time, inherently leaning towards the Birdman. I can't articulate how the minor characters change, as the movie abandons their side stories well before the climax.

That leaves us with Birdman/Riggan. His character is a wreck, despite directing and starring in a Broadway show. He is constantly unsatisfied with his show, primarily because Norton is hogging the spotlight from him. Combined with one critic's promise to destroy the show and on-stage embarrassments, Keaton is in constant conflict with his former self, a true superhero. Literally. He has mental, sometimes physical, arguments with himself in a Birdman costume. Keaton's losses and victories over himself, and the world, might be the first time I discovered how talented he really is, beyond his works with Tim Burton. Within Keaton's vision, we see him exploit telekinetic powers and the ability to fly. No one else sees that though. I won't spoil the climax, but what happens afterwards warps what I assumed to be the real world. Rather than people seeing Keaton as mentally ill, they hail him as a truly groundbreaking actor. The film ends with others seeing him as the superhero, as Keaton flies around New York City and possibly fights crime. I understand that the superpowers are metaphorical. That's not what I'm talking about. By the end, I couldn't tell what Birdman wanted to be. A satire on the celebrity culture of Broadway, in comparison to Hollywood? A 'hyperrealistic' depiction of how less successful shows can beat the odds and trump the critics? It can't be both, so whatever the screenwriters and Gonzalez were going for, I'm opting for neither. The lack of focus and undeveloped characters are disappointing. It may not be the decades-to-last art piece that I wanted, but I would still recommend seeing this once for the cinematography alone, with committed performances, some enthralling scenes, and a definite New York feel as bonuses.

My thing is, you can't bash a movie that's original and experimental in nature. Especially one that provides such deep commentary as this one does. Look past narrative and character depth and acting--which are all on point here anyway--and realize that you will rarely watch anything like this in your lifetime. There's nothing commercial about this. Much could be said about the equally innovative Boyhood. 

But in Birdman's case, the long takes adds to the complexity of the story and the palpability of it. You know there's no BS because you're seeing everything--and it all makes sense. And while the film seems to mostly be one single shot, it still has so many stories intertwined that all relate to one another as though the characters are apart of the same plain--and they can't avoid each other.

It's a commentary of show business, but it isn't preachy, and it doesn't blatantly take sides. It shows things for what they are.

To me it's impossible to criticize something that's as honest as this. You watch this film an then you go and watch the next Nicholas Sparks film and compare their integrities. One of those you feel like you're a customer at somebody's business, and the other you feel like you're staring at a masterpiece at an art gallery. A masterpiece of film is greater than the sum of it's parts. Birdman doesn't fall apart at the seams if something is out of line. It isn't dependent on one aspect of the film. Even with mediocre acting this film would be incredible.

Riggan (Michael Keaton) is a washed-up superhero actor straining to add artistic credibility to his career by writing, directing, and starring in a Broadway drama derived from the work of Raymond Carver. Aside from the fragile ego and short temper of its leading man, the play's production is troubled by a jaded method actor (Edward Norton), Riggan's drug-addled daughter (Emma Stone), and the hallucinatory specter of the superhero who resulted in Riggan's eternal typecasting. Director Alejandro González Iñárritu uses a lot of handheld cameras and extreme close-ups in Birdman; this results in a claustrophobic film that gives the audience the impression that they're spying on the actors rather than watching them perform. That helps the film achieve a chilling effect, but the principle strength of Birdman lies in the excellent performances by Keaton, Norton, and the rest of the well-chosen cast.

The story which is presented in Birdman isn't really compelling or particularly interesting. What is though is the Oscar worthy acting and the unbelievable cinematography.
The Camera - When the camera simply refuses to jump cut, as an audience member you are stuck along for the ride that is this fluid film.  You feel like you're part of the film.  As the actors do their thing each innovative transition gracefully moves you from room to room and scene to scene and you are right there with them. Because of this effect you are infinitely more invested in what's happening because it is as though there is never a moment to naturally blink.
The Acting - Actors are good memorizing lines. Though too often dialogue feels like just that, a memorized line.  The filming style of this movie (super long takes with complicated behind the scenes choreography) purposely left in 'mistakes' in the dialogue. But in reality everyone stumbles, repeats, stutters, etc. when speaking in everyday life.  The actors in this movie, and within the play within the movie, really do seem like they are just improvising everything, speaking normally, and it comes across as really real. There's no other way to put it, it's as though you are watching real life. Even the outlandish moments, like Michael Keaton's fantasies, are believable because the world created by the non cutting fluid camera moves refuses to pull you out of the story.
The Music - It is sparse consisting almost entirely of jazz drumming. And it fits perfectly. Enough said.
Conclusion - The performances truly are Academy Award deserving (See the Emma Stone and Michael Keaton scene where they discuss using drugs). The cinematography is so engaging you simply cannot get away from the story if you want to. This movie is an example to all other movies on how to almost force an audience to like your movie; by making an overall bland story interesting with phenomenal acting, 'in real life' camera work, and the 'less is more' mantra repeated throughout every aspect of the film.

"You're doing this because you're scared to death, like the rest of us, that you don't matter. And you know what? You're right. You don't. It's not important. You're not important. Get used to it."

No matter how people feel about this film, there is no denying that Birdman is a technical marvel. Emmanuel Lubezki is one of the best cinematographers in Hollywood and he should continue working and experimenting with his fellow Mexican directors. Birdman is visually astonishing and one of the most unforgettable moviegoing experiences of the year. He blew us away last year when he took us to space in Gravity, and now he astonishes audiences once again by giving us the illusion that the film is taking place entirely in one single shot. From the opening shot, Lubezki is letting us know that we are going to get our heads spun and so he circles around a table with four actors discussing their roles in the play they are about to act in. Birdman is unlike any other film I've seen in that sense, where you feel like you are watching actors in a live theater. The audience becomes the camera which follows around these egocentric and troubled actors as they interact with one another. The film has stuck with me and it is one of those rare movies I'd like to experience once again in the theaters. I can't think of another film that manages to portray the passage of time so well without having to cut from one scene to the next the way Birdman does. 

Alejandro Gonzalez Iñarritu is better known for his realistic and depressive films focusing on separate characters whose lives intertwine someway or another (Amores Perros, 21 Grams, Babel). This was quite a fantastic change of tone from his previous and more depressing films. He has crafted one of the best films of the year with groundbreaking editing effects that magically make us believe the film is all a continuous shot. He also uses dark and satirical humor to critique egocentric Hollywood actors, critics, artists, and even audiences who eat up anything they are served as long as there are loud explosions and non-stop action scenes. Iñarritu takes a shot at just about everyone.
Alexander Dinelaris's script was wickedly smart and satirical with some great and memorable dialogues that complement the technical achievements of the film very well. Birdman has a lot to say about our human nature and our desperation to become relevant and important. It is a complete film that deserves all the recognition and awards it has been receiving.

The performances in Birdman also stand out above most films released this year. Michael Keaton is fantastic as Riggan Thomson, a once popular actor who starred in a superhero franchise but hasn't been able to do anything relevant since. He is known for the character of Birdman, but he wants to prove he is a real artist and not just a washed up celebrity. That is why he is risking everything in a play he is directing, writing, producing, and starring in. His good friend, Jake (Zach Galifianakis) is co-producing the play with him. Lesley (Naomi Watts), Laura (Andrea Riseborough), and Mike (Edward Norton) are the actors he hires for the play, while his daughter Sam (Emma Stone) is working for him as his personal assistant as she tries to recover from her former drug addictions. The supporting cast is excellent in this film, especially Edward Norton and Emma Stone who share several great scenes together along with Michael Keaton. Galifianakis also impresses in a much more serious role than what we are used to seeing him in, but this is still Keaton's film who displays a wide range of emotions. Birdman has become such an important part of his life that he actually interacts with him in a surreal way. The film balances this magical realism very well and Keaton pulls off the feat of having these inner conversations with himself. The intimate camerawork only enhances these performances even more.

Funny and unusual kind of movie

It isn't hard to see why Birdman is lapping up all the awards this season. After a long time I have seen a film that made me laugh, sad, surprised but most importantly THINK. Intelligently layered and presented in the most unusual fashion Birdman signifies the difference between ordinary and pure class. Michael Keaton plays the role of a lifetime, his troubled character unfolding like the acts of the play he is struggling to stage. Ed Norton, Naomi Watts and Emma Stone provide the icing on the cake cast while the groovy jazz drum soundtrack adds a raw touch to this polished film. I thought I had predicted the end correctly but the director beautifully does a trick twist that is both shocking as well as beautiful. Go watch Birdman, and experience the unexpected virtue of ignorance.
Instant cult movie. Insanely good.
Now here is a movie that entertains as well as challenges the mind...
Interesting!!!!!!!!! Different!!!!!!!!!
Actuaciones, narrativa y técnica impecables con un ilusorio plano secuencia excepcional...

Terrific performances by Keaton, Norton and Stone, but it seems as though this was a script about the obstacles of presenting a drama on Broadway and the narcissism of the actors that the author could not sell, untill he added the fantasy devices to the script.  The art gets sold with Marvel components.
pseudo intellectual, genuinely boring. two star for the performances

Entire movie done in one moving shot? Why didn't someone tell me earlier. 

(extra 5 stars for Emma Stone.)
An excellent acting ensemble, brilliant directing and cinematography, Birdman is a captivating look at the world of acting today (blockbuster v indie, the madness of method acting and more).
