Birdman (2014) in undoubtedly a bold experiment in film making from director Alejandro González Iñárritu. As far as I can tell, it is composed of four continuous shots interspersed with time lapsed edits. This becomes somewhat tedious during the first, longest 54 minute continuous shot but Birdman begins to soar in the second hour when the more fantastical elements of the story come to the forefront (involving Michael Keaton's 'split personality' as an actor/celebrity and his superhero alter ego, Bridman). This filming technique and the Broadway setting leads to some 'theatrical acting' (especially from the three biggest stars, Keaton, Zach Galifianakis, and especially Emma Stone). This unbalances the performances a little against the whole ensemble (Edward Norton, Lindsay Duncan, and a notable Amy Ryan). This doesn't help the (somewhat elitist) intellectual, nazel-gazing at its heart about the difference between acting and ACT-ing (thank you). Birdman is certainly a bold experiment in film making  but that doesn't mean it's necessarily a great film. Mark's Grade: B

Birdman is easily one of the best films of 2014. Michael Keaton, Edward Norton, Emma Stone and Andrea Riseborough, all give their very best and the result is a masterpiece.
It's Oscar season and, rightfully so, Birdman is one of the films everyone's talking about. From its lead actor's phenomenal performance to the astounding visual effects that make the film feel like its going real-time, director Alejandro González's palpable commitment to Antonio Sanchez's almost primitive yet electrifying score, everything adds up so beautifully that you can't help but feel privileged to witness such a dazzling piece of art
Speaking of dazzling, well, the cinematography can not get better than this. I salute Emmanuel Lubezki. He is a genius, period! I mean... Children of Men (2006), Tree of Life (2011), Gravity (2013), and now Birdman (2014)... This man has become the undisputed king. Words can't do justice to his work, so i'll leave it to you to witness the art and judge for yourself.
All in all, a perfect 10/10 score from my side. And, well, the film deserves loads of Oscars, especially in the lead actor and cinematography categories.

Birdman follows Riggan Thompson, portrayed by Michael Keaton, an actor known for playing a superhero. He's clearly past his glory days, and now, wants another shot at glory, in a completely different medium. Everyone, from critics to his family, laugh and ridicule him for his upcoming project. He writes, directs and starrs in his own play, on Broadway.

It's a story of redemption. Riggan falls into the trap of trying to please everybody. Ever hear the quote 'I can't tell you how to succeed... but I can tell you how to fail, by trying to please everyone.' That's Riggan. Michael Keaton is magnetic, desperate and angry. He plays an actor so well, his problems, his superficial problems are relevant and funny. Like most actors in our generation. He desires another shot to escape mediocrity. Something he clearly lives in, and is reminded of everyday.

Supporting Keaton, is an all-star cast comprising of Edward Norton, Emma Stone, Naomi Watts. Who all carry and distribute the load well, they have their own issues. These characters could have their own story, their own film, they meld in this seamlessly. These actors and actresses know what they are doing, they know when to be loud, and they know when to be quiet and blend in the background as to not takeover the story. Brilliant effort by the supporting cast.

The most memorable scene of the film occurs when Riggan argues with a renowned critic. Who wins that scene? Still wondering.

Superhero actor stages and stars in his own adaptation of a Carver story on Broadway in an effort to reinvent himself and find artistic integrity.  Magical realist story, filmed in apparently a single take, with a fine script and brilliant performances, especially from Keaton, Norton and Naomi Watts (and all others).  Not exactly a laugh-out-loud 'comedy', but a darkly comic, thoughtful and engaging study of mental disintegration and (of course, this being America, after all) redemption.  Fine selection of music from various composers out of copyright (can you identify them all?), and a not-too-intrusive drummer.

One thing that this film proves is that even at the age of sixty three, Michael Keaton can rule! This time he is poking fun at the his own career choice of playing a superhero with the fact that he has played Batman (Batman & Batman Returns) in the past makes his appearance all the more hilarious & ironic. The story follows Riggan (Michael Keaton), a washed up actor who used to play a superhero icon called Birdman. In a valiant attempt to reclaim his career, he adapts, directs, and stars in a Broadway play. With problems from one of his very method actors (Edward Norton), assistant daughter (Emma Stone), emotional co-star (Naomi Watts), overly sexual girlfriend (Andrea Riseborough), flamboyant producer (Zach Galifanakis), and loving ex- wife (Amy Ryan), Riggan prepares for the breaking point of his career well of course while dealing with his "inner voice" of the alter ego Birdman. This movie left me feeling as though every emotion I've ever experienced and every thought I've ever had were condensed in 2 hours of amazing cinema and then reflected back at me, defying me to stare them in the face, right there, where I sitting & saying wow! Every aspect of the film is masterfully crafted and executed & the brilliant cinematography only exemplifies this. The brilliant choice of always having the camera rolling lets the viewer see what happens before and after any given event. This added information creates a realism unknown to nearly every other movie ever made. What better way to capture the raw emotion and awkward stumbling of an angry outburst at your father than to show the immediate reaction of the ranter following her outburst; you get to see the anger slowly fade from her face as the reality of what she said sets in. Rarely does a film come around that manages to be creative, original, funny, well acted, spectacularly anchored, well written and technically profound. The film has an excellent cast ensemble - Michael Keaton, Zach Galifianakis, Emma Stone, Ed Norton, Amy Ryan, Naomi Watts, Andrea Riseborough, every single actor gets to shine in their moment of screen time provided & utilize its full potential. Michael Keaton has been criminally underutilized in his career, despite some iconic performances. While the nerd crowd (Like me!) worships him as one of the most ideal Bruce Wayne/Batman combo, his career hasn't been stellar and it's a surprise I even knew his name before I saw this film! But his performance in this film deserves all the attention he gets and all the awards he is being nominated for. Riggan is a complex character and you are never quite sure about him, how he feeling and how he feels towards others, not only because of how Riggan changes as the film goes on but also because of how that reflects the ever-changing nature of the film, moving from one question or theme to the other without actually leaving it behind, instead leaving it in the back of your mind for you to think about later. A scene-stealing standout, Edward Norton makes us realize how unspoken dialogue between characters can be just as humorous without the punchline. is brilliant (playing the self-obsessed, ego-driven actor who feels more real on the stage than off it, Mike Shiner). Emma Stone has finally arrived in 2014!! Criminally misused and passed over by Hollywood for "bigger name" actresses, Stone finally shows the world what they've been missing. In one single scene, Stone revolutionizes and captures the essence of a "father-daughter" with a ferocity that you couldn't see from any other performer. She finds the heart and soul of Sam, laying her on the screen meticulously and transparent. Zach Galifanakis (playing Riggan's agent, Jake) is probably his most grounded role, is also brilliant. Though brief in screen time, the vivacious Naomi Watts, the sexy Andrea Riseborough, and the seasoned Amy Ryan make their marks exquisitely. Watts gets the most chuckles out of the ladies while Ryan has the greatest arc for us to explore. The only criticism I have about the film is that more aren't like it. A smart, satirical movie that is capable of criticizing without being hypocritical is unfortunately rare. However, it's rather nice to have movies like this stand out from the crowd instead of being the norm, because the relative quality only makes them that much better. On the whole "Birdman" is so damn enjoyable and one of the most entertaining films I have seen in years. It charms not just because of its story, but because of the performances and slick way that director Alejandro González Iñárritu plays with tone. It's downright hilarious in parts, and then there's the dramatic edge that comes into play, and simply breaks your heart. Above all, "Birdman" is a celebration of cinema. It's an audacious achievement that floors just about every aspect of film witnessed in 2014.

Narcissistic, washed-up action film star decides to "get serious" and restart his career on Broadway by writing, directing and starring in a play.  He brings along his narcissistic and annoying daughter as his assistant.  She is a cliche: cynical and wise and saves the day with her social media savvy. He employs a narcissistic actor to co-star.  Oh, did I mention that narcissism is a recurring motif?  The all-purpose friend/manager/attorney/house manager is quite the multi-tasker.  Various couplings occur, or don't occur.  Eruptions of magic-realism do occur (note to director:  films by Latinos do not dishonor their heritage by not including such scenes).
Very entertaining on all levels. Stellar cast all in top form. Great script, funny quirky, imaginative, pacey. Wee worth seeing.

Really? A long drawn out, swearing homage to druggie Hollywood theater types who have failed in life? The main character tries suicide and finally succeeds. It's black and depressing but hardly a comedy. We can see washouts all around us.

Only 2 actors I know that can pull this off, one is Jack Nicholson and the other, Michael Keaton. This film makes full use of his unique acting style, a combination of suppressed aggression and hyper energetic qualities, always seemingly about to explode at any time, totally Oscar worthy. The camera and editing technique is amazing, almost the whole film seems to be in one continuous roving shot with just a single camera. If the story doesn't grab you, the images and acting certainly will.
Mind-blowing, from start to finish. Highly recommended.

This is the beginning of the Keaton Renaissance & there's a great chance he will be in high demand when he takes home that Best Actor Oscar he has all but won. Birdman is undeniably Alejandro González Iñárritu's largest project; a masterwork of size, scope and ambition. Its far-reaching impact on the world of cinema shall be felt for many years into the future, its commentary on the criticism and management of the showbiz world real and resonant.

So why does Birdman feel so god-damned overdone?

Former cinema superhero Riggan Thomson (Michael Keaton) is mounting an ambitious Broadway production that he hopes will breathe new life into his stagnant career. It's risky, but he hopes that his creative gamble will prove that he's a real artist and not just a washed-up movie star. As opening night approaches, a castmate is injured, forcing Riggan to hire an actor (Edward Norton) who is guaranteed to shake things up. Meanwhile, Riggan must deal with his girlfriend, daughter and ex-wife. Courtesy of Google

Every single scene in this film is full of bright lights, energetic performances; shouting, screaming, laughing, weeping, thrasing, sweeping. The melodrama is constant. The aggression is admirably palpable; though strangely not as consistent as one would desire. Birdman is, honestly, a bit of a mess. It's a redundant, self-indulgent, highly entertaining mess of a film. It's a film of pretentious standards; one that believes in merits, ideals and concepts that it views, at least from my examinations, as profound or unique. The concepts that it tackles are so overtly blatant that it's completely laughable. Iñárritu smashes the idea that corrupted, ungenuine film, stage and entertainment criticism is ruining the business right into our heads, and you can be sure that no audience member, whether they actually give a shit or pay attention to the metaphorical components behind the flashy exterior, will be able to gather a clear understanding of exactly what the director is trying to provoke. Hasn't the man ever heard of the word "subtlety"?

Perhaps he's saying that the only way to get through the thick skulls of casual cinema-goers and producers alike is to shout at them; to throttle them and throw them about; to scream right into their ears until they adhere and can fully comprehend what you're saying? Tell them in the loudest voice possible that they're spending money on bullshit franchises, sagas and action films whilst the "art", what should be earning recognition and money, is shunned and thrown into the dirt. But by doing this, everything within Birdman becomes so immensely literal; for something that appears to be trying to provoke higher thought or commentary, there really isn't any place higher to look for Iñárritu's thoughts on the showbiz world than the surface level of the film. That coupled with the fact that nothing that Iñárritu is saying is really that original or inventive makes Birdman into a thoroughly disengaging film on the level of metaphorical importance.

At this point, it sounds as if I'm completely shitting on the film. In all reality though, I really loved a majority of this picture. It's infuriatingly obvious in what it's trying to say, but that doesn't necessarily mean its message is unimportant. It's self-importance doesn't at all have me disregarding the technical weight of this oft-times astounding picture. The cinematography, provided by one of the greats of our generation, Emmanuel Lubezki (responsible for the cinematography for Gravity and The Tree of Life; two of the best looking films of the past decade), is fast-paced and always moving forward. As you've undoubtedly already heard, the film is made to look like it's shot in one take, and it is an amiable effort from all those involved to produce a film which looks as good as this does whilst also contending with the issue of not having time to recoup between smaller takes; every single individual take is long and arduous, and so even minor changes in terms of the lighting equipment and set design would've been irritating, time consuming and major in the scheme of things.

Lubezki's cinematography, working alongside the immensely compact set design which emphasizes the limited space provided within Broadway theatres, is intimate, even in the scenes of larger size, and is always frantic and moving. Whereas many directors vie for complete and utter control of their camera movements, Iñárritu and Lubezki allow the frame to roam, traversing high and low, capturing all the variables of the performances provided by the incredible actors and actresses on offer. There really isn't a film which I can actively compare to Birdman on a visceral level, and so despite any gripes that anyone may have with the film on a storytelling level, I find it hard to believe that anyone can fault the efforts of those involved in terms of cinematography, lighting, set design, etc.

Also deserving of universal acclaim is perhaps the greatest editing I've ever seen in a film, period. To match up the individual takes so goddamn perfectly deserves nothing but praise; Douglas Crise and Stephen Mirrione are geniuses. I can't even imagine how much tedious work it would have required to have it feel so seamless! And then we move into the performances; to describe the acting in this film, the vast majority of it feels alive. Invigorating, as fast as the speed of the camera, and full of personality; despite my numerous quibbles with the slapstick comedy and dull "raunchy" humour that the screenplay contains, those who deliver the lines are oft-times sensational. The lead, Michael Keaton, is nothing short of outstanding. Every single second that he was on screen, my heart was pumping and I felt rejuvenated. It wasn't on the same level as Benedict Cumberbatch in The Imitation Game or Bradley Cooper in American Sniper, but Keaton's immensely aggressive, assured performance is worthy of admiration all the same. The rest of the ensemble is either outstanding with their roles or greatly melodramatic (still entertaining at that, though). Edward Norton is fantastic, enacting the self-indulgence that his character displays perfectly, and provides what is undoubtedly the closest thing to a perfect performance from a supporting cast member all throughout. Zach Galifianakis is almost as incredible, his line delivery some of the fastest and most versatile on offer; his humour always hitting. Other performances, including those from Emma Stone and Naomi Watts in particular, feel far more artificial, and despite a quality monologue from the former around halfway through, don't contain as much lively energy as the others around them.

All that said, no matter how impressive the performances, they can't help but be pulled down into the unavoidable abyss that is Iñárritu's constant bombardment of melodrama. Whilst the numerous (by this, I mean a shit-tonne) hostile exchanges between characters are often engaging to begin with, their constant reintroduction and implementation feels immensely forced; not necessarily due to the work of the performers, but because of Iñárritu's relentless direction and need to make everything as flamboyant and huge as possible. There are only so many times where I can take a verbal sparring match seriously, before it becomes repetitive and redundant, as it does here. Still, there are times when it is entirely applaudable; the first few times Keaton's character Riggan loses his shit, whether it be towards himself or a fellow actor, it's hard not to sit up in your seat and watch with interest and intent.

Whether I sound like I'm contradicting myself when I say this or not, I don't care; I did enjoy Birdman. I enjoyed its technical achievements, the performances, the intensity and frenzied pace of the entire thing. It was a heap of fun! All the same, I can't help but feel like Iñárritu is being immensely self-indulgent all throughout; I can almost hear him screaming at the Academy to award him with as many top honours as possible. His desire to provoke something more, something we haven't seen, seems only detrimental to an otherwise fun and vibrant picture. How this can be seen as groundbreaking or one of the best of the year, I may never know. Films like Under the Skin, Whiplash and The Grand Budapest Hotel seem far more unique in their execution and ideas than Birdman, a film which thinks of itself as if it is the opus of cinematic expression in 2014. It's a great film all the same, whether or not you can move past the ego that is obviously at play all throughout.

Riggan Thomas is an actor famous for portraying a superhero (Birdman) on the big screen. He has decided to step away from it all and throw all his money in on produing, writing, directing and starring in a Broadway play. Here we see the trials and tribulations leading up to opening night. Riggan battles against the cast, his family, his agent, critics, but mostly his own ego which comes in the form of his former alter-ego.
Keaton is quite the perfect casting in the lead role, but he heads up a delightful stellar ensemble. The story has notes of Woody Allen in it, especially as it is ensconced in New York, but its wry snappy humour does help too.
The cinematography is quite something from Emmanuel Lubezki. Tracking shots flow out through walls, up and in through windows. The magical realism has some lovely subtle touches at the start, but in the last reel they do get a bit much. Brilliant editing though.
Tis a very wry look at acting. Cinema vs theatre. Art vs commerce etc. Sometimes things get a little too on the nose, but this is a fun time to be had. Edward Norton's performance is a riot.
Age old questions wrapped in shiny new packaging for young and old. Fabulous.

Beautifully shot and directed - it's almost presented as a complete one shoot movie, as we follow Riggan Thomson (Michael Keaton) around preparing for the opening night of a serious play on Broadway. He's haunted by his alter-ego and persona that made him famous  - 'Birdman', who appears to imbue him with tele-kenetic powers and the ability to fly - of course he is merely battling himself - but it makes for sublime cinema. We haven't seen Keaton substantially on screen for a long time, and he himself played Batman once-upon-a-time - so he inhabits his role perfectly, and is thoroughly enjoyable to watch. A last ditch casting also brings in Mike Shiner (Edward Norton), who throws yet more spanners into a few of the theatre previews, making every time the play is rehearsed or performed an entertaining experience. This is a film that builds and builds, and you will laugh with enjoyment with - it's rich in dialogue and the various spats between characters invest you in the success or failure of the opening night. Superb!
Inarritu slaps everybody in the American entertainment industry, including the critics, right in their sorry faces.

What is success? What is art? Does artistic integrity exist? Does it matter? What's the function of professional criticism? These are some of the questions, playfully and expertly explored in this satirical black comedy, and surely one of the most distinguished achievements of the year.

Where to start... Micheal Keaton and Edward Norton are fantastic, but the thing is that there so much good acting going on that one never stops enjoying this movie. Love the technical style of the filming, raw but necessary sometimes, it's just perfect. It's much more than a refined comedy, it will screw a bit with your head too.

After the critically lauded Boyhood (which I didn't like) I entered the critically lauded Birdman with some trepidation but within just a few minutes I felt that I was watching something genuinely special. We begin by following an out-of-the-limelight actor Riggan Thomson (Michael Keaton) who is attempting to put on a Broadway play after 20 years of being known as the star of a Hollywood superhero franchise called Birdman. After an accident knocks out his underperforming co-star, Keaton is recommended to use the actor Mike Shiner (Edward Norton) who joins the ensemble, yet comes into conflict with all involved especially Keaton himself. As Riggan prepares for the preview shows, he is also seen battling with his relationships including the ever-watchable Emma Stone playing the "hot mess" of a daughter and with Andrea Risenborough (seen in the sci-fi Oblivion) as Keaton's possibly pregnant girlfriend. The acting is top-notch throughout with brilliant group dynamics and a cast that also includes Naomi Watts as a frustrated actress and Amy Ryan as his ex-wife. 

Although Edward Norton will be rightly regarded as playing a great supporting performance the real surprise here is Zach Galifianakis as Keaton's producer trying to help his client hold it all together. Zach to me is a cinematic jinx for me, playing the same unlikeable idiot in each film but here I felt he was much more suited to the straight man role as the Producer trying to keep it all together emotionally and financially. Although flashes of his comedy were here, it was all part of the story and played with a much lighter touch. The film includes both laugh out loud moments and tenderly played family scenes as well as metaphorical scenes of the metaphysical - as Keaton is shown floating and using telekinesis - which are brilliantly used when he trashes his dressing room and fights his "alter ego". 

You could view the movie as a narrative on Hollywood versus Theatre - there's plenty of heavy handed moments involving critics as well as YouTube and social media commentary - or as a treatise on getting old and feeling relevant but it's the private moments and Keaton's subtle performance that stick with you most. One technical aspect of the film which never took me out of the movie (unlike Boyhood's unique conceit) was that the film 'appears' to be one shot. That's right, there are no obvious cuts at all in the film- digital trickery plus clever pans like Hitchcock's 'Rope' cover the breaks - but it works brilliantly as the camera floats around the actors, up the side of buildings and through windows whilst also using different devices to show the passing of time. 

An enigmatic ending open to interpretation is fitting for a film that balances both sides of someone's self-image and the audience can bring their own views on the story at its conclusion. With a unique style, a group of actors playing to their strengths, a well-played out narrative and an interesting score (by jazz drummer Antonio Sanchez) Birdman is a great achievement and one I recommend you checking out before a no-doubt successful night at the 2014 Oscars.

9/10 Midlands Movies Mike
Sheer visionary genius.  THE film of the year!!!

(80%)
Cinema and theatre combine in this oddball mash-up flight of fancy that results in something quite unlike anything else out there. It's also something that is really hard to know exactly what to make of it in just one viewing, but the fact is that I enjoyed it enough to happily sit through it again. In fact it may be brilliant and I simply haven't realised it. Only time will tell. But in the mean time this is a wonderfully assembled comic drama with brilliant one take direction that needs to be seen to be fully believed (even if you can spot the joins), the amount of work that must have gone into it is unimaginable. The writing, despite the story not being what one would call overly substantial, is razor sharp; and as everyone who's seen this already have thus far said, the acting throughout the entire cast is outstanding. This has its sights set on the jugular to many different aspects of the entertainment industry, from the differences of attitude in stage and screen; with critics getting a good roasting, which is both fun and brave. If you want something smart, unique, with solid lumps of pure gold quality added in every corner, then this is an enjoyable, very quirky must watch.
Amazing performances. Funny and quirky and very stylistically original.

A very chaotic piece of art house cinema, which in fact reflects the state of mind of its main character. Despite its rave reviews, I honestly find this film less enjoyable among all Inarritu's films that I have watched so far, and I like his style a lot - raw setting but utterly humanistic and sensible; multilayered storyline yet very relatable; and excellent treatment of characters, even the minor ones. This film still possesses almost all of those qualities, but the chaotic plot distracted me a little bit, especially given the continuous-shot style (which is actually trademark of the film's cinematographer - Mr. Lubezki), which followed the intention of Inarritu and built an emotional bridge between the protagonist and the audience of being restrained and claustrophobic,  but I did not enjoy that much (except for the final shot with the big blue eyes of Emma Stone scintillating under the sunlight, which is simply perfect shot!). Still, this film has absolutely excellent cast, which are all very very cinematically beautiful (even the male characters) and very very able in their roles. A strong film but major contender to the Oscar for Best Picture? I think not.

"Birdman (Or The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance)" is a simply excellent film. Why? There is a scene in "Birdman" where Riggan Thompson (played by Michael Keaton), who is trying to direct and star in his Broadway adaptation of the Raymond Carver play "What We Talk About When We Talk About Love", walks towards the front of the stage and talks about love, what it is to be loved, and how we all crave that. But is it love we crave? Or, as Sam (played by Emma Stone) puts it, is Riggan confusing love with admiration? These are some of the many wide-ranging questions that "Birdman" leaves you with as you leave the cinema and you thus don't really realise how good the cast, direction, dialogue and score are until you've given up on those questions, realising that they are just too difficult to answer.
The cast is simply stellar in "Birdman", brilliantly led by Michael Keaton in what Variety's Peter Debruge calls the "comeback of the century" and which I agree with him over. However, I'm not sure if Michael Keaton would accept this title, in a recent interview promoting the film he laughed at the concept, yet the comparisons between his career and that of Riggans are unavoidable, he also laughed when this was bought up too. But, to be fair, all I knew of Michael Keaton before I saw "Birdman" was that he had starred in the 1989 "Batman" film as well as in its 1992 sequel "Batman Returns".  His career hasn't been stellar and it's a surprise I even knew his name before I saw "Birdman" really... But his performance in this film deserves all the attention he gets and all the awards he is being nominated for. Riggan is a complex character and you are never quite sure about him, how he feeling and how he feels towards others, not only because of how Riggan changes as the film goes on but also because of how that reflects the ever-changing nature of the film, moving from one question or theme to the other without actually leaving it behind, instead leaving it in the back of your mind for you to think about later.
Again, as I said earlier, the rest of the cast is great too. Edward Norton is brilliant (playing the self-obsessed, ego-driven actor who feels more real on the stage than off it, Mike Shiner). But then Miles is so much more than that and again it's hard to put your finger on what or who he is and what he is looking for. Zach Galifanakis (playing Riggan's agent, Jake) who is trying to keep Riggan grounded, is also brilliant and then so is Emma Stone and Naomi Watts (although both seem to be in very familiar roles). I could go on listing actors and actresses but it would just be a paragraph of names. (Last one I promise but Amy Ryan also does well playing Riggan's ex-wife Slyvia.)
But each of these is alleviated, and should thanking him in any of their Oscars speeches, by the film's director, Alejandro González Iñárritu. Alejandro hasn't done many English-Language films before (except Babel in 2006 and 21 Grams in 2003), and considering that, it makes his direction in "Birdman" even more outstanding. Where he really excels is in how "Birdman" is seemingly filmed in one take. These really emphasise how good the acting is in this film, be it a monologue by Emma Stone as she rants at her dad, a take that involves Michael Keaton walking in just his underpants through Times Square, or a scene where Keaton and Edward Norton rehearse on stage. What makes these one takes even better is how the film is almost entirely set in St. James Theatre and you really get a feel for it as you glide around it in these one takes, feeling, seeing and hearing everything that is going on. It truly is an experience. I loved every moment of it and what this ultimately did for me was make me feel like I was part of the production, as if I was being given this behind the scenes look at what was going on. This thrill inspired me to get back into acting, something that I used to do a lot of. What happens with this you as the film goes on, you begin to realise that this is less of a trip to the cinema and more of a trip to the theatre. It's a good mix of both and I can't really imagine it being the same on DVD, although it never is. I will definitely be seeing it again.

Birdman's dialogue is great too and it matches the fast-paced score of "Birdman". Both are unique, with the dialogue being fast-paced, witty and blackly comic and the score being performed and composed entirely by the four-time Grammy winner and first-time film composer drummer Antonio Sanchez. Yeah. Drummer. The film's score is made up of two instruments, the drums and the cymbals. And it works perfectly! Its good not just because of how I haven't experienced something like this before, but also because it builds on that idea of you being a part of the production thanks to the one takes, but makes you feel as if that these drums are not just in your head and are there for benefit of the audience, but that they are in the actors heads. In testament to this, we occasionally see Sanchez' brother performing as we walk past be it in the theatre or in Times Square.

"Birdman" is a unique film. And that is where its brilliance lies. Just like how when you are in a production and the curtains come down on closing night you come to think that you really did not want that to end, and I had the same feeling when "Birdman" did. Its cast, score and direction are all what will be directly nominated come the Oscars, but there is no specific award for the questions "Birdman" made me think about, the way "Birdman" made me feel and the lessons "Birdman" taught me.

With an excellent cast giving it all, Alejandro G. Inarritu's finest directing job to date and a terrific score, Birdman is 2014's best comedy by far.

The Acting in this movie is just on a different level the most movies could hope to even be, i mean of the last 10 or so years i would probably put Birdman and Whiplash in the 10 for acting. Edward Norton is my stand out in Birdman hes amazing I forgot he had this in him it's been a while since fight club but he showed his true power in this movie. not that hes ever really done poorly but this was just something special.

The show biz satire and dissection of Hollywood, Broadway and fame in the film Birdman,  written, produced and directed by Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu, will either satisfy you or turn you completely off.  I have heard both from various people; I happen to belong to the former.  The film stars an extraordinary performance by Michael Keaton as the leading protagonist, Riggan Thomson, Edward Norton as Broadway actor, Mike Shiner, Zach Galifianakis as Riggan's lawyer and friend Jake, Naomi Watts as Lesley, Mike's girlfriend, Emma Stone, as Riggan's daughter, Sam, and Andrea Riseborough (Riggan's girlfriend Laura) and Amy Ryan (Sylvia, Riggan's ex-wife). The supporting cast, chosen well, only highlights Inarritu's script and directorial abilities.
The story deals with a Broadway adaptation of Raymond Carver's short story, "What We Talk About When We Talk About Love" written, directed and starring a faded Hollywood actor (Keaton) who was well-known for his superhero role as Birdman in an attempt to recapture some of his fame through this particular production. Is this reality imitating life? (Keaton played Batman twice in Tim Burton's versions of the same!)
The plot tells the story of Riggan (Keaton) who unfortunately is being besieged by the voice of Birdman, a character he became famous for, while he envisions himself performing some small acts of telekinesis and levitation.  He is hoping as I have already stated to reinvent his sagging career with the adaptation of Carver's short story in this Broadway play, being produced by Jake, and starring Riggan and his girlfriend Laura, plus Lesley, Mike's girlfriend.  Riggan's recovering drug addict daughter works as his assistant. Realizing that he needs a better actor in one of the supporting actor's parts, Riggan replaces him with method actor Mike.  During a preview, Riggan laments that he does not exist and shoots himself.  It is here that Riggan is advised by Mike to use a more realistic prop gun, and while reading the early reviews of the play, discovers that Mike has stolen the spotlight from him and that Mike is his daughter Sam's lover.  
Locking himself out of the theater, Riggan has to walk through Times Square in his underwear to get back inside.  Running into critic Tabitha Dickinson, who lets him know that she really does not care for Hollywood celebrities who she believes pretend to be actors and will give the play a negative review, in essence, killing its chance for success.  Using a real gun for the final scene on opening night, he shoots his nose off while he is on stage, receiving a standing ovation.  In the hospital, he learns that the critic gave the play a positive review.  Sam visits and then leaves and returns to his room only to find him gone and the window open.  Looking up, she smiles while looking out at the sky.  
The film has been nominated for seven Golden Globe Awards, including Best Motion Picture, Best Screenplay, Best Director, Best Score, Best Actor, Best Supporting Actor and Best Supporting Actress and SAG awards in the same categories as well.  The screenwriters, Nicolas Giacobone, Alexander Dinelaris Jr. And Armando Bo, along with Inarritu have written a marvelous script, and the cinematography by Emmanuel Lubezki (Oscar winner for Gravity) was filmed as if it was one continuous take going back and forth from reality to illusion with little or no break in the filming.  This is a very dark and twisted comedic film showing what someone's desperation can cause his behavior and actions to succeed in his chosen career that has hit the skids can do.  
The film, shot at the St. James Theater in New York City, begins with a quote from one of my favorite writers, Raymond Carver, whose short story the play being performed in the film is about and an excellent choice to explain what is happening in Riggan's life (and head).  I am not a big fan of voiceover and the film had more than enough scattered throughout the film, which to me was very annoying.  The use of drums also was used strongly and seemed to distract from the action on screen.  It is a well scripted and acted film. Plus makeup, costuming, dialog, acting, lots of close ups to show emotions...all done wonderfully!   If you haven't seen it, you should.  It is worth the price of a ticket, if nothing else then to see Michael Keaton (or his double) fly over the New York City skyline!  GRADE: 4 of 5 crowns
A existential film which balances on the line between the true modern struggles of a fading actor and the fictional fading of the same persons psyche

Michael Keaton delivers one of the most convincing performances I've ever seen, simply by completing the difficult trick of making us believe in him. His performance is so utterly believable that it throws the slightly odd 'birdman' episodes into juxtaposition. The cast all round were superb in carrying a film which could have easily come across as pretentious if not handled with such tongue-in-cheek aplomb. The ending however did feel slightly aloof, no matter what interpretation you take of it (no spoilers here!) but as a whole Birdman is a gripping, emotional film with some of the best camera work and music scoring I can recall. Fantastic.

Quite seriously, I would rather undergo a ROOT CANAL than sit through any part of this "movie" again.  From the "fingernails scraping a chalk board" percussion soundtrack to the "dialogue" consisting almost entirely of the "f" and "s" words (yawn) to the "full of itself" non-plot, it was torture.  Do yourself a favor and save the cash and 2 hrs of your life that you'll never get back.  85% of the audience liked this garbage????  This seriously makes me wonder whether these reviews are legit. I only gave it half a star b/c there is no way to rate it lower.

What can I say, what a fantastic film. From the gripping performance of Michael Keaton to the camera work that seems like one tracking shot. It is all fantastic, and is worth all of the hype. It has so much to say about film today, which had such a great impact on me. One of the best of the year, no question. What are you still doing here, go see it. RIGHT NOW.

There are some really cool technical aspects to this movie, but I found them to start to become distracting after a while.  It seems like most of this film is done in one take, which made me start thinking about where the film was really cut, and where the cameraman was in certain scenes.  I shouldn't be thinking those things in a film.  It is distracting.  It might have been a cool idea in a student film, but here it just feels like a gimmick.  In fact, just casting Michael Keaton in this film feels like a gimmick - he is playing an actor know for playing a super hero, leaving the franchise, who is trying to be taken seriously as an actor now.  Also, the ending is just such an "Independent movie" ending.  It just makes my eyes roll.  We've seen it before and it wasn't all that great the first time.

The performances were all good.  I thought Edward Norton was perfect.  I think this movie is good, but considering all of the award attention it is getting, I thought it would be better.  I expected more.

I had to give it 4 stars , its an actors perfection , and also a nice twist .
I love it .
Ha, the marketing for this is funny, trying to lure in all the superhero fans. Very clever!
Birdman demonstrates how sheer technical ambition, when driven by a rich narrative and brilliant performances, is capable of stretching relatively trite ideas to exhilarating new highs.
Birdman soars in its strong performances and its clever one-shot technique that is more than just a mere gimmick.

Fame

Inarritu has made an unquestionably original, technically brilliant and possibly great film about fame, self recognition and human frailty.

With the main narrative shot in a single (maybe not quite) take to add intensity to the surreal storyline, the film is gripping beyond any thriller I have seen in ages. And the sharp script, witty, profound and very funny, has such an unpredictable edge that except for one or two points, you really can't see it coming. And yet it all makes sense.

As for the acting, the entire cast is spectacular. Of course Keaton rises to the occasion, exceeding anything he has ever done on screen. But so has the marvellous Ed Norton, long a favourite of mine and Naomi Watts, the former King Kong screamer. 

This is easily the best film of 2014 that I have seen so far and one of the best in years. It is nothing if not challenging, yet should be a mainstream hit among adults.

The ending is my only slight concern, but who cares when the preceding 115 minutes flows by with such fluency and power.

The emperor has no clothes.  While Keaton's performance is certainly stellar, the film itself is pretentious twaddle.  It felt like nothing so much as a rather talented high school film student trying to demonstrate how profound and clever he can be.  ("Oh, I know, lets have the street drummer appear in the theater."  "Oooh, telekinesis!")  The only person I did not get really tired of seeing was Zach G.  I don't appreciate being lectured in the middle of a film as to how anti-intellectual I am if I dislike the film.  Add to that one of the most annoying "musical" soundtracks in cinema history, and it adds up to two hours I will never get back.

A lady texting on one side, a couple kissing on the other, but I inch ever closer to the edge of my seat as I watch a phenomenon mind-blowingly soar on to the screen... Birdman.
   Ten minutes in and the masters behind this wonder still had me believing it's all been shot in one take. The illusion holds up seamlessly by outstanding cinematography from Emmanuel Lubezki, exceptional performances from all actors who are no doubt perfectly driven by the man at the helm, Alejandro Gonz찼lez I챰찼rritu. 
   The writers of "Birdman" were certainly biting their nails as the story would have to be flawless... the illusion of one take has very little time for breaks. On the outside it would be easy to call this a simple tale of hardship, but told through the eyes of a washed up actor named Riggan (Michael Keaton), the writers have definitely created what could only be described as twisted perfection of story telling.
  This is certainly Keaton's finest performance. Playing a washed up actor who starred as a super hero once upon a time, now trying to hit it big again with one last show. I'm sure Keaton used notes from his own career to drive this character, nevertheless he played the part to an absolute tee. Emma Stone and Zach Galifianakis are exceptional in their roles, but the award for best supporting role, in my opinion, would have to go to Edward Norton. Whether it would be through an awkward, disturbing or heart felt moment, his relationship on screen with all his fellow performers was an absolute pleasure to watch. 
   This film is an inventive leap forward for film making, a joy to watch and one that shall not be forgotten any time soon. Birdman or The Unexpected Virtue Of Ignorance is a must watch for all movie goers.
Well-written, well-directed, and well-acted. Found it a little bit difficult to relate to, but still worth the watch.

The last movie I saw in 2014 and one of the best. Birdman is an extremely meta film about acting, movies, theatre, the current state of Hollywood, criticism and a Character study. As an electric drum line soars through a flawless set, an ambitious and complicated tale of a failed career is concocted in what feels like a single take. Birdman is honesty, it confronts the troubled mind of a human and lays it out to the viewers as complex and stressful, like life itself for the character depicted. The character, driven by a career best performance from Michael Keaton, fits the films tension and anger. The cast backing up Michael Keaton is varied yet perfect, each character proves their own importance, no character feels forced or useless. Past the obscurity of what Birdman offers, the visual effects are inventive and intriguing, the sound mixing is flawless, and what a feat this has been for Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu. Never have I seen such a complex, thought-provoking and busy script be executed oh so carefully and proud than Inarritu's newest film. The film is left seamless, with not a hole or dent in the detailed plot. The film is worthy of any award it receives, due to the attention the film gives to details. Most movies now a days are about the big picture, or the plot twist ending, but Birdman's strongest moments fall within the detailed conversations between the cast, and the way Inarritu makes us think with reoccurring themes. The film is open to interpretations, but neither Keaton or Inirratu ever lost the vision. The vision was to create a study of self respect, and the angry tendencies of the human mind, and a whole lot more was achieved in Birdman than that single vision.

A very weird and interesting film. I went into this knowing the buzz and came out both thrilled and puzzled. This is not a confusing film but you definitely have to use your brain to understand its many rich themes. The film feels like a theatre production due to its cinematography (seriously the DP of Gravity must of said "oh I had so many shots in my last movie, I really should do less"). It is seamless thanks to its editing and all comes together for a fantastic experience. Of course how could I forget the performances... they're amazing, just yeah. I could see this getting nominated for 3 out of the 4 acting categories (Oscars) and at least winning 1. This is a (dare I say it) masterpiece for the director. Even the soundtrack and writing, this movie is flawless, simply flawless. The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars is because I didn't feel fully resolved with all the characters and plot threads and the ambiguous ending doesn't help resolve characters either.

I am very sorry, I do not understand these "rave reviews", Birdman is not, on any level, a good film.  It is thoroughly uneventful, and without a substantial plot.  If I was going to be generous I would say mildly funny in places, but we are talking a couple of lines in an over-laboured movie, and by mildly I mean Chicken Korma.
I can understand how poncy film critics who never quite made it to the big screen themselves might praise it to look cultured, but for the average film buff, this is not going to score heavily and certainly will not be remembered,
Take my advice, do not waste your time with this movie.

Alejandro Inarritu was one film away from being typecast as the director of immensely moving films that spit you out with a soul-crushing sadness and a metaphorical sucker-punch to anyone who takes anything for granted. Birdman is both his 180, and proof that he can literally do anything he wants with a camera. Michael Keaton plays Riggen, a washed-up actor who's fifteen minutes of fame was years ago when he played the famed superhero Birdman. Dejected, drunk, depressed and estranged from his daughter, Riggen plans a comeback in the form of a broadway play he is directing, writing and starring in. Birdman is a smorgasbord of technical brilliance, as the script's diamond-cutting dialogue is hilarious once, dramatic then, and is merely a catalyst to move the narrative forward. Truth is, the Birdman is so deeply metaphorical, it's impossible to keep up with its trajectories. And the directing is one for the books, as Inarritu painstaking direction gives us the impression Birdman was filmed in one long continuous take, while the cinematography burns itself into your retinas. Incredible. One of the most captivating aspects of cinema is it's almost limitless capacity for creativity, but it's difficult to conceive of a film that can up the game further than this.
What we talk about when we talk about Birdman: the ending. (You'll believe a man can/'t fly.)
