I fell asleep but it was so good..

For every person out there, there is a time when, no matter who you are, will ask yourself that one big question "Am I still relevant?", this is no truer for artists themselves, musicians who continually have to shake their style up to sell records, Actors who have to take on a drastically different role from their previous outings, directors who have been out of the limelight for too long, or even an author putting pen to paper after writers block. Birdman addresses this question in the most hypnotic and emotional manner, not only producing one of the best ensemble performances I have ever seen period, but is so in a fresh and exciting way. Riggin is an aged actor, once famed with movie star dome in his box office smash Birdman, he has now plunged everything he has into a theater show on broadway in a last ditch attempt to ignite his flame. The previews are going less than to plan however and soon Riggin's mental state of mind is pushed so beyond the limit, himself and his team are forced to do dramatic things, in order to keep the show alive. As mentioned earlier this is not only wonderfully acted but perfectly cast, the casting agent in this film deserves an award, really. Michael Keaton as a washed up actor trying to stay relevant is not only powerful but true. Name the last time Michael was even at his peak, never mind big news, if this film does not ignite his career, nothing will. He plays Riggin, wonderfully, constantly arguing with his inner turmoil and cast, in order to make sure his dying effort is not in vein. Emma Stone plays his daughter, a stage hand, who is not long out of rehabilitation, she is a constant reminder to Riggin that his parenting skills have a lot to be desired for, the emotion in her eyes alone, tears your heart strings tenfold. Zack Galafanikis, who I dislike at the best of times, rattles forth a performance as a producer that gives Keaton a run for his money, although not always present he provides a sense of urgency the piece needs in order to feel the weight on Riggin's shoulders. Niaomi Watts as a wannabe big time star is a straight up winner, she has no reason to prove her talent at all, but this performance is another powerhouse, with some spot on comic timing. Edward Norton, christ, Ed knocks his role as a pretencious actor, who needs everything to be real on stage in order for him to get it right, is just a joy to watch. Even his sub story where he describes why he acts because anything off the stage doesnt make him feel alive. Its brutal and hilarious stuff all the way through. The look of the film is jaw dropping, give an award to not only the DP but the Steadi-Cam operator, who pretty much does 96% of the entire film. continually moving the camera to the exact point of focus we need. The film also runs on a never cutting away schedule, meaning it gives the illusion of it being continual, which not only helps the pacing of the film dramatically, but it weaves the story so magically together, I have never seen it does so professional before in my life and christ Hitchcock tried it. The writing is flawless, the soundtrack, the constant drumming, the background noise, makes the entire thing feel real, you feel there, not sitting in a cinema or a couch, you feel like your in the film. Finally direction, out of all Innaritu's films I have seen, this is by far the most superior. Everything slots into place, no stone is left untouched. Do I have any problems with the film? Yeah, some CGI moments cheapen a couple of moments slightly, but their inclusion is looked upon as not of this world anyway so it doesnt stick out like a sore thumb. Also the film ends about 8 minutes after it should. It's almost as if someone was afraid to go the whole hog, however the ending were left with feels magical, so yet again, nothing really wrong there. This film is easily one of the best films of 2014, yeah we've had some big titles, equally as stunning in different ways, but this, for what it is, and for how it makes you feel, it will be a long time until we are given something quite so wonderful again.
Well acted but boring
I knew I was in for a good time but wasn't expecting something as deep as this!! Also, it's the best Spider-Man has been since Sam Raimi's Spider-Man 2 (you'll understand when you see the film)
The acting and direction are stellar as is the approach to having a scene last up to ten minutes instead of cutting away every two seconds.
Easily one of the best of the year.
Great film - fab performances from all including norton. Keaton gotta win some for this !
I walked out apologizing to my friend for suggesting it. I give it four yawns....
good film, different well acted but a bit schizophrenic regarding the cinematography.

I have to say that I was thoroughly impressed with 'Birdman' which had received rave reviews and a much celebrated single take which was quite incredible to watch and trying to work out where the joins were and the acting which was led by a trio of actors who had past pedigree in the superhero genre most notably Michael Keaton who has never been better and a special mention to the bloke out of the Hanover who too has never been better and Emma Stone who more than holds her own.

A very interesting insight into the world that is apparent behind the scenes in theatre and film. The movie portrayed the ups and downs of success. I loved every second of Birdman and thought that the secret link to Michael Keaton and 'Batman' was very clever. Can't fault this film in any way!

Technically superb with the single take illusion working very well and exemplary performances all round but not the touted masterpiece. Pictures based in the film industry have never sat well with me and this is no exception. The biggest issue is the ending though, a definite misstep there when a finer climax was certainly present.

A true original, Birdman is technically masterful, moving, thrilling filmaking, with the whole story telling a washed up ex- superhero actor trying to put together a play done in seemingly one giant continuous take (it's actually more like 10 minute takes that are near seamlessly edited together. It's full of really incredible performances too, in fact it's an outright acting showcase, with Michael Keaton stunning in the best role of his very varied career, this is a major comeback for the man who was once Beetlejuice. Edward Norton too reminds us why he was once touted as the Deniro of his generation, where the fuck has this dude been? and Emma Stone is just extraordinary. Everyone should win awards and so should this film, it becomes a little unfocused here and there, but is a wonderful and truly unusual film.
Omg, will have to watch again.  Gags by the dozen.  An interesting take on the theatre world
A funny yet dark film. Interesting direction and performance from Michael Keaton. Not worthy of the accolades IMO however.

Two things stand out during this film, 1) was Keaton ever this good at acting in his previous films? 2) the use of sound in this film is outstanding (jazz, the silence, drummer) Overall this film has splatterings of comedy and passion but I felt they just drew the ending out a little longer than required. This film is not quite the must own of 2015 but still a must see!
Great movie, but not an Oscar winner!

Brilliant performances from Ed Norton and Michael keaton, and Naomi Watts is outstandingly good. However, Birdman has several natural endings occur during the last half hour, none of which end the film. It drags through a technically wonderful but plot obscuring sequence , on through more "Please just make it end now" moments to a conclusion that defies the dream logic of the film. Great acting and directing, brilliant camerawork but why go with this turkey of a script?
A near perfect film experiment that is equal parts engrossing drama and raucous meta-humor.
This was a different and interesting movie. A little violent and disturbing at parts tho

I feel completely blown away! This movie is unlike anything I've seen. 95% of the film is presented with the illusion of being one single continuous shot and it flows at a brisk immersive pace. The behind the scene New York Broadway setting is very cool. Every performance from every actor is top tier. This also might be the best movie about show business that I've seen. The pop culture/entertainment industry satire is very well done and made very relevant by today's comic book blockbuster craze. It is also an emotional roller-coaster; sorrow, anger, optimism, joy, amusement, fear; it's all here and the fact that it's Michael Keaton makes the entire story endearing and very meta. This and X-Men are the two best movies I've seen this year.
This movie sucked a bag of dicks. Quite possibly the worst movie I've seen, I want to punch everyone involved in the face for thinking this pretentious sack of shit was worth releasing.
Strange, quirky and funny... but it's so unique I'd hesitate to recommend it

This was good. Really good. 
Loved the vibe, the drums. 
Edward Norton always a favourite but Michael Keaton was fantastic.

Outstanding movie. An actors movie! Brilliant writing, great camera work....on and on....

Mr. Keaton was phenomenal! As were ALL of the other actors!
I slept in the middle of this movie. It is not a comedy flim at all.  Don't waste your time.
Birdman is smart, funny and a unique filmmaking. The performances delivered by the actors were all Oscar worthy especially Michael Keaton. And the drum score was brilliant.
Michael Keaton at his best.
Birdman is original, incredibly funny and with great performances from all involved.  Michael Keaton is the standout & is an absolute joy. I cannot wait to see it again.

Imagine sitting there and having everything you thought you knew about cinema and film ripped up in front of you and shit on. Everything you thought you loved and hated. Now imagine it being built up again and presented to you by a mildly irritated but smiling, your new ideology of film is dirty and wrecked but he did his best to put it back to together.
This is Birdman, it would be so easy to label it and say it was like this or it was like the other but simply put it just is.
It's not a film, it's art. It sits there looking down at you condescendingly laughing at everything you are, and you're far to weak and feeble to disagree so you sit there laughing with it.
Birdman isn't there to be liked or appreciated, it's a painting being hung on the wall for you to gawk at and appreciate with your open mouth as you shovel in popcorn bit by bit.
Enjoy it (or don't)

From the start with the depiction of Michael Keaton meditating off of the ground to the end of the film (no spoiler here) it's clear that the film has thrown  metaphors into a world of nostalgia. Its a comedy at Its heart but its more than that.  A story that juxstopes the character of Michael Keaton with the story that he writes. 
Fantastic performances from all the cast make this a must see film more than worthy of it's 7 golden globe nominations. 
If I was to describe it in 1 word it would be intriguing.
Well that was weird... superb performances, interesting cinematography, but weird...

Emperors new clothes !!!!!!!!
Terrible movie sustained by total hype.
Give it a miss.
Amazing camera work. The storyline is extremely intriguing. The acting is first-class.
Don't bother wasting your time.
I feel like a changed man after seeing it.

A tricky movie to review.  This clever, hugely pretentious movie about acting and identity features a career turn from the long forgotten Michael Keaton playing a pastiche of himself.  Norton, Riseborough and Stone are very good in supporting roles and I predict oscar noms for as many as 3 of the cast.  Galifankis is outstanding in a rare dramatic turn

On the other hand I just didn't enjoy this movie at all and was glad when it ended.  The jazzy, offbeat soundtrack made my head hurt and the plot was strangely predictable.  Movies about plays tend to be very pretentious and this was no exception.  I'm sure the hipsters will LOVE this movie

In every way possible, Birdman is a modern masterpiece from start to finish. Even more than the impressive cinematography, perfected performances and excellent score, the self reflective nature of Birdman is truly its defining feature. The film is a chilling and darkly humorous critique and exploration of the struggles faced by the modern actor, director and critic as well as the poor material that assails the modern Hollywood. Birdman is strikingly original as well, challenging stereotypes and willingly turning the finger back towards Keaton, who bares much of his real life story for critique. Stone, Norton, Watts and  Galifianakis deliver completely as a supporting cast and Inarritu hits it out of the park with the runaway choice for best movie of the year.

Absolutely Incredible Filmmaking & Acting. A truly Mind Blowing Experience. I have seen this twice & have yet to find anything not to like about this film. A Magnificent Masterpiece that Elevates the Art of Film. It combines surreal storytelling with pop culture cynicism to create this atmosphere of consistent humorous wonder & philosophical grandeur. In short....just, WOW!

A decidedly quirky film that at times, felt more like watching a live play than it did a film. Refreshing to see a film work based on strong performances rather than gratuitous CGI etc. Ironically the film makes the comparison throughout. Sterling performances from a strong cast and possibly an Oscar nomination for Michael Keaton. An multi layered, intelligent film that kept me engaged from start to finish.
The whole film feels like one breath. Stunning.
Very weird... Actors are crazy!!

In my opinion it is very much an 'emperor's new clothes' film for the critics and 'seasoned' film buffs only. No doubt an Oscar or two will be awarded but lesser mortals may find it painful to watch ! Those who enjoy being entertained by a cinema trip may be better off at Annie. It's certainly not a first date film .....
This has got to be one of the WORST most PRETENTIOUS films I have ever had the misfortune to sit through. Absolutely awful. The half a star is for Michael Keaton. Terrible
Good but strange movie starring Michael Keaton.

First film I watched in 2015 is an absolute masterpiece! 5 star indeed! I love pretty much everything about this film---the phase, the rhythm, the fantastic casting crew and each individual plays the right part, even the constant humming drum in the background, actually in particularly those drumming sound in the background. The way the camera plays the lights... It's like a beautifully choreographed modern dance performance of an old tale but rather playing the cheap cassette tape for the music they hired a symphonic. The best feeling is afterward your feel every piece of nerve and all the senses are being pampered, moved, touched.
This movie is nuts!!! Its a must see.....again and again!!

Honestly one of the best shot films I've ever seen. Although the ending kind of annoyed me because it wasn't concrete but still great acting, great plot and really great character study. One of the favorite of the year. Favorite quote, "You're not an actor, you're a celebrity" kind of sums up this generation of famous people who are know for not having talent and how some people try to prove themselves with their talent but will never be as famous as the people without talent. It's a weird world.

Pretty Amazing Execution.  Great Story.

Its 5 stars, but I was happy to see it end... ;-/

Birdman is quite possible the strangest film I have ever seen.  I went into only seeing the trailer and nothing more and if you think you're going to see a superhero movie you're going to both confused and disapointed.  What we do get is a a very clever, witty and intelligent satire on social media and celebrity.

This has touches of life immitating art as ironically Michael Keaton is playing an actor who was once famous for playing a superhero mirroring his own portrayal of Batman which has since been rebooted not once but twice.  Here we have Keaton wrestling with his past and yearning to be recognised as a serious actor on broadway.  Ed Norton, Emma Stone and all the supporting cast shine in their roles and I have no doubt that it will feature come award season.

The only problem I had whilst watching it was deciding whether I liked the film or not.  It is both abstract, ambiguous and adventuous but the head scatching factor that some of the visuals bring did put me off slightly.
Epic. Mental. Baffling. Captivating. Intense. Sexual.
Birdman was damn near perfect. The story was fully engaging, great character development, brilliant cinematography, just all around amazing.
Amazing film. So cleverly done, absolutely masterful. Spot on performances too, I reckon Edward Norton stole it rather than Keaton though. Would happily watch this again.
A must see. Truly captivating.

My synopsis: Demented, often funny, a little bit sad look at aging, ego, and how it feels to feel irrelevant. Michael Keaton is phenomenal as a mad movie star. Only criticism is that it felt a little bit too long.....specially the birdman bits.

Visually speaking, Birdman is fascinating to watch.  Keaton's performance is riveting and spot-on, as an aging actor attempting to mount a comeback by producing/directing a Broadway play.  Haunted by his alter-ego "Birdman", he struggles with personal and mental issues all-the-while attempting to reign in his star actor (Edward Norton).

Is this metatheatre or is it film? 
Mad brilliance.

Birdman succeeds on every level!  Wonderful acting by the entire ensemble.  The camera work will have you wondering how, what appears to be one two-hour take, is pulled off.  Terrific soundtrack.  And, the story will have you wondering long after the movie is over.

Michael Keaton is amazing.  The supporting actors only enhance the performance for a movie that never stops...  The appearance of 'one long take' is clever and keeps the viewer glued to the screen.  By far one of the best movies of 2014.

Hace poco vi a varias personas comentar cual era la primer película que habían visto en el 2015, y la mía es Birdman. Y lamentablemente le tengo que poner cinco estrellas porque no hay diez. La película es una joya, hace mucho no salía así del cine, todo es perfecto pero Lubezki e Iñarritu son magníficos y hacen magia dentro y fuera de Birdman. Las actuaciones están bien Keaton siendo el mejor del reparto pero no es roba escenas. El guión es fabuloso, inteligente e ingenioso con grandes líneas. Regresar de NY y ver Broadway y Times Square en pantalla hace que todo se te mueva por dentro. Ganará oscars, y bastantes. Joya.
Undoubtedly weird, undeniably brilliant. Birdman is an eccentric picture of struggles we all have, and Keaton, Inarritu and company deliver.

Wow! One of the most visually engaging and original films I've seen in ages, this story of slightly washed up 90s action star Michael Keaton (playing up to his Batman past) putting on a Broadway play is quite hard to categorise. Is Keaton going nuts? Does he really have superpowers like his Birdman character? Are super serious celebrated actors Edward Norton, Naomi Watts and Andrea Riseborough taking the piss put of themselves and method acting? 

There are so many factors that make this film so good. I LOVED the camera that follows the characters around, making the film seem like one long uninterrupted take. You really feel like you are there in the theatre with the actors, walking into dressing rooms and along the streets. Forget 3D, this is one of the most immersive films I've seen, taking you right into the scenes. Which makes the flights of fancy near the end when Birdman seems like he is turning New York into an action movie set, all the more dazzling. I guess director Alejandro Inarritu took note of fellow Mexican Alfonso Cuaron's Gravity, which similarly redefined immersive camera work.

Then there are the performances, led by Michael Keaton's manic lead Riggan, but ably supported by a never funnier Ed Norton, Emma Stone showing why she's one of the best young actors around. Naomi Watts, Andrea Riseborough and Amy Ryan play smallish, less showy roles but are still very good too. Comedian Zach Galifianakis plays it pretty straight while Lindsay Duncan is one of the most vicious critics we've ever seen on screen, dismissing Oscars as 'prizes for comics and porn' and totally unimpressed with Riggan's lack of theatre credentials. Everyone is excellent as they drift in and out of frame, to the centre then the periphery of the action. Michael Keaton has received a lot of praise and he carries the film well, although he isn't exactly a likeable, sympathetic or warm central character.

The script and story is another great thing about this film. I had no idea what was going to happen, what was reality, what was Riggan's hallucinations. There are some funny comments about the preponderance of superhero movies and social media these days. The Birdman alter ego appears onscreen, hissing vindictive bile in Riggan's ear like an anti-Jiminy Cricket. We get 5 minutes of an Avengers-like alien attack on Broadway as Riggan's Birdman character seems to take control. Then there is that ending. Huh??! What was real?

This isn't an easy film to categorise. It's not quite a comedy, but has a lot of black humour for a drama. However, Inarritu's previous films 21 Grams and Babel were so grim, this is positively laugh out loud funny by comparison I guess! The characters aren't lovable or even particularly likeable, but this is definitely one of the best films I've seen in a long time and I'm keen to see it again to see if it holds up. Oscar nominations are surely on the cards!

It's a bit hard to explain my feelings for this film. There was certainly a lot to like about it. I even enjoyed watching it most of the time. And then there were the art-school touches that kinda made me throw up my hands. The movie starts off very slow. I suppose it was important to give one brief moment of calm before the chaos started but the film takes about twenty minutes before you're really given an idea where it's going. Once it begins it's basically a long slippery slope as things slide completely out of control. Some of the best scenes come from that chaos, including Edward Norton as a ridiculously method actor, a scene where Michael Keaton gets locked out of the theater in the middle of his own performance and has to walk around the building to the lobby in his undies, and another where the laws of reality seem to completely vanish amid flying and explosions. Keaton's great in here by the way. The entire film is made in one take, or at least the illusion of one take, and this adds an immediacy and sense of liveliness to the film. It's a big part of what makes the film unique. 

It's very apparent that I saw the film differently from the creators. From the way they speak of it they view a superhero actor trying to redeem himself by doing serious art an inherently noble pursuit. I saw it as just another desperate attempt for him to receive the adulation he so craves, only this time with a new audience. So to me, there was nothing inherently wrong with his starring as a superhero. He doesn't need redemption so much as crave celebrity. It seemed more like a defence of such roles since he is constantly being belittled by others for not having the credentials needed to star on broadway. I saw his opponents as incredibly snobbish and elitist and didn't realize that, while they are supposed to be snobbish to an extent, I was supposed to listen to them and realize they were also partly right. Whoops. I'm glad I didn't know that going in. It would have annoyed me for the whole film. Maybe that's the mark of a good film: that it can be interpreted in multiple ways. But there's another part of me that feels that there was a whole level of subtext I was just blissfully ignorant of. I'd never heard of the short story they were adapting so I never realized they were poking fun at his crassness and intellectual pretensions by having him put on an unfilmable play. In this case I think ignorance is bliss.
It's not profound in any sort of narrative sense, but it's got a fun Allen-esque verve that compliments the very omnipresent (and at times borderline overwhelming) technical wizardry.
"weird, but cool."  I enjoyed the camera work and the acting, but the story drags a bit.

Cinematically, 'Birdman' is amazing. It's the perfect comeback role both for Michael Keaton and the character he portrays. It's weird and at times downright crude, but in a year of blockbuster duds this epic stands tall.

"I am going to destroy your play".

I never realised how much camera technique can mean to a film. Naturally the more 'out there' or different the more noticeable it is. And with that in mind 'Birdman' (As I will be shortening it to) and it's camera work are inseparable. Obviously if the rest of the film is terrible then the camera may as well be used by a 2 year old. No such issues here as the rest of it is pretty damn good.

Bringing in the new year in a fantastic manner 'Birdman' is a slightly quirky, hilarious and dark film about a man's troubles to taken seriously. It's set leading up to opening day of Riggan's (Michael Keaton) play. He struggles with his own psyche, his former roll as 'Birdman' a super-hero follows him around - telling him the hard truths he doesn't really want to hear. The story spans no longer than a handful of days and with the rolling cameras really feels like one take. Occasionally it switches to others in his life - daughter 'Sam' (Stone) and other cast members 'Mike' (Norton), 'Lesley' (Watts), 'Laura' (Riseborough) and solicitor 'Jake' (Galifianakis). It's all backed up by a fantastically frantic soundtrack of drums and symbols. Close ups when in deep conversation and following behind in the tight corridors of back stage.

it's really a non-stop ride that is full of the things that go wrong with Riggan's play - and the bits that go right. Some of it isn't real some of it is in his head, which makes you wonder how much of it is actually 'real'. It's deeply funny with ridiculous lines like: "yeah, she does look like she's licked a homeless guys ass". At times it may be dark (mostly) towards the end as he starts to unravel (and the ending itself depending on your view) - but I always had a great time watching it. I don't know whether it was the camera, the hilarious delivery of lines or just the outstanding performances all round. But it was just a joy to watch. the side characters may appear somewhat shallow at times as it has a fair few side story threads going on but the interactions are always interesting.

Many have described this as Keaton's best ever performance and it's easy to see why - he's magnetic and slowly unravelling as 'Riggan'. Has the type of humour I believe is severely missed in comedies now and that wonderful camera work - and yes I'll keep taking about it. I saw this on Jan first and I can't think of a better way to kick of the new year than with 'Birdman'. Crafted with expertise, I get the feeling that everything just fell into place with 'Birdman'. I may have some very minor issues but I had such a good time they're obsolete. Funny, dark and flowing.
4/5 best film ot the year so far ...

Who doesn't want to change the world, have an impact, do something serious, be somebody, rise above the trivial lives we all live? Despite the yearning, few actually do any of these things in any kind of a remarkable way. So does that give us the license to use the F-word in every sentence, practice it with anyone anytime the opportunity presents itself, destroy property, punch people who are just like you but remind you of your own narcissism? Please - does it take two hours of grimy back stage scenes to illustrate this dead end?  The one redeeming scene in the film is when Emma Stone lets us know that all arrogant human striving is just one sheet of toilet paper on a large roll. "Profound" as critics claim or sophomoric despite the acting? Sophomoric!

Birdman is a surreal piece of cinema with dark humour that we leave you scratching your head at the end. Keaton is a movie actor Riggan Thomson embarking on staging a play on broadway. Dealing with other actors egos as well has his own. As the play comes closer to opening his seems to be coming closer to losing his sanity to his Birdman alt-ego. This is a film you'll either enjoy or a leave you cold.
Dreadful - self indulgent & boring. This is one of the worst films I've seen in ages, feel robbed of the two and a bit hours of my life I invested watching it.
quite possibly killed two birds with one stone (pun intended), one of the worst films of 2015 already. And completely lost my interest in 5 minutes so much so. I'd like to fly out the window!!

A zany satire of Hollywood, theatre and the cult of celebrity. An intelligent film, that has something to say about the price of fame, whilst being artistically brave in its own right and most importantly laugh out loud funny in many places. Keaton's performance as the loser Riggan, the former Birdman star, is subtler and warmer than I was expecting. Whilst Norton is hilarious as the pretentious diva and Stone finally gets the chance to prove her acting mettle. It's bonkers, but an engrossing and entertaining bonkers nonetheless.

I enjoyed this but it's definitely for the theater/Broadway people of the world, and I'm not so much into theater.  I did really enjoy the near-constant drum track playing through backstage moments and scenes out on the street, which occasionally included a guy playing drums right there in the room.  I loved the illusion that the entire movie was filmed in one take -- it definitely wasn't but it's as if the camera is a set of eyes that never blink.  And a bunch of great performances -- please let Emma Stone get some wins for this one!
Can't wait for Birdman: Origins

A terrific black comedy from acclaimed director Alejandro González Iñárritu based on Raymond Carver's short story What We Talk About When We Talk About Love.

This big screen adaptation stars Michael Keaton playing a washed up actor, once famous for playing a superhero, looking to revive his career with a Broadway comeback.

It's an utterly brilliant performance from Keaton, a career best, which could see him nominated for an Oscar and Academy recognition.

Alongside Keaton there is star studded supporting cast including Edward Norton, Zach Galifianakis, Emma Stone, Naomi Watts, Andrea Riseborough and Amy Ryan. Although uniformly good, Norton puts in an award caliber performance as a volatile actor with an ego as big as his talent and a never better Stone shines as an embittered daughter fresh out of rehab.

A very off the wall black comedy full of all the drama from behind the stage at a Broadway theatre, where the egos are large and everyone wants it to really mean something.  The film is entertaining, stylish and bizarre with great acting, but doesn't know when to stop and doesn't seem to have a point, although I guess that is the point.
Worth the price of admission for Keaton's performance alone... and that's probably about it for me.

Technically impressive and filled with top-notch performances, this film nevertheless isn't what you'd call enjoyable.  It plays like an agitated jazz musician, and like that genre, suffers from lack of a melody.
Rather self-indulgent, pretentious... Appealing perhaps only to those who have worked in film or theatre.  Very disappointing.
Great filming, it looked like the first 20 minutes was one take. Lots of action, intense great dialogue, great acting.A bit depressing and sad, but real and definitely worth seeing.
First film of 2015 and it was brilliant!  Weird and wonderful take on celebrity v actor, film v theatre with amazing performances - would have given it 5stars but wasn't keen on the ending ;-0

Even though there was a clear ending point for this film that the director ignored, choosing instead to go on for another, in my opinion, needless ten minutes - I didn't want this to end.  I seriously could have watched this for another 3 hours or so, it's just so good.  
Firstly, I love movies that are about Hollywood and the entertainment industry.  I love that cynical self-examining tone, and this nails it.  Michael Keaton plays a somewhat washed up actor who never quite topped the success he had playing "Birdman" in a series of superhero films.  Now he's trying to earn respect from his peers by adapting a book into a Broadway play to show that he isn't just some one dimensional blockbuster-type, he's an artist too!  Michael Keaton plays it brilliantly because, of course, his career sort of emulates that of his character - he played Batman, and since then he's kind of faded into the background.  
All the performances are great, from Keaton, to Emma Stone and Edward Norton - Norton especially, he's hilarious.  
There's plenty of jibes at mainstream Hollywood, specifically at the comic book genre, and they lead to really funny exchanges between characters.  I don't know if it was an intentional thing to cast actors who had dabbled in superhero movies in real life, I mean, we know Keaton is an obvious one, but Edward Norton played the Hulk, and Emma Stone is in the new Spider-Man films too.  Either way, the actors knock it out the park. 
It's really funny, original and at times, totally mad, but overall it's one of the best films I've seen for a long while.  It's just a shame it didn't end at that perfect spot.

Although I recognize and can appreciate that it IS in fact a great movie, I can't honestly say that i enjoyed it as much as most did. The story can be jarring and the shift in tone was unpredictable. It lost my attention a couple of times..however, the performance by the casts drew me back in. The technical aspect of the film, is its greatest achievement.
Smart, brilliantly performed fantasia with feathers on. Keaton and Norton's stiffy steal the show.

Filled with some great imagery, camerawork, and performances, this ambitious Oscar contender is also more than a bit pretentious. Challenging and surreal, but also predictable and familiar. Funnily self-reflexive.

Birdman is a disappointing and frankly messy film. The cinematography is nice, but serves no purpose. That main plot is good, but predictable, with an ending that goes against the message it was trying to bring across throughout the rest of the film, other subplots are started and forgotten about and the acting really isn't anything spectacular.
Birdman never wowed me, and most of the good bits are not only in the trailer, but are at the end of the film, leaving it to drag on and on and on.

A fantastic cinema experience in which the lines between reality and fantasy and between madness and sanity are blurred. The backstage corridors of the theatre seem to be a picture of the complex labyrinths of the main character's mind.

Brilliant, well crafter satirical comedy/drama that is deliriously enjoyable on many levels.   There are some excellent performances on display from the cast assembled, the cinematography and sound are breath-taking (lots of very long takes throughout the film), the script is as razor sharp as you want a film like this to be.   Highly recommended!
A bit strange and psychological. This film seems more niche than I expected for such a highly acclaimed film but still enjoyable.

Bewildering, and I'm sure there's some deeper message and / or metaphor I'm not getting ... but I must say, the artistic direction here is simply incredible. Those tracking shots, that cinematography, hell, even the edits ... hnnng. So. Smooth.

In what is perhaps one of the most metaphorically mind-consuming and cinematically astounding films of 2014, Birdman excels in its unique storytelling and symbolic undertones on the current state of humanity and entertainment.

Michael Keaton's talent and wit are unmatched as Riggan Thompson, a man struggling with his inner demons as he attempts to make his comeback in a Broadway production. However, it seems Riggan will always live in his own shadow for having played the infamous role of "Birdman," a blockbuster comic book adaptation he starred in twenty years prior to this.

The film is presented in one long, continuous shot, giving it a dizzying, maze-like effect akin to Keaton's state of mind as he constantly doubts himself and his mental stability. Every scene in the film is filled with thematic meaning, from its surreal imagery to its unnerving score. The film is also a fascinating character study on vanity, self-doubt, and fame, along with numerous other thoughts that buzz through Riggan's head-portrayed with comical perfection in voiceover form.

Ultimately, Birdman is a gorgeously stylistic and dense piece of cinema that demands to be analyzed and interpreted upon viewing.

Birdman is an incredibly impressive piece of work that has some of the best directing and cinematography I've seen all year; how the director managed to pull off this film so effectively is beyond me. My praise doesn't stop here however, the film has a terrifically sharp script that gives every character a moment in the spotlight and inherently gives every actor a moment to shine, and they really do shine. I really liked how the movie manages to be so thematically rich but also be incredibly thrilling and entertaining. I enjoyed Birdman a lot and I could easily recommend it too anyone.

Loved it. All the actors in it were amazing, the story was unique, and the way it was filmed was excellent. Added bonus: my mom is an extra in the audience in one of the scenes. She's a blur in the front row of the theater but I could tell it was her by her expressive hands.

Birdman is an instant classic. Drawing on Hitchcocks brilliant film technique of Rope, the film is near seamless in its transitions and movements. But beyond the wonderful direction, its the actors and the dialogue that are the real stars. There is not a bad performance in the bunch. Keaton is fantastic even in his more reserved scenes, Edward Norton has never been better, Emma Stone shows real range,(especially in every moment of non-dialogue), Naomi Watts is wonderful, Zach Galifianakis is great, and Amy Ryan is also superb. The film is like going to see a Broadway play with the best in the business and never loses your interest for a second. This brings the cinema to life and will be remembered for years to come as one of the best.

Birdman is an unusually fulfilling black comedy with superb writing and excellent direction. The story was realistic and intriguing putting a washed-up superhero actor into the shoes of a washed-up superhero actor. Keaton's portrayal of Kiggan is brilliant, giving an Oscar-worthy performance that raises the question of how much of it was really acting? (92%)

Some of my same comments on "The Imitation Game" (2014) can apply to this movie, as well. While Michael Keaton and Emma Stone are excellent in their roles, the rest of the film fails to deliver on that same level. It is decent enough, but certainly not what I would consider the Best Picture of the year. Though the "one-continuous-take: style looks cool (like a documentary or a stage show, appropriate to this film), it gets disorienting at times and ends up feeling like just a plain gimmick unnecessarily added to spice up the movie. Some of the themes that are brought up throughout the film are interesting (like artistic "merit' versus commercialism and how social media plays into that), but the movie never delves into it deep enough, and those ideas are much more intriguing that what is going on in the story itself. Ultimately, it is weird and interesting, but unfortunately shallow.

Finally got the extreme pleasure to watch this and this film impressed me in every way possible. This has to be one of the most unique movies I have seen in quite some time and the talent brought to this film is astounding. This movie was filmed to look like it was done all in one take and that is one of the many reasons to see the film. This film brings together one talented cast and you can tell that every actor was fully committed to their material and played their characters so well. This is probably the best performance I have ever seen Michael Keaton give and he handles his funny and dramatic scenes really well. His role in this movie kind of resembles Michael Keaton as an actor and he was the perfect actor to play the part. He highly deserved his Golden Globe win and his Best Actor Oscar nomination. Edward Norton also gives one of his career best performances and it refreshing to see another great performance from him. I also thought that Emma Stone gave the best performance of her career and she had some really memorable scenes. Zach Galifianakis was actually really good in this film and he shows us that he can really act and play somebody else other than Alan from the Hangover movies. Naomi Watts and the remaining members of the cast all brought something to the film and I can't praise the acting enough because it was just fantastic. Another aspect that really shined was the brilliant directing from Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu. With this film, he really shows he direct a movie with such skill and passion and he works to get the best from his actors. The interesting story and characters matter in this film and they were presented in a way that was engaging from scene one. Emmanuel Lubezki shows us once again that he is a master at his craft when it comes to filming a movie. He has filmed Gravity from last year and won a much appreciated academy award for Best Cinematography for that film and I think he will take home that same award for this movie. His ability to be able to film a lot of long takes is brilliant and his scenery is always great to look at. The way the team behind the film edit it did a flawless job making the movie look like it was done in all one take was something different and refreshing to see. In the end, this movie is a must see for anybody who loves movies and it is a front-runner to win Best Picture at this year's Academy Awards.

A brilliant,elaborate variation on the "actor's nightmare" dream in terms of its structure, Birdman is a touching, hilarious and perceptive take on celebrity worship and the state of our legitimate theater, movies and TV, in general. Inarritu's movies aren't for everybody, but Birdman was a delight. 4/5

A truly exhilarating, inventive and breathtakingly original film with an achingly superb central ensemble cast and some visionary direction by Innaritu. 

This was the one of this year's batch of Oscar grouped films I was wariest of; it featured a stellar cast and had opened to some glowing festival reviews but always seemed a little too intense, a little too pretentious for my liking. Perhaps this just wouldn't be my thing: both Interstellar and the almost universally adored 12 Years A Slave had both passed me by as films that I really couldn't stomach for the run time (particularly in case of the former's testing 3 hour marathon).

I did, of course, love this film.

Technically marvellous in the truest sense of the word, Birdman skims through its run time with such poise and grace, ripping up ordinary conventions of the cinema and serving the adoring audience a plethora of messages and ideas (some perhaps subtler than others) in the form of a masterful cinematic invention of only the highest class.

Whilst I must disclose that I have never actually had the chance to see any of Iñárritu's past work other than glimpse a few shots of Buitiful (2010), I gather the 'gimmick' used in this feature (a word used politely in this instance, similarly to Boyhood) is not a recurring feature of his films and so is arguably completely unique in the fact that it was elegantly stitched together to create the look of a movie shot in one continuous take. Indeed, (save for the initial shot of a meteor crashing towards earth and the final scenes) the film grabs us from Keaton's first mediation shot and slams the door shut, not letting go and immersing us in the claustrophobic interior of a theatre and the oh so troubled lives of the people currently inhabiting it. Whilst done before (most notably with Hitchcock's 1948 film Rope) this trick is undoubtedly used to far greater effect and done so proficiently that one can only sit back in awe, appreciating the sheer dedication and persistence to this project unfolding effortlessly on screen.

Aside from the technical triumphs of this film, as with Boyhood, the performances are equally vital to the film's success. Keaton is of course the shining star of this piece, playing perhaps an extension of the man himself with anxious unease and roaring instability. The supporting cast, meanwhile, is composed both of those who have provided mild to moderate irritation on previous works (Zach Galifianakis) and also those who have made me want to gauge my eyeballs out using only Ebola infected floss (Emma Stone) but, through the work of miracles (or just wonderful direction from Iñárritu) are tolerable and even, dare I say it, enjoyable at times as the churn out the performances of their career.

Rich with subtexts, Birdman constantly reminds viewers of its overarching messages, some times perhaps less gracefully than others (Norton's Shiner preaching at a preview early on in the film comes to mind) with messages of the drive for fame and the ambition to be respected ("popularity is the slutty little cousin of prestige") running through the veins of this movie.

Whilst most of the opinions offered up aren't particularly groundbreaking in their message, they're presented so skilfully it's impossible not to just go with it. Accompanied by a relentless drum kit soundtrack, Birdman hurtles along at a breakneck and often frantic (perhaps indicative of Riggan's mental state) speed and could never be accused of meandering at any point in the movie.

When the film finally jolts to a halt at, the electrifying energy of this thumping movie had been injected into me and I left the screen illuminated and positively thrilled about what I'd just seen. This felt like a classic. This felt like one of the best of the year.

It was unashamedly frenzied at times, but the culmination of a hugely engrossing filming technique, the seamless merging of surrealism and harsh reality and a savagely funny (and yes, it's hugely funny at times) satire delivered through beyond Oscar quality acting made this film utterly compelling viewing.

Oscar-wise, it is pretty likely this will win Best Picture now (having swept the board precursor wise) and such a win would undoubtedly be deserved as this is undoubtedly the best FILM of the year, whilst Boyhood is the best cinematic experience and a film I simply love more.

When a movie is titled Birdman or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance) you better believe it's going to be a pompous, pretentious piece of cinema.  I'd kind of like to call it a piece of something else but I'll try to keep this review tasteful.  Upon first hearing of the rave advanced reviews this movie was getting, I was happy to see that Michael Keaton is having a comeback.  He's always been an underrated actor who had some very interesting film roles early in his career.  But I remember seeing some of the trailers for the film and not really liking anything about them.  Maybe they were saving the good parts for when you actually see the movie, right?  Wrong. 
It looks like my intuition was right.  But then that kind of means that all the critics are wrong.  Well this is all subjective of course, but yes, sometimes movie critics see something that's a little different from other films and they go crazy for it.  Especially once there's the slightest talk of Oscar buzz.
As for the plot of the movie, it's actually pretty simple.  Keaton plays an actor named Riggan Thomson who rose to fame playing a superhero named Birdman.  He then falls from grace by choosing not to do a third sequel and moves onto other things.  This is a bit similar to Keaton's own experience playing Batman in the first two films and then not doing the third or any after that.  He had some other hit films but his career eventually faded.  So his character Riggan decides to stage a play which he will write, direct, and star in to get some of the acclaim that he's been missing for years.  But when the big-name actor he hires for the role winds up being difficult to work with, it puts both the play and Riggan's comeback in jeopardy.  The whole film pretty much revolves around the play.  I mean that literally; most of the scenes are on the stage itself or backstage in dressing rooms.  It tries to emphasize the character's inner struggle between selling out and going back to the Birdman role or simply finding peace within himself no matter how bad his career may seem.
The one real positive thing I could say about the film is that the director does a great job at making the whole film appear as if it's been shot in one take.  The camera follows characters from one scene to another and it's unnoticeable when the camera switches to a new shot.  But this really is one of the most pretentious films I've ever seen.  It's full of one arrogant artsy shot after another.  The movie even begins with a shot of Keaton in his underwear floating in the air sitting Indian-style.  In fact, there are numerous scenes of him in his "tightie-wighties" as if to say look at how he's baring his soul on screen and letting it all hang out!  Even the music is pretentious.  There are no actual songs played in the movie and barely even a musical score.  All we get is the sound of drums being banged on as the character walks through hallway after hallway.  It's loud and supposed to stir up the dramatic tension that other music normally would.  But that's all it is, an alternative that makes the scene no better.  And there are so many metaphorical moments of the actor flying in the sky or controlling objects with his thoughts as if to show that he's still in full Birdman mode.  It's all just really ridiculous.  And it's sad to know that this movie will most likely be nominated for multiple academy awards including Best Picture.  I can think of plenty of other movies I'd rather watch this year that don't try so hard and scream Oscar at all the people who think they're watching a unique piece of art.  I just feel like I watched a so-so movie.
Everything about this film is brilliant. Acting, directing, cinematography, soundtrack all superb the storyline is basic yet so brilliant and complex. I cannot praise it enough. Best film of 2014

Wow, I was so bored. The only reason I can fathom that this movie is nominated for best picture is because it is artsy. I found the story long and uninteresting. The acting was good, but couldn't save my interest in the story. The cinematography was pretty cool as the whole movie appeared to be one continuous camera shot. I have never seen a movie like Birdman, and I doubt you have either.  To me, this movie is simply a ground-breaking flick that blew my mind.  First off, I love how this thing was shot.  It's basically a one camera shoot, but it isn't...kind of hard for me to explain, but very cool.  Second, Michael Keaton may have won himself an Oscar.  You know how art imitates life, there's a major case of that here.  He simply is top notch, and I think may win Best Actor over what will be a crowded field.  The rest of the cast quite simply bring their A-games and are outstanding with a special shoutout to Ed Norton who raises the bar himself. This is a movie that keeps you on your toes and never let's you stop to think. The cinematography will win an Oscar or hell will have frozen over. Incredible performances, witty writing, and an ending that leaves you thinking long after it is over. Great film and one of my top 3 of the year.
Excellent cinematography, editing, scoring, acting. Great story!

For this review I will defiantly need to have spoilers as I just can't talk about this film without it. I think everyone should watch this film at all costs. 

it is a truly inspiring film that is masterful written with a ending that is not only shocking, but strange and appalling for what it is. It pushes our ideals and look on the world that we have come to live in today.It pushes how we see our dreams and desires and just how far we are willing to take them.
In today's film world we see that the superhero genre is growing with films like Man of Steel, The Dark Knight, and The Avengers, but we can't help but ask ourselves do these characters, actors, directors have anything for themselves outside of just being the big superhero beat em up movies that they are. Well Birdman or the unexpected virtue of ignorance puts this question down on a silver platter and begins to ask these mind numbing questions that must be asked.
We see Michael Keaton take on the role of an actor gone mad after leaving his franchise known as Birdman. He has started to see things now look at strange images in the mirror along with hearing voices as well of his former self. He tries to discredit the voices as he pushes himself to become a true artist on the stage. he takes a huge risk much like the director does with this story. In this story we see a man try and tell a story on the stage that inspires people while at the same time he wants to shock them. He goes through rehearsal after rehearsal trying to get his audience to enjoy what was going on while he was on the stage. The actor also deals with his daughter who feels he is washed up and finished as an actor and makes fun of him for trying so hard.

The actors really are what helps to make this movie work as Emma stone gives us a stellar performance as the daughter upset a disgusted with her dad whilemi Watts helps build the structure. However neither Naomi Watts nor Emma stone ever take the spotlight off Keaton at any point and help make the movie feel well rounded.


Now what is stopping this from being 5/5 well while this movie is defiantly gonna win a Oscar it still has some hurdles. For instance the lesbian scenes and side story with Emma Stone was dry cut and never went anywhere aside from giving the audience loads of fan service to watch. Which is fine I just believe in having some balance in fan service, but I am not going complain to much. Though I wish there was more to this than what we got.

Either way Birdman is a amazing film that you should get everyone seeing you know.

This was not what I thought it was. 
Profound, thought provoking......I'm really not sure. 
Perhaps it was just too high brow for me, I never really got into it and struggled to find a point. 
I cannot see how it has been rated so highly. 
One mans struggle to gain acceptance of his piers by producing, directing and starring in a broadway show, having been known for his role as a super hero actor in trashy but popular films.
Does he do it? I'll let you decided. I'm not actually sure.

An absolutely amazing film!!! The performances are top-notch, the cinematography is brilliant, the story is mind-blowing and creates some interesting and almost-uncomfortable parallels to reality, everything is just 100% incredible!! Birdman will literally leave you speechless. My parents and sister went to see it one night, and everyone in the theater was left dumbfounded for five minutes after the credits started to roll. I went a week later with my mom, and a similar thing happened. I sat in my seat totally devoid of any words to say about it. Of course, now I know exactly what to say: if Birdman doesn't pick up Best Picture at the Oscars, I will have lost all faith in Hollywood.

Taking a deep (dark) dive into the fractured persona of a performing artist where the world around them is falling down like the red curtain in a theater, Alejandro González Iñárritu's 2014 wonderwork Birdman is a jazz-like narrative of control, the arts and existential acceptance (or ignorance)-really light material to counter the heavy thinking substance that is continually released every weekend for the masses. Not the first of its kind (others like it is David Lynch's great Mulholland Drive and Darren Aronofsky's shallow Black Swan), Birdman stands out due to superb acting (Michael Keaton-the former Batman-potentially playing a warped version of what his own career could have panned out to be, is magnificent as the titular Birdman), great production design (the film takes place in a singular playhouse that feels lived in and has a distinct personality) and is all tied together due to a persistent and focused direction from Iñárritu. His bold and steady film aesthetic is a departure from his erratic and choppy style from his past works (including 2006's Babel and 2010's Biutiful). Part of this is due to Iñárritu working first time with the long-take expert Director of Photography Emmanuel Lubezki (2006's Children of Men-shot by Lubezki-is a clear inspiration for Iñárritu) as the two orchestrate a seamless exploration within the labyrinth of the playhouse, but more importantly, the labyrinth of the mind. As the stream of conscious-like surreal filmmaking begins to up the tempo throughout the picture, it would be easy to label Birdman as a pure visual experience.  Although it is visually magnificent, everything you see is directly tied to the characters, where every minute detail tells us more about the story. The amount of forethought that went into Birdman and the general ease that Iñárritu and all of his collaborators display oozes confidence that is rarely seen in cinema. To label the film in one paragraph is too little, but Birdman is an achievement in cinematic vision from everyone involved and will undoubtedly leave a lasting impact.
An absolute powerhouse of a film.

Here Iñárritu avoids the train wreck and gives the right pace to this frantic media-age satire, in a symphony of acting with accomplished leads by Norton, Stone and especially Keaton. The ending feels quite producer-pleasing though.

Bird man is ambitious, unique and a very interesting take on importance and everything in Hollywood. With a interesting ending and many strong performances it could drag on at sometimes, but the doesn't detach from its meaning .

Rating: 8.0 (A-)

This movie is more sci-fi than I was expecting - the former action hero is haunted by his alter ego (Birdman) and seems to possess some remnants of his powers. This makes the whole thing a little hokey, but the dark humor and ambiguous ending make the film an entertaining watch.

Full review at: http://worldofblackout.blogspot.co.uk/2014/12/review-birdman.html

This two-hour joyride of surreal adrenaline stretches 'the form' to breaking point, being a film, play, dream-sequence and monologue all-in-one. Presented as a single, unbroken hand-held camera-shot, 'Birdman' is relentless, picking up the viewer like the levitating Riggan Thomson (Michael Keaton) in its opening scene and refusing to put them down as they laugh, cry, rage and fly with Keaton for the duration of the film. The screenplay is brutally self-aware, with the Birdman character and in-movie actor names seeming to be the only fictionalised aspects, as pop-culture references and icons of the 20th and 21st centuries are ruthlessly deconstructed. This is Keaton's show of course, in a career-defining role played as only he could, but it couldn't be done without the stunning supporting performances or Iñárritu's intense direction.

By no means a throwaway film, 'Birdman' will command your attention from start to finish, but that's not to say it won't be enjoyed by fans of indie-film and superhero-movies alike.

Every once in a blue moon there comes an experiment film that every director wants to make or actually does helm it. They don't know if it is going to work, they don't know if it will win audiences, they just go forward into the unknown hopefully their movie is liked. BIRDMAN is Alejandro Gonzales Inarritu's experiment film and has now won the prestigious Best Film at the Oscars this past Sunday. Technological wise it is great, not THE HOBBIT great but even better because it utilizes few CGI to keep the story rolling. I also would like to mention that the film is a one shot film for an hour and 43 minutes. Wow. When I first saw the film in theaters, I was sucked into the film that I didn't even notice that it hadn't cut for a while. Once I noticed, I wanted to see how long it had gone without a cut. That's just impressive, there are a lot of closeups, tracking shots, Steadicam shots and it all takes place inside the theater where Riggan Thomson (the legendary Michael Keaton) is conducting his play.

The camera follows this great ensemble inside the theater, outside the theater, into bars, into alleys that it just creates this "following" illusion that you're just ALWAYS there next to the actors, I really loved this style of filming. I've read many articles stating that one shots are very hard to do, they always mention the opening shot of Orson Welles' TOUCH OF EVIL as the originator of the one shot scene. More recently they mention Alfonso Cuaron's opening ten minute opening to GRAVITY and the motorcycle chase scene in CHILDREN OF MEN. There have been a lot of good one shots and when you see them you are just in awe of this technique. But enough of this technique, I feel like I'm rambling on, let's talk about the film shall we?

Riggan Thomson is a washed up actor who starred in the popular billion dollar franchise BIRDMAN. He's trying to revive his career by adapting a Raymond Carver play, he tells one of his fellow actors that what made him want to be an actor was the time when Carver wrote on a cocktail napkin that he had "a great performance" when Thomson was a kid performing in a school play. Riggan is so caught up with his Birdman character that he hears Birdman's voice in his head all the time, but he comes off as a perverted, manic, much more vulgar version of Birdman. Maybe this is what Riggan is ACTUALLY thinking but is too scared to say? A lot of people believe that this is loosely based on Keaton's own career having done BATMAN and whatnot now trying to revive his career with this film and Keaton nails it. If Eddie Redmayne wasn't nominated along with him, Keaton would have won the Oscar for this film. It was a great performance but Eddie just took it one step further by portraying Mr. Hawking. How do you explain Riggan's secret levitating? Is it all in his mind? Was he high? The ending was a little weird, hence the four and half star rating instead of five but all in all it is a triumph for Inarritu who has had a great film career so far ever since he burst onto the big screen with his gritty and raw directorial debut in AMORES PERROS. It was just a matter of time before he won a Best Director Oscar. Great film.

I enjoyed Birdman immensely. Michael Keaton and Edward Norton were amazing, the magical realism was never a problem and the technical execution was really interesting. And the story, one man's existential identity crisis, was astounding. The movie worked as a satire, as a comedy and as a drama. Oh! the music!

After viewing this film three times now I can certainly state that many elements within it have been masterfully crafted. The near seamless editing alone is something to behold, no straight cut are ever made, instead beautiful long takes weave each scene together giving the actors the time and space to showcase some truly phenomenal performances. Michael Keaton and Edward Norton are on top form throughout this film, a perfect scene to watch out for is when they are rehearsing on stage with each other, they play off each others performances brilliantly. The merging of diegetic and non-diegetic sound is another unorthodox element that this film experiments with and the results are incredibly immersive. To summarise Birdman is technical masterpiece which satires our modern society and outlook on other individuals within that society, though it may not be for everyone it's definitely worth a watch purely due to the amount of passion that has gone into making it.

At the center of it all are its phenomenal performances with Michael Keaton turning in some of the best work of his career and surrounded with a talented ensemble with impressive showings from Emma Stone, Edward Norton, and Naomi Watts.

Audacious at every level, Iñárritu's breathtaking examination of the wages of fame and pride just blew me away. Start with the fact that here we have the story of a washed-up actor known for playing a superhero, played by, yes, a somewhat washed-up actor known (in part) for playing a superhero. And then, a ferocious depiction of an all-consuming obsession to be both famous and taken seriously, to the point where all relationships are destroyed. And then, a delirious experiment with a camera that swoops and flies in what would appear to be a single uninterrupted shot, which sounds like a gimmick, and certainly is, but still, it works. And then, well, world-class acting that is so raw and funny it makes you want to cry, scream and cringe at the same time. This is, quite simply, the best "movie" movie in a very long time, and I loved it.

Michael Keaton gives his all in his performance here, as a washed up actor best known for playing a superhero trying to stage a Raymond Carver play in order to get a little respect...it isn't going well, and he is losing his mind a little. Keaton has always been an actor I really love. As a kid my favorite movie was 1989's "Batman", and it remains high up on my list. I also love "Beetlejuice," "Night Shift," and more...so to see an actor like Keaton, who I've always felt was a little underrated finally get some praise for his acting abilities in a big bad way, I couldn't be happier.  The film is tremendously inventive, it is shot to like like you are just flowing through the movie, as if it is all one shot.  The story is solid and the characters are all alive...but it is Keaton who knocks you out here. Norton is great as a parody of method actors...who can't actually act if he can't completely buy whatever he is supposed to be acting in. This would be my vote for what deserves Best Picture this year, time will tell if it actually gets the credit it deserves.  If Keaton doesn't win Best Actor, then the awards will continue to showcase that they have little real merit.

Birdman is an audacious and compelling film about the performance arts and features two excellent performances from Michael Keaton and Edward Norton. Their characters are quirky, but relatable enough to succeed and feature several darkly comedic moments. There's also several supporting turns that are very good. Birdman has some important topics to discuss when it comes to performances arts, from commercialism to the overreaching power of critics, and even how much actors sacrifice for their careers. It reaches a little too far in spots and some of the psychedelic scenes feel out of place, but ultimately this is an excellent film that should be seen by cinema lovers or jaded filmgoers.

It's a bird, It's a plane, actually it is a bird! It's Birdman!!! And definitely one of the best movies of 2014. Alejandro Gonzalez Iñarritu's directed "Birdman" stars Michael Keaton as Riggan, an aging actor who had his thespian heyday in the early 90's playing an iconic superhero named Birdman. And do I have to hit you with a bat on your head, to discover the irony in this since in the early 90's Keaton himself played.... well, you know the rest, or at least I hope you do. Well, anyways back to the current Riggan era. Riggan is now in production of a Broadway play based on a Raymond Carver novel. He stars, wrote the adaptation, and is directing the play. It is here where "Birdman" flies with greatness as Iñarritu brilliantly sends us to the backstage Broadway theatre world, and shows us all its complex eccentricities and politics. Alejandro the Great also scribed up a very witty "Birdman" screenplay with co-writers Nicolas Giacabone, Alexander Dineralis, and Armando Bo. Michael Keaton was more than phenomenal as Riggan, and Keaton is deserving of all the award love he is receiving. The supporting work of "Birdman" also did not fly the coup. Edward Norton was spectacular as Mike, a feisty Broadway actor. Emma Stone was standout as Riggan's daughter Sam. Zach Galifianakis was superb as Riggan's lawyer Jake. Watts out, here comes another brilliant acting effort from Naomi Watts', here playing the emotional-wreck theatre actress Lesley. And other solid supporting work were delivered by Amy Ryan, Andrea Riseborough, and Lindsey Duncan. But this was really Michael Keaton's main stage, and he kept us birdwatching throughout his stupendous performance. My only minor flaw of "Birdman" is the one-too-many fantasy-like scenes, but that was just a minor mishap in the "Birdman" nest. So rise up and catch the "Birdman".

The film tells the story of a forgotten star who is producing and starring in a play to stray away from his superhero past. Really the play is done to boost his ego as he feels that he is not relevant. One can say it is a satirical look at the star Michael Keaton. An actor who hit it big with Batman and kind of wither away after Batman Returns. Sure Keaton has done some great performances. But much like any actor that goes into a role of a superhero or Bond, will always be known for their big role.
The style of the film depicts the main star as a manic depressive who's trying to show the world that he is a true actor. I love the surreal scenes of him using telekinesis or the scenes of him flying. The voice that we hear in the characters head, is his inner ego pushing him to make another Birdman so he can be relevant again.
That's what makes the film work for me is relevancy. All of the characters want to be relevant and matter to the world. It also deals with themes of how the big New York Broadway scene views big Hollywood actors.
Great performances from Edward Norton as the completely vain Broadway star. His performance really sells for me as I always viewed him as the hardcore actor that is so dedicated to his work that his ego makes him shallow to everyone else. Another great performance from Emma Stone as Keaton's daughter. Her character has been ignored by her father during her childhood. Her character has dealt with a lot of depression to relieve her from the strained relationship she has had with her father. But who really shines is Michael Keaton.
Overall this film was interesting, creative and different. It is an unconventional film, a must see.
Keaton and Norton lead a great cast, that all deliver on their performances.  If you're an actor, as I am, it's definitely a must see.  Very relatable and entertaining!

You can fight for you success, you can fight for your money and fame, in the end, not being alone and irrelevant in the world is the final judgment. In a year where comic-book character speculation and superhero adaptations are at an all time high (a bar which I'm sure will only be raised with each passing year) the Batman we all grew up with came back with a vengeance in Alejandro Inarritu's Birdman.  To put it simply, Michael Keaton is powerfully charismatic, and only fails to steal the show when having to share a scene with Edward Norton.  Shot by Emmanuel Lubezki (the DP who shot Gravity) Birdman is just as visually interesting as it is confounding.  A movie about an actor who was in a movie and is now doing a play, there are moments that feel like they were drawn from old-school behind-the-scenes plays and films like Noises Off or Bullets Over Broadway, but there's a spiritual through-line that's difficult to ignore.  The entire cast is solid, though, and they better be, since they're the only things anchoring this film, which is essentially the fever dream of "How To Make It On Broadway for Dummies". Never once acknowledging the line between reality and fantasy, Birdman glides above everything, allowing the audience to draw its on conclusions.  Redemption, success, life, love, all the big themes are explored in a film that I'll easily love watching over and over again.

Birdman is a fine sample of postmodern narratives: a narrative that is full self-referential parodies and plays on meta level. By borrowing cultural studies thoughts from the likes of Barthes, Birdman outspokenly comments on action movies, showbiz, stage production, social media and even press and mass media The continuous long shots in alleyways and corridors of the theatre building add a labyrinthine association and metaphorical layer to the storytelling.

The acting by Keaton is amazing no doubt and he deserves the praise and awards he's recieving, but this movie is full of great performances. Edward Norton and Emma Stone both do a great job as you might expect, but Zach Galifianakis really shows how good of a actor he is this movie. So I loved the different approach in how it was filmed and also the acting in The Birdman, but the story kinda dragged a little for me.  So it was good, just not great in my opinion.

Artistically filmed, as it's also directed with blurred imagery of fiction and reality (what was imagined vs real). This film also takes a stab at critics, Hollywood productions, feeble minded audiences, social media and etc. Edward brings life to the film during the slow development phases. Superb acting by all of the cast  with #MichaelKeaton #EdwardNorton #ZachGalifianakis and #EmaStone leading the way. I feared the hype, but "Birdman" lived up to it!  It's almost like the flip side of the equally glorious "Boyhood".  All cylinders were fired, and all of them worked:  the technical camera & editing wizardry, the drum score, the performances (and the performances within the performances), the unexpectedly LOL hilarious dialogue, the skewering of Hollywood and celebrity (despite our reverence of celebrity, they really cannot fly) -- and the palpable heartache simmering underneath it all.  But put that all aside, and it's a simple allegory about how each one of us continuously redefines our relevance.  An individual's relevance is completely subjective, and it changes throughout his or her lifetime (and the changes accelerate as the years do).  Whether you want international celebrity success, or to be a star in your own household, it's entirely your job and it doesn't stop until you do.  That's why life is so tiring, but interesting.  I definitely plan to watch this again sometime, it should age very well.

Which brings me to my next gripe of the film. Michael Keaton's very involvement. He participated in a film that spits in the face of hollywood. Listen up, Mike. Without all those "apocalyptic porn" films you say are so mindless YOU WOULD BE NOWHERE! You would be nobody. These executives made the name Michael Keaton a household name and how do you repay them? Spitting in their faces and calling them greedy. You were Beetlejuice, you were Batman and now you are an emulation of your true self. Let's talk about the ending. You're going to love this. These geniuses fake out Michael Keaton's character's death FOUR TIMES! The first fake out is him jumping off the building and I'm like "Okay the movie's over. Okay. Pretty well rounded." And it shows him flying. "Okay so he's gonna hit the ground and die. We get some neat visuals and a little chuckle out of the sudden change of mood." No he lands on his feet and goes to the theatre inexplicably. So then he uses a loaded gun as his stage prop for the climatic suicide scene in his stupid play. "Ok cool he's going to kill himself in front of thousands of people as one final screw you to the world" He wakes up in the hospital missing his nose and I'm like "OH MY GOD JUST END!" He jumps out the window. "Finally he's dead. Now I can go home and watch a real movie." Emma Stone's character looks up and laughs. "WHAT?" 

This movie is stupid! It is stupid in every single angle! Nothing makes sense. It's an artsy, annoying, immature college freshman perspective of the world that tells the critics of Hollywood what they want to hear and they eat it up. I would rather watch The Room than this movie again. I would rather marathon four episodes of Frasier than watch this movie again. I liked Birdman from the get-go. I still do, in spite of the fact that it really rattled my cage. What set's this film apart is the exquisite writing. The screenplay is fantastic. The meaning of its alternate title, The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance, is a perfect metaphor. 

The setting of the film is the St. James Theatre in New York, a sparse and bedraggled venue. Behind the scenes, relationships are repeatedly tested. The characters are plagued with conflict between truth and dare, love and the quest for immortality. 

The main character too, is sparse and bedraggled. As the man in charge, Riggan Thompson's agony of doubt is so exquisitely tense; he seems to go in and out of his head as often as he rips off his wig. He is literally possessed of the super-power of movie stardom, yet struggles to cast it off like an addict yearns to deny his drug. 

Also inherent in the screenplay is theatre's comparison to film, and especially to CG action films, which dominate general audiences and make stars into super heroes. How can Thompson's bid for meaning hope to survive against the flash of his former film persona? 

Enter an accidental viral video as the play's literal deus ex machina, and the second title is foreshadowed, but not defined. Thompson, in an ill-advised attempt toward greater reality, is destined to take matters into his own hands. In the end, we are left with only our willingness to suspend disbelief. 

Birdman, the Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance, is a perfect social commentary, besot with tragic irony. It is artfully delivered in a screenplay bridging ancient to post-modern storytelling where the real struggles to overtake the surreal. 

This film shows exactly how far passion can go to drive one to the edge. It also shows how the public yearns to embrace this concept, as the only place art can be in order to be true.

Okay, I'll say it: "Birdman" soars. Finally, a film that feels original, fresh, provocative, challenging, funny, poignant, intimate and epic all at the same time. Director Alejandro G. Inarritu brilliantly skewers everything from Hollywood to Broadway, fame to art, mere existence to making a difference. Using the real St. James Theatre in New York as his labyrinthian canvas, Inarritu has crafted a surreal, dark comedy that was constructed as if to appear in one single, very long, continuous shot - it is truly a virtuosic achievement. Inevitably tapping into its leading man's own cinematic history, "Birdman" earns its wings from a moving, textured, riveting performance by Michael Keaton. He is ably supported by top notch actors at the very top of their game: Edward Norton, overdue for Oscar, may finally earn the statue by playing the most pretentious, obnoxious, and indulgent of actors. Emma Stone, who continues to impress as her resume grows, portrays a galaxy of emotions so expertly that after one of her scenes I desperately wanted to applaud. The divine Naomi Watts and Andrea Riseborough also bring pathos and authenticity to their actress roles. Though ostensibly about the theatre, "Birdman," with its stunning metaphors, imagery, and sound elements, exudes such cinematic flair that make it truly one of the year's very best. And that's something to crow about.
