Michael Keaton delivers a transcendent performance in this Oscar worthy trip down the rabbit hole as Regan Thomson, former star of the Birdman superhero franchise, tries to launch a Broadway production of Raymond Carver's What We Talk About When We Talk About Love. Hiring his recovering addict daughter (Emma Stone) to handle gopher tasks to try and keep her on the right track as his own life spirals out of control, Keaton begins to halucinate, convinced his psychic powers have injured his castmate, forcing them to recast a prime role with Edward Norton's Mike Shiner, a pompous stage actor (reportedly based on Phillip Seymour Hoffman) whose erratic behavior and backstage antics cause even more stress for Thompson and his stage manager Jake (Zach Galifinakis). Each performer within this inventive piece of cinema deserves Oscar recognition, as does its stellar cinematography (much like Alfred Hitchcock's Rope, the film flows as one singular shot, and its a marvel to behold). It captures the spirit of live theatre with a maddening authenticity, which both draws in those who understands the allure of "the boards" and very likely will alienate those who don't. Its a strange, divisive film, but its one hell of a ride to take, so those willing to try something new would do well to give the film a chance.

You don't have to be an actor to appreciate the film ... but it does add to the pleasure ... and the horror.   In short,  I loved it.

Birdman is a very unique and well made film. The cast is terrific, Edward Norton and Emma Stone are really great. But the real standout is the excellent performance by Michael Keaton, who owns the title role, and whose character is given a define and effective character arc. The cinematography is great, the whole movie is shot to make it look like one long take, and its so amazing and stylistic. The story is simple but unique and creative, with some powerful messages about our society. It even has a few entertaining scenes, as well as an ambiguous ending. My only problems with it are that it runs a bit long at times, though it is never boring, and some characters are not given full arcs such as Norton's character after being at the font of almost every scene. Birdman is very smartly made and different, a definite must see. Birdman gets 4.5/5 stars (A).

Although this film is slow at first, it soon finds a steady pace. Most iconic and distinctive form of directing since Under The Skin (directed by Jonathon Glazer). When you hear about Emma Stone's character, you are a little wondrous to whether she can take on such a challenge but the outcome is monumental. The imagery this film creates, is unlike anything seen before. (Sounds cringe, but really is phenomenal). Alejandro GonzÃÂ¡lez IÃÂ±ÃÂ¡rritu has a completely new style of directing, noticeable from the first scene. "Birdman" digs at the surface to give a sour taste of the 'real' Broadway. The music score is compelling, although the drums were repetitive. It seems the director wanted to give a drummer a chance and let his work be in a film, but you roll your eyes when you hear drums after the first half hour. I thought that Naomi Watts was good for Lesley but I thought if the director can change the way we look at Emma Stone, could Christina Applegate have played that roll? For the roll of (Riggan's ex-wife, Samantha's mum) I honestly think Allison Janney or Julianne Moore would've contributed far more than Amy Ryan. To end on a lighter note, the ending is great. It allows you to procrastinate on the whole film and just wonder and those people (like me) that quite often want an answer at the end of a film, won't get one but won't be unsatisfied.

So I actually didn't know what to expect about this movie. I had seen some of the previews but after viewing how much praised it received, I was actually intrigued to know just how good it was. Plus, it's director Alejandro Gonzalez IÃ±arritu is a great director, and it also featured a star studded cast. And so, after watching the movie, it was inevitable to feel just a little disappointed because the movie wasn't what I was expecting. However, it was an excellent film nonetheless. What amazes me the most, was how it seemed as if it was shot continuously as if it was a single shot, and how amazing the score and sound editing was thought the whole experience. It has been one of the few movies that have caught my attention of those aspects, and so that was new to me. Moreover, the acting was also a great factor of the movie, mainly Michael Keaton, Edward Norton, and-surprisingly, but not so much-Emma Stone. Keaton seems to be back with this great role, who he embodies almost too real to be true, it was amazing to see him make fun and play with what could be himself. Meanwhile Norton was excellent in every scene he was in, even if he was sometimes kind of a douche. And finally, Emma who to me reminded of how great of an actress she is, giving some of the most powerful and strongest lines in the movie. But overall the whole cast was on point. As to the story, the message was a very meaningful and important one, that truly comes through in the script and characters, with a lot of metaphors and imagery. And it's inclusion of fantasy really ups the movie and gives it this another level of craziness and fun. It serves as a great comedy, but also a very dark drama that even though it aimed times deviates in its story, it's pretty amazing to watch and be amazed of what an spectacular work IÃ±arritu and Emmanuel Lubezki just accomplished. And I'm sure this will be one of the best movies of the year. 
~December 12, 2014~

Brilliantly shot and wonderfully directed, Birdman is exceptional. The ensemble's performance, replete with chaos and punctuated by jazz riffs, exist in what feels like a two hour single shot. The magic of Riggan Thomson's super heroic abilities leave the audience wondering if he's the real deal or a lunatic. The only true moment of clarity for Riggan comes at the end when he decides to switch out his prop gun. Some of the dialogue was predictably self-effacing toward actors in general, which detracted slight from the story. Otherwise it's a celluloid slice of cinematic wizardry.

So, after seeing Birdman or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance) for a second time, I see it has a hopeful examination of the artistic endeavor.

When you go out and try to create something, you do die a little bit, but when you accept your final effort for its truth, you gain more life, you soar with achievement.

Screw the naysayers, fuck the critics (each and everyone of them and their bullshit opinions), if one is true, if one is honest, in their undertaking of a work, then they have reached for something worthwhile.

I'm not saying that all "artistic" endeavors are honest, and neither is the film, it is not kind to Hollywood's Superhero fetish (something I am also tired of), and it openly mocks those tent poles.

I think it's a great film for creative people to tackle, but I think that people who lean toward the critics side cannot understand the real meaning behind it, they are too aligned to their own small, selfish worldview. They don't understand the process and are too locked on to the surface of a project, the names attached.

Very quirky but still a very good, very textured movie. In a way, this movie is like eating a big, sloppy slice of pizza and washing it down with a pristine, fine wine. The acting in this movie is phenomenal with a powerhouse cast led by a redefining performance by Michael Keaton. The movie is about an actor (Keaton) who is basically washed up, most known for his role several years prior as the comic book hero "Birdman," but now he wants to do something serious that actually requires "real acting," so he turns to the theatre for which he adapts a script for a play and prepares for opening night. From here, the film takes many different turns, exploring, in very quirky, colorful, and funny ways, the man's frustrations, anxieties, insecurities, and, ultimately, his fear of rejection. A great detail that sticks out in this film is that there are a lot of very long takes in which the actors switch seamlessly between moods and tones in a matter of seconds. The camera work is also very dynamic; the camera is almost always in motion whether its circling around a table or traveling down a hallway. It is almost impossible to look away from the film because something is always happening; the movie moves very quickly from scene to scene, arousing the feeling that if you turn away you might miss something. I would definitely expect to see this movie showing up at the Oscars, particularly in the Best Actor/Actress/Supporting Actor/Supporting Actress categories. This is a very fun movie to watch in general, and, from the look of things, this movie will most likely become one of the overlooked gems of 2014.

When I go see a movie, I want at least 1 of 3 things:
1. To be entertained
2. To see something that I've never seen done before
3. To become invested in the events happening on screen

This movie fails on all 3 counts.

The humor in this "black comedy" is relegated to jokes about genitals and faux molestation admissions. There are perhaps,
4 or 5 of these instances peppered throughout the film. So this movie fails as a comedy.
The other praise being lobbed at this movie are the performances from Keaton, Norton,
and Stone. Norton's presence is mystifying. His character essentially serves no purpose, as 
he is meant to embody the swaggering bravado of Brando-esque method actors, but 
instead comes off as an unpredictable jerk who doesn't even follow the "rules" of his
own character.
Stone, on the other hand, is such a tired cliche that she almost isn't worth mentioning.
Her schtick of being the emotionally fragile ex-druggie daughter is never fleshed out,
never interacting with anyone in a meaningful way except for a sexual tryst on a roof 
and the obligatory reconciliation with the dad who was never there.
Keaton does a fine job here, even if he is overacting a bit.

Compounding these issues is the decision to shoot the movie as if it was one continuous
shot. Is it kinda neat to see? Yes. Does it add anything significant the the film? No.
I've seen this done in other films, better I might add, and there the decision made sense thematically.


My main issue is the fact that so many plot lines are present but the film never really sees
fit to close them, just showing them to the audience and letting them sit there. A lesbian 
sublot is introduced and then vanishes (???), Nortons' own romantic arc fizzles out to nothing,
and the ending...well let's not talk about that...

There are ways to present an artful film without engaging in pretension. Unfortunately,
it seems as though Inarritu has never seen Bunuel or Jodorowsky. The symbolism is as subtle
as a sledgehammer and I can't help but feel a little insulted, paying $20 to watch a movie
that is essentially calling the audience morons.

With his daughter Sam(Emma Stone) being hired as his personal assistant, movie star Riggan Thompson(Michael Keaton) aims to take Broadway by storm with a play he is adapting, directing and starring in.  Except, he is finding it more challenging than he originally expected.  Namely, that Ralph(Jeremy Shamos), one of the key actors, can't.  Which is taken care of easily enough through an industrial accident which Riggan confesses responsibility of to his agent Jake(Zach Galifianakis) due to psychic powers.  In any case, this means Riggan gets to replace him with Mike(Edward Norton), a definite improvement, unless you discount his adherence to realism on stage.  Oh and Laura(Andrea Riseborough) might have some news for Riggan.

"Birdman" is a well-acted and complelling back stage drama, filmed on location at the St. James Theatre in New York City, that allows Emma Stone and Zach Galifianakis to extend their range.(It is ironic perhaps that Lindsay Duncan who plays the New York Times critic/great defender of theatre is currently appearing in 'A Delicate Balance' about a block away.)  Also, it is something of a technical achievement in its apparently seamless editing which imitates the onstage feel of a play with a rotating background.  So, while Riggan is doing the right thing by bringing serious theatre to Broadway, he is doing for the wrong reason, namely his ego, always dwarfed by that of a superhero he once played and now suffering under the strain of.

It's nice to See Michael Keaton back in leading man form, and Birdman (or the unexpected virtue of ignorance) is quite a bit to take on. The bulk of the film takes place on the set of a Broadway play devised by former movie star Riggan Thompson (Keaton) and rarely strays.Riggan was once the title character in a would be superhero franchise that went belly up after he declined to return for another sequel, and he has been struggling to prove his worth ever since. There isn't a whole lot that is sympathetic about this guy. Riggan's ego has overtaken the more important things in his life, such as his relationship with his estranged daughter, Sam, played by the ever likable Emma Stone. The writing is rich, and the rest of the cast delivers in spades. Edward Norton is great as Mike Shiner, who is perhaps the manifestation of Riggan's acting aspirations in all of their self aggrandizing glory. Director Alejandro González Iñárritu's talent behind the camera is evident in his brilliant single take tracking shots. In fact the whole film is structured like the Broadway play at it's center, with characters coming and going smoothly (sometimes not so smoothly). Birdman is frequently very funny, but it's also quite tragic. There is an element of Riggan Thompson's psyche that comes into play multiple times during the film that I won't divulge, but it leaves you with a lot to think about.

Birdman is, for all of its few faults, one of the most interesting major releases in recent memory, and worth seeing for that fact alone. As a director's medium, Birdman is visually unique, with its single-take style paying dividends for it's self-aware tension. As an actor's medium, Birdman excels, with Michael Keaton proving himself worth a meta-damn and a supporting bench so deep that Amy Ryan shows up for a thankless three scenes. Birdman is not for everyone, but as a piece of cinematic wankery, it is unmatched; sometimes, that's all I want to see.

Just when you think you have seen every type of movie there is, an unexpected gem such as Birdman or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance) comes along and changes the way you think movies can be made. Birdman is smart, inventive, beautifully shot, expertly acted, and about as perfect as a movie can be these days. Director Alejandro G. Inarritu has crafted a modern masterpiece with this film. Everything from start to finish is nothing short of masterful. This film's editing, cinematography, pacing, and overall look is groundbreaking. This was shot in a way that looks like it is all one panning shot. Every scene blends together in such an extrordinary way that it is almost impossible to describe. This is simply something you must see for yourself. The use of visual effects are also breathtaking with subtle exectioun to where this all looks natural and you believe whole heartedly that everything is on sceen. Inarritu's direction is clearly the star here but his writing and storytelling methods are just as spectacular. The story here is that a down on his luck actor, who is famous for playing a superhero named Birdman twenty years ago, decides to adapt a novel into a broadway play and try to revitalize himself as well as his career. The script here is absolutely solid filled to the brim with thematical elements, deep symbolism, and literary refrences to elevate this story to something beyond description. Inarritu uses very unconventional ways to tell the story that you instantly understand. Delivering this script is arguably the best cast assembled in a movie this year. MIchael Keaton plays the star Riggan and delivers the performance of his career. Keaton has such passion here and so much heart it is easy to see why he is getting all of the Oscar buzz now. Joining him are Edward Norton, Emma Stone, Naomie Watts, Zach Galifianakis, and Amy Ryan. All give beyond spectacular performances that should all be given accreditation for their efforts here. All in all Birdman or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance) may be the best film of 2014. Everything here is flawless and there has never been a movie like this before and I doubt if there will be after. This is a cinematical achievement that only few directors and actors have ever achieved. Keaton and Inarritu have a lot to be proud of here and I can't wait to see how it fairs in award season. I encourage everyone to witness this film, you will be glad you did.

A former action film star attempts to make a come back with a Broadway production.
There is no doubt that this film features some of the finest work in Michael Keaton's and Edward Norton's careers, and the almost constant cinematography directed by Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu is captivating and frenetic eye candy. However, the story is a hodgepodge of dangling the plot threads and missed opportunities. While it is true that Keaton's protagonist carries the film, The subplots with his daughter, the lesbian affair, and the failing marriage never tie into Riggin's journey, and these sections of the film leave me with more questions than answers. Also, the last shot of the film seems to change the rules established by the first hour and fifty-eight minutes. 
Overall, while the films performances are a joy to watch, the story fails to have any cohesion.

BIRDMAN soars above the rest as a tale of tragedy, humour and introspection. We've all heard the "it's not all about the fame" aphorism before, but this is different. This is fun. This is exciting.

As the title credits appear, it becomes apparent that they are almost exactly like those used in the opening of Jean-Luc Godard's acclaimed film, Pierrot le Fou. Such a decision is surely a bold move - attempting to emulate one of the greats is not something to be taken on lightly.

The film follows the story of ex-movie star Riggan Thomson, the leader of 90s film franchise 'Birdman', as he tries to shake off this reputational stereotype and make it in the world of Broadway theatre - by directing, writing and starring in his very first play.

The opening begins with our protagonist, Riggan, clad only in his underpants, floating in mid-air and meditating on the fact that his dressing room "smells like balls". Throughout the film, we are treated to many more surreal moments interspersed with the otherwise (fairly) naturalistic feel of the film. Fans of films such as Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind will love this aspect.

The continuous shot effect (helped along by some very clever editing) seduces us viewers into the story. You'll feel exhilarated, like the scenes are live, happening right now, with us in the moment. It almost converts the film from cinematic expression to theatre, as we explore the backstage habitat, and pound the streets of New York. The fast paced nature of the film is helped along by the infectious percussion score - it almost feels driven by this wild and unstoppable beat.

Michael Keaton is impressive as Riggan, finely balancing the tragedy and humour of his character, with the film itself as a satirical reference to his own real-life success as Batman in the 90s.

Edward Norton is great as asshole actor Mike, and Emma Stone holds her own as disillusioned ex-addict Sam, a far departure from her usual sweet roles in films like The Help and the Spiderman series.

If Riggan is our Icarus of this fable, the New York Times critic Tabitha (Lindsay Duncan), who despises what he stands for, is our Greek Chorus, highlighting Riggan's internal struggle, the dirtiness of the film industry and the modern focus on celebrity lifestyle.

The film is visually stunning, particularly the shots of characters on the theatre stage. The score is perfect and the cast give it their all - no moment is left feeling lacklustre.

The themes of celebrity and art may be old, but the delivery is not. Awards will be showered on director Alejandro González Iñárritu for Birdman.

An ambitious, and brilliantly satirical drama that is a much-needed return to form for actors like Edward Norton, and it may be Michael Keaton's magnum opus. The film is made to look like it is one continuous take (though it's been done before) and the level of intricacy to pull off all the camera-moves and timing of events between the actors is an amazing accomplishment! The acting is off-the-charts outstanding and surprisingly Zach Galifianakis is one of the biggest highlights holding his own with the greats around him. The story and actors involved are very much winking at the audience with Keaton and Norton playing spoofs of their own careers, and the conversations between characters very much pointing out the flaws with Hollywood filmmaking; and it was wonderful to hear! It is definitely for lovers of film as the techniques, surreal direction, pitch-perfect acting, and very original score (being percussion only) may go unnoticed by the average viewer. I don't think it's a perfect film as the ending left me a bit cold and after much speculation, it became difficult to reach a fitting conclusion and I could've used more clever integrations of the Birdman character himself, but it is the whole package in terms of ingenuity and is a power-house acting bonanza!

The 2014 film Birdman leaves one feeling buoyant and calm at its end. Like a buoy resting in the ebb of the sea's deliberate churning, the movie rises and falls between lulls of set up and crests of conflict in strokes of intense passion and flourishes of absurd quirk. 
The characterization in this film is spot on. The actors show the eccentricities of each character in subtle ways that push each of their arcs. In the specific cases of Michael Keaton's Riggan and Edward Norton's Mike, they reach unforeseen climaxes that respectively mystify and shock viewers. 
Riggan, the lead, is shown to be a self-important man struggling on a quest to validify himself as a respected Broadway actor after acquiring early celebrity decades prior to the current story events for portraying an iconic comic book character. He is psychotic, hearing himself in his mind as the iconic Birdman, the character Riggan is famous for in the film. This gravelly voice antagonizes Riggan with reminders of the perceptions others have of him and of the glory he held in his younger days, which are now behind him and never fails to mock by assuring that he is always there for Riggan, even calling him brother after one intense breakdown. This cajoling often sends him on violent tantrums that see his property damaged apparently through the use of telekinesis. Now Riggan is on his last leg. He is desperate to revitalize his tattered image by bringing the genius of an obscure short story by Raymond Carver to the stage as its director and lead actor.
Riggan is a kind enough character, quirky and earnest if not a bit self obsessed. These elements of his personality make the audience sympathetic toward him, though his quest is a personal one and not concerned with important social issues or deep philosophical quandaries. Although there is no intrinsic universality to the characters quest it's easy enough to care that he succeeds when one considers the passion and subtlety in Keaton's performance. 
I was shocked after one intense scene where Riggan's daughter, played by Emma Stone, ripped him a new one for his self imposed social detachment and his condescending attitude for the social media, which she finds so appealing. When she was done ranting she offered a hollow apology. The faux smack of sorrow written across her brow was telling. It suggested awareness that she should feel bad for what she'd said, but in actuality she wasn't concerned how her words had hurt her father. It was just the courtesy drawn from social convention that birthed her apology and did not express real compassion. 
The very real load of anxiety written across Riggan's brow told a story of being put in one's place whether he liked it or not. The painful truth exposed in this exchange lingered in silence as he gave no response to her apology, so when he lit and smoked the short marijuana joint of her's he'd found hidden in a peanut butter jar, the same joint, which had started the tense encounter, I felt resonance in his need for the near instant relief that doobie drag gave him, despite the hypocrisy in his actions. 
Life can be that way sometimes and that sentiment was frozen in a snapshot in this scene. It made me wish for my own instant relief as the scene was tense and thrilling, but not in a bomb explosion/car chase way, rather in the gritty slice of life way this film nails so often. Kudos to Stone for the visceral intensity she delivered in this scene and to Keaton for his response, which conveyed a stayed apathy that worked in tandem to cement a perfect moment in film history and in the cognition of the audience.
Mike (Edward Norton) was grim and cynical and obsessed of a unique type of narcissism, which expressed itself in his convoluted pathology toward the dichotomy of truth and illusions. A talented and known stage performer, Mike's entire life was the stage. This was shown clearly when, after receiving a supporting part on Broadway on short notice, he arrived, proved himself worthy, than stripped naked for a fitting, in front of Riggan's daughter, with a just-another-day-at-the-office attitude. 
Mike was a character that believed that only what he did on stage was truth, so the way he behaved off stage and the reactions and opinions that behavior generated were of no consequence to him.  To Mike the stage was a holy altar where the right and ritual of truth was practiced and to do anything else was sacrilege. His characterization as a snarky, detached, manipulative jerk felt rushed early in the film, but it soon became clear why Mike needed to be characterized so quickly. 
His character arc climaxed promptly in a scene where he nearly raped his offstage girlfriend, Lesley portrayed by Naomi Watts, who was also his love interest in the Broadway show, before the 150-member audience in attendance. It was clear that he was a do-anything-for-the-part actor to the extreme and his rushed portrayal as a pathological maniac was necessary for this scene to be believable. 
His given excuse for trying to copulate on stage with Lesley was in order to give the audience truth in acting. This pathology was elaborated after the scene ended, backstage when Lesley suggested that Mike hadn't been able to get it up for six months and now before 150 people he was hard as a rock, to which he replied, "I need it to be real." His reality was constructed of the complex emotions he dealt with on stage before the audience, and life for Mike was merely what happened between performances. Director Alejandro Gonzalez Innarritu, the screenwriters and Norton himself, expertly handled the mix of showing and telling in characterizing Mike.
The cinematography in this film was a call back to a time when frenzied cuts didn't exist. The long shots flowed from one scene to the next like a live performance caught on tape. This gave a stage play-like feel to the film. It was tiring one moment and refreshing the next and added to the quirk built in to this story. The extended shots of halls, some smoke filled, accompanied by audience applauding or sonorous horn music served as transitions between acts and added an art house feel to the movie's aesthetics; and were all tasteful choices I might add. 
The music can't be over looked in this film. It was nuanced and sparse, but heavy when played and drew the audience instantly into the world of the characters. One notable example of this affect was when Mike and Sam, Stone's character, were on the cusp of lovemaking, backstage hidden in a cove of ropes and shadows. The music sprung into the frame, a close shot of the two actor's faces, their lips just inches apart. 
This music conveyed reverie and optimism and all the virtues of ignorance that the movie tried to portray. And as Mike laid her down, Sam's smile enveloped the rich bliss that only ignorance can offer. Wisdom is full of sorrows and none of these characters are wise, but what they lack in wisdom they more than make up for in the experiences of real living. 
They are all plunged into the real emotions of life and love and jealousy and unfulfilled desire, but somehow blind to the intellectual baggage that living has built into their lives. While wading through this bog of emotions, the type personal reflection that give one insightful comprehension and helps to forge a fully constructed view of one's self are lost on these characters. This is the realm of ignorance that director, Inarritu is subtly tapping, which brings us to the conversation of powerful emotions in this film.
Powerful emotions pervade this story. They often draw on the audience in shocking ways and sometimes act as camouflage to cover the lack of plot development in the movie. This film stands in a long tradition of the emotional development, which is touted here above plot development as the narrative meanders, dawdling through the sentimental gestures of the main characters and leads to no conclusions. 
The main characters embark on a spiritual journey that climbs toward an inner climax. It is not a high point in dramatic action, this climax, but a moment of truth or clarity, which shapes the characters' lives after the apex event. In this film the highest emotional arc is dispensed on Riggan when, on the night before the big opening, he verbally attacks the Broadway critic who wields the power to murder his play on the tip of her pen. 
The two characters go at each other's throats firing unveiled hostilities that center on their respective identities. Riggan implies that the critic must have suffered artistic blight to become the woman who sacrificed nothing to tear down the dreams of others. He posits himself an actor who has sacrificed everything for his work. She draws a distinction, which is the crux of Riggan's whole emotional journey by clarifying that he is a celebrity, not an actor. She tells him she will kill his play solely because of what he represents, which is in her words the cartoonish and pornographic portrayals of Hollywood's conception of acting. She tells him that his life is measured in weekend box office takes, reiterating the idea that his existence is not valid. 
The ensuing emotional low brings Riggan to that moment of clarity where on stage, during his opening night when that most important critic is in attendance in the second row during the play's climax Riggan says that he is nothing, that he is no one and wields a loaded pistol. It is a real pistol and despite the fact that the audience doesn't know this he fires on himself apparently ending a tragic and shallow existence. An existence consumed by his obsession with acting and proving himself valid in the eyes of the critics and the audience. His quest for validity seems to end once he's finally accepted the fact that Riggan is not valid. Then the camera cuts to black. 
In the next scene we see Riggan's wife in a hospital room and eventually learn that he miss fired, shooting off his nose, not killing himself as we are led to believe. In his recovery room Riggan learns from a news report that he has finally regained the status he'd desired as his fans hold prayer vigils and lay flowers for him while he convalesces. After this we are given an ambiguous denouement that ends the plot with a question, not a conclusion. The overall emotional effect inspires hope and cheer and leaves the audience on an upswing alleviating all the anxiety experienced through out the film with comedic panache while tying up no loose ends.
The quirk of Riggan as a delusional celebrity who's sees and hears things that aren't there when experiencing anxiety, and who may or may not have the ability to levitate, are this movie's charm and offer emotional breaks that are much needed as this black comedy is quite intense. On the whole watching this character study was an enjoyable experience. And I definitely suggest you see this film.

Review by Jesse Burleson of VIEWS ON FILM


Michael Keaton has been appearing in movies every since he burst onto the scene doing the fast-talking, kooky, morgue worker thing in 1982's Night Shift. Since then, he's been in mostly semi-memorable comedies, a couple of stints in two Batman films, and forgettable duds like 1998's Jack Frost, 2005's White Noise, and Herbie: Fully Loaded (oy vey). Watching 2014's Birdman made me wonder why it took so long for him to I don't know, star in anything Academy Award worthy. He's always had the ability to someday be nominated for an Oscar. Director Alejandro G. Inarritu's latest is a raw, unflinching, bracingly original play on words and for what it's worth, might just punch Keaton's thirty-two year wait of a ticket. As an acting showcase, this "bird" is definitely the word as quiet as it's kept.

Filmed primarily in and around one location (NYC's St. James Theatre), edited brilliantly by Douglas Crise (Spring Breakers) and Stephen Mirrione (George Clooney's The Monuments Men), and featuring a lot of male characters fighting/running around in their underwear, Birdman immediately hones in on a washed up actor named Riggan Thomson (Michael "my real last name is Douglas" Keaton). Thomson hasn't been in much of anything lately whether it be Broadway or Hollywood fodder. His one salvation: direct, write, and star in a play adapting Raymond Carver's (a real-life, famous writer) short story, "What We Talk About When We Talk About Love". As the proceedings move along, you don't get the feeling that you're gonna see many acts in said stage production (within a movie). It's more about the behind-the-scenes stuff that is conflicted with multiple actor egos, creative differences, actual fist fighting among the cast members, daughter/father resolutions, and attempted, co-star rape (very mild and only in one short scene).

Michael Keaton's performance, which if you haven't already heard, is the high point. It has a nasty, kick-in-the-door intensity to it. Is his Riggan Thomson on drugs? Is he a chronic alcoholic? Or schizophrenic? Does he have an imaginary friend in alter ego "Birdman" (his superhero character popularized in movies over two decades ago)? Finally, can he actually move objects with his brain? And can he fly (you know I'm kidding, right)? It doesn't matter. Keaton's Thomson probably possesses a lot of these things and he plays him with a visibly weathered, unassuming style. You can't quite see the wheels turning in Beetlejuice's head. That's the brilliance you get from a veteran screen icon who seems hellbent on literally acting his testicles off. The rest of the cast, well they fade in and out and still kill it at the same time. Edward Norton is despicably good as Thomson's belligerent acting rival. Emma Stone, with her gigantic, glaring eyeballs, emotes wonderfully in a couple of scenes as Keaton's character's druggie daughter. Zach Galifianakis is unexpectedly brilliant playing Thomson's hopped-up best friend/lawyer (this is quite a diversion from his Hangover doofus) and Amy Ryan, well she's a soft revelation playing I guess, Thomson's intolerant ex-wife.

Then there's Inarritu's knockout direction which has to be seen to be believed. He's a filmmaker who doesn't fly by the rules and gets away with things every time. Remember in 2003's 21 Grams when he filmed every scene out of order (like a bunch of puzzle pieces) only to put them neatly back together in the end? I do. This guy's out of bounds but in a good way. With Birdman (his 5th feature), he fumbles a bit with his confusing storyline only to shoot some of the most elaborate tracking shot sequences this side of Goodfellas and Boogie Nights. You drop your jaw in amazement as to how many marks the actors had to hit, how many takes their endless shots might have possessed, how many hundreds of lines of dialogue they had to memorize, and when in said shots, did Inarritu actually yell "cut" (it's conceivable that the first hour or so might have been one long tracking bonanza. That can't be right, can it?).

In retrospect, Birdman is set to a film score that is mostly fused with solo, jazz-inspired drumming. It's a fall release posing as part hallucinatory dream, part suicidal character study, and part frigid, black comedy. Watching it made me think that what's on screen might be too radical for title as best vehicle of 2014. It could however, get a shot in the category of Best Picture nods come January. Only time will tell. Anyway, as a celebratory Steadicam feast that makes you think, "how the heck did they film that?", Birdman is Keaton's finest hour and for my money, truly a top "feeder" (ha-ha).
Not sure if it deserved best picture, but it definitely had the makings of one with the story of an insane actor. Hollywood loves themselves more than anything else.

Inarritu's awesomely directed film, helped in no small part by cinematographer Emmanuel Lubezki, is a feat on the technical level alone, with it's "one-shot long take" proving to elevate the fantastical and touching screenplay about mounting a Broadway play in the face of failure. Keaton is a masterclass in acting (deserving of a Best Actor nod), and the cast is rounded out with great performances by Emma Stone, Edward Norton, Naomi Watts, and Zach Galifianakis .

Meh! I think the point of this film is focusing on how ignorant and unaware actors and the film industry can be in their own self-indulgence. But this movie itself seems to me to be very self-indulgent, not very interesting and just plain boring.
We saw "Birdman" on November 9th at the AMC Rolling Hills 20.  The movie had very high Tomatometer and Audience ratings but we didn't care for it that much.
Great performances. LOVE Edward Norton!
Such a terrific fictional biography, about the past and the role model of our youth. Portrait by an hilarious good Michael Keaton.

I really wanted to like this movie.  My dad (age 63) and my cousin (age 24) both liked it when they saw it in NY.  My husband enjoyed it when we saw it here in Scotland tonight.  Most critics seem to be impressed, and there are Oscar murmurs.  Unfortunately, whatever its merits, may be, they seem to have been largely lost on me, as I was left feeling a combination of disappointed, bored, and dizzy (due to the camera work).  It's made me question whether my tastes may in fact be more pedestrian than I like to imagine, at least when it comes to art films.  The acting was good - if anything, I felt frustrated that most of the characters weren't really allowed to develop, and some aspects of the plot seemed to just fizzle out or disappear inexplicably.  My difficulty with the disjointed narrative didn't make me question my own intelligence or open-mindedness (let alone deeper philosophical questions) so much as it made me question what the filmmakers were really hoping people would take away from this.  Because what I took away was mainly a headache.  If I had been wearing a watch, I would have started checking it long before the ending.  My feelings were similar to those I experienced after films such as "Synecdoche, New York", or the less accessible works of P.T. Anderson, David Lynch or Michel Gondry.  So if you like those, you'll probably like this.

Stunningly shot (30 mins w/o cut?) and subtly, darkly funny, but relying on characters rather over gags.  It's only let down by its inaccessibility and unreliable perspective, but that's what fancy/snobby is all about, right?  Still so good that it really should be among the best of the year.
Stylistic with great performances from Keaton and Norton.
Amazing film wonderfully written and directed. Michael Keaton completely captures you with his performance a definite Oscar worthy actor and film.

This is a movie about a play, shot as a play, giving the illusion of one continuous shot, which made the direction kinda genius. The direction cleverly captured and made you feel part of the chaos, tension and heart behind a Broadway and off Broadway play. The casting was perfect as were the neurotic characters the actors portrayed. Funny how I couldn't separate Keaton from his Batman role, but I think this dark comedy was meant to mirror his life in an exaggerated way. 
Highly recommend this fresh and cooky film. No mediocrity here!

has no equal

could potentially sweep
keaton, norton, & stone are front runners
strong contender for picture, director, original screenplay, editing, cinematography, & score

Never dull or slow with unique, precise, and skillful directing. Well-acted all around. Very peculiar and enigmatic. Challenging just such that certain aspects of the film are clear to understand artistically and others are completely elusive.

Inarritu has always been a director that I have had a hard time getting on his wavelength. I've always found his films interesting, but never felt emotionally invested in them. Birdman breaks this pattern. Now, there are problems that I have with some of the stylistic choices, especially towards the end, but overall I really enjoyed the "one-shot" idea that Inarritu employed here. All of the performances are really great, so much so that you can't really solo out any performer as being better than the other. I know it's natural to choose Keaton, but he gets more to do than many of the others, as well.

I really enjoyed this film, and I think it's one that you need to see in a theater or if you see it at home, be a captive audience. Commit to it. Don't have your laptop or your tablet out, commit to watching the entire film. Because Inarritu's idiosyncrasies can make the film feel too weird and too tedious to keep up with, but by the second act, you'll be with his rhythm. And Birdman will be rewarding.

Not that all of the film works, but as a technical achievement, it's phenomenal. Not just in terms of filmmaking, but in the performances as well. Everyone feels real, and Inarritu really works every part of the story. There are some of the hallucination scenes that didn't all work for me, but over all I was really invested in the characters. Birdman's pretty great.

What a complicated, beautifully constructed parody of show business and hero worship. It is a movie about now and it satirizing what we love in this time period. The acting is top notch and pitch perfect, a technical masterpiece that boosts it's performances. Michael Keaton is a true marvel and deserves every award this year he proves that he is more than Batman and Beetlejuice.
A film full of powerful performances and a lingering beat that won't leave your head.
Balls-to-the-wall acting from Keaton and Norton.  This movie shot to my top 10 list after my first viewing of it.

With a powerhouse performance from Michael Keaton, along with its supporting cast of characters, 'Birdman' excels as both a character study and as a commentary on culture, film, theater, critics, and more. It's sublimely shot, written and directed. One of the best films of the year.

The incredibly long camera shots that follow Michael Keaton as Riggan, a once iconic actor who once played one of the larger then life cinematic superhero as he walks through the Broadway Theater inside and out, to give us a intimate perspective his characters personal journey from screen to stage. Riggan finances a Broadway play hoping to recapture the glory of his box office success in the movies, only to stumble through the process of what is expected from him as an actor on stage. He doesn't know how to reveal his inner depth to give the performance he needs to pull off this play. Ed Norton's Mike is his nemesis as a method actor who comes in to replace an actor that becomes injured (by Riggan). Mike pushes Riggan 's buttons as an actor in every way with heavy criticism, seriousness, and conflict. Riggan's substance abuse daughter Sam played by Emma Stone despises her father & blames him for her inability to move forward in life.  Riggan tries to balance his time spent to discipline the actors to be at the top of their game before the play opens despite personal dramas unfolding backstage, while his daughter is having her own drama...and everything that can go wrong, does go wrong. Managing chaos, being threatened by a New York Times critic who wants to close your show, and the internal doubts about himself as an actor surface right before the opening. See this movie to see how it all comes together on opening night in a spectacular performance that transforms everyone's lives. Michael Keaton is brilliant as Riggan.
Most challenging movie of the year. Acting that wrenches the gut. Terrific camera work. And that drum score? Can't be beat.

I guess I didn't get it. So many fantastic reviews but the movie I saw wasn't the one that I read about. I wanted to enjoy it but the love just wasn't there for me and it left a jerky unconnected feeling.
Sucked big donkey nuts. Academy award for best picture??? Horrible.

This film is shot to feel like one continuous take which is not just creative and impressive, but also creates a voyeuristic feel which is exciting and real.

Edward Norton steals the show as an actor who is entirely committed to his craft, often in hilariously inappropriate ways. Keaton is inconsistent with his performance, but also offers up some terrific moments. Emma Stone is her usual solid self.

Birdman fulfills it's potential and shows everyone just how enjoyable, powerful, and unique a film can be when the whole team is firing on all cylinders. From the lighting  to the camera work, to set design, to the writing and acting, Birdman did it well.

This movie reminded me of a Fosse play.. really amazing shots and settings. It remined me of a stage play, even when the shots were in the streets. Acting was superb, sound effects were amazing. Only a few scenes where the dialog was difficult to hear clearly. Everything was great except for the story... story? No story, just a bleak. dirty look at life with everyone on the wrong track.  The Alien hates this world and leaves it, leaving all his s**t behind. No redeming qualities, just a horrible, empty look at life. In these times, I don't need that, enuf around me in reality; I'd rather concentrate on finding the light in this darkness.

Birdman is smashing, just smashing. Director Alejandro González Iñárritu (Babel and Biutiful) leaps into creative mode with this juicy, ambitious, powerhouse story, Birdman. 

Going into Birdman I had no idea what to expect from this film, but coming out of the theater I couldn't help but keep an enormous grin on my face. So let me break it down to you in several parts to show you how memorizing this film really is. The first part is the star stunning performances of Michael Keaton, Edward Norton, Emma Stone, Naomi Watts, Zach Galifianakis, Amy Ryan, and Andrea Riseborough.  All performed to the fullest extent of perfection. Birdman is a Broadway satire and black comedy all in one, hint its subtitle: An Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance. 

Riggan Thomson (Keaton) is a washed up actor who has fallen into hard times since he stopped playing his iconic superhero, Birdman, sum 20 years ago. Sound familiar? I thought so, this film actually parallels right with Keaton's real life when he played the Caped Crusader in Tim Burton's Batman sum 20 years ago.  With two Batman films under his belt Keaton stopped and tried to move on to something else, but nothing came. The same goes for Riggan, after completing the Birdman trilogy Riggan called it quits to move on to bigger and better things, but still nothing came. 

Keaton knows what it is like to be in a slum in the acting business, while also trying to move on from those damn tights in the past. Riggan is trying to get back on track with his acting career and makes a gusty call by writing, directing and starring in his own Broadway debut of Raymond Carver's What We Talk About When We Talk About Love. His inspiration of the play and becoming an actor was influenced by none other than Carver himself. Riggan states that Carver apparently caught him, as a youngin, on the stage years back and wrote "Thank you for an honest performance. Raymond Carver" on a cocktail napkin. Keaton goes all out in his tour de force performance in this film. 

 Which leads us to the rest of Iñárritu's stellar cast. There's Norton who gives us an award-worthy achievement as Mike Shiner, a Broadway actor whose ego is as big as his talent. With his mocks of mainstream media he drives Riggan off the wall and when the two clash it's hilarious. Stone plays Riggan's daughter Sam, a recovering junkie. Stone is raw and vibrant as the daughter who was over shadowed by her dad's acting past and tells him he doesn't exist anymore because he didn't adapt to the viral world. Galifianakis breaks out of his comedic form to a more dignified role as Riggan's loyal producer. Next, there's Watts and Riseborough who are both trying to shine as young actresses, but Riseborough is a little distracted because she's too busy screwing Riggan. Finally, there's Ryan, Riggan's ex-wife, who's trying to bring balance to her family and a self-doubtful man whom she still cares about. 

The second part is on a technical scale because Birdman blows every film out of the water this year. This film was shot too look like one meandering continuous take. This technical showcase was executed brilliantly by camera genius Emmanuel Lubezki (Oscar winner for Gravity). This aspect in the film, of course, is a major key to its glorious success. We follow all of the characters continuously throughout the film as their stories unfold right before our very eyes. The film smoothly veers from Riggan's reality to his imagination and back again with no breaks ... it's breathtaking to watch on screen. Iñárritu throws us into the mist of Riggan's craziness all throughout the film. One minute we are levitating off the ground too performing a play on stage too flying high above Manhattan. All of these illusion's are pouring right out of Riggan's head and blooming perfectly on screen. 

The third part of this film that amazed me was its layered storytelling. Keaton's narration is spot on and gives the film a since of ooh and aah. From the moment Keaton brings out his Birdman voice you're hooked. Birdman gives Riggan hell and continues to stress him out until he gets to the point of a nervous breakdown in the film. Is he mad? A narcissist? A lunatic? Or just an actor? Either way, Keaton is potent and gives his best performance of his career. I'm smelling Oscar bait right here. The forth part that made this film vibe is the music. There's nothing but powerful drumming throughout the film, which drives Birdman to not fly but soar. Drummer Antonio Sánchez gave us a lively and upbeat soundtrack that jazzed me up. 

Lastly, this all couldn't have been done without the mind power behind the camera and that's Iñárritu himself. This bold and beautifully captured film shows the human side of actors and their fight for survival on and off the stage. Iñárritu didn't just create a film; he created a high and flying masterpiece that is sure to get lots of Oscar love this February. Birdman is a creatively risky work of art painted right on screen. Birdman is solidly performed, shot and executed from beginning until end. Plus there's tons of laugh out loud moments evenly placed throughout. You'll laugh until your sides hurt. It's one of my favorite films of the year and receives the highest of highs ... five out of five stars. This is a film that will be talked about for years to follow. So brace yourself and buy a ticket now.
Superb avant-garde cinematography and exclusively percussion soundtrack.  Wonderful performances.  Keaton is superb.  Highly recommended.

Surprisingly funny, emotionally relevant, and not overly complicated, the subtlety of "Birdman", and amazing performances from its entire cast make this the most thought-provoking film to come out all year.

Absolutely the biggest piece of garbage I've ever seen. I watched it twice to give it a fair chance and it was worse the second time. Stop getting obsessed with the names Keaton and Norton... This movie sucks.
Incredibly innovative and superbly acted by Keaton, Stone, Norton, Watts, and Galifianakis. Don't be a fool. See this now.
Highly original in style and genuinely jawdropping in places, it may be a little too overstuffed with ideas. But it's so well acted by Keaton, Norton and the rest, it is hard to not feel impressed.
Michael Keaton is back!

Well, that was, um... Different. 
Stellar performances, but the style of shoving the camera right in the actors' faces while they bared their souls and/or ripped their scene partner a new asshole got rather repetitive.
Birdman was an ok movie. It had really good acting, story, and a moral to the story but it wasn't oscar worthy in my opinion. Michael Keaton and Edward Norton were great.

'Birdman' is brilliant on all technical levels, but the characters and the performances are what breath life into the layers of surreality. This labyrinth of a film would make Borges cry with appreciation.
odd, very dry, weird humour. wouldn't recommend to see...

Strange. The very good acting, casting, camera work and the editing .. These alone will win it awards, for that reason it's three stars otherwise it would be two. Worth seeing but be warned its not an action hero movie or a comedy as four young lads who came to it thought. Watch the trailer and don't just look at the title n poster. Oh and look out for The Shining corridor carpet shot... I so wanted to leap up and shout "The Shining Hotel" while pointing at the screen. Nice.
Birdman is easily the best film of the year. In sharp contrast to what one may expect, the film is genuine throughout, with no pretentiousness in sight.
Beautifully shot, great acting, amazingly uninspiring and dull movie..

An extended camera trick with people acting really hard in front of it. It craps on superhero movies, yet the best part of the film is why they spoof the genre - until that gets ruined with some flying metaphor. Artsy fartsy nonsense.
Love the drum score that backed the film...overall better than I could have expected. Great cast and twists I didn't see coming from the start.
Excellent cinematography and a deep story line, completed with superb acting makes this one of the best movies of the year.

Alejandro González Iñárritu's latest film attempts to be many things - an "All About Eve"-esque backstage drama, a biting satire of social media, a Michael Keaton biopic, a magical realist fable, and a jab at blockbuster action films. That this film not only succeeds at this, but triumphs, is just one of the reasons for its extraordinariness. Phenomenally performed by a cast at the top of their games (Michael Keaton achieves near-brilliance, and Edward Norton and Emma Stone in particular are phenomenal) and shot in a simulated-one-take that trumps "Goodfellas" and even Hitchcock's "Rope," the film is endlessly inventive in its exploration of an actor on the verge of a nervous breakdown. It is merciless in its ridicule of all aspects of the entertainment industry, even going so far as to take jabs at itself. Yet somehow it revitalizes one's faith in all aspects of film, and that (in addition to all that other stuff it's trying to do) is no small feat.

Artsy is good. Even Fartsy is good. Artsy-Fartsy? That's bad. Like this film. Reminded me of a high school production. Trying to be soooo deep but ends up just being a  heavy-handed piece of schlock. It's greatest sin: It's boring. Too bad. I really wanted to like it.
A hard look into a reflection I didn't know I had. Ambitious project with great character work complementing each other actors performance and the underlying turmoil they all face
That one guy on the drums tho...

Michael Keaton as Adam West. Also Bruce Banner and Bruce Wayne having drinks. 

It's got some funny moments, some wtf moments, and it's all wrapped in an honest depiction of an aging superstar pouring everything into a passion project in its last days before opening night. The feeling of the movie being one Long Take is different.

Powerful performances but despite this, I really, really did not like this film which I found confusing, overly ambitious and very long.  It is not a black comedy, it is just black and the most damning comment I can make is that despite the fact the acting is terrific, I just didn't care a whit for the characters; they are not engaging on any level.

My wife and I went into the theatre with somewhat vague expectations about "Birdman"...which is appropriate given the film's sub-title.  The film's gimmick is its faux continuous one long take.  Though it's fairly clear where the director subtly transitions from one take to the next, it's still very effective.  The film also feels like a play, which itself is about a make or break new Broadway play.  That's quite interesting too.  The film follows former action star (of the superhero Birdman series, played by Michael Keaton) who's trying to make a comeback as  a real actor.  He's on the verge of a mental breakdown.  There's a lot of tension, the actors are great, the dialogue is sharp and the direction takes chances.  I felt an edge-of-the-seat excitement as to what to expect next.  I found the ending a bit disappointing, the dark humour was OK,  while the one-take shtick was at times distracting.  I liked it.  My wife gave it a "meh" much like much of the audience.

Birdman is the best movie I have seen in a long time.  See it in the theater.  When was the last time you were watching a movie and you suddenly realized that the SOUND track was remarkably well crafted?  Every aspect of this movie stands out as exceptional.  'Nuff said.
http://www.santuariodomestreryu.com.br/2015/02/sessao-critica-birdman-ou-inesperada.html
Michael Keaton's performance was Killer!
Keaton was great. Overall a very solid movie. Karen did not like; said it was "too gritty" for her.

Who's truth is the real truth? Is it the artist's interpretation or is it the viewer? These questions won't be answered nor should they be when amazing technique and great choices are made in a performance. And what a performance from the entire cast. Extremely engaging and thrillingly entertaining. If you like great movies, this is one to add to the 'must see' list.

This is an interesting and bizarre film.  If you are a fan of the offbeat, indie film that makes you think, this is a good option.  It's funny, confusing, and thought-provoking.  At first I was bothered by the odd camera angles until I realize that artistically it really made you think because the reactions that you CAN'T see are more fascinating than what you are watching.  This is not a hand-fed film, this is something that requires some consideration on the audience's part.  There are blurred lines between fantasy and reality and some fascinating character actions.  Edward Norton and Emma Stone really stand out and Michael Keaton may be nominated for an Oscar for this one.  It's fascinating if a bit off-putting at times.  I really enjoyed the film overall.
Great cinematography. An actor's film to enjoy and nicely performed all around. Oh, it was also boring and pointless drivel.

Birdman stars Michael Keaton, Edward Norton, and Emma Stone. Birdman is about Briggin Thompson, a washed up actor from the 80's and 90's who played an iconic Superhero named Birdman during that time. He tries to mount a comeback by writing and staring in his own Broadway play. This movie is fantastic. From the acting to even the way it is filmed. This movie is made to look like one continuous shot and will pan not cut from scene to scene which makes this film feel original and unique. The acting is superb not one bad performance. Stands are Keaton, Norton, and Stone. It is interesting how this film has so much social commentary on media and critics. Overall Birdman will be a front runner for many Oscars especially best in the visual and acting department. It is a must see for movie lovers and I guarantee it will walk away with an award of some kind by the end of this movie season.
Love it! Great performances, crazy camera work. A story that is captivating to the end
"Is that alright? I was trying to you range."

Bravo, Michael Keaton! One of the most underrated actors of our time delivers an absolute tour de force. Without giving away too much, the movie moves seamlessly from its focus on the great cast to being wholly within the mind the protagonist Regan Thomas (Keaton). The cinematography is beautiful with a range of long, uninterrupted shots that take you through a journey of joy, anger, sadness, despair, and back to joy. Everything about the movie screams 'inside joke' (Ex. Keaton, the Batman of the 90's, playing a washed up actor who played a superhero), but much like the premise of this movie, Keaton creates a stage (pun intended) to explore his acting range, and uses it perfectly.
Too depressing for me.

Birdman is a blast of style, humor and pathos with each of the people involved giving their all. It's undeniably funny and weird in all the right ways. Even though, in some of its bigger themes, its reach exceeds its grasp, it's still an invigorating story about show-business and where we should find our worth.

Great acting...loved the depiction of what goes on when you're on stage vs. off stage. Michael Keaton, where have you been all my life? Glad you're back because you rocked! Edward Norton, Emma Stone, and Naomi Watt also fabulous.
A ton of fun. Wonderfully shot. Long takes everywhere - no jump cuts or quick edits here.

This movie is a masterpiece and it isn't afraid to let you know... and beat you over the head with it. This is truly one of the most innovated and all together beautifully strung pictures to hit the circuit in a long time. The acting is superb from all the usual suspects but the stand out performance, a surprise one, comes from Emma Stone. She fearlessly steals every scene she's in and even gives the chewing Ed Norton a run for his balls. 

Technically, it's amazing. Don't think for a second this won't get nominated for best score, editing, directing, cinematography, of course script, and sound. The top four will be covered. This movie IS the quintessential Oscar worth choice. It covers all it's bases, unique, inspiring, ground breaking, gorgeous, fun, funny, timely, meta, etc, etc, etc.
It's one and only fault is... it knows this. This almost perfect masterpiece is too self aware to let the audience savor it and insists on delving into the arthouse form of guessing and forgoeing nuance for the sake of commentary that MUST be discussed outside the film. Director Trademark: Pretentious overambition.
Michael Keaton is back!
Spectacular. The cinematography suits the tone and elicits a plethora of emotions as you watch it. One of the best films of the year, and featuring AMAZING performances.
This darkly funny and deeply tragic comedy turns a new leaf for director Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu, and Michael Keaton delivers the performance of a lifetime
Has to be one of the best films of 2014/15 utterly brilliant.

With a captivating performance from Michael Keaton, this film is a big contender for me as best of 2014. Thought-provoking and unsettling, the film deals with questions surrounding the need for validation or admiration from others, the significance of individuals, and the strive to make a meaningful existence. Another stand-out aspect was a particular monologue from Emma Stone, which was explosive and impacting. Finally, the repetitive score was haunting, marking a sense of urgency or madness that led to the film's final moments.
The degree to which the director relies on shiny objects and technical novelty is a tell on how little substance there is in this story.

Irreverent, sublimely casted and with content that felt so sincere you couldn't help but be drawn in. This movie though not what i expected was absolutely amazing and hands down the best film ive seen in the last 5 years. The selection for actors matched with the characters they played created a completely realistic and spot on depiction of the relations that are so identifiable to each and every one of us. Amazing movoe you must see you will be grasping to guess each new twist and turn. Side note the way in which it was shot was beautiful it was the first time a thrid person view felt natural to me in a movie.
Not really entertaining but certainly a display of brilliant acting. The kind of movie you may think you don't like, but find yourself talking about it days after.

A fascinating tale of the life of a not too stable artist trying to get back on his feet. Keaton delivers a thrillingly manic-depressive performance in a film that is both funny and sad, and almost always crazy! The magic act comes when you actually start to believe the crazy might be real (a question I truly do not know the answer to)
Senseless and baseless
The more I think about it, the more I relate this film, with it's extensive use of symbolism and art, to something you could read in a literature class in the future. Amazingly well crafted.

A little on the head at times, but that's part of what makes it so good.

I really enjoyed this movie. It was beautifuly shot, wonderfully acted and deep. Holy cow, its deep. It took me a while to decide whether I loved this movie or not.  The more you think about it, the more you admire it. In fact, I want to go see it again. That being said, this movie is strange. It is soooo weird.  This movie contains some of the best monologues put to film I have seen. You may not like it, because it is abnormal, but you can't deny it's originality  and credit as a smooth and well articulated film.

I personally am a fan of both the artsy and the fartsy. Objectively speaking, you'd probably have to be. Even I took issue with the final moment. But I love insider views of the workings of the processes of acting and staging plays. And the performances are smart, the writing is insightful of the characters, and the photographic structure was wowza.
Too "artistic" for me. Was a good movie until the last 15 minutes, then it got weird. Really weird. Edward Norton and Emma Stone were excellent!  Michael Keaton, not so much.
Excelente. Maravillosa. Innovadora. Creativa. CrÃ­tica. Una obra de arte.
There you go, you motherfucker.
Absolutely outstanding performance by Michael Keaton, my Oscar pick, and fantastic performance from Edward Norton and Emma Stone. Seriously, what a genius movie.
Unlike anything before it. It's almost as if Black Swan and Jazz Music had a baby.

Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu's Birdman or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance) is the best movie of the year from now.  The outstanding cast is doing an awesome job.  It's fun, original and intelligent.  His photography is so ambitious and it works all the movie long.

This may be my favorite film of 2014. Emmanuel Lubezki is the best cinemotographer out there. Emma Stone was amazing. This film had me sitting with an empty beer for almost its entirety. Yes. It was that good.

A film so beautifully shot I was entranced from the first frame to the last. Alejandro González Iñárritu has made a truly remarkable piece of art, a magnificent blend of real and the surreal, creating a film that seems to live and breathe in imagination with hints of magical realism. A film about struggling to become relevant and being scared of fading into existence, about taking the easy way out, or striving toward your true potential. A story so interesting and heartfelt that is made even better by the phenomenal acting from Michael Keaton, Edward Norton, and Emma Stone. Birdman was so wonderfully Meta and fresh, it has the opportunity to revolutionize the process of filmmaking. Birdman is a snapshot of the convoluted and dog eat dog world which is the current culture of Hollywood and blockbusters, and it's honesty makes it a modern day masterpiece in the making.

The first thing you'll notice in this film is the amazing cinematography and directing. The incredibly long shots make this film about a play feel like a film of a play. Keaton and Norton are fantastic, but everyone on screen deserves a lot of credit for making a movie with virtually no cuts look so smooth. The story is bizarre, but also thought-provoking with a lot of humor mixed in. The writing is not this movie's strong suit, and that hurts it, but this one is to be admired for the actors and the cameramen.

Quirky, unpredictable, and skillfully acted by Keaton amongst others, Birdman is the best film I've seen in 2014 so far, surpassing Gone Girl. Very impressive camera work and narrative flow, too. I've seen nothing like it before. Go see it at once, Eveningstar Cinema.
A little heavy handed but still fun to watch
Came off pretentious.  Some good performances, technically ambitious, but definitely less than the sum of its parts.  Way less.
I couldn't even wrap my head around this film. I only liked the music and how the camera was like always following and never off

Brilliant.  Every frame is like a work of cinematic art.  Keaton gives an award worthy performance that should absolutely be his comeback as an A-lister.  The way he and Norton send-up their own Hollywood personas adds something special to an already excellent film.
Brilliant performances and admirable ambition can't make up for a meandering story and unbearable pretension.

Meta. That's the best word to describe this movie. It's a movie that is so self-aware of its existence as a deconstruction of artist vs celebrity vs film vs theatre that art itself is placed in front of a mirror and mocked as it is simultaneously lauded. 

This movie couldn't have worked if it weren't for the brilliant casting, especially that of Michael Keaton. In a brave performance, Keaton gives us a character that could just as well be Keaton himself. In fact, that could be said of Edward Norton, playing an actor who is known for not getting along well with castmates. 

This movie shows the intimacy of theatre and the power of the movies. It shows the way dialogue and visual effects help tell a narrative without dismissing either. It shows how the cynicism of believing one form of art to be better than another is as foolish as it is short-sighted
This movie is not for everyone but definitely for me.  Keaton is superb as interest of the cast. A movie to savor.
That was a really original movie, crazy and really good.

Wow. What a fantastic movie. Fantastically acted, technically brilliant, and a script that offers such incredible substance. Give all the Oscars to "Birdman."

Sometimes reminiscent of "Black Swan," "All That Jazz," and "Network," like those others it's an incomparable and  seminal film that's utterly original and will be studied by filmmakers for years to come.  Daring, experimental, and sometimes bewildering, it's simultaneously intimate and melodramatically thespian, with the cinematic smoke-and-mirrors compelling us into a jaded post-millenial examination of fame, personal identity, and the shifting truths of our values.  

With its theatrical setting, structural gymnastics, and thematic density, "Birdman" may hold its greatest appeal only for audiences deeply familiar with the parallel worlds of stage and film.  However, the tour-de-force performances here, especially of Michael Keaton, aren't to be missed.
Funny, smart, and raw.
Highly introspective and poignantly emotional, punctuated by committed acting and an ever more committed (art) direction

There's a definite Oscar-contender, if for nothing else than originality. A film that's almost one dolly shot, with smart edits to maintain the continuity. A musical score made up almost entirely of drums. Michael Keaton, Ed Norton, Emma Stone and Naomi Watts are all brilliant, as is the script, which is funny, and satirical. Smart and artful movie with standout performances from Stone, Keaton, & Norton as well as a great soundtrack that encompassed the whole tone of the movie. Birdman felt very similar to the Black Swan, but more chaotic.

I honestly didn't know what to expect with a cast like this, and the rumor of a non-stop camera take. First of all, the cast made this film come to life. From the quick little comedic bits of Zach Galifianakis's hilarious supporting role to the believable daughter role created ever-so-brilliantly by Emma Stone, this film delivers the perfect amount of comedy, drama, action, and even tragedy. But the true highlights of this film are from the two leading men, Michael Keaton and Edward Norton. Norton creates a character that the audience just loves to hate, and then loves to love at the end. A supporting actor nomination and even win are VERY likely for him. As for Keaton, I have never seen an actor as dedicated or believable as he in this film. He truly comes to life in this film and in my mind, deserves the Oscar right now...why wait till Spring?! There are plenty of films about "washed up actors" or "wannabe stars," but Keaton takes it to the next level, bringing tears, laughs, and emotion to the audience in the most believable way. Believability, in my mind, is vital, and Keaton nails it to the bone. Aside from the acting, the cinematography that Birdman offers, as well as the (less than) five minutes of special effects, are truly breathtaking. For those of you who don't know, the entire film is done in ONE take, even transitioning from night to day, without cutting the camera ONCE. Seeing the camera seamlessly transition between scenes makes the whole thing seem real and like you're literally walking through the hallways and backstage of the St. James theatre. Everything about the writing, cinematography, and acting, make Birdman a must see, and create a LEGEND out of Michael Keaton. Watch out for this film come Oscar time, for you'll see it on the list in MANY places.
The film is shot in continuous takes, which is impressive enough but when you realize the pressure it put on the actors, it is all the more amazing. Michael Keaton and Edward Norton are both amazing.

Ver la pelicula desde el contexto de los treintas te da la oportudidad de recordar que viejo eres, jajajaja, para mi Batman siempre sera Keaton.

The subplots were just more "I'm AFU, You're AFU"  and did not draw me into any sympathy as to why they got AFU, especially the daughter.    It was a movie who's category is: YCHIBINYCT&ATI. Easily in my top three of the year. Michael Keaton plays a has been super hero actor (think Val Kilmer as Batman, now) who wants to prove his legitimacy by producing, directing and starring in a serious Ray Carver play on Broadway.
What ensues is the battling if his own sub-conscious and demons from his last and present. A wide array of actors throughout the movie who turn in magnificent performances. 
The tracking shots alone are crazy and demand respect with how they are placed throughout the film and how each actor delivers their lines while in them.
This film is not for everyone. In fact it is probably not for a lot of general audience members who will probably find it not to their liking but if you give it a chance and like the out of the way movie this may become one of your favorites.

Let me gush up front. I loved this movie. I don't want say too much so I'll do my best to give an enthusiastic recommendation without spoilers.

Written by Alejandro González Iñárritu (who also directed), Nicolas Giacobone, Alexander Dinelaris and Armando Bo, Birdman is one of the best movies I've seen all year. Warning, you do need an attention span and your forebrain to fully appreciate it. Critics who called this a fiasco or godawful mess need a check up from the neck up.

It stars Michael Keaton, Zach Galifianakis, Edward Norton, Andrea Riseborough, Amy Ryan, Emma Stone and Naomi Watts. This is truly an ensemble cast with a 5? intense, complex, layered, tortured performance by Keaton as Riggan Thompson who was the titular character in several blockbuster action movies back in the day. I was particularly impressed by the subdued, leveled acting accomplishment delivered by Galifianakis. His almost unrecognizable presence reminded me of how Philip Seymore Hoffman would have done it given the chance. I hope he gets more roles like this.

The film flows in real time and is beautifully edited to invite viewers into the room as a participant. Up close shots and intimate angles gave me the feeling that I was part of character's conversations...even the ones in their heads.

The cinematography and set design brought me into the claustrophobic banality of an actor's life backstage in the narrows of labyrinth hallways, cramped dressing rooms, and dark interconnect stairways doubling as access and refuge.

I've commented in recent posts like Gone Girl and Listen Up Philip on how poorly the disembodied voiceover is used in movies. More annoying and distracting than informative or useful. In this case it really worked as Riggan questions his abilities, reality and the world around him folding in while he tries to break free from the restraints of recognition. Both his own inner voice and that of the imagined superhero Birdman, bully, coach, haunt, mock, taunt and confuse him as he searches for validity as a performer, maybe even as a man.... via writing, directing and acting in a Broadway play about love. He's desparate for authenticity in a world of make believe littered with broken relationships and regret. Yet he struggles through, driven by conviction.

The tense power dynamic between stage and screen principle actors, supporting performers and the behind the scenes crew who have to nurture their fragile egos, and critics, is crackling good.

The thing for me that works about this film is the vulnerability each character shares. Beneath obvious talent and disagreeable exteriors they are believably flawed, and scared so it made me care about what happened to them.

Ironically, we all know Keaton played Batman back in the day. He looks like an actor who once had 'that career'. The competition between him and the younger Norton (playing the 'real' Broadway leading man the play needs for gravitas) is a scab that is always being picked.

At one point the story reminded me of Top 5, a brilliant comedy by Chris Rock I saw at the 2014 Toronto International Film Festival. In both cases, the main characters struggle to shake off previous acting roles by taking a daring risk in their careers. Rock has a muse in Top 5 but Keaton only has voices battling in his head. Both films are darkly funny with great dialogue. But Birdman has some touches of fantasy that break the momentum with questions best left unanswered (you'll understand when you see it).

Birdman is a Phoenix for both Keaton and my movie going experience. Do yourself a favor, and go.
