The first thing I realize after watching this movie was, the people who made this really love cinema, with a passion. As an art and as vision for expression. 

I'm not going to lie, the 'gimmick' of the movie does and a lot to it. The fact that its shot and edited to look like one single long take for most of it, does add a new layer of depth to it. Taking that away would have lessened the film a bit. Yet, the story and acting are fantastic on their own, so the adding of the cinematic style is a plus but not necessary. 

That's what you must keep in mind when you film a movie with a 'gimmick.' It must work outside of said 'gimmick.' Blair Witch works outside of the found footage angle, Pulp Fiction mostly works outside of being out on chronological sync (for the most part), and Birdman works without the long take aspect. But it helps, dear God it helps.
One of the best movies I've seen all year.

Starting off this is probably THE best movie of 2014. I would rank this somewhere close to the top five films I have personally ever seen, so before you read my in-depth and SPOILER-filled review I would recommend seeing this masterpiece of a film, it is truly cinematic perfection. 

On to the review, this movie by Alejandro Inarritu is amazing. Under the genre "black comedy" it takes advantage of poking fun at things other movies won't like murder, sex, racism and other touchy topics. This is what separates this movie apart from others in terms of comedic taste and substance. 

The actors in this movie are plenty: Micheal Keaton, Emma Stone, Naomi Watts, Zach Galifanakis and the man who stole the show: Edward Norton. Everyone did a suburb job, and they had to, but I will touch on that in a second. Keaton had an exceptional performance as a washed up actor living out his dreams as a Broadway director, writer and actor and then on top of that being a father to a recovering drug addict (Emma Stone). Emma Stone is amazing as well, her body is more slim than her other roles and she fits the part well and adjusted accordingly to play her part as a drug addict. Her monologues with Edward Norton are amazing and hold true value and meaning to them. Now to being on Mr. Norton. God is this man funny. Norton stole the show with his amazing performance and his comedic timing, i don't know if it was a good script or his improvisation was just on point for this film but damn, he was amazing throughout. 

Now for the most astonishing point of the movie: it was filmed in "one-shot" takes. The first hour of the movie is one shot. No cuts, no editing the order, one long shot without these actors messing up. It is amazing what Mr. Inarritu did with this and it was so fun to watch as the camera panned around to add new characters in the scene and to remove them, to show the passing of time and other things that a movie would normally cut to. IT was visually pleasing and so much fun to watch as i stated earlier. 

To end, I will be seeing it again in the near future. It will be an instant download and a movie I will watch, and laugh at for years to come. A 5/5 from me, its beautiful film making and I hope to see more of Mr. Inarritu's work soon.
Alejandro Gonzalez Birdman is one of the most innovatively ingenious films of the 21st century, but without Emmanuel Lubezki behind the camera, Gonzalez vision wouldve never been fully realized.

Promising director Alejandro González Iñarritu has been known for making dramatic and depressive films so when it was announce that he was going to make a comedy about a wash-up superhero starring Michael Keaton, it surprised audiences but "Birdman" manage to become one of the best films of 2014 with overwhelming reviews. Is this films as good as most critics say it is?   
 Riggan Thompson is a washed-up Hollywood actor who once played the superhero Birdman but twenty years later Riggan´s career has been almost eradicated. Decided to reinvent his career, Riggan decides to take Raymond Craver´s short story "What We Talk about When We Talk about Love" and make it a Broadway play with him as writer, director and protagonist. Soon the making of this play becomes a complete disaster thus breaking Riggan´s sanity and putting his reputation at the edge of oblivion. 
My fellow countryman Alejandro González Iñarritu surprised audiences with his directorial debut "Amores Perros" and its follow-up "21 Grams" but his other two films were of lower quality but "Birdman" managed to return to his early career quality of filmmaking. The first that needs to be said about "Birdman" is that is not your typical superhero film, it's an expertly made and engaging drama which satirizes modern franchises and the superhero genre in general. "Birdman" counts amazing performances by every single actor of this huge cast with the best being, of course Michael Keaton in a Academy Award caliber performance, which has Keaton using both of his over the top comedic persona and his dramatic acting, followed by Naomi Watts, Edward Norton and Emma Stone; it has a simple but energetic and memorable score, a well written script, hilarious dialog which is surprising considering Iñarritu´s reputation, spot on references, an engaging story, great characters, intriguing character relationships, perfect pacing, beautiful cinematography, a masterfully made mixture of various genres (comedy, drama, satire, "superhero", etc.),  jaw dropping directing, it encapsulates the way theatre works, an expertly executed criticism at today's standers of filmmaking and one of the best filming and editing styles I´ve ever seen, the whole film feels like it was shot as one long tracking shot.
"Birdman" is a film that has everything a great film needs, it's pure cinematic magic and one of the best, if not the best, film of 2014 (my favorite so far and one of the best films I seen in the last few years). I hope the 2015 Academy Awards give "Birdman" the credit it deserves. A must see film!
Filled with rich, single-shot takes and brilliant, multi-faceted dialogue. Brilliant.

I myself will try to forget the scenes including the jellyfish scene in Malibu, which I think was a real confession, but I lived in Malibu, and never got stung once at night. From now on, I will walk out on this, and "Black Swan" crap-like this. Oh and go figure this will do well at the oscars... Shows how lame USA film has become.

You know, for me setting out to see a particular movie, I stay away from reading extensive synopsis, and critical reviews; as they often over-hype the experience of seeing a movie. I like to instead, employ The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance and avoid disappointing expectations. That was a good call today; key to enjoying a spectacular film: BIRDMAN. 

So I sat down and reclined the plush new theater lounge chair, anticipating a lite-hearted story of a washed up superhero and his attempted return to fame. Instead I was transfixed by a seemingly, seamless portrayal of an actor, artist, father, businessman and his world class cast of characters in an amazing satire on showbiz, pop culture, and distorted social trends and internal conflict. I found the film to be a wonderful visit to a poet's surreal sense of artistic integrity vs temptations and anxiety in the quest for fame and fortune; honest brutal truth, reality affecting ego and drive. So, I'm not going to fill YOU in on the storyline, but I will suggest you go in knowing you are about to really love this film or possibly hate it.

Director Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu, Cinematographer Emmanulel Lubezki , have combined talents to produce not only a Biutiful film, but also one with haunting and significant Gravity. Together, director, cinematographer, and an amazingly inventive cast that shines with individual excellence as they each get a shot at Oscar worthy performances support a visual and enlightening work of achievement that may well be controversial on awards night. I'm curious how Hollywood and stage entities may embrace the solid, groundbreaking efforts here.  
You HAVE to see this film if not simply for the talents of Michael Keaton, Edward Norton, Amy Ryan, Naomi Watts, Zach Galifianakis, and in my opinion the greatest effort I've ever seen from Emma Stone- WATCH FOR THAT.

Technical accolades are warranted here too.....A freeform percussive soundtrack drove emotional waves, a slithery camera revealed intimate coverage of the theatrical environment as it often went with long continuous takes. Soft fades and minimal edits were utilized to join surreal ideas with conscious thought; time transition from night into day and back, all drawn and conveyed upon a fine line between reality and illusion allowed the audience to see our own inner Birdman. 

I suggest that anyone who loves seeing good films take a chance... Birdman (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance) should not be missed.
Michael Keaton and Edward Norton have career-best performances in this comedy/drama. Excellent in every way.
Please we need this movie to SWEEP - best in every category - well wait INTERSTELLAR - that is a good race.

Every daring, hilarious, biting, dazzling frame of Birdman is pure movie heaven. Like all films that are allergic to Hollywood bullshit, Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu's cinematic tour de force will bring out those who just don't get it. Screw them. Birdman is bursting through the screen with ideas. You won't know what the fuck hit you.

On the surface, Birdman seems like just a hard-hitting satire of showbiz, but it's only that in the sense that The Dark Knight was just a comic book movie. This is a film centered on art and the act, or at least attempt, at reinvention. Michael Keaton, in an electrifying, volcanic performance is Riggan Thomson, a washed up actor fallen on hard times since he was once on top of the world playing the title superhero in the Birdman trilogy of films that made billions. Sound familiar? Keaton himself of course starred in two acclaimed turns as the Caped Crusader himself in Tim Burton's Batman film, so he knows exactly from what he's acting. Riggan sees his way back into relevance by making his Broaadway debut writing, directing and starring in a stage adaptation of Raymond Carver's What We Talk About When We Talk About Love. It seems Carver saw young Riggan onstage many years ago in which the author sent him a note on a cocktail napkin that read 'Thank you for an honest performance. Ray Carver.'

So that has Riggan trying like hell to be honest on the tightrope of Broadway, where sharp-eyed critics are all too eager to rip movie stars to shreds. It's not all that new in terms of premise but as filtered through the keen eye of this Mexican filmmaking visionary (see Amores Perros, 21 Grams, Babel and Biutiful) and his co-screenwriters Nicholas Giacobone. Alexander Dinelaris Jr. and Armando Bo, everything feels bracingly fresh. As the film's subtitle, The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance, huge blunders can be total freedom and bliss.

One of the strengths of Birdman lies in its visuals, amazingly executed by camera wizard  Emmanuel Lubezki, an Oscar winner for last year's Gravity, to create the illusions that the film is unfolding in one sinuous take. Lubezki's work is stellar, particularly for the way it skillfully allows the film to swing from reality and back again seamlessly so that when Riggan flies above Manhattan and fire balls of flame for his fingers we are also living in his head. Hell the first time we see Riggan he's levitating in his dressing room,listening to the voice of Birdman (Keaton himself in a lower register) who insists he's way too good for these theatre pricks.

That leads to the rest of the cast who all bring their A-games and stress Riggan out as he goes back and forth between narcissism and self-loathing. Zach Galifianakis is outstanding as Riggan's harried lawyer and producer. Naomi Watts is excellent as one of Riggans co-stars, as is Andrea Riseborough as the actress Riggan is getting it on with and Amy Ryan as the ex-wife trying not to see a conflicted man fall deeper into turmoil.

Keaton himself delivers his greatest performance yet, but there's also much to be said of Edward Norton as a volatile, immature Method actor whose talent is as large as his ego. Not to mention a never-better Emma Stone who is just great as Riggan's embittered daughter fresh out of rehab and looking to get Dad hooked on social media where quality is measured by how many 'Likes' you get than anything else.

Above all, Birdman, a dark comedy of desperation bouyed by Inarritu's humanism and optimism, is damn funny and a portrait of someone fallibly human. Birdman is a rollercoaster, pure exhilaration. No one who loves film would miss it.

while the movie-buff me had some minor issues with the goofiness of the gimmicks on display, the theatre-geek me was completely captured by this incredibly well-written (and well-performed - especially by Norton and Keaton) satire.

WOW! Every once in a while there comes a movie that changes cinema itself. Last one to do so was The Artist. (Boyhood should get a side mention here). This movie has just blown my mind. I can write an essay, wait, I can write multiple essays on each shot, but wait, how many shots are there, but wait, I can write multiple essays on each aspect or scene, I don't know! The fact that the only perceptible break in a shot was after he shot himself and the fact that the entire movie is about Theatre VS Film and the fact that its Superheroes vs Realism and the fact that ignorance IS the greatest virtue (for an audience member or an actor!) and the fact that there are just sooooo many facts. A lot different from what I thought it was going to be like. Birdman from director Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu best known for 21 Grams (2003), Babel (2006), and the absolutely stunning Biutiful (2010) brings about a dark comedy that holds its own, but ultimately will not be for everyone. The film in a nut shell is about an actor named Riggan (Michael Keaton) who is adating a novel into a broadway play. Many people think he is a washup and doesn't belong in the theater light because of his past success playing the superhero Birdman. He constantly is breaking down and having his own little crisis going on. The voice of the Birdman keeps telling him what he wants. His agent Jake (Zach Galifianakis) tried to keep him jovial and on he right path, but his two co-stars Mike (Edward Norton who is basically playing a parody of himself since he's known to be difficult to work with) and Lesley (Naomi Watts) are making it ever so difficult. Add to the mix his fresh out of rehab daughter Sam (Emma Stone) is around and constantly a reminder to Riggan about how terrible a father he was. The film is downright an entertaining flick, but many people may think its a bit slow. There's a lot of dialogue (to the point where the film looks like its shot in one long take, so actors had to ham out a lot of dialogue to keep it going). The story has so many allegories and meanings to it that its up to the viewer to decipher them all. What does it all mean and whats the significance of the Birdman? Great way to almost incorporate Keaton's own fame as Batman into the story. Keaton by the way is absolutely brilliant in his role and worth the ticket price alone. Overall, any film buff will enjoy this one and deciphering what it all means.

There was something I felt I was missing from this movie; though I really enjoyed it, I didn't really get the same reaction that it seems like a lot of people have. I certainly don't think it's one of the best movies of 2014.

That being said, this movie was really enjoyable, and really strange. Of course, there's the amazing way it looks like the movie is all (pretty much) one shot, and I'm a sucker for cool cinematography like that. I love that most of the movie takes place in the same claustrophobic set, the various rooms of the theater. Thanks to the cinematography and overall tone, the movie has an immediacy and excitement to it, which also lends it tension going into the performance scenes.

There are lots of great individual scenes, including pretty much any scene with Edward Norton. Emma Stone's performance was also pretty great, especially in that monologue she shouts at Riggan. Oddly, maybe my lack of extreme enthusiasm for the movie was that I enjoyed the scenes with Edward Norton or Emma Stone or much of the rest of the supporting cast more than the scenes with Riggan himself. I liked Riggan's arc, and it certainly comes to a thrilling conclusion, but I more personally connected to and was interested by Mike's ability to be himself on the stage - and his inability to do it off the stage.

There were only two scenes I was iffy about. The first was when Birdman actually takes a physical form and appears next to him, and he begins to fly around New York. It was cool visually, and I'm sure most people would consider that one of the most important/stunning scenes of the movie, but for whatever reason it made me kind of roll my eyes, though I won't deny the over-the-top visual effects as he unleashed his powers and imagination were both awesome and hilarious. The other scene was the one where he skewers the critic, Tabitha. I liked some parts of it; Tabitha obviously deserves it, because she seems like a genuinely bad critic, especially considering she'll write a bad review just because she doesn't like the type of person Riggan is. But that's the thing, I think - Tabitha's problem is that she's a bad person and bad critic, not that she IS a critic. Riggan denouncing criticism altogether was a tad annoying in the same way that Jon Favreau's character was irritating when he did it in Chef. Just because he's the one that creates the art doesn't mean that it's noble to try to dissect it or explain its virtues/failings to audiences.

Altogether, though, this was a really fun movie to watch, with lots of great visuals (so many wide-angle shots) and a really great atmosphere to spend some time in. I definitely want to watch it again, or maybe even just read the script.

This is the best movie I have seen in a long, long time.  The pacing of this movie is fucking brilliant.  It's very much a type of old school stage comedy where you'd follow a conversion through a door, and another one would start from out of another door.  The camera-work and angles were fantastic.  Shot very much at eye-level or angling up, which lent energy and a great sense of perspective to the film.  The dialogue was just a tick behind Grand Budapest Hotel, which still makes it excellent.  And the acting was exceptional.  The first half of the movie was owned by Ed Norton (who I consider a top 5 actor in the business), and the second half was dominated by Michael Keaton.  Both put on one of their best performances of their respective careers.  The supporting cast was outstanding as well.  Both Emma Stone and Naomi Watts nail their parts, and their is chemistry between all the actors from scene to scene.  Even Zach Galifianakis was good - and he's not a favorite of mine.  The more I think about the ending, the more I love it.  Coming out of the theater, I wasn't sure how to interpret it - but I feel I now have the correct interpretation (at least for myself), and I love it.  I won't spoil anything, but the final scene to me isn't what it appears.  This is my only 10/10 film this year and probably in the last couple of years.

A triumph in filmmaking, Birdman is gripping and relentless from the get go, the one cut feel achieved by really long takes forcefully involve you in every little detail and demand your absolute focus and make you sit on the edge of your seat as you try and keep up with the film's layered plot. Only a genius would make use of such limited shooting space like this, given that most of the movie takes place in a theatre and the rest is just a few blocks away from the theatre, and use it in such a way to show how this is all that's needed, all that this is about, all that matters. Furthermore, Michael Keaton, Edward Norton, Emma Stone and Naomi Watts deliver such raw performances in a movie that blur the lines between what's real and what's not, noting how the play is a mirror image of Michael Keaton's character's life, and how the whole plot is like a mirror image of Michael Keaton's real life. A film about what truly matters, fame or respect, love or absolute love. A film that commands both love AND admiration. A masterpiece.
Add me to the chorus... The first true masterpiece in a year full of solid but unspectacular or slightly flawed movies.  Rarely is a film so striking in its originality, so perfect in its execution.

"Theatrical" is the word I would use to describe Birdman.  ("Pretentious" is one that less impressed critics would give it.)  Most of the action of this dark comedy takes place in a theater, as our has-been protagonist attempts to jumpstart his career on Broadway.  But the reason I used this word is a result of the one camera focus - using one long, continuous take - and the almost improvised and organic feel to the dialogue.  The soundtrack consists mostly of restless jazz percussion and the audience gets a real feel and flavor for Manhattan (which are two things the film has in common with Whiplash).  Michael Keaton returns to a starring role as a sympathetic, humorous, and self-absorbed person.  He seems to enjoy himself and all the neuroses his character carries with him.  Honorable mentions are in order for Emma Stone, Edward Norton, and Zach Galifianakis.  There are also elements of magical realism, with flights of fancy and telekinesis showing up randomly.  How literal these moments are to be taken is up to the interpretation of the viewer and this feeds into the ambiguous, but emotionally satisfying ending.  This could well end up a best picture nominee with some nods for performances and more importantly, it is a pleasant character study unafraid to satirize the entertainment industry and artistic integrity.

A lot has been said about this movie, and I won't really say anything differentely. This is an excellent example of how to make an 'artsy' film! I'd like to talk about the directing first. He feels so real in this movie, like Riggan is really him. Also want to point out the role of Emma Stone and Edward Norton who were also terrific! Now for the story. The story is very strange. Riggan Thomson (Michael Keaton) is a Hollywood has-been who's famous for having played comic book superhero "Birdman" in three blockbuster movies twenty years ago. (What the hell kind of a name is "Riggan" for a guy in his 60s who was born before parents thought it was their duty to be creative in the assignment of monikers?)

Though the general public would go wild about a "Birdman IV", Riggan has cast aside his Hollywood roots and is attempting to write, direct, and star in a highbrow Broadway play that no one particularly wants to see.
 
Riggan appears to have mental issues. He's regularly taunted by the voice of his Birdman alter-ego (who sounds kind of like the Simpsons character "Duffman") who thinks Riggan's current endeavor is beneath him. He also has either real or imagined superpowers:  we see him flying, levitating, and moving objects with his mind. 

The film focuses on the several days leading up to the play's premiere. Things are not going well. Riggan's lawyer best friend Jake (Zach Galifianakis), who's producing it as a favor to him, is forced to deal with both legal issues and budget overruns. One of the actors is replaced at the last minute with the talented but temperamental Mike (Edward Norton). In addition to being difficult to work with, Mike, who's involved with one of the plays actresses, is also putting the moves on Riggan's young daughter Sam (Emma Stone), a recovering addict who works as Riggan's assistant. Riggan is also unhappily involved with one of the actresses and his ex-wife makes regular set appearances.  Adding to his stress, a NY Times theater critic has informed him that she has the power to make the play fail and she intends to do so, sight unseen, because he's a Hollywood interloper.

Though it's a very inventive movie, I didn't love "Birdman" quite as much as everyone else seems to. Not much to fault about the film itself, more just one of those "cup of tea" things.  The soundtrack - one big long drum solo with occasional staccato symbol smashes - was really getting on my nerves. I'm sure it's supposed to add to the tension but I sometimes found myself focusing more on the annoying drummer than the movie itself. 

I also wasn't wild about the who's-bedding-whom side plots or the many frenetic backstage encounters, preferring the scenes with more substantive one-on-one dialog, especially between Riggan and Sam. But my biggest gripe, and one that I assume I share with many others, is the movie's strange ending which will quite likely leave you scratching your head for days.

Much the same way a thimble-sized nesting doll finds itself coated inside layer after layer of something more than merely larger aspects of itself, BIRDMAN or The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance has the ability to plant itself deep in the viewer's heart and mind.

Director Alejandro Iñárritu drives the film's development along with vigor--an energy that he instills into Keaton, Stone and the supporting cast. Through the use of a much-enjoyed-by-this-movie-goer shooting technique Iñárritu doesn't let the camera, nor the characters take nary a breath, in effect passing on the experience to the viewer.

Awkward, raw, deliberate and fantastical--just what entertainment needs going into this blockbuster holiday movie season.

Hace un año por estás fechas, Alfonso Cuaron sorprendía al mundo con Gravity y su pequeña historia de 90 minutos con grandes efectos especiales triunfo en taquilla y en los Oscar.  Pero lo que hizo Alejandro González Iñarritu con Birdman es técnicamente superior y complejamente más exquisita.
La edición es una obra maestra, parece que fue grabada en una sola secuencia, una sola toma que dura 60 minutos en donde la cámara se mueve con mucha agilidad siguiendo a cada uno de los protagonistas. Pero tal vez no recalque que en realidad no hay cortes en el 95% de la película lo cual es asombroso. 
Por segundo las actuaciones son brillantes, Michael Keaton tiene talento, su actuación es impresionante y Edward Norton es fantástico, aunque la labor de Naomi Watts y Emma Stone es al 100%
Por último cabe mencionar que los efectos visuales aunque son pocos son muy buenos y algunos trucos de cámara frente a espejos o transiciones de interior a exterior son impresionantes, el mayor acierto de Birdman es también su mayor error, ya que al introducir al personaje en un mundo real donde mencionan a George Clooney y Robert Downey Jr. y demás actores, al final no se entiende si solo el personaje de Keaton tenia problemas existenciales que compartía con su hija (Stone) y el final termina siendo uno abierto y muy frío para lo que habia logrado culminar con todas esas relevancias técnicas que antes mencioné.

En conclusión Birdman brilla por sus aspectos técnicos y grandes actuaciones no me sorprendería llevarse la mejor Fotogafía, montaje y edición y alguna mejor actuación femenina o masculina en los Oscar.,,

This is a magnificent film about a washed-up movie star attempting to resurrect his stardom by redefining himself on the Broadway stage.  Lots of things stand in his way
and unlike the super-hero he once portrayed, he doesn't deal with obstacles so effortlessly. I suppose the film could serve as a metaphor for the human condition or whatever but Michael Keaton in the role made the whole thing sufficient enough taken  literally.
A technical masterpiece... the two-hour long seamlessly uncut take was maximized and used perfectly. Every scene makes you feel like something big is gonna happen. And it does.

"Birdman" es la graduacion de la primera etapa de la carrera de AGI, o al menos asi se siente, ya que refleja la sensibilidad de un verdadero artista de la lente (duela a quien le duela). Es un guion interesante que te lleva tras bambalinas al proceso creativo de una obra de teatro, a la "locura" del creador (Michael Keaton - con el Oscar en la mano por este papel) que busca deshacerse de la imagen de un superheroe para convertirse en su propio heroe. Varios criticos alaban a Naomi Watts, Emma Stone y a Edward Norton (este ultimo sobre todo) pero es Amy Ryan la que debe llevarse las palmas por su brillante, sutil y oportuna actuacion como la ex-esposa del protagonista. Fotografia, edicion y sonido impecables. De las mejores peliculas del 2014. (Texto intencionalmente sin acentos).

At first I wasn't sure how I felt about the film. Immediately, there was no response. As the credits rolled I sat in my seat wondering how I felt about the film and how I should rate this. Not that my words matter to anyone but seemingly myself. This film held many truths behind how stage actors feel about movie stars and how stage actors feel when movie stars come to the live stage. I found that to be very refreshing. I also found this film to be different and creative. I do see why it has received the buzz this film has had and will continue, even after Oscar season ends. However, I did not see the huge hype to Emma Stone's character. Don't get me wrong I adore her and she has come a long way from "Easy A" to this sort of role. I had much hoped for a larger role for her in this film, though her character did play a good part. Michael keaton, who is hit and miss for me, was a definite hit for his character. Naomi Watts continues to prove she is where she belongs. I found it interesting the plot to the film. A play within a movie is always difficult to do and intertwine this with the characters and their lives, however, Alejandro did so very well. There was no stutters and flowed very well. The ending can be taken as a great ending, creative ending, or one of those "what just happened" thoughts. Which is why this film can't be immediately judged. One you need to sit with. I would recommend this film to others, just to see something different.
I want to see this one at the Oscars.

It may take a few minutes to figure out what is going on, but Michael Keaton is fantastic in the lead role. Naomi Watts and Edward Norton give strong supporting performances while Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu expertly pieces this dark comedy together. While the extended shots are exciting to watch, the final few minutes of the movie leave a bit to be desired.

An incredible work of art that manages to feel incredibly real while at the same time appearing profoundly surreal. Superb acting from Keaton as a washed-up actor trying to mount a Broadway play comeback while his inner ego tries to take control and change his destiny. In the end it's a film about leaving your mark on this world, with some commentary on the current state of entertainment and the overblown superhero film franchise phenomenon happening right now. The star of the movie is really the incredible camera work and special effects, creating a seamless single take for the entire film, even though it covers several days of time. The film plays like a play, but with an intense beating pace, set to unnerving jazzy drums.

"Birdman: Or the unexpected virtue of ignorance"

This sounds like the title of a movie that is pretentious, doesn't it? So far up its own butt it's forgotten anything resembling connectivity to an audience? An "Art Film" mess that only those "In the Know" could appreciate? How wrong you are.

"Birdman" (let's abbreviate, shall we?) is anything but unapproachable. It is accessible for the average audience, but odd. It delves into the nature of self-worth and insanity. It asks questions about the line between art and "product" and how we view them. It deals with the very nature of a man questioning himself and everything he has ever known or believed, but it never once gets high on itself. "Birdman" asks questions without asking, it tells a simple story with deeper intent, but remains small in scale and very, very focused. Few "Art" films can claim this. Focus and "Art" rarely seem to go together. It seems we insult the "Artist" when we ask to be able to connect to their creation. The ephemeral has to be good enough. You can never touch it, only view it and despair of ever knowing anything about it. It is good to see that sometimes there is a film maker who can weave the misty artful nothingness with a solidity we as viewers can shake hands with in a firmer sense.

Riggan Thomas (Michael Keaton) is a washed up super-hero film star trying to regain his self-respect and the accolades of the acting community at large. This sounds familiar somehow, eh? He is financing, starring in, producing, and directing a Broadway play adapted from the works of his favorite playwright. He has a misfit cast and crew, including Ed Norton as a notoriously difficult yet brilliant actor. Again this sounds oddly familiar. Riggan has a daughter fresh out of rehab, and no one is taking him seriously as a true stage actor. His only friend is his cynical yet doggedly devoted lawyer (Zach Galifinacus playing it totally straight) who merely wants Riggan to keep it together long enough to break even financially. To top it all off, he talks to himself and has money problems. He's coming apart at the seams. Or is he becoming sane after years of self-delusion? Are his lapses the truth and the more "normal" moments the lie? Is he above the mere mortals surrounding him? Or is he a suicidal maniac and a drunk? A child lost inside of a man who only desperately wants to be loved? That's for you as a viewer to discover.

Without revealing any spoilers, I can safely tell you this; this is an amazing movie in the truest sense of the word. It amazed me. It may even be a masterpiece, as one of my colleagues put it. The atmosphere is thick and rich, savory like a perfect meal. There is tension, humor, tearful confession, depth, meaning, heart, insanity, abuse, love, loss, triumph, pain. I am gasping for the words to describe it. It is ingeniously scored with ambient sound and jazz drums making way for one another as the scene (and sometimes the characters themselves) deem necessary. It is ingeniously filmed, with some shots lasting upwards of fifteen minutes and the entire movie being seamlessly edited together to work as one long, continuous scene.

Unfortunately, this last point seems to be all anyone can talk about as if it were some magic trick to "ooh and ah" and walk away from, but it is so much more than that. The technique never feels intrusive or like a gimmick at all. It instead feeds the atmosphere of a stage play and the organic nature of that medium. And that, in turn, allows us as viewers to more naturally flow into and out of the main narrative, the play within the film, and the burgeoning psychosis of the main character. When he finds himself blurring the lines between his old superhero persona, the play he's performing in, and reality itself we feel as he feels, we break as he breaks. And just as he cannot tell what is real and what is fantasy, neither can we.

Without a doubt, Michael Keaton is astonishing in the lead. Every actor in this film that has been marginalized in any way for their previous works will find justification for their craft here. Every actor and actress seems either cast according to their reputed real-life "type" or to the complete antithesis of audience expectation, almost as if we are to be kept in a state teetering between completely comfortable and just off balance for what is to come next. And as Keaton's Riggan seeks redemption and respect from a public that has sidelined him for one reason or another, so Keaton and his fellow actors and actresses will be redeemed by their performances here. It is fitting that Keaton play Riggan as, in the most general sense, their stories are the same. Good actors, who played super heroes, were forced into work that was beneath them afterwards because no one could see past the mask, and now they are rising from the ashes like the triumphant Phoenix, blazing into glory.

This movie was a huge risk for everyone involved. And the risk paid off in spades. Director Alejandro González Iñárritu and his cast and crew have found their wings with Birdman. Superman would be jealous of the heights to which this film has flown.

Birdman explores the fissures between entertainment sectors; theater vs cinema, New York vs Los Angeles, method vs technique, celebrity vs. sensation. Even Michael Keaton's performance synchronizes marvelously with his character as he navigates professional and personal concerns; his past as a 1990s super hero film star who is making an artistic statement on Broadway. Also the seemingly invisible the camera moves fluidly and impressively as  if in a single shot. Most importantly drama unfolds seamlessly with life imitating the stage portraying life and love. Very impressive.

Asombrosa. Todo en ella deleita: las preciosas tomas de Lubezki, la música, el reparto, y sobretodo la actuación de Keaton, Norton y Stone. Invita a compadecerte, reír y sorprenderte. Más que una historia es una experiencia cinematográfica.

For every second you spend not watching the amazing new film Birdman, another goat farmer uses rough and unclean milking practices while milking a goat, causing clinical bacterial mastitis. Now you could go see the movie right this second, or you could live with the fact that you caused a goat to develop a bacterial infection leading to inflamed breast tissue, a drop in milk production, and, if left untreated, death. Protect the noble goats of America; watch Birdman.

After seeing an amazing film like Birdman, one has the urge to reevaluate his own life. Only the most powerful, prestigious pictures can make that happen, and add Birdman to that list. Everything from the amazing acting to the superb cinematography (which never lets a scene cut , but rather fade into the net one) is achieved with grace authenticity. Director Alejandro G. Iñárritu (21 Grams, Amores Perros) has made some pretty great films, and this definitely goes in his top three. Needless to say, Oscars will be a-comin' to this one.
Perfection all around!  My top candidate for best movie of 2014!

Daringly taking filmgoers on an ambitious flight of fancy, Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu's brilliantly layered, acted, and staged bit of fuss and feathers surges the boundaries of filmmaking and filmgoing forward. As subtitles go, The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance offers up a mouthful and mindful that's definitely less playful than Dr. Strangelove's How We Learned to Worrying and Love the Bomb. What results, however, proves nearly as ridiculous and engaging as Stanley Kubrick's 1964 comic masterpiece. Birdman might serve up the existential crisis of a man who may or may not be suffering a breakdown, but the film fails to provoke an ounce of sadness. Pity's another thing entirely. As funny as it is dazzling, the film keeps the audience amused as they unwittingly get whipped up into the director's imaginative frenzy. Birdman effortlessly whisks you into its intoxicating insanity because the story feels so real, the performances so true, and our own delicate bruised egos so exposed, just like characters themselves.

In this R-rated absurdist comedy, a washed-up actor known for playing an iconic superhero (Keaton) must overcome his ego and family trouble as he mounts a Broadway play in a bid to reclaim his past glory. 

Stretching his creative wings after the mosaic patchwork dramas 21 Grams and Babel, Inarritu keeps the action flowing seemingly as one long take. The camera follows the characters walking and talking before turning to catch the next scene already in progress. In what must have taken a mind-boggling amount of preparation, the technical aspects of Inarritu's latest manner of filmmaking simply astound the viewer. Of course, it's hard to gauge how remarkable this feat is when you're marveling at the acting. Michael Keaton always demonstrates an innate gift for pulling off oft-kilter comedy, but his transformation here is absolutely hypnotic. He leads a brilliant cast likewise swept up into its exhilarating and bizarre ether.

Bottom line: Birdman Forever

Can we just give Michael Keaton the Oscar, please?  But seriously, he is awesome in this. This isn't to discount the rest of the cast, however. All the main actors give great performances, even if some of the characters are pretty 'eh.' This helps build to an excellent film, one with actors working at the top of their games, and one that is technically very impressive. The film is edited together seamlessly, and the one shot technique really fits this film. As we go through the film, we slowly piece together that what we're seeing is through a biased narrator. We are merely spectators to Riggan Thompson's (Michael Keaton's) POV, and it really works as it goes along.

Broadway theater propaganda and NYC's publicity machine at it's best. Not really what I want to see when I go to the movies. Also the movie tries to portray the city's love affair with the "F%#k You" interjection by using it every chance it gets. Using it a gazillion and one times was annoying and ineffectively overused ... sort of the way it is in real life here in nyc. Ironically enough though, in some of the scenes, the interjection was softened a little, in an attempt to make it more palatable for a wider audience, but came off half hearted and unauthentic.

Prob one of the most movie/stage fan movies of recent years if not in general, the the shear fact that half of the people seeming this won't get it is enough to say how brilliant it is (but not in a self stroking Nolan kinda way- but a actual film actor/director/writer/cinematographer/editor/production kinda way). Top notch around the board in all aspects including what seems like a silly statement to make but "Keaton can run circles around your performance son" still.

Most of us remember Michael Keaton's successful string of comedies in the early 1980s that started off with "Night Shift" and "Mr. Mom".  Afterwards, he starred in Tim Burton's highly anticipated "Batman" in 1989. By 1992, he once again played the caped crusader in "Batman Returns", earning Keaton widespread acclaim. Then something happened; Keaton's movies were more "misses" than "hits" until he seemed to disappear from cinema screens overnight. Keaton's career had fallen into the category of insignificance.  He missed out on meatier roles and blockbuster box office winners. Years later, even as he found himself providing voices to successful animated films ("Cars", "Toy Story 3"), Keaton was never handed that potential Academy Award acting part or movie. Until now.

Keaton's enthralling performance completely dominates this film from start to finish. As the character Riggan Thomson, Keaton plays a once famous actor still revered by his fans for his superhero movie persona Birdman from years ago. Riggan, perhaps similar to Keaton following his Batman days, doesn't want history to only remember him for wearing the crime-fighting costume. Unwilling to reprise the Birdman gig for a fourth movie installment, Keaton's character leaves Hollywood for the world of Broadway plays. Now, struggling to gain acceptance from critics, fans and his family, Keaton's Riggan becomes despondent. Keaton's intensity shines throughout the movie like a laser in a dark theater.  But by no means does he carry this remarkable film solely. The film's edgy behind-the-scenes look at a Broadway production reveals a combative storyline from its entire cast and crew.

Just as impressive as Keaton's acting gem in this movie is the extraordinary job two-time Academy Award nominee Edward Norton ("Primal Fear", 1996) does to keep the plot and film moving along effortlessly. Norton's character, Mike, is hired as a last-minute replacement actor to co-star opposite Keaton's delusional Riggan in the Broadway play. Together, Keaton and Norton give movie audiences a volatile mix of personalities so convincingly testy that viewers will be left cringing at times and shaking their heads. Likewise, Naomi Watts (2-time Academy Award nominee) perfectly stars as the uncertain female lead in the play's production.  Rounding out the splendid cast are Zach Galifianakis ("The Hangover" trilogy) and Emma Stone ("Amazing Spider-Man").

"Birdman" marks such a powerful, riveting masterpiece by Keaton and his co-stars, that this film should garner several Oscar nominations. It's almost certain to make the list for Best Picture while Keaton is a heavy favorite to get a nod for Best Actor. "Birdman" also makes a strong case for Academy Award nominations in the Best Supporting Actor (Edward Norton) and Best Directing (Mexican director Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu) categories.

Aside from the exceptionally strong acting performances, the movie also excels in the cinematography department. Despite being filmed almost entirely within the confines of their Broadway theater, the terrific camera angles and shots deserves separate mention. Director Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu gallantly captures the long, maze-like hallways containing the brisk-paced walk of Keaton and others in single, continuous shots.  Viewers become transfixed on the theater set itself; both the happenings in front of the stage and behind it--never missing a step with the characters.  At other times, the film holds a shot an extra few seconds for effect and audience reflection. It's that unique showcase of the film's storyline on camera, combined with brilliant leading and supporting acting, that makes "Birdman" one of the best films in 2014.

"Birdman" provides Michael Keaton the opportunity to remold his film legacy.  While Keaton has attempted for years to rekindle his 1990s popularly at the box office, fictional superhero Riggan Thomson has refused to be typecast as Birdman--despite the insecurity that his decision costs him.  It's only fitting that Keaton's character in "Birdman" desires relevancy and acceptance while taking on a new direction. After all, it's the movie "Birdman" that stands to help return Keaton to the top of the entertainment business. And in return, look for this film to gain massive Oscar buzz come this January--thanks to the dynamic duo of Keaton and Norton.

Grade: A+

La reinvenciÃ³n siempre es algo positivo, pues lleva implÃ­cito el salirse de la zona de confort, desechar viejos hÃ¡bitos y mejorar las debilidades que se vienen arrastrando, ademÃ¡s de hacer un autoanÃ¡lisis y autocrÃ­tica para tratar de mejorar. Eso es exactamente lo que hace Alejandro GonzÃ¡lez IÃ±Ã¡rritu en Birdman (o La Inesperada Virtud de la Ignorancia), quinto filme de una carrera que ha dividido opiniones pero que ha demostrado ser exitosa.

Totally kinetic and terrifically fun.

Michael Keaton plays a washed up actor betting his career on a stage play in an effort to become relavant again. The irony is that Keaton has had a great career and this movie may have ruined it.  If I lived in his he state I would take him to small claims court for $20 and 2 hours of my life back.
Good performances, particularly Edward Norton.  I loved the long takes behind the scenes of a theater production, but the ending threw me off.

My hats off to Antonio Sanchez who provides a drum soundtrack that helps draw you into the soul of the performances and Keaton's madness. Phooey to the lonely New Yorker Review who so reminds one of the same in the film. Kubrick would have loved it.
A Jazz riff of a movie, a fluid flowing mess of perfection. Everything works here at all times and on all levels. Keaton should win best actor.
Intense. Superb job by all the actors led by Keaton. Deserves Oscars for Actor, Director, Cinematographer.

Birdman is a technical marvel of a film. Done in up to 45 minute-long single shots, it shows off the visual effects allowed to the medium while giving its talent--completely deserving of the term--a theatrically timed playground to live and play in. The only downside is that it isn't showing outside major cities.

Keaton's performance is one of the most impressive in recent memory. Also absolutely the best cinematography I've ever seen, the entire film is almost 1 continuous shot. The only thing keeping this from a perfect 5/5 for me is, I didn't LOVED the ending
Birdman is an artsy-fartsy movie done right! Everything about it was so interesting!
Funny yet tragic, Michael Keaton as Riggan is mesmerizing, and the rest of the cast is right there with him. Best film of 2014 so far.

The Emperor has no clothes.
Don't believe the hype. This self-indulgent and self important homage to the emotional roller coaster of actors is wholly unentertaining.    Great acting and cinematography in a mess of a movie.
Thank you Alejandro!!!!! I dont usually have to wait til November for my Oscar fest to get going but you made the wait worth it.  Watch out American film culture, "Birdman" is putting you on blast.

'Birdman' absolutely riveting. Brilliant on every level. Director Innaritu has developed a new way of filmmaking that is simply mesmerizing.

Michael Keaton delivers an Oscar worthy performance in his comeback role, that is nothing short of incredible. Edward Norton is terrific.

A must-see film, the best film I've seen this year, so far.

With out a doubt the best and most imaginative movie of 2014.Keaton's performance is beyond Oscar-worthy and the rest of the cast is equally stellar, most notably Norton and Stone.  Great cinematography and a really fine story of a tortured  soul seeking redemption on the Great White Way.  (11-16-14)

The viewer is a salmon.

Swimming up streams of consciousness, occasionally leaping between parallel tributaries to follow movements of different characters.

That's right, folks - the old head-hopping narrator.

Extra thought provoking because the voiceover only chimes in to pester the protagonist.

What's most noteworthy about Birdman is exactly that: Creative and original storytelling techniques.

Another example is the stylistic editing: The film has the appearance of all occurring within one take.

Therefore the cutting is minimal. Which is incredibly refreshing.

Big names are visibly acting in the same space, oftentimes physically interacting.

There's no 'cut to close-up' as characters deliver dialogue, which makes for a more organic viewing experience.

(Sidenote: Hollywood should ban the 'cut to close-up.')

Birdman isn't going to be your favorite, but it's still great.

The writing is strong; the protagonist's plight is timely and moving. The characters interact compellingly. The subject matter is thought provoking.

Although this term is overused, it takes a 'gritty' in-depth look at stage acting.

The metahumor is consistent and pointed. Even the casting is ironic.

Michael Keaton playing the washed up retired superhero. Edward Norton as a pompous know-it-all veteran.

Wanna know who's excellent? Naomi Watts.

She delivers a stellar performance as Lesley; in a role that somewhat calls back to Mulholland Drive, in which she plays a sexually conflicted up-and-coming actress.

Emma Stone is ten types of terrific, but they shouldn't have spoiled her monologue in the trailer.

Turns out Zach Galifianakis can play off-type extremely well, which comes as no surprise.

Andrea Riseborough is lesser known, but holds her own.

Finally, Amy Ryan plays a totally different character from her role in Gone Baby Gone and fits in perfectly with a slew of other great performers.

Although the trailer spoils most, the special effects are decent enough.

The surreal portion is a welcome addition to the common cinematic experience, and contributes uniquely.

Birdman's a visual treat, as they say.

People seem to enjoy this flick. After all, what's not to like?

It's still in limited release, but you shouldn't have trouble finding a screening nearby.

Expect a moving dramatic piece about the thespian business and you shouldn't feel disappointed.

As always, the best advice remains the same.

Be a salmon - expect nothing, and eventually, you'll feel something.

Resonates nicely with the subtitle, no?
Yes the acting was great but the story was terrible and uninteresting.
This movie is not a good movie. I like Michael Keaton. He is a good actor, this movie just tried to hard, some funny parts, but just kind of pointless.

an extremely and captivating masterpiece
amazing acting cool story great camerawork a must watch for anyone who likes a good sort of weird movie

I liked this flick very much.  Great comedic moments,  great intense scenes. And you really get the feeling of being sick in the bowels of a Broadway Theatre whilst in the middle of a production.  All done with a heavy touch of a dark undercurrent, which perfectly complemented some truly absurd material.  And the first person cinematography was outrageous... very cool!  Felt like a dream... or a nightmare.  But I didn't LOVE IT.  I really wanted to. I went into it cheering for Michael Keaton. But the whole thing was laced with a tinge of cynicism,  so much so,  that I still find myself thinking about it.  Perfect example of a movie being less than the sum of their parts.  Great acting.  Great script.  Great premise.  But why didn't I love it?  I'll leave that question to the birds.
Every couple of years we get an INSANELY imaginative, unique movie that we'll never see anything like again... This is one of those movies. Seriously. Need to watch again.
Bustling with so much kinetic and intellectual energy, Birdman showcases some of the year's best performances in a funny, smart and very unique black comedy.
Keaton a shoo in for Oscar nod; camera work and editing are amazing, too. A must see for anyone in the theater biz.
good movie, but a little quirky.
Completely unexpected and totally brilliant.

It's probably to early for me to try and sum up a movie as I just watched it, but there were great performances.  Someone almost obsessed with himself adopt a role's persona as another part of him.  The shallowness of wanting to be recognized probably before it's too late and before funds are totally depleted overcomes and also maybe mentally breaks that someone.  Worth the watch if you enjoy the theater and the cast.
Loved Michael Keaton and the other actors.  The  story -- I didn't quite get it, but I'm still thinking about it.

As far as acting is concerned the movie is top notch, however it lacks in story. The movie, focuses mainly on Riggen (Michael Keaton) a washed up actor from the nineties trying to regain his popularity. While the movie goes through, the characters all feel genuine, however almost none of them seem relatable. The  story is bland, due to its symbolic nature, and often times you find yourself waiting for a truly pivotal moment that does not ever seem to come. The comedy is few and far between, and when it hits, it does not  stick. The acting, cinematography, and sound editing for the movie are the real highlights of the movie itself; However, these do not justify the hype surrounding the movie. Save your money, or at least go into this movie with a lower expectation.

A really weird journey through Riggan Thomson's life as a movie actor turned stage actor. Really dives into art for art's sake and allows you to bathe in all the emotions associate with success and failure as an actor. Simple set and setting for the movie. A crazy ride but worth the ride!
Cinematogpraphy was incredible. long scenes with hints of Kubrick. will win an Oscar for this among other things like the best Michael Keaton role ever

I have no doubt this film will be dissected and studied in film classes for generations to come. Why? Put simply, it reset the bar for "masterpiece". It is at once bold and surreal, funny and deeply moving, grounding and satirical, and most of all poignant and provoking. The cinematography was certainly off-beat, but brilliantly so, as it left me entranced upon the actors as they flew around the dingy corners of the narrow (and at times soaring) avenues. Michael Keaton easily stole "the show", and delivered quite possibly the most versatile and breathtaking performance I have seen from an actor in my life time. Nay, I kid you not. And Edward Norton and Naomi Watts both rose far above the challenge shown in previous roles, to say nothing of Emma Stone's bringing of the heat, which was turned up considerably more than in her typical "geeky girl next door" roles. Zach Galifianikis, while very svelte, seemed slightly uncomfortable among the rest of the cast, yet still managed to bring more sophistication and class than previously shown. The writing was brilliant. The execution of the narrative was impeccable. This movie deserves to be in every theater, but sadly, it isn't. So, if you want to be taken on a roller-coaster of laughs, deep emotion, and mild insanity, you'll need to get to your local art house or movie tavern to experience this journey. The journey of Birdman.

A strange, magical realism-esque  type of film.  Michael Keaton is outstanding. And, the parallel to his real life is hard to miss. It's still got me thinking. The music is amazing. It's as if the percussion reflects the ticking of his mind or his conscience.

Michael Keaton, where have you been? Though he hasn't been in much over the last decade, this movie is an excellent come-back to a leading role. He is fantastic in a movie that pokes fun at the over-the-hill actor's ego along with the theater industry and social media circus as a whole, wonderfully balancing hilarity with hubris. We're mostly kept in the dark whether his "Birdman" schtick is schizophrenia or a hidden power of sorts. While Edward Norton and Emma Stone steal some scenes, we're reminded that this is Keaton's movie. One of my favorites of 2014 alongside "Boyhood".
I enjoyed a lot this film, not for everyone!

Oh, NYC. Oh, Broadway. Great directing. Great performances. Loved it.

What a wild ride. Come inside the psyche of Riggan Thomson, former blockbuster movie star, now a man trying desperately to legitimize his career (by writing, directing and starring in a Broadway adaption of Raymond Carver), his life as a father and husband and what that all means in the scope of life. A tour de force for director Inarritu, whose camerawork here is extraordinary as one scene flows into another without pause in what seems to be one continuous two hour plus shot. The acting doesn't disappoint, with stand out turns from Keaton, Norton, Watts and Stone. This is a meaningful reverie on fame, show business and life. Theater people especially will love it.

The sound of drums play as we hear Riggan Thomson (Michael Keaton) for the first time. We see him from behind, in just his underwear, levitating off the ground. The former superhero movie star is in his Broadway dressing room looking out onto the world from his window. All the while a voice in his head is growling, the devil on his shoulder,  judging his every move. 
Keaton plays a washed up actor who used to be a box office superhero star decades before. He is trying to get his last big hit on Broadway, in which he by directs and stars in. But for Riggan, it is hard while his alter-ego makes him doubt himself all the time. His alter superhero background in the film is clearly an allusion to KeatonÃ¢(TM)s role as Batman back in 1989 and this realistic film references other box office superheroes such as Robert Downey Jr. and Jeremy Renner by making jokes about how theyÃ¢(TM)re all Ã¢wearing capes now.Ã¢?
    Birdman guides you through a journey of tight staircases and crowded hallways. You experience the fictional flight of Riggan, escaping his daily stress as he soars above skyscrapers. You can feel the pain of Emma StoneÃ¢(TM)s character, Sam, as she watches her fatherÃ¢(TM)s rapid break down. These perfectly choreographed shots are just the beginning of the many things that are great about Birdman. Every scene is accompanied by a powerful score and incredible acting.
The biggest struggle Riggan has with his play,Ã¢What We Talk About When We Talk About LoveÃ¢?, is his co-star, Mike Shiner. After the lead actor gets injured on set, Shiner is called to fill in before audience previews. Shiner, portrayed by Edward Norton, known for Fight Club and American History X. He is an outgoing actor who acts as if he is just being himself on stage but is self-absorbed and shallow off. Shiner struggles to find his way as a human being and how to become the best he can be. Lesley, played by Naomi Watts who is known for The Impossible, ShinerÃ¢(TM)s significant other, who is fulfilling her childhood dream of playing on Broadway. Her stress over her first Broadway role, coupled with Shiner playing her stage love interest, is a recipe for disaster.
Another actor who pulls off a great role, is none other than Zach Galifianakis. As RigganÃ¢(TM)s manager and best friend, Brandon Vander Hey, he helps him through his toughest moments and does his best to make everything right. Amy Ryan, who was in Gone Baby Gone, plays RigganÃ¢(TM)s ex-wife, she only has brief screen time, but through her presence, we witness Riggan at his lowest and highest points. 
In the end, every actor in this movie did a huge amount work to pull of such a phenomenal production and the director, Alejandro G. IÃÂ±ÃÂ¡rritu, made a fantastic film. Birdman is a rollercoaster that shows us that we must hit rock bottom to rise back up. Birdman is one of the best movies you will see all year.

-Chris Honthy

As an experiment in technique I suppose it was interesting. The cast did a great job and the characters were well formed. But from a stylistic and story point of view, it is gimmicky and trivial. The pacing is monotonous and the themes are very immature.

Michael Keaton multidimensional performance brought to this film his talent for comedy, drama and absurdity.  The supporting cast allowed his character to shine but it was the director that put all this film together and made it flow so well.

This movie is a critic's wet dream but for the rest of us not so much. it's just an average to above average movie I found myself a bit bored. I kept waiting for it to get much better and it never did.

Have you ever wanted to punch a movie in the face? Neither have I until I saw Birdman or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance) or (The Unexpected Flaming Pile of Shit). Turdman is about a failing actor named Riggan Thomson (Michael Keaton) who is trying to make a comeback by adapting a short story into a play which he is starring, writing and producing himself.

While the movie isn't 100% terrible, it tries to cover the fact that it is bad by throwing an all A-list cast at you including Edward Norton, Emma Stone, Zach Galifianakis and Naomi Watts. They all play people that seem to just serve the purpose of distracting the main character and delivering some very flat jokes.

All the actors give in good performances, it's just that they are all such big assholes or immature children that it was extremely annoying to watch. I know some black comedies are mean in nature but I couldn't help but feel like every character deserved a kick to the head. Emma Stone, playing Keaton's daughter Sam, was the most likeable for me and actually the only character I was invested in. She's doing her Emma Stone shtick but it played well here and felt very sincere.

The major issue with this movie is its message and writing. It spends its two-hour running time trying to undermine the superhero genre and everyone involved for lacking substance or selling out. Which is a very fair point but the way it goes about it is very poor. You can't knock a whole genre of film for lacking substance when the very movie saying that lacks it as well.

That's the thing, the whole time this movie is trying to say "FOCUS ON THE ART". This movie has an attitude that feels like from the get go has earned it's praise and recognition while it's constantly massaging it's own ego till the very end.

One scene in particular shows Keaton completely ripping apart this woman's review of his play (which he does have good reason for) and saying that critics are people who wanted to create but couldn't. Which is very hypocritical of Birdman because as I said, it wants to be this Oscar darling but at the same time is making fun of the people who dictate what's Oscar worthy? I'm sorry Birdman but you can't have your cake and eat it too.

And I'm not saying the Oscars are the final word on what's good or not, it is just that it's so obvious this movie wants that attention. Like American Hustle last year, all star cast, sub-par story/substance.

Another issue is the quality of the writing for this -ahem- "COMEDY". The awkward pauses after some lines should have just included a laugh track as the silence lasts long enough just to let the viewer know that they should be laughing at that part. Also, there are enough ball jokes in here to make Seth Rogen blush.

Behind Birdman's fantastic direction and cinematography are a weak story, dumb script and annoying characters. Birdman needs to take the pedestal it puts itself on and shove it up it's own ass.
Not what I expected. A little too boring for my taste.

From its breathtaking one-shot direction to its spot-on performances including Michael Keaton and the scene-stealing, career-best Edward Norton, there's a truly unique ambition at play here with Birdman.

Technically audacious. Formally rigorous. Beautifully acted. Incredibly entertaining. Really hilarious. Iñárritu's best film since "Amores Perros." Finally Emanuel Lubezki gets to shoot a film worthy of his immense talent. It's a film which the cinematography adds to the meaning of the film. The meaning might ultimately be "eh" but it's so engrossing and entertaining that it doesn't matter even a little bit. My favorite film of the year.

With a cast that Birdman provides, it is almost impossible not to simply enjoy watching them act. Norton and Keaton were phenomenal, working alongside Stone and Galifianakis. The majority of the movie portrayed a dismal tone, leading all the way up until the end. Michael Keaton's loose hold on reality should have the audience yearning for more until the ending, which fell just shy of what the rest of the film brought to the table.

After spending 119 minutes in a darkened theater watching Birdman (or The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance), I offer two words to describe my experience. I found  Birdman (or The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance) to be TRANSCENDENTLY BRILLIANT. I experienced a similar reaction after viewing 1985's The Color Purple, 1997's The Apostle,  2007's Into the Wild and 2012's Beasts of the Southern Wild. Each one tapping into sensations and emotions unlike other films and leaving me speechless as I viewed the world with a new perspective.

This movie had an interesting tale about the acting world in general, touching on themes of celebrities versus actors, the role of social media, and the grander theme of life and what makes life worth while.  It had strong performances from an excellent cast, and I greatly enjoyed its cinematography and they way it was shot to seem like one continuous shot for the majority of the film.  Overall, I found it dark at times, but very enjoyable.
Definitely an artistic movie with lots of emotions. Great movie, great acting.
Without a fault, Birdman, filmed in seemingly one shot, is held gory her by its fantastic acting, script, themes, and ideas.

Very Weird.....but compelling. My husband left by the time Michael Keaton (Birdman) got done wrecking his dressing room in a rage. So he missed the 2nd half, the best parts. But Riggan Thomson, Keaton's character isn't the craziest person in the movie. But I get it that everyone takes themselves, and their mostly inconsequential lives, too seriously.

I loved Birdman the first time I saw it. However, after a second viewing, I consider it a total masterpiece. This is a ridiculously impressive film with stellar acting and cinematography. It's clever, managing to appear as if it was filmed in one long shot. As great as those aspects are, the biggest accomplishment here is the dialogue. It's long and drawn out, but it feels natural and kept me engaged the whole time. I think that's a hard thing to pull off, because it's easy to get bored when there's not a whole lot going on. That's definitely not the case here, as I found myself grasping on to every conversation that takes place. Michael Keaton totally shines, really showing us what he's capable of. Simply put, this film is a fantastic blend of dark humor and style, which really brings something unique to the table. I'm really blown away by this film, my second favorite of 2014.
Absolutely ridiculous camera-work, with a passionate and deep story to boot. There's not a dull moment.

First and foremost, Birdman is a satire. The movie swings a razor sharp sword that leaves virtually no segment of the entertainment industry uncut. I just wanted to get that out of the way, so it doesn't get lost in all the other crazy-awesomeness this movie brings to the table.

     What elevates this movie into the realm of greatness is while it is skewering all of the egos and insecurities from Hollywood to Broadway, it presents itself in such a way as to showcase all that is admirable, compelling and wondrous about the very subject it is ripping to shreds.

     The movie, which is fully titled Birdman or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance), is the brainchild of Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu, who directed the movie and co-wrote the wildly original screenplay.

     Inarritu is best known for bleak, weighty (yet exquisite) films like 21 Grams, Babel and Biutiful, so while it's not surprising to see him deliver something this complex and ambitious, it is a little jaw-dropping to see him make a movie this buoyant, lively and funny.

     I really can't go any further without talking about the movie's star, Michael Keaton, who quite bravely delivers the performance of his career in a role where at first glance he appears to be playing himself. Keaton plays Riggan Thomson, a middle-aged actor trying to emerge from decades of irrelevance after helming an insanely popular superhero franchise. You can see the similarities.
     Riggan was Birdman decades ago, but now he is desperately trying to reignite his career on Broadway by writing, directing and starring in a play adapted from a Raymond Carver short story.

     But once you get past the meta-façade, Keaton dives deep to play a man burdened with regrets after falling victim to nearly every single one of the trappings of fame.

     Riggan is barely keeping it all together with (some) help from his high-strung attorney and co-financer, Jake (Zach Galifianakis). Of course, it only complicates matters Riggan is dating one of his co-stars, Laura (Andrea Riseborough), while his other two co-stars - gifted prima donna Mike (Edward Norton) and highly self-conscious Lesley (Naomi Watts) - are involved in their own toxic relationship.

     To top it all off, Riggan has employed his volatile, recovering-addict daughter, Sam (Emma Stone), to be his personal assistant. You can already tell when you've set up the chessboard with this many screwed up characters played by such talented actors you are going to be in for a treat.

     There's also the added wrinkle of Riggan's sanity as he hears the voice of Birdman in his head and appears to be capable of fantastic feats which may, or may not, be as real as they are presented.

     But then this movie is just getting warmed up as it doubles down and achieves the amazing technical feat of appearing to be filmed in one continuous shot (there are a few "cheats," where the camera is taken off the actors for a moment or two, but for the most part, it spools out like a real-time play).

     Birdman also looks fantastic as it was shot by Oscar-winning cinematographer Emmanuel Lubezki, who, for my money, is one of the best directors of photography working today.

     There is a lot going on with this movie, but never once does it feel overbearing or pretentious - an impressive achievement in itself when you think about it. Birdman is quite simply one of the best movies of the year and certain to be touted when year-end awards start rolling in.

    Keaton has some commanding scenes. This is his movie and he seems to know it. We get to see him like never before in pristine moments of whimsy, defeat, despair, and agony. It's one of the year's best performances no doubt.

     Keaton, Inarritu and Lubezki should be locks when it comes to Oscar nominations (along with the discordant, jazz-drum score by Antonio Sanchez which seems to compliment the chaos of the film perfectly). Stone and Norton are also certain to snag themselves some Best Supporting nominations.

     Birdman is a film-lover's dream, as it gives you everything you love about movies and then mocks the rest. And if we're being honest, actors, directors, producers and critics deserved to be mocked a whole lot more than they are.

I am not one to give praise easily to a movie since there are so many bad ones out there. Birdman was a complete pleasure. The story keeps you guessing "where is this going?", and is brilliantly acted. The cinematography was mesmerizing. It has a style similar to "The Life Aquatic" but really grabs you with the story. One of the best movies I have EVER seen. It's luminous. Riveting. Brilliant. Evocative. Keaton and Norton are awe-inspiring. The entire cast is superb and the writing is innovative and addicting. Extremely well directed, great score and excellent performances. Sometimes you have to hit the ground in order to bounce up again. The difference between a celebrity and an artist, most people can't tell the difference.

Full of win.  So this is about an aging, washed-up former comic strip actor (Michael Keaton) who used to play the renowned Birdman back in his heyday.  He's trying to do something relevant with his career by adapting, directing and starring in a production of "What We Talk about When We Talk about Love", but circumstances such as difficult actors to work with, a faltering relationship with his daughter and his antagonizing alter ego are sure to make things as difficult as possible.  This was easily the movie I was most anticipating this Oscar season; the trailer was brilliantly cut and one that I watched a countless number of times, everything about it appealed to my sensibilities as a moviegoer, and this boasts a cast that you can get excited about.  Then, I learned about a technical element that made me made me get exponentially more pumped up: this movie is filmed to create the illusion that it is all one shot.  A tracking shot that lasts longer than a few minutes is difficult enough to choreograph, imagine the hurdles they faced doing that for an entire 2 hour movie, or at least creating that illusion that it was done in one take.  To the extent of my knowledge, this has only been executed twice previously, with Russian Ark and Rope.  Still haven't seen Russian Ark yet (but I will eventually, as it's on the 1,001 list), and if I am understanding correctly, it is the only one that legitimately accomplishes the feat in one shot.  Rope, on the other hand, does it by masking the cuts at appropriate moments when they are the least noticeable, which is what Birdman does as well, only without awkwardly crash cutting into the back of somebody's sport jacket.  You may label this a gimmick, but the fact of the matter is that this is a technique that works, and because of this innovative tactic, it makes for a much more immersive experience.  You don't want to take your eyes off the screen because after five minutes, you've already realized that you are watching something special, and you can't wait to see what will happen next.  Apart from being a technical marvel, this is just a very enjoyable film and a treat to watch.  One thing that you may not anticipate is how funny it is; it is unexpectedly hilarious, and while there is many a moment of hard hitting drama, it is perfectly paced with comedic timing to break the ice on any tense moment.  There is totally an additional layer added here when you add the fact that Keaton used to play Batman in 1989 and 1992, and if there is a word that I would use to describe this movie, that word would be relevant.  We are at the height of the superhero craze, and from a logical standpoint, this makes so much sense for not only Keaton, but for what a number of actors may be doing 20 years down the pipeline.  He does an amazing job, really putting himself into this character with no boundaries; he could have easily turned down this role and been above it all, but instead he delivers a performance that rings incredibly honest.  And the supporting cast is nothing short of stellar; Emma Stone has a electrifying monologue that will give you chills, Edward Norton is the best he's been since Fight Club, and Zach Galifianakis delivers the performance of his career so far.  This also plays very well if you have a background in theatre, which I happen to have, with the most coincidental thing being that these actors had to rehearse tirelessly to get the timing of it all down for the for the one shot technique, which is something you would have to do if you were starring in a stage play.  This succeeds wildly at every point, and with a vibrant drum score to underscore the drama, get ready to be mesmerized.
Overhyped and absolutely nonsensical. I've seen better storylines with cartoons than this neurotic white people shit.

A satire of the modern day entertainment industry, Birdman not only has an incredible cast, terrific script, and technical prowess, it also represents everything wrong with the industry, while simultaneously representing everything right with it

A movie hasn't stuck to me like Birdman has in a long time. Everything is flawless in this movie. First time a movie has made me say holy shit out loud. This holds up on second viewing ... for the most part.  It's great to see Iñárritu break from the pattern of dour, joyless features he's been in.  This is the best film he's done since "Amores Perros".  The style of the film is flashy, but it fits the story he's telling and enhances the performances.  I only really have two serious problems with it.  The depiction of the critic is really just a cheap shot that feels beneath the rest of the movie.  It belongs in a Shyamalan movie, not this one.  It should also end about 10 minutes earlier.  The ending he has feels like he had no idea how to end the film at all.
