This movie has got everything on point. Acting, writing, cinematography, editing, sound, and whatever else you can think of. When it comes to dramas or comedies, people usaully don't pay a lot of attention to sound design; those types of movies tend to focus on the characters and their story. Birdman, however, does a very admirable job at making sure the music, sound effects, and little tiny things here and there awesome. Breaking down movies to the very core, it's video and audio and audio is basically 50% of a movie, given it's not one of those artsy silent films, so why not do the 50% some justice. I know I'm making it sound like sound is everything by gushing so much, but it was just something that I noticed and really appreciated. Moving on from that, this film is funny and never too dramatic; any time someone is being emotional or when a moment is getting dramatic, they're able to save themselves from getting too cheesy with some humor. Everyone gives outstanding performances with special mention to Keaton, and they're able to shift between theater acting and movie acting. As the cast performs their on-stage and off-stage roles you can see a change in tone, giving the film a low-brow outlook on theater, acting, and films. It celebrates the art whilst making fun of it and if you've ever been in drama class, you'll be laughing a lot due to its very accurate portrayal. One last note; amazing camera work and editing. The movie is one seamless shot pulled off by a few clever editing trick here and there. Still with the editing it's done beautifully and gives it that play kinda feel. A love letter to movies, theater, and acting; Birdman is pretty fantastic.

Only held back by a useless lesbian scene (why can't girls be just friends anymore?) this movie is the best shot in cinema. Absolutely unparalleled. A brilliant commentary on the bloatnedness of the entertainment industry and how vapid people's conception of art is.

Great dark comedy with excellent performances all around. The tortured artist vibe reminded me a bit of Black Swan at times. It's also a technical achievement, with tracking shots blending together to make it seem like it is all one continuous take. Not the most fun I have had at the movies, but very impressive.

Grade: A

Pretentious, un-original screenwriting with a few magical moments. A film which is so engrossed in "truthful acting", not one actor had a solid performance, including the lead himself. This film, in which is built on the ideology of extreme artistry is nothing more than Acting 101 "porn" for upcoming thespians and a pretentious audience. Depression and moral conflict of an Actor, who blindly has the industry at his feet, is nothing more than a Hallmark story with financial and "name driven" backing.

I haven't seen a performance like this in a while from Michael Keaton.  He nailed it.  Emma Stone, Naomi Watts and Edward Norton deserve praise for their performances because the amount of humanity in their character is beautifully portrayed.  That's acting!  All of the characters want to be "relative" in their own interpretation of the word.  The story is simple and moving.  Accept yourself before anyone else will accept you.  Real stories.  Real and flawed characters.  Greatly cinematic and addicting.  I won't say anything more because I don't want to spoil but check it out ASAP!!  You won't be disappointed.

This movie sucked. So much hype about it but it didn't even come close. If all you can say is that it was 'one continuous shot" then the movie sucks. The plot was confusing and depressing, the acting was good! but what about the meaning and purpose? You can't just throw a bunch of meaning in a box and shake it up and end up with a movie! Sucked.

Such an exquisite film not only to watch but to hear. There is no way something could take away the second consecutive oscar for Emmanuel Lubezki and his beautiful photography this year . The way that this film is directed and edited is a way that we haven't seen before.
Must see. Incredible camera direction

Just saw this with my dad.  Not bad!  Very art-house.  Great cast.  Always liked Michael Keaton and Ed Norton, and Emma Stone could read IKEA instructions to me.  I was impressed with how there are NO cuts in the entire film. I don't even want to know what kind of work went into that, but I bet it was really something!
Actors are outstanding, cinematography is fascinating, it's a comedy for adults who love film.
One of the more ambitious films I've seen in a while.
Birdman is a masterpiece. It is filled with humor and spectacular performances. This deserves to be nominated and win many Oscars.
Really great dark humor movie. Very different. Very refreshing. Love the cinematography it's unlike anything I've seen before. The acting was excellent. Loved this movie! ORIGINAL!
Really awful and I LOVE Michael Keaton

Way over rated by critics.  A very few funny moments even for a black comedy.  Keaton's 'Birdman' voice sounds a lot like his Batman voice.  With actors playing actors playing actors, its hard to separate real bad acting from fake bad acting.  After a while I didn't even try.

Birdman was a beautiful film.  The performances were almost as brilliant as the camera work, and the effects were seamless as well.  I had issues with Stone's performance at times, and with such ambiguous yet pointed dialogue, its amazing there weren't more moments of second guessing.  But between titans like Keaton and Norton there was little to complain about.  Watts, Riseborough, and Galafianakis all had very polished performances that matched the tone of the film to a 'T,' which was perhaps the film's greatest value: a consistency of mood, character, and theme that drove the, albeit thin, stroryline to its inevitable conclusion.  Though I must admit, the last moment I felt was a bit of a copout.  Like the ending the "Inception" we are left with a blurred line between fact and fiction that sticks with us, but I'd argue, not for the right reasons.  Still, a tremendous film and an Oscar contender to be certain.

So I just saw Birdman and it was absolutely fantastic.  Alejandro González Iñárritu is director that's caught my attention form hearsay on his previous work.  I haven't seen them yet but after watching Birdman I'm excited to check them out.  Now something that I knew going in was that most of the movie is filmed to look like one continuous shot and it's amazingly executed.  To my knowledge, only Alfred Hitchcock's Rope (1948) has tried this but had it's limitations because of technology of the time.  With this movie the cuts are so carefully planned they're practically invisible and the effect was pure cinema.  There were moments where you can guess the cut but that's as close as it gets.  I wouldn't doubt if I was wrong either.  The story was absolutely fantastic having a self awareness and relevance to the movie industry.  The criticism never felt self indulgent and were honest.  After all, what better movie to make criticisms than one as masterful as this one.  And of course, all of the performances were great and everyone had a moment to shine.  Needless to say their was a lot of thought and effort put into this movie and the end result really delivers.  This a movie that dared me to look at it's structure, meaning, and characters; the truth is that this is one of the best movies I have ever seen 10/10.
You just have to see it to understand what it gets right.

Birdman is an excellent film about a man who used to be an iconic character and now wants to be taken seriously in acting. He has done this by creating his own play in order to build his reputation up.

I loved this movie so much as it had incredible performances from every single cast member. I couldn't pick the best one as they were all equally as good as each other. My favourite part of this film is that they did it in one shot. This means that recognition needs to be given to the editing team as they have to make sure that the whole shot syncs. This is something that I have first hand experience on as I used to do media and found out that this is a hard process. Credit also needs to be given to the director who came up with this idea and wanted audience members to have a great story as well as letting us appreciate cinematography. The whole way through, I didn't want the film to end.
       This film does follow certain characters at some points on how they have problems during the starting point of this play while dealing with their consequences. It shows that everything may look good in front of the screen but behind the scenes, they are just ordinary people trying to figure out how they can get through life. 
       In the end of the day, birdman has made me appreciate actors and those behind the scenes as they deal with a lot in order to impress people and become the person they are today so that they can be remembered
The best movie of the year. It's direction, acting, and presentation is flawless. It's so incredibly entertaining and fun to watch. I think Norton will finally get his Oscar!

a brilliantly shot and performed master piece that gets progressively intense in a chaotic, egocentric world which audience can relate to as a fantasy. Norton's, Galifianakis's, and Stone's supporting effort compromises well with Keaton's powerhouse performance.  One of 2014's best films that's worth for multiple viewings.

Wild. Trippy. This movie pulls you to the edge of a damaged man's mind, and I love it. The whole movie is one long shot like a theatrical play, the music is seemingly random drums as heavy punctuation. The characters have heart and it feels oddly real for how absurd it is. Go see it, And bring an open mind for art.

I know. I know. I'm going against the grain here and not giving this 5 stars. I know. Maybe I'm just not as cerebral as everyone else. I don't usually like "dark" or "deep" films. Quiet and introspective? Sure! But my morality system and understanding of life is kinda limited to superhero movies. Maybe give me another decade and I'll enjoy this better. It was definitely a cinematic spectacle to watch, though. The entire movie is one take, and this adds a beautiful sense and tension and continuity to the movie that I've never felt before. Having everything in one take forces you to be present, and it makes the movie, fittingly, almost resemble theater. I know I watched something great. I guess I just don't relate to the characters. And, there was that one scene where I thought the movie was laughing at me.
The best movie of 2014.

Extraordinary and makes me want to visit theaters again to watch something other than 'event' blockbusters. If the movie's message is a little heavy handed, it's more than balanced out by how easily it flies.

Brilliantly directed movie which is worth the price of admission alone. Almost surreal in his approach, Inarritu embraces this troupe of actors in a warm blanket of intimacy. Does Keaton's character have super powers? Is he hallucinating the whole time?Who knows, and who cares?
Birdman is a brilliant and cleverly filmed masterpiece with outstanding acting, beautiful cinematography, a deep story, and a darkly comic premise.
I have never rated anything 5 stars before.
Great acting but the film should have ended 2 minutes earlier
This is really good.

Such great performances by the whole cast! Yes even Zack Galafanakis, everyone can relate to this movie whether it's on a personal level or just on the way we see celebrities, great writing great casting & great plot is what makes birdman one of the best movies of year.

Birdman.  Not to be confused with Harvey Birdman nor the basketball player.  Michael Keaton helms the lead role in this black comedy.  It's a dark look under the hood of Broadway plays and the egos of the actors who embody them.  Keaton somehow finds a way to tap into a real piece-of-work of a person to bring his character to life without making you think Keaton may actually be this kind of person in real life.  Keaton's range has always been his strength from Batman to Beetlejuice to Birdman.  

Ed Norton, Emma Stone, Naomi Watts, Zach Galifianakis and Andrea Riseborough are all great supporters.  Norton probably plays the exact opposite kind of character as he is in real life as a real brandish and over-confident egomaniac.  Unfortunately, he sits out most of the final act.  Stone comes in second as the troubled daughter who is both endearing and repulsive in nature with her bad habits and carefree attitude.

The real strength of this film is the direction.  Alejandro pulls of one of the most outlandish feats I have ever seen in a movie; making the entire film seem as if it was one entire long cut without any cuts or breaks.  I heard the actors talk about the trouble and difficulty with this kind of technique, but it really made everything feel fluid and suspenseful.  This and the entire premise of the film of a washed up, old actor trying to revive...maybe refurbish...his one historic career in a new avenue just to prove he still has it gives Birdman a real presence.

With a stellar cast that performs phenomenally and a innovative cinematography showcase, "Birdman" is the best film of the year in my view. The original screenplay is very interesting and unlike any I have seen before. Although this film is not for the light-hearted, it really proves to be worthwhile.
Very funny. Nice to see Michael Keaton making a comeback.
fucking insanely cool... and the lighting and camerawork was magnificent. Very close to home... but inspiring none the less.

Hallucinatory and hilarious, Birdman reminded me a little bit of Hitchcock's noble experiment in single takes, Rope. Rope was probably a bit more of an effort since the digital enhancements weren't available then, nevertheless, the effect here is stunning, never knowing when it's in dream state or real life. Norton is outstanding as usual. One can't help but wonder if he is merely playing himself. Keaton is intense at that crazy stage, desperately trying to be relevant. The Birdman sequences and outfit reminded me a lot of Brazil.

4.5 out of 5 stars. this movie is so "au courant'. Its capturing 'the moment' while its happening. Well acted! and the "long shots" weren't as noticeable as the camera "zoomed up in the face of two actors", somehow combining the best of theatre and movies.

A multilayered contemporary study of the human condition; a flat out masterpiece in all facets-- storytelling, visual aesthetic, directing, and score. The most human film of 2014 features career defining performances from Keaton, Norton, and Stone who deserve legitimate award consideration for their turns. BIRDMAN is one of the most cathartic film achievements of 2014; the film of the year, without a doubt.
Ain't no film like "Birdman". Motherfucker, your gonna soar!
Hands-down in my opinion the best film of the year.

Birdman. A hyperactive expression of breathless cinematic exploration and filmmaking magic. See it the first time for the endlessly entertaining story. See it again to catch the parts of the story you missed the first time. See it a third time to marvel at the way the camera moves, and doesn't stop moving (the first cut comes an hour and forty five minutes in) throughout. After that you still haven't seen all there is to see.
I have no idea how they pulled this off, visually and otherwise and in a way, I don't want to. The fever dream of the year.
Absolutely brilliant movie in all respects. A must see.

Is it a bird? Is it a plane? Whatever Birdman is, I was knocked out by it. The basic story is older, formerly successful  action movie star goes for broke trying to make it as a Broadway play director and actor. If the story sounds familiar let me guarantee you the execution of it is anything but. This is a movie with kinetic style from the opening frame; even the credits burst with visual creativity. Michael Keaton will easily be up for an Oscar for this and may very well win it. The entire supporting cast was excellent as well, particularly Edwad Norton and Emma Stone. It's not an art film. exactly, but an artfully done film with fantastic cinema photography, great visual flair, and a cooler than cool soundtrack. I pretty much enjoyed all aspects of this film. I suspect it will get multiple nominations for both Golden Globe and Academy awards, all of them no doubt deserved. It is an extremely potent cocktail of black humor and moving drama. It is , in a word, absolutely riveting.
Great acting and an interesting approach making the whole movie look like one camera take.
Honest, raw, brilliant acting, best movie I have seen this year.

A movie about broken people fighting against themselves and their flaws as they attempt to be better (or maybe a better word would be transcend), grappling with their own humanity and weaknesses along the way. Keaton, Stone, and Norton put on riveting, raw, real, honest performances as our leads. The camerawork and cinematography is pretty, unique, and at times surreal. It's a very different kind of film, and ultimately emerges as its own bizarre masterpiece.
A rare film that is shockingly strange, humorous, bitter, and human - a near perfect film.
Looked great visually but the story wasn't very engaging to me.

Smart, provocative and mesmerizing that centers around the world of entertainment both inside and out of the business. Michael Keaton as the main lead is one of the best casting choice I've ever seen and a worthy contender for Best Actor. The same could be said towards Edward Norton for his brilliant and energetic work as Mike. I can also see a Best Director nomination for  Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu towards his  one tracking shot presentation. Overall, terrific film.

Birdman is the best movie I've seen this year. The movie is shot beautifully and is one tracking shot. The directing and performances are nothing short of spectacular. Birdman deals with many complex themes yet the themes are ones an audience member has most likely dealt with in their life. If you are lucky enough to have a theater near you showing it go see it NOW!! It is definitely worth your time and money.
Loved it. Great acting with nice long scenes.
Multi-layered, clever, artistic, funny, stylish, and greatly acted. I loved the cinematography. It only felt it's length a couple times. 8.5/10
Very different, left you thinking "hmm"! Michael Keaton was phenomenal and so was the directing!

One of the worst movies I've ever experienced. Felt more like a play, with obvious over-acting that can be useful in plays, but present in film which ruined form. The film is outrageously boring, and seemingly never ending with these constant cinematography techniques that merge separate times together, it felt very amateurish.

This movie is a great movie to watch.  It's very heavy with surrealism, which I thought tend to distract a few times.  The cast is wonderful, especially Keaton.  Was it the best movie of the year, no.  Even so, I enjoyed this movie very much.
Simply a masterpiece of filmmaking and performances. The entire film is a roller coaster of character drama happening left and right, but it all intertwines perfectly in a beautiful crafted package.
Wow. The quality of the acting (loved Norton, by the way, and Emma Stone), and Innaritu's vision. Wow.

'Birdman' is a wickedly clever piece of meta-art. Riffing on his own career, Michael Keaton stars as an aging actor ostensibly searching for authenticity and respect while actually seeking petty fame from a new source. 

The movie unfolds very amusingly as an adaptation of the play its characters are themselves adapting from a short story. It's a bit tongue in cheek, but the narrative complexity is a huge amount of fun to observe. Dysfunction flows from stage to screen with hilarious (and sometimes heart-wrenching) results, and the characters, who are vainly obsessed with "art," subtly deflect a cultural critique of celebrity back onto the audience itself.

The glue that holds the movie together is its cinematography. The entire film is composed as one long tracking shot. It simulates the effect, of course, of a bird's eye view and suggests a symbiosis between the audience's constant demand for more and the actors' constant demand for attention. One can imagine entire film courses being taught about the film's technique.

Alejandro Inarritu has made a career out of depressing audiences with contrived stories and melodramatic acting. It would have been hard to guess that he had something so playful in him. The movie takes a few trips to the soul-poisoning sludge that fills New York (and humanity's) gutters, but it generally offers a hopeful vision of redemption.

And Michael Keaton? The movie pokes fun at the worthlessness of awards, but when Keaton wins his, they will be quite valuable and well-deserved.
I was totally disappointed with this... I guess if ur into crappy plays you might like it. Low budget artsy drama, such a slow horrid pace it was difficult to sit through.

My prediction is both my review: "Birdman" is one of the best films in years! and it will be nominated for an Oscar in the following categories: Original Screenplay, Director (Alejandro González Iñárritu), Actor in a leading role (Michale Keaton), Actor in a Supporting Role (Edward Norton), Cinematography (Emmanuel Lubezki), Editing (Douglas Crise and Stephen Mirrione) certainly for best picture and best chances are in the categories for Best Actress: Emma Stone, Naomi Watts and Andrea Riseborough. In this next Oscars edition will again be a Mexican Director - Alejandro González Iñárritu- the center of attention.

What is a critic but a crusher of dreams? A film critic is a cold and cruel mind that looks only once at the months of sweat and passion of artists and either discard or regretfully stamps approval. A critic is a coward, a failed artist that has become a pessimist and envies other artist's success and opportunities. A critic's opinion can crush a film's success, but what is a critic's opinion but the opinion of one person? How many people are the same? How many people have identical opinions in the vast subject matters covered in film? Don't worry, I'm not going to stop writing reviews, or be merciful for any film, but this most recent film has really made me reflect on the fragile lives of artists.

Birdman is a film that took a lot of risks, and that is admirable whether such risks ended up rewarding or condemning the film. In Birdman's case the results are unpredictable for every audience member. Birdman is such a unique film, that it can either be loved or hated by fans, there is no in between. Its risk ends up appealing more to critics than the masses, but it overall makes your reception to it be unique from anyone else's. However, if you ask for my opinion, I will tell you that Birdman is one of this decade's best films. There is no other film like it. 

Birdman reminded me a lot of Begin Again, in the way that it conveyed the career struggles and benefits of an artist (in the case of Begin Again it was musicians). Birdman tells the story of an actor, Riggan (Michael Keaton), who seeks to revive his career on a Broadway play he adapts, directs, and stars in. In his peak years, Riggan had been the titular character in a superhero franchise called Birdman, decades ago; after refusing to do any more sequels, however, his acting career faded away. But in his journey for re-vindication Riggan has to also battle: to gain back the love of the daughter he was never there for (Emma Stone), to prevent his celebrity co-star (Edward Norton) from outshining him, to keep his cast together, appease critics, and to prevent himself from going mad. 

There are various aspects that make Birdman different from any movie you've ever seen. For one, Birdman is filmed so that it all looks like one seamless shot. Now while the cinematography might get all the credit in this feat, it really is the editing that deserves the praise, it must have been nerve-racking to stitch together the film so that it would look that way. Another aspect that I enjoyed was the fact that the music was percussion-based and performed in a jazzy and loose kind of way. When analyzing it one sees that there really is no other music that could have properly conveyed the immediacy and complete chaos of an artist's life. 

The acting was spectacular thanks to a resurrecting Michael Keaton (who's own career parallels that of Riggan) who might just have given his best performance yet. Keaton portrays Riggan in such a realistic and confused way that, along with the seamless editing, the audience felt they were seeing everything in the first person. One literally felt as if we were experiencing the film from Keaton's own eyes. Meanwhile Edward Norton also might have given a performance that not only earned him critical acclaim, but a mainstream resurgence as well. The more minor players include Naomi Watts who plays a cast member and Edward Norton's wife and is able to give us the true distress and emotional breakdowns that actors and generally artists feel. And Emma Stone, the actress that appears in every movie today, ranging from The Amazing Spiderman to Woody Allen's Magic in the Moonlight, she keeps mesmerizing audiences and bettering herself with every film. 

One mustn't overlook Alejandro Gonzalez Iñarritu's responsibility in the film. The Mexican native was the man responsible of taking such risks in the narrative and cinematic aspects. Iñarritu wrote and directed Birdman and he does so in such a way that it reminds us of the long lost auteurs of the likes of Hitchcock, Orson Welles, and Billy Wilder. 

Birdman is a must see, it hypnotizes those loyal moviegoers, and lets them experience a unique journey. But for other the film might seem incredibly weird and boring, who's ending and symbolism you did not understand. Depends how you choose to look at it.
Now I know why this won Best Picture. What an amazing film about the struggle of acting. Edward Norton was phenomenal. Feels more like a documentary then a film at times. Loved it.

Bottom Line: 4.5 stars out of 5. This movie was so good! I didn't know hardly anything about it before seeing it. Hadn't seen the trailer, didn't really know what it was about. All that and more.

Directed by: Alejandro González Iñárritu (who you may know from Amores perros)

Written by: Alejandro González Iñárritu, Nicolas Giacobone

Starring: Michael Keaton, Zach Galifianakis, Edward Norton, Andrea Riseborough, Amy Ryan, Emma Stone, Naomi Watts

Music by: Antonio Sanchez

Cinematography: Emmanuel Lubezki


I'm going to try and not get carried away with this review, but I do love this movie. Like I said, I didn't know a whole lot about this movie going into it. Right in the beginning you see Michael Keaton's character, Riggan Thomson, meditating. Three feet off the ground while a gravely voice starts to narrate. A voice very similar to what many actors have attempted when portraying Batman. Which Keaton has done. Quickly we learn that Riggan used to play Birman in very successful movies. Now he's past his prime and watching other actors in massive superhero blockbusters long after he hung up his wings. Now he's trying to open a play on Broadway that he adapted, directed and is starring in. And he's risking it all.

Under normal circumstances if you told me a movie was about a play trying to open on Broadway I'd say "well... that's nice." I wouldn't be interested. But this movie got me hooked right away. So many different stories going on below the main plot.

Riggan is depressed about his place in his career, desperate for this play to be a critical and financial success. He's dealing with a daughter he doesn't have a good relationship with who is also fresh out of drug rehab, and he might be a little crazy. The Batman-esque Birman voice makes several appearances, acting as a kind of devil on the shoulder voice for Riggan. It's hilarious and feels real. Maybe I'm wrong, but I think we all have that dark little voice. Maybe we don't all actually hear sounds like someone who's possibly mentally ill does, but we can feel it, right? When a co-worker says or does something ignorant or offends us, we all have that dark voice that says "Who does this guy think he is? I'm the man around here." Or something like that. 


Edward Norton's character is brought in at the last minute to take over a role (Mike Shiner). Mike is supremely talented and the critics love him, Riggan is desperate for critical attention so his play can be successful. Edward Norton really shines in the movie, but besides Mike stepping in, he's also in a relationship with one of the co-stars (Naomi Watts as Lesly), he butts heads with Riggan over parts of the production, flirts with Riga's daughter, and is also suffering from his own personal issues. He's charming, funny and also really kind of a douche nozzle.

The rest of the cast has their own problems that get a couple minutes here and there. Everyone is great.

The real treat of the movie is the cinematography by Emmanuel Lubezki. Using some editing trickery, most of the movie is presented as one single, long take. This means that when Riggan and Mike meet for the first time to rehearse a scene, it appears as though we are really watching rehearsal. There's no cuts back and forth to each actor, just a subtly moving camera for coverage. 

Every blocking movement by the actors was planned out months in advance so that the camera movements could be as well. Which is especially remarkable because the actors seemed so comfortable I would have guessed the opposite while watching the movie. It felt like the actors were much freer to do what they wanted.

Similar to Interstellar, Inception and others, Birman is going to have people talking for years about what happened at the end. What truly happened? I think I know, but I'm not sure. Might have to watch it again before I decide. But in the end, it doesn't really matter because everything you just watched was great.

I think it's likely that this movie gets nominated for some awards, possibly for the actors, certainly for the cinematography and it deserves whatever it gets.

Bottom Line: 4.5 stars out of 5. Really great movie. Can't wait to see it again.

Super realism is a good way to describe this movie. It's too meta to be meta and too magical to be magical realism. At times it is charming and silly. Mostly, it's suffocating and clanging.
Michael Keaton plays Riggan Thompson, an actor once famous for playing a winged superhero with a guttural snarl. Sound familiar? Now he is the writer, director, and star of a Broadway play, and he believes his last shot at redemption. 
It's a shame that the actors talents are wasted in a film that is so self-aware it becomes self-conscious. At an early point in the film, Emma Stone's character asks Keaton's what is the point of the production? Is it for the recognition and praise of an older, rich, mostly white, audience who will quickly forget the play while getting coffee? The question can easily be applied to Birdman and it is a question left unanswered. There are few answers and even less meaning in any of the characters. 
 The cinematography, while technically amazing, becomes distracting. Emmanuel Lubezki makes the camera run, fly, and occasionally breathe. However, it's an moment where you focus on the camera instead of what is in front of it. Another instance is the music that starts in the soundtrack, then occasionally bleeds into the action on screen. The drummer playing the music is seen on screen and then disappears but is still heard. It is one of many moments that you marvel at, but forget because it doesn't add anything to the film. 
It's a tiring film that is all sound and fury, signifying nothing.

Ids, egos and superegos collide and combust (in a single take!) on stages as concrete as the Broadway theatre and as fantastical as the imaginings of a self-obsessed actor in Alejando González I?árritu's Birdman. As in the myth of Icarus, to which his wily script often alludes both visually and verbally, I?áritu has high-flying ambitions for what is possibly his most personal film to date. But rather than crash and burn, his satiric slant on the artist's odyssey soars magnificently on its dark feathery wings.

Michael Keaton stars - in a performance that vies to redefine his career - as Riggan Thompson, a washed-up former movie star seeking respect and validation by directing and starring in his own adaptation of Raymond Carver's What We Talk About When We Talk About Love on Broadway. He had once played a popular superhero (the eponymous Birdman) in a series of lucrative but disposable comic book blockbusters that brought him fame and fortune, but not artistic fulfillment.

Now, some twenty years after hanging up his dopey bird suit, he's risking so much more than just his money and reputation by mounting this prestigious production. The tenuous relationship with his recovering drug addict daughter (Emma Stone), his fragile sense of self, and even his grasp on reality hang in the balance while the pressure mounts.

I?árritu has taken some bold artistic risks himself with Birdman; Much ado has been made about his splashy, "unedited" single-take approach. There actually are several digital editing cuts so expertly achieved that they're invisible to us. Otherwise, the film is designed to resemble one extended single take, shot by the modern master of lengthy tracking shots, Emmanuel Lubezki.

The trick itself isn't an original one; Alfred Hitchcock famously attempted it with Rope, as did Alexander Sokurov more recently with Russian Ark. But Lubezki's magic with light, colour and kineticism elevates this camera stunt above the gimmick into which it could have deteriorated. Beyond its visual panache, the greatest virtue of this uninterrupted shooting style is the chance it affords us to observe the cast's uninterrupted performances. Seems appropriate for a story about live theatre, no?

But the thing about live theatre is that there's a lot that can, and does, go wrong. As the days left until opening night are counted down by a gong show of disastrous rehearsals and previews, Riggan finds himself at odds with his actors, his family, his audience, but most of all himself. One minute he's humbly self-aware, the next he's the sort of egomaniac who'd shoot his nose to spite his face.

The show within a show we see him preparing reflects more and more this struggle between his doggedly driven superego and his hallucinatory id, the victor of which may decide the fate of his very existence. One of the masterstrokes of  I?árritu's devilishly funny screenplay (which he co-wrote with Nicolas Giácobone, Alexander Dinelaris & Armando Bo) is how it populates Riggan's world with characters who represent the conflicting levels of his psyche.

All the self-conscious perceptions he has about his family, his career, and his art are reflected in the interactions he shares with his concerned ex-wife (Amy Ryan), his harried best friend/agent (Zack Galifianakis), and the New York Times' hostile theatre critic (Lindsay Duncan). His raging subconscious delusions, meanwhile, are embodied by his prickly method actor costar (an hilarious Edward Norton), his leading lady/lover (Andrea Riseborough), and the ghost of Birdman himself, who taunts Riggan with barbed reminders of his lost stardom.

It's only fitting that a piece of art that's about about art imitating life would imitate life itself. So cinephiles can be forgiven for gleefully reminding those of us who've forgotten, that Keaton - much like the character he plays here - hit the apex of his own big screen career (until now, that is) over twenty years ago by playing the iconic title superhero in Tim Burton's Batman movies.

While it's impossible to measure the extent to which Keaton's own history and perspectives inform his performance, what's undeniable is that he's tapped into something truly special with his work here. Ever the versatile performer, he plays Riggan as a grounded human being and as an artist driven mad with equal conviction, building to a climatic epiphany that's as terrifying as it is bleakly comical.

Yet as tempting as it is to play up the "meta" aspect of Keaton as Riggan, the truth is it's probably more accurate to read I?árritu as Riggan. He is the artist who has put himself out there on the line and delivered a near masterpiece. Sure, Birdman's not perfect (a few too many unresolved subplots clamber for our attention), but I?árritu flies just close enough to the sun for us to see the world from Riggan Thompson's eyes... without falling back down in flames.

This is an actor's movie, a critics dream but not an audience pleaser.  It feels like watching a play shot as a movie but without the closeness you feel in live theater.  Great acting but the first 3/4 of the movie feels slow and disjointed.   Sadly there was not one character in the movie that I found likable.  There are enough self absorbed, undisciplined people in real life without having to pay to watch them on the big screen.   In conclusion, great acting, interesting cinema but not enjoyable to watch.
Complexity. Surreality. Sound design and mixing. Distinct camera work. Use of light. Acting. Editing. Another gem from the director of Amores Perros. It deserved the Oscar. I need to watch it again.

Birdman, the story of a almost washed up actor, Riggan Thomson, who acted in 3 superhero films 20 years ago. He wants to become relative again. He wants to be more than Birdman. This film is art and brilliance. I care what happens to Riggan, I feel for him when he goes into unhinged psychotic rages. He thinks he can manipulate objects, but in reality, he is just throwing and smashing stuff. This film is very Oscar-worthy. The film, Michael Keeton, and Zach Galifianakis should all be nominated for an Academy Award.In a nutshell, this film is greatness!

Unlike any movie you will see this year, in a good way. A character-driven film that nonetheless retains great narrative momentum. A genre-defying movie experience.  Daringly filmed, with tracking shots that give the actors no place to hide.  Michael Keaton's performance, is wide, deep, courageous and nuanced.  Edward Norton will receive a well-deserved  Academy Award nomination for best supporting actor, and Emma Stone will earn a nomination for best supporting actress.

Overrated. I think the reason this movie is getting hyped so much is that it seems written for entertainment industry insiders. Not only that, it also seems like it's making excuses for their incessant narcissism. I've enjoyed all the previous movies this director made, but this is nothing like those. Also, took off a full star for the grating soundtrack-- sounded like a teenager who just got a drum set.

I so wanted to love this movie but it left me thinking "WTF?"  The cast was great.  Acting was great but the story line was all over the place.  Perhaps I'm an idiot and just couldn't follow it?  I dunno.  I was in a theater with only about 50 others and they all seemed to have the same sentiment walking out.  If my main take away was "Michael Keaton has abused the hell outta his skin," that shows I didn't get it.

This movie is edited to the format of having one continuous shot, with a few brief moments of cuts thrown in. The following film that is being reviewed today is a masterpiece of cinema. What film is this you ask? Why, it's "Birdman or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance", a film that will blow the viewer away after watching it. There is so much to talk about this movie, it is too much to actually discuss; you just have to see it for yourself. "Birdman" is a great look at an actor's ego being pushed to the limit, and the choices he must make to maintain it being in balance.

The story follows a washed up actor named Riggan Thomson (Michael Keaton), who rose to fame by playing a superhero named Birdman. Unfortunately, Riggan cannot let go of his past as he tries to make a comeback on Broadway. Here, Riggan must deal with the demands of actors, his production team, his family, and ultimately, himself to get back to reality.

"Birdman" is a fantastic piece of film that needs to be seen. Alejandro González Iñárritu who directed the feature, as well as co-wrote it, made this movie work with a great script and superb direction. While the music of simply drums is the only soundtrack you hear, it represents the action being taken by our character Riggan, and all the thoughts and emotions running through his head. The setting of the theater world is perfect as we have an actor trying to reclaim his fame and glory. The costumes definitely fit our characters, even Riggan who has an interesting scene where he is running around in his underwear. The cast is amazing; we have Emma Stone, Edward Norton, and Naomi Watts delivering great performances. Even Zach Galifianakis, who traditionally is not accustomed to films with the theme of repentance, gives a grand performance in a supporting role.

Yet, there are two things there are two things that make this movie really stand out. First off, Michael Keaton delivers a magnificent performance; considering he is an actor that has played a superhero before, this is totally related towards his character in the film. Keaton just nails the character of Riggan, and it is a marvel to watch. Secondly,  the story goes into some very mature subjects along with the lesson of repentance. How can an actor turn away from the past, and what are the consequences that go into a mid-life crisis, are all explored in this movie's story. There's even a bit fantasy thrown in the mix, which gives the whole scenario a more in-depth look at how a production can take on an actor's personality. The whole movie is a showcase on what the acting world is like, and how is can literally change a person.

In conclusion, "Birdman" is a wonderful film showcasing what extremes an actor must do in order to keep his sanity going; all through one glorious shot.

Oh man, where do I start? What a film by Alejandro González Iñárritu. His previous works ( Death Trilogy, Biutiful ) included stunning visuals, story and amazing acting talents but Birdman takes everything to a whole new level. Keaton, Norton and Emma Stone have been nominated for Oscars and rightly so. 

The one continuous take style cinematography is the thing that kept me glued to the screen for two hours. Another Oscar worthy work by Emmanuel Lubezki (Children of Men, Gravity)

It is that weird but nice feeling I have about the film after I've finished watching the film just like Iñárritu's previous works. 

For me it's one of those films that I'll watch once in a few years to remind myself how great it is but also how different it is that I just can't watch it again in a short space of time. 

Easily one of the best films of the year!

I've Had a passion for a few years now of movies. Very few of the hundreds of movies I've seen can compete with the brilliance of Birdman. for the first time, I left a theater absolutely astonished at the perfection I had see onscreen. Alejandro Inarritu far exceeds any expectation i had of him(I was already a big fan of his work) and produces a truly revolutionary work. There is not a flaw noticeable in this movie. The acting of the cast is outstanding with Emma Stone, Michael Keaton and Edward Norton giving career best performances, every scene gripping with them in it and well acted. The drum score beat of the soundtrack gives a restless energy to the movie like its alive. The cinematography of Lubezki is his best since Tree of Life, and the continuous take it tires to achieve is no gimmick, but great camerawork pair with acting. The script has great elements of black humor mixed with emotion. And Inarritu juggles this circus masterfully as director, showing us the promise from Amores Perros and Biutiful. Every time i put on a movie, I hope for an experience like this. I couldn't help but sit staring at the screen excitedly, grinning at the the movie on hand and its glory. I was so in awe by this movie it took hours to recover from it. It is a masterpiece, a compliment far too given. If cinema is alive today, it is in this movie. 5 out of 5

My eyes were hurting after about 45 minutes since this whole movie is ONE SHOT! That in itself is just very impressive. Great acting, direction, and the best cinematography of the year. Just didn't care about the plot and it seemed to drag a bit at times..
Acting is brilliant, film construction is flawless
Not nearly as deep as it thinks it is, but the craft here is solid and the performances are a joy to watch.

This is a very stylized talker. It is an indictment of the explosions, chases, and general CG of superhero flick. It scores in intensity. The gimmick of shooting as one long tracking shoot is cool without out actually feeling too labored. Keaton, Norton, Stone and the rest  of the cast are great. The movie loses me in some of its pretense, and its Broadway actory insiderness. And even more in playing with the edges of reality when insanity or suicide should be more stone cold serious. Zach Gallifinakis is great in drama without having to ham it up, and he looks great at his new weight. Oh and having a former Batman play lead lead is perfect. And when he monologues about a different former Batman, it's very sly.

The cinematography and acting were fantastic however the story while clear, was jumbled and uninspired. 

I left the theater wondering what greater story the director was trying to tell, but I get the feeling he did not know either.
The whole movie was one shot. What an Amazing film. One the best of 2014.

I wanted to love it. It's like one looooong tracking shot. I didn't love it. However, Keaton is such an amazing actor. No surprise that there should be Oscar noms for Keaton and Edward Norton (who was the best thing about the film) for sure

Solid movie. I think the one take camera shot thing is gimmicky because it's pretty obvious sometimes when it's impossible that it's just an editing trick so it's not that impressive if it's not real.  But it adds to the movie because it's a movie about live theater so I get it and it's kind of cool for a while. Plot wise you can think of this as the male version of Black Swan except the ending wasn't quite as good or as clear. I thought the music was especially good, it's all just jazz drums but really good jazz drums. A lot of the humor is good. There are some really shocking and dark moments and turns in this movie that definitely make it worth seeing despite it's flaws. I don't think it quite matches the hype but it was one of the best movies I saw this year for sure. I doubt anyone I know would have regrets about investing 2 hours into watching it.

This feels like a sad industry insider fluffer piece. Tried too hard to be deep, has parts that are painfully over symbolic, and ultimately isn't all that entertaining. It's not all bad, I liked parts, but in the end left with the "I'm not sure if I liked that" vibe, which generally means I didn't.

Where the heck has Michael been? Best movie of the year, and there will be several Oscar nominations for this story about an old "has-been" actor trying to find his road to self-respect and happiness, and all of the stumbling that occurs along the way. A great story and great acting makes this a movie you would see again.

There's quite a few epic superhero scale battles going on here in Birdman or (The Unexpected Virtue Of Ignorance). To start with, we have Riggan (Michael Keaton) as the aging actor, once famous for playing the iconic superhero, Birdman. Battling to find himself, rediscover his family, and bring meaning to his career by financing, directing and starring in his own Broadway play. This is turn leads to a discussion about the theatre and acting as art versus the seemingly shallow offerings from Hollywood. And how weird is it that Keaton, once famous for playing Batman, is here, in this? Is this some crazy Hollywood introspective therapy session? Is Keaton okay? Can we expect to see Robert Downey Jr. in Birdman 2 in a few years?

In a way, I thought of this movie as a marriage counselor working with these two theatrical worlds. Someone saying 'hey, look, you both have your strengths, so can't we all get along?' Because this movie, incredibly, is like a blend of the two. Its single camera, single shot style acts like a fly on the wall, recording live events as they happen. This is a stage play, about the creation of a stage play, by a man trying to reconcile his past glories, and we the movie going audience get to watch the drama unfold.

This style of film making incredibly doesn't ever feel gimmicky or overused either, as Alejandro González Iñárritu never gets too carried away with the idea. The camera serves the really great script, moves when it's time to find another element in this drama, and stays put when it's time to focus on the film's superb cast. Michael Keaton's performance is almost certainly going to get some attention during the next award season, as will Edward Norton's, and maybe even Emma Stone's.

Movie Prep:

This is a quirky little film, and its style may take a little getting used to at first. Just remember you're the fly on the wall watching this drama take place. The movie is rated R for language, limited sexual content and violence.

Best Format:

This is a great looking film, shot in and around Times Square in New York City, so I suggest you see this in a theater. At home a HD viewing on your TV is recommended. I wouldn't suggest you watch this on anything portable.

Best Moment: << mild spoiler >>

Keaton's performance is one of the best I've seen this year, and there's a moment where he loses his cool in his dressing room, that's just mesmerizing. Seemingly using his Birdman powers (or is he?) to throw and destroy objects with his mind!

Birdman or [The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance] (2014) - This black comedy directed by Alejandro G. Inarritu stars Michael Keaton, Edward Norton, Zach Galifianakis, Lindsay Duncan, Emma Stone and Naomi Watts. Former blockbuster actor Riggan (Keaton) after decades tries to regain former glory by directing, writing and acting in a Broadway play based on a Raymond Carver short story. Things don't go as planned as Riggan must deal with the play as it crumbles around him.

Might be an unorthodox way to start my review but I freaking love this movie. This is a rich, challenging, poignant and deeply funny screenplay brought to life in the best and most entertaining way possible. Keeping my typical review structure in tact will be tough considering there's very little, if nothing at all that I dislike about this movie. First and foremost this is a movie about the meaning of "Art" but goes so much deeper than that. This film is about relevancy, existence, duality, purpose, family, drinking, film criticism, the nature of the blockbuster versus art itself and how they all interact and intermingle; It couldn't be more perfect. This movie is like you're favourite meal prepared by a top chef; exploring new flavours with each bite you didn't even know existed in that dish.

Let's start with the performances. Michael Keaton makes perfect sense for this role in so many, on the nose, ways its crazy... But that doesn't take away from just how damn good he is in this. It couldn't have been nicer to see a return to form for not only Keaton but Edward Norton as well, who hasn't been this good in a very long time. Now that I mention it, every single performance in this movie is... GREAT! There wasn't a single weak link; from Emma Stone to Naomi Watts to even Zach Galifianakis, these players brought their A-game. These characters are just so likeable, flaws and all. The movie creates a paradigm between the performers and the people themselves making an interestingly layered palette of characters. The dialogue is so self aware, sharp and witty; And the best part is the actors know it and they're eating it up.

The most noteworthy character in the movie by far was the camera or hell the "movie" itself... Shot by the DP for 2013's "Gravity", the free-flowing, seemingly one-take nature of the film's execution is just so much fun to watch. Through use of clever editing and impeccable talent from everyone involved, this movie makes goes out of its way to make you feel like you've literally drifted into this world. It's like you're a spirit floating through this wonderful world of angst and theatre. Whether you're looking to see where they hide the cuts or just kicking back and enjoying the show is irrelevant as the result is the same; it's simply remarkable. The movie's jazz drum driven score is not to go without mentioning either as in conjunction with the cinematography it makes for a completely unique movie going experience, one of which I will never forget.

"Birdman" not only achieves a lofty goal of saying an awful lot in a mere 2 hours but it also becomes art in its purest form within this medium. It's without question a flawless film in my books, one of very few this year. Every masterful sequence was instilled with raw emotion and thought provoking questions which kept me engaged respectfully while still being so much fun. It's entertaining, sharp, ridiculously funny and just down-right impressive in every way. Though it's certainly not everyone's cup of tea, I do think there's a little something for everyone in "Birdman". For the casual, general movie going audience who seek out nothing but conventional mediocre predictability; Make it known that this movie is NOT for you and it knows it... And frankly, it doesn't care (neither do I).

GRADE: A+

Birdman is Ace!

I have to preface this review of Birdman by saying that this kind of film was right up my street. As an independently minded, foreign director helmed, black comedy film featuring recently sub-par actors (Keaton, Galifianakis, Watts) who were pulling out the all the stops I loved the idea at conception.

Then I saw the the film and was blown away from it from the first scene and sentence. Birdman is genuinely inventive on many counts.
Firstly, the idea of the story progressing "one take" propagated by a steady cam and invisible edit points was astonishing. I have not been taken in by such inventive cinematography since Gravity, so it was no surprise that it was shot by the same DP (Director of Photography) as Gravity was; Emmanuel Lubezki.
Secondly, the way that the minimalist jazz drum score drives the film forward was fantastic. I now have the soundtrack on constant repeat.

Thirdly, the genius casting of Michael Keaton to reference to a failing actor from a film franchise. Who else could it have been? Val Kilmer's Batman? Brendan Routh's Superman? Michael Crawford's Condorman? None of the above would have sufficed!
In Summary

It should be noted that all these points would add up to a gimmicky if it wasn't for the story and the way that it unfolds. Riggan Thomas, Keaton, seems to have everyone against him; his daughter, his ex-wife, his new-love interest, his manager, his fellow actors and that strange hidden "Birdman" character push and pull him in multiple directions. It's impossible to know which way he could turn.

On top of all this it is genuinely funny!
I love it when you leave a film and you aren't quite sure what happened and you know that you'll have to watch it again and soon.

Michael Keaton has his best role in years as a washed-up actor, and former star of a superhero franchise, trying to make a comeback by adapting a Raymond Carver story as a play, in this fantastical comedy. Alejandro G Inarritu directed this backstage farce, which uses elements of magical realism, as a self-reflexive satire on actors and celebrity. Shot in an artificial, continuously fluid, seemingly single take by the virtuoso cinematographer Emmanuel Lubezki. The movie fails as a conventional meditation on an actor seeking redemption, and a sequence where Keaton confronts an antagonistic theater critic expresses a contemptuous superiority that is reprehensible. It doesn't have the rambunctiousness of classic farce or the piercing humor of a great black comedy, but it's enjoyably slight. Won Oscars for Best Picture, Director, Original Screenplay, and Cinematography. Music score is by Antonio Sanchez. Written by Inarritu, Nicolas Giacobone, Alexander Dinelaris, Jr., and Armando Bo. With Edward Norton, Zack Galifianakis, Andrea Riseborough, Amy Ryan, Emma Stone, and Naomi Watts.

I had no idea what this movie was about until I saw it for the first time last night. And I can say 'Birdman' is one of the best movies of the year of 2014. I can't say anything bad about this movie but it just falls short of being a perfect film to me. It's just that I wanted more from some characters like Edward Norton's character as a jerky overly unstable actor. Trust me he's probably the best thing in the whole entire movie next to the the theme, Michael Keaton, and cinematography! I also wanted more from Emma Stone's Character as a drug habit that just got out of rehab and is harsh on her dad most of the time. I know that the movie wants us to know that these are complex characters. Even though I know that I would like for them to have a little more development over the course of the movie. Ok, now let us go to the good stuff! The cinematography is probably the best I have ever seen in film history! The technique of shooting the whole movie in one shot with a camera is brilliant, unique, and affective! The acting was phenomenal all across the board was terrific. The movie is funny, smart, charming, dark, intense, and fun. All these elements makes the movie great as a whole. Screenplay was magnificent with a good script as well. I will love to see this movie again in a month or so! The movie is that good go see it right now! The themes of the movie are brilliantly portrayed in scenes. Fair use of CGI in the movie and it actually looks real! The best directing I have seen this year just absolutely fantastic! The movie is very complex which is good and boosts up the film to a high degree. I wanted to see more of these characters and what happens next in the film. I wasn't to much of a fan of the ending to be honest. Not just it's complex, it's uncertain and doesn't have a real explanation. It expands your mind for a explanation for a movie but endings like that for me I truly dislike. Overall, 'Birdman' is a once in a lifetime movie that you'll encounter and be so amazed from it that it will think about how good it is. The movie is remember ably and raw. I'm going to give 'Birdman' an HIGH A+ (98%) grading!

Golden Globe nominee Michael Keaton of Batman, Batman Returns & Beetlejuice stars as Riggan Thomson, a former movie star known primarily for playing the superhero character Birdman tries to revive and dignify his career by staging a play he wrote, directs and stars in based on Raymond Carver's "What We Talk About When We Talk About Love." During rehearsals, Rigganâ??s manager & best friend Jake (Emmy Award winner and The Hangover series star Zach Galifianakis) is worried that Riggan is floundering in this unfamiliar territory.  Birdman was more than a role for Riggan, Birdman is his alter ego and he is in consistent, passionate and often contentious dialogue with this sometimes supernatural aspect of himself as well as with his fellow actors and estranged family; Lesley (two-time Academy Award nominee Naomi Watts), Mike (Academy Award nominee Edward Norton), his daughter Sam (Golden Globe nominee Emma Stone), and ex-wife Sylvia (Academy Award nominee Amy Ryan). Two-time Academy Award nominated director Alejandro GonzÃ¡lez IÃ±Ã¡rritu co-wrote screenplay with Nicolas Giacobone, Alexander Dinelaris, & Armando Bo.  Birdman is an unique world of fascinating characters all brilliantly performed. This is Michael Keaton's best work to date. The camera work was flawless and artfully edited to illustrate the "long, strange, trip" Birdman is orchestrating. I HIGHLY recommend SEEING THIS FILM.

This is jazz in movie form. Except for the beginning and near the end, the camera shot never blinks. Our window into every scene is with one continuous perspective. But that doesn't mean it paints with a stiff brush or in broad strokes - strikingly the opposite is true. It plays a pivotal part in this ensemble, always in organic free-form and in perfect synchrony with the other "musicians," intimately playing off of their beautiful performances. Both the story and it's structure also fit the jazz motif, wondering, exploring, feeling, and each actor in the ensemble is given a chance to shine throughout this incredible tune. What a timely piece.
The cinematography was incredible. The story, even more so. Michael Keaton was born to play this role.

Granted I still have to see the likes of Nightcrawler (which I am currently sitting in the theater waiting to watch), Whiplash, and Imitation Game, Birdman is certainly the best film I have seen this year. Certainly the best direction and editing of the year, the film is cut together so well that the entire film is convincingly edited together into essentially one continuous shot, when in reality it is a collection of continuous shots. The acting in this movie is top notch. The best performance in the movie, and of the year, is that of Michael Keaton. He deserves that Oscar. The great performances continue, with Emma Stone, Edward Norton, Zak Galifianakis, and Naomi Watts also giving some fantastic performances, and perhaps one of the best of each of their careers. The score also fits the movie very well. The film does a great job of critiquing a variety of important topics related to entertainment, including even the critiquing of entertainment itself.

Overall, the directing, editing, and acting in Birdman (or the Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance) is some of the best of the year, and it would be a very deserving multi-Oscar winner.

This hyper-kinetic film about a superhero movie star who goes Broadway chronicles a mental breakup, family tension, and career frustration. Its gimmicky editing contributes to the impression of a postmodern backstage drama with tons of acting talent and some bravura scenes and monologues (especially from Emma Stone who here graduates to capital A Art). What I liked about it was that someone's finally taking on the superhero flicks with some thought and depth, looking at their place in our culture in a way that's really interesting. What I didn't like about it was that it was just too busy and over-the-top in almost every way, too fussy and confusing and ultimately not sure what it wanted to say. But it's a funny, entertaining, in-joke filled film, nonetheless.

'Strange' is the game when it comes to Birdman.

The famed long scenes start off having a significant impact on the feel of Birdman. For the first third of the film, I felt like I was watching a play on screen. Everything in front of my eyes felt so real, and I felt like I could almost feel the actors shuffling behind me to get into position for their next part in the 30 or 40 minute shot. This, along with how the first act took place in one confined setting, made for an excellent portrayal of the theater, and I loved it. Sadly, I soon got used to the lack of cuts. By the end of the movie had almost completely forgotten that this movie was doing something different with its cuts, which took away a bit of the fun.

The cinematography added to Birdman's unique feel. Alejandro González Iñárritu and Emmanuel Lubezki pushed the camera into some very interesting spaces that really changed the feeling, emotion, and emphasis of certain scenes. Birdman deserved it's Oscar for Best Cinematography.

The social commentary in this movie is heavy and relevant, and frankly, the best part of the film. Birdman has Riggan (Michael Keaton) dealing with his role as an actor and family in a very melodramatic fashion. Riggan's struggles give off points and arguments that are very meaningful in this cinema climate of superheroes and blockbusters. The way our protagonist interacts and deals with the other actors, who all appear to represent current Hollywood stereotypes, gives more social commentary. The acute nuances are what drive the film, and get you through the boring parts.

The rising action didn't rise, but instead stayed at a mostly constant level of action. It could feel somewhat stagnant, yet, somewhat compelling at the same time. Very 'strange,' and difficult to describe. I postulate that the long scenes added to the second act feeling slow but interesting.

Parts of Birdman seem intentionally ambiguous, which is fine, but I would really like to know some of the exact details after my time with Riggan. I would highly recommend Birdman to everyone, even if just for them to experience Alejandro González Iñárritu's unique take on film making.

Probably the best film I've seen all year, and I think it's the only one to be released in 2014 which I've given five stars. It begs repeated viewings, and I am incredibly eager to see it again. And again. And probably again several more times.
Aside from a couple slow (but not bad) scenes the movie was incredible from start to finish.

When you set up Edward Norton and Emma Stone as love interests, only later to drop that subplot completely, or when you create so much sexual tension between Naomi Watts and Edward Norton, only to drop that subplot completely, or when you write Michael Keaton trying to rekindle a relationship with his ex wide, only to drop that story completely, you are left with a cute, well acted, but ultimately confused film that remembers how much better the 90s were for Michael Keaton. Well, they got that right. The 90s WERE better for Michael Keaton.
Riggan: "I wasn't even present in my own life, and now I don't have it, and I'm never going to have it."
