Theater is one of the main resources to make films, a long list of plays based on books or plays based on plays been made throughout the film history. But make a film about the making of a play is pretty rare. 

Birdman which tells the story of Riggan Thomson (Michael Keaton) an actor famous for portraying a action hero on hollywood films. Birdman a fictional character Batman type who haunts Riggan as a voice and alter ego. Riggan is struggling to become actor, director, writer from a theater play in NY escaping the blockbuster world and making real art on stage.

Alejandro Gonzales Iñarritu (Amores Perros, 21 Grams, Babel) directs an stellar cast Michael Keaton, Zach Galifianakis, Edward Norton, Naomi Watts and Emma Stone with groundbreaking film techniques by Director of Photography Oscar winner for Gravity Emmanuel Lubezki creating the illusion of a single shot instead of several editing cuts.

Replicating techniques like Alfred Hitchcock  "The Rope" Gonzales Iñarritu  and Lubezki use halls and passages as well dark rooms to transition between shots Douglas Crise and Stephen Mirrione edit the film masterfully. 

Gonzales Iñarritu pay tribute to theater by using the single shot technique instead of several cuts a perfect fit for a theater goer who basically have to choose which angle to see and where to cut.

Michael Keaton is amazing, as well Edward Norton.
Antonio Sanchez score is masterful.
One word; chef-d'oeuvre!

Wow. The camerawork and staging create amazing momentum through the movie with variations in intensity and urgency that ebb and flow with the needs of the story. Performances are strong. The backstage setting which plays on some of the actors' actual lives and reputations is engrossing (though not necessarily very accurate).

BIRDMAN is so well made that minor quibbles and lapses loom large. But, really, the quibbles are things that I may not have even noticed in a less well made movie. And they're so brief and transient that I was sucked back in within seconds. The artistic accomplishment of the movie lends importance to the often less than truly profound 'insights' offered by the characters; which I find really interesting in the same way RENT is a great play about artists who aren't really very good artists.

BIRDMAN has earned a revisit or two before it leaves theaters.

Truly one of the best films of the year. Director Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu does outstanding directing and this one of the best ensembles I've seen this year. Michael Keaton plays an actor who was once popular in films as an action hero, who tries to make a comeback with a broadway play delivers a truly award winning performance. I truly believe he'll win the Oscar for best actor. Edward Norton who plays an actor that nobody really likes and is such a jerk delivers an award worthy performance as well and I believe is a shoe-in for a supporting actor nomination. Emma Stone who plays Keaton's messed up teenage daughter also delivers the best performance of her career so far and is possibly a nominee for supporting actress. Naomi Watts, Lindsay Duncan, and Zach Galifianakis also deliver great performances. One thing interesting about the film is that they say it's a comedy but the truth is it's not at all a comedy. It's heavy, dramatic, intense, though it has a few funny moments. It's a film that'll leave you hanging asking yourself what happened in the end. This film will hit Oscar season for sure. It's not a film for everyone, but it's a must see film.My grade=91%(A).
Trippy. Weird. Entertaining. I love Michael Keaton. Great cast all around.
Edward Norton and Michael Keaton are both fantastic. This movie is good but also very weird and the ending bothers me. I personally felt this was a little overrated.

It was funny and I definitely think the director deserves the awards because the way he shot it was very intimate and gave you a real stage theater experience. The jazzy percussion score also enhanced what we're seeing on screen. That being said I didn't get what the hype was about. It was a good movie but it wasn't amazing,
Michael Keaton's back in the spotlight and better than ever! Beautifully scripted and directed with a show-stopping cast. Ambitious, grounded and a must-see.
Filmed entirely in very long shots, this artistic inspiring film may not be for everyone...but it as sure as hell offers a must see experience for everyone. It's near perfection.

Aside from a disappointing final 10 minutes Birdman is as smart as it is funny. Although the entire cast is nothing short of brilliant, Keaton and Norton are at the top of their game. A great film for people who love film and an especially great film for people who love theater.
Great movie, just don't sit too close to the screen.

This movie was simply amazing. I honestly didn't think I would walk out thinking it would of been my favorite movie of the year. The cinematography is mind blowing. It's such a well orchestrated movie. Amazing performances from everyone involved.
A real gem with real emotion.  Welcome back Michael Keaton.  Best movie of 2014.

With incredible performances from the ensemble cast, especially from leading man Michael Keaton, as well as a thought provoking and a genre bending screenplay and great visual and technical aspects including the long 'continuous shot' cinematography, a unique drum score and slick direction, "Birdman" is a film that belies expectations and is a unique exploration of egotism, mental breakdown, actors and the unexpected virtue of ignorance.
Really good! The entire movie seemed like it was filmed in one single rolling shot.
there's going to be a ride based on this movie at my fantasy theme park.
Strong performances all around complimented with beautiful tracking shots.
There is a lot I like about this movie and there's a lot I think I'm still trying to figure out about this movie. Overall it was good and I'm not disappointed.

"Birdman" is spectacular because while its imagery and its action is often worthy of awkward laughter and face-palming, it has a seriousness to it, an intentionality behind it that I noticed and admired every moment. It has much to say about the culture we live in now and how it warps our priorities so that we focus on nothing more than the best way we can be adored. "Birdman" explores this with scenes of both over-the-top comedy and heart-wrenching drama. What REALLY sets "Birdman" apart is that it can have such a daring, albeit bizarre, style and structure, and yet its innovations do not distract because all weirdness is absorbed so deftly through the performances, particularly by Emma Stone, Edward Norton, and of course, the Birdman himself, the dynamite Michael Keaton. His performance as Riggin Thompson is, to me, despite all of the character's oddball misfortunes and eccentricities, like Atlas carrying the world on his shoulders. And Inarittu's direction, along with Lubezki's swirling cinematography, help us feel that weight that Riggin is carrying. All in all, every facet of the film was fascinating, skillful, and refreshingly original. "Birdman", from quite early on in its two hour run, peeled back my lips for a dumb-euphoric smile not only because it was funny and entertaining (and it was!) but also because I was genuinely moved. Films are rarely as inventive AND as full of technical unison and firestorm acting like this one.
Maybe one of the weirdest most existential movies I have ever seen. Be prepared to not know what is going on.

A kind of ingenious film that works as a chilling character study and a bleak satire of celebrity culture, "Birdman" is Michael Keaton's screw-you to the Hollywood that forgot him after the Batman movies of the '80s. His loss is the audience's gain.

Revised rating as it is one movie I have thought of most since seeing it. Master class in acting. One of the better movies I have seen this year if not a downer. The characters are not the most likable but acted so well. It's quirky and not like any movie seen this year. Challenging at times to tell what is real and in his head. Direction was fantastic. Best I've seen Emma stone in any movie.

Birdman or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance) is the latest film from Alejandro González Iñárritu and it's every bit as brilliantly bonkers as it's title might sugguest. Michael Keaton stars as Riggan, a washed up movie star once famous for playing an iconic superhero, Birdman, 20 years ago. Facing an existential mid-life crisis, Riggan takes it upon himself to write, star and direct a Broadway play adaptation in order to kickstart his faded career, but mostly to prove to himself that he's still relevant.

Keaton delivers a stunning performance as a deeply conflicted actor/father/husband burdened by his own ego (or is that alter-ego?). The film also features really terrific supporting performances from Edward Norton as a nutty, self-center method stage actor, and Emma Stone as Riggan's frequently neglected and recently rehabbed daughter, and Zach Galifianakis pops up every now and again as Riggan's high-strung production partner who seems on the edge of his own breakdown.

But as great as this ensemble cast is, perhaps the real star of Birdman is the film's dazzling camerawork by cinematographer Emmanuel Lubezki, which consists of several long tracking shots seamlessly blended to create the illusion that the film was shot in one continuous take. Lubezki, who won an Oscar last year for shooting Alfonso Cuarón's Gravity makes that film seem like a walk in the park compared to the high-wire work on display here. While this might sound like a gimmick, after 15 minutes of this 119 minute feature, the effect actually elevates the restless nature of the film's narrative; helping to blur the line between reality and fantasy. When Riggan's grip on sanity slips further away and confesses he hasn't slept in days, we not only sense it in Keaton's performance, but also feel that relentless exhaustion through Lubezki's camera, which never quits.

Iñárritu's film is a tragi-comedy about life, love, passion, ego, career, centered by a man who just might not be content with being merely just a man, and the jokes often land with a cold sting. It's ambiguous ending is very bittersweet and has been rolling around inside my head for days, and perhaps because of this it's hard for me to not think of the word "masterpiece" when describing the wonderfully bonkers fantasia that is Birdman or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance). So far, this is my favorite film of 2014.
Technically phenomenal. Keaton soars. Norton steals scenes. Five stars

Fantastically weird, amazing shot, acted and directed, and the cinematography (the tracking and panning shots especially) was beautiful. This won't be for everyone, but for those that it clicks with, it is wonderful.
Loved the movie. Was annoyed by the ending, but still loved the movie. Michael and Ed give amazing performances.
Amazing use of jazz percussion; also very intimately shot, and particularly captures the breathtaking feeling of being onstage. Still, not perfect, in my opinion.
great. see it immediately

Birdman!!!! Holy cow, amazing! I'm admittedly a little befuddled by the ending. Terrific performances by Ed Norton, Michael Keaton, Naomi Watts and Emma Stone. But the movie direction is the real star of this movie. Absolutely phenominal.
It's so crazy that this is already being heavily advertised! I don't understand?

What I got to say about "Birdman" is that there are three words to describe this movie. "talent, criticize, and fame." Does this movie give that? Your answer should be YES! The performances by the cast is great. "Everyone in this movie is on the top of their own game." The directing by Alejandro González Iñárritu is good. The screenplay by Nicolás Giacobone, Alexander Dinelaris, Jr., and Armando Bo is great. The cinematography is this movie is the best I have ever seen in a movie before! "It's so well done and I'm really pleased." The score in this movie has a good beat that works great in the movie. Finally, the effects are good as well. "I'm raving/declare that "Birdman" is an ambitious technical showcase powered by a layered storytelling. It's a must see movie!"
Good. Overrated. One of those movies your supposed to love but just isn't that good.
Can see why it won all the awards

Mesmerizing from start to finish. The one camera long shot technique used by IÃ±arritu was definitely another character that shined in this story but without getting in the way of the telling of the story. It was clever and smart. Mr. Keaton definitely deserved a best actor nomination from the Academy because of this amazing performance.
I sense some Oscars!
Satírica manifestación al mundo de Hollywood.
Worst movie I've seen for a while. I was constantly wanted to walk out, but stayed to see if it would have a redeeming ending, but it never did.

Amazing. This movie has it all too especially with some of the best directing, camera work and editing ive ever witnessed. Each scene flawlessly flows into the next which lead to some big wows from the audience. The acting is also top notch here. Im so glad to see Keaton back, starring in a role like this. Hes always been one of my favorites but theres definitely been a huge lack of him in movies for a long time now. Everyone else is just as great here too and there needs to be a ton of nominations here come Oscar season.
Loved it. The differences between fantasy and reality were a bit hard to follow at times, but they were great, strong artistic choices.

Yes, Michael Keaton is riveting in a truly fearless role (much like all early screenings have been buzzing since its release) and he will no doubt be a front runner for a well-deserved Oscar nod. THAT being said, room should also be saved for the other actors that inhabit this wild film who all shine just as brightly (save even more room for Emma Stone's show-stopping, mid-film firecracker). The flick itself is a meditation on the effects of fame, over-reaching ambition and artistic acceptance propelled by a jazzy, all percussion score. Saying any more would ruin the experience, so do yourself a favor. Oscar nominated Director Alejandro González Iñárritu (Babel) and cinematographer Emmanuel Lubezki have certainly outdone themselves here. A completely unpredictable tour-de-force of sights, sounds, emotions and humor.
This movie should be a big winner at the Oscars....especially for M.Keaton and Ed Norton...Knocks Nightcrawler out of the ballpark....don't miss this one.
One of the best flicks I've seen in the last decade or so.  They couldn't have possibly picked the main crew better.  My only gripe is maybe the last 5 minutes.

This is a Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu film, the same who directed Babel, 21 Grams, and Amores Perros. Much like his surrealist Biutiful, Birdman has all sorts of bizarre and fantastical imagery all around, making it a cinematic puzzle.

Struggling actor Riggan Thomson used to be Birdman in three epic movies, but hasn't done much until now. Risking his money, sanity, and reputation, he decides to bank everything on a play. He has adapted it from Raymond Carver's book, and everything is unraveling. His current girlfriend is pregnant, his ex-wife wants him to tend to their ex-druggie daughter, and his newest actor Mike Shiner (Norton) is a jerk/diva who likes to mess with other people for the hell of it. Showcasing floating cinematography that makes you feel close to the characters, (literally) the raw emotional scenes are directly in your face, making it feel really personal and close. The ending is ambiguous, but Birdman is ambitious and well acted, and a very scathing look at celebrity life. It is a very unique piece of filmmaking.
Outstanding performances, directing and flow.  Keaton and Norton are fantastic. Seamless. The supporting actors were pitch perfect. WHEW!!!

Very interesting movie the acting is superb the storyline is great until the end No definitive conclusion can be drawn. I don't understand  what happen. It's one of those movies that they didn't know how to end it.

Expecting a comedy from Mexican director Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu would have preposterous. The man was known for his cinema verite of suffering, notably Babel, 21 Grams, Biutiful, and his best film, Amores Perros, roughly translated to Love's a Bitch. Perhaps there isn't much of a shift going from tragedy to comedy. Inarritu's newest film, Birdman or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance), has been wowing critics and audiences alike, building deafening awards buzz for its cast, Iarritu, and the superb cinematography, but will it fly with mainstream audiences? This may be one of the weirdest Oscar front-runners in some time.

Riggan (Michael Keaton) is an actor best known for playing the superhero Birdman in the early 1990s and walking away from the franchise. He's still haunted by that role (sometimes literally) and struggling to prove himself as an artist. He's brokered all his money into directing, adapting, and starring in a theatrical version of Raymond Carver's short story, "What We Talk About When We Talk About Love." The show is in previews and about to open its run on Broadway but it's already got a rash of problems. The leading man needs to be replaced immediately. The supposed savior is famous actor Mike (Edward Norton), an undeniably talented but temperamental actor who pushes buttons to find some fleeting semblance of "truth." Mike's girlfriend, Lesley (Naomi Watts), is growing tired of his antics and desperate for her own long-delayed big break. Laura (Andrea Riseborough) is Riggan's "girlfriend" and co-star and may be pregnant. Sam (Emma Stone), Riggan's personal assistant and also his detached daughter, is fresh from rehab, and spiteful against her neglectful dad. Toss in Riggan's best friend/manager/play producer (Zach Galifianakis), Riggan's ex-wife (Amy Ryan), and a feared theater critic (Lindsay Duncan) who is determined to kill Riggan's show to send a message to the rest of Hollywood polluting the integrity of the theat-tah. Oh, and throughout all this, Riggan hears an ominous voice that alternating encourages him and humiliates him. 

It's an industry satire, a bizarre comedy, a father/daughter drama, an examination on identity and the complicated pulls of affection and admiration, and a stunning virtuoso technical achievement. As a movie, Birdman is hard to pin down or categorize. It's a movie that you definitely need to experience on your own rather than have described (don't stop reading, come back...), and that is a reason enough to see the film, a rare aspect among modern movies. It's an artistically offbeat movie and yet it ultimately is about one has been actor looking back on his career and coming to terms with his own impact with pop-culture, art, and his family. It's about a man struggling to find his place in his own life, beset at all odds by doubters and traitors and obstructionists. The refreshing aspect about Riggan is that he's a has-been but not a sad sack; he's fighting from the beginning, sometimes pathetically and sometimes in vain, but the man is always fighting to regain his dignity, to reclaim his life's narrative, and to fight for his legacy. Riggan, after all, set the stage for the modern superhero industry that currently dominates Hollywood bean counters. He was too just soon, and the parallels with Keaton (Batman) are superficially interesting but there's more of an original character here than a reflection of the actor playing him. He's neurotic, egotistical, hungry, and fighting for respect, like many actors, and the film flirts with the façades people inhabit. Many of the characters are emotionally needy, desperate for validation wherever they can find it. 

Another strength of the film is that it finds a moment for each of its talented ensemble players to shine, chief among them Keaton. The actor hasn't had a showcase like this in some time and he is a terrific guiding force to hold the entire story together. Whether it's marching in his tighty whities or working through his complicated degrees of neuroses, Keaton is alive in a way that is electrifying. We see several highs and lows over the course of two hours, some moments making us cheer on Riggan and others making us wince, but he comes across more like a person than just the butt of a joke. It's also just fun to watch him adopt different acting styles when he steps on stage, including one early on where he's purposely too stilted. It's so comforting to watch Norton (The Grand Budapest Hotel) get to be great again, not just good but great. Early on, you see the appeal of Mike, his allure, and Norton keeps pushing the audience, as well as the characters, back and forth with his wealth of talent. Stone (Amazing Spider-Man 2) spends most of the film as the sulky daughter but she gets to uncork one awesomely angry monologue against her loser dad. The thawing father/daughter relationship ends up supplying the film with its only degree of heart. Watts (The Impossible) is comically frazzeled for the majority of her time but gets a memorable character beat where she breaks down in tears, realizing her dream of "making it" might never materialize. Riseborough (Oblivion) also has moments where he sadness and vulnerability cut deep. The supporting characters aren't terribly deep but they all have a moment to standout. 

It's a decidedly offbeat film that dips into the surreal though never dives completely inside. The movie is rather ambiguous about whether or not the fantastical flourishes are a result of Riggan being mentally ill, or at the least overtaxed with stress. Is there really a Birdman or is it a voice in his head, a manifestation of his ego or a ghost to remind him of the past when he was a star? Does Riggan really have the powers he seems to believe he does, including the ability to make objects move with his mind? Innaritu playfully keeps the audience guessing, treating the bizarre in an offhand manner reminiscent of magic realism. The bizarre embellishments blend smoothly with the film's darkly comic tone. It's a funny movie but one that you laugh at between clenched teeth. 

Is it all the unblinking camerawork a gimmick? I don't think so. While the story can engage with its weirdness and surreal unpredictability, the long tracking shots bring a heightened reality to the unreal, they bring a larger sense of awe to the proceedings, watching to see the magic trick pulled off to the end. If anything, it's an extra thrill to the script and greatly compounds the artic audaciousness of the film, but I think it also channels the live-wire energy of theater, of watching actors have to walk that tightrope of performance and blocking, weaving together to pull off the ensemble. It makes the film medium feel more like live theater. Thematically I think the style also connects to the anxious mentality of Riggan. In the end, I don't truly care that much whether it's a gimmick or not (though I vote it is not) because the camerawork is rapturous. Made to resemble an entire two-hour tracking shot, it is a joyous thrill to watch these technical wizards do their thing, to watch the best in the business perform a visual magic trick over the duration of two hours. Even if you don't care for the overall movie you can at least be entertained by the imaginative and thoroughly accomplished cinematography by Emmanuel Lubezki, fresh from his Oscar for Gravity and who should be clearing shelf space for the next bushel of awards he's destined to win with this film. It's an intoxicating experience to behold, though the film is structured into 10-minute or so chunks for feasibility. If you want to watch a real cinematic magic trick, check out the film Russian Ark, which is an entire movie, performed in one uncut single tracking shot. 

I'm still wrestling with the debate over whether Birdman is an artistically ambitious romp or a truly great movie. Much like the characters in the film, I'm wrestling with whether I have confused my admiration with adoration. It's a movie that I feel compelled to see a second time, and maybe a third, just to get a handle on my overall thoughts and feelings. That may be a sign that Birdman is a film for the ages, or maybe it's just a sign that it's not as approachable and denied a higher level of greatness by its obtuseness. Inarritu's surreal showbiz satire is plenty entertaining, darkly comic, and a technical marvel thanks to the brilliant camerawork. The percussion-heavy musical score is another clever choice, naturally adding more urgency and anxiety to the proceedings. Birdman is a strange and beguiling movie, one that deserves to be seen, needs to be experienced, and stays with you rolling around in your brain. That sounds like a winner to me. 

Nate's Grade: A

MOVIE REVIEW - "BIRDMAN"


Maybe once a year, the Red Bank Arts Theatre devotes a single movie on both screens. I think
films like "Life is Beautiful", "The English Patient" and "Juno" played both screens at this fine
theatre for a time.

Though I knew nothing about "Birdman" starring Michael Keaton, Naomi Watts and Edward
Norton, I just assumed it had to be darn good to demand both screens. Before hitting
the theatre, I did a quick look on moviefone.com for a rating, and it was just 3 our of 5 stars.
Then I asked the long time clerk at the theatre and he said response has been mixed.

So I wasn't too optimistic but for $6 bucks plus Naomi Watts and Edward Norton in the
mix, it had to be good right?

This movie sailed totally over my head. Sort of like a wacky Coen Brothers movie, I just
didn't get it. Keaton, who in the movie, is a box office dynamo as the lead in "Birdman"
(a sci-fi action hero a la Spiderman). Wanting to break the stereotype, he tries his
hand at Broadway and not only is the lead and the director, but also funder the show.

While he tries to journey towards live theatre success, his "inner birdman" voice and
buddy, keeps whispering advise to return to his tried and true character and make like
"Birdman 6". Plus Keaton struggles with an ex-wife, a recovering daughter and nuts
co-lead (Norton) and more.

This movie just made no sense to me. If I used adjectives like weird, obscure, confusing
and dark, I'd be barely touching the surface. Folks, I did not like this movie at all. To
me, it put the "P" in pointless....save your $.

(Note - now that I've written this review, I went to copy and paste it onto
Rottentomatoes.com (which I always do) and was SHOCKED to see huge, very
positive rating #'s from both critics and audience viewers alike. Now I'm
totally confused. I didn't fall asleep in this movie at all hoping beyond hope that
the film would right itself..but it didn't. I'm totally bewildered that some many
folks like it so much.

Not for me.
Maybe the best film of 2014

Brilliant performances across the board! Especially, a dark and powerful leading performance from Keaton, a comical, yet almost slightly sad performance from Norton, and horrifically sad depiction of a lonely daughter from Stone. However, the story felt a bit repeated from the 2010 Black Swan film and yet it held its own as a method of which actor strive to become great by any means.
Fantastic movie. Definitely the most creative film of the year.

This is sure to be viewed as one of the best films of 2014; at least it ought to be.

Anyone can discuss the obvious correlation between Michael Keaton's character being an older actor, once known as Superhero Action star "Birdman", and his real life.  But whatever similarities there are, end with Keaton's masterful performance here.  In fact, the cast is absolutely brilliant.  Keaton is very deserving of award discussion, but Emma Stone and Ed Norton put on 2 of the best performances of their careers.  Turns out, Ed Norton playing himself  is a wonderful thing.  And Zach Galifianakis proves he's more than just a zany comic willing to do anything for a laugh.  Something told me he had much more to him.

Loved the one camera approach, and Inarritu's overall direction as well. 

Wouldn't shock me to see this movie get plenty of buzz; but, could easily be ignored as well.  Please, don't ignore "Birdman".
What a strange and unique film. Captivating and emotional. Entertaining and exhilarating . Great!
I liked it well enough, because of the heartfelt performances, but it was quite "theatrical" and a bit pretentious.

If you want to see something different this year see this movie. If you crave stellar performances by amazing actors then see this movie. If you want to say WTF at least a dozen times...then see this movie. If you want a memorable experience see this movie.

My only gripe...not enough actually Birdman. But given what this movie is...it is forgiven. Oh and also I still don't know what the Hell was going on. But I truly enjoyed it. 

P.S. Keaton vs Norton (nuff' said)

I don't see how flixster arrives at some of their ratings. Ed Norton and Michael Keaton are 2 of my favorite actors.  this movie the plot and production were terrible. they both must have owed someone a favor
Acting was superb with great directing but I found the story to just be okay.
Decent movie. Good acting and a very cool style, but it was weird and the plot didn't seem focused. It just seemed like a jumbled up series of short films.
Excellent movie. Loved how the film felt like I was watching an actual play. The acting is outstanding especially by Michael Keaton and Emma Stone.
Cinema, theatre and dance melt together into this unapologetic and glorious fable. Inarritu skillful single shot is a joy for the eye; Keaton and Norton give outstanding performance.
I am still pondering the film, and really enjoyed the acting. The direction was a bit screwy, but it works well for the story. Enjoyed the craziness!

This a weird movie.  The acting was great and the cinematography was well done.  This just wasn't the type of film I enjoy. 

I get it. A story about a man who has misplaced priorities, who struggles with what the external world says about the value of someone as they get older.  When you give your power to the approval of others and what society says your value is, you lose yourself.  

I would skip it. Zzzzz
Best movie I've seen in a long time. So unique. So attention-grabbing. So entertaining. Amazing acting.

There is loads of hype around this film and what is being spoken about as a monumental return for Michael Keaton as he plays an almost meta-version of himself.

Is his performance Oscar-worthy? Yeah, I really think he is, at this very early stage, the front-runner for sure...but the film itself?

Odd, very odd. A whimsical, almost supernatural film that does sometimes fly beyond comprehension. But it never stops being interesting.


However, the single most fascinating aspect of this film? For almost the entire two hours, it is filmed like it was taken in one long, uncut shot.

For reals.

A very big, Roger Ebert-style two thumbs up for the best Michael-Keaton-vs-Ed-Norton-in-his-underwear fight sequence of the year. This movie was so bizarre the bizarreness eventually became normal. When it was over, I was disappointed with the oppressive normalcy present outside the theater.
A legit best picture, stunningly shot

Delightful! Michael Keaton almost parodies his own career, which can be a little depressing at times. Other exceptional performances by Stone, Norton, and Galifinakis, who had the best line of the film near the end. A few weird sequences, but overall they kept me interested. Cinematography was great, filmed to appear as if the entire film was one continuous take. Go watch it if you've even been in a play, you'll love the drama of backstage antics!

Why does everyone love this movie? Yes, there are great actors in it, and they give excellent individual performances, but this movie was BORING. Nearly walked out, as this movie is so self-indulgent. Felt like an art house movie rather than something from Hollywood. I normally like this type of movie (like The Wrestler, etc), but not this one.
Perfect. A big f u to blocker busters. Make sure you have an i.q. high enough to realize  what this movie is trying to say.

Birdman is probably one of my favorite movies that came from 2014. The story of Birdman just feels new and original. I really enjoyed the film style of the movie it's all one shot which is incredible how they do it. The whole cast for Birdman did a phenomenal job especially Michael Keaton who gives his best performance of his entire career. I really enjoyed the score for this film which is all jazz music. I think this film is a technical achievement in movie making. One little problem I had with the film was the ending it just ends but it kind of works but I really just don't know.  I really don't have that much to say about this film but for you to check this film out it's an movie that I haven't seen before but I highly recommend checking this film out.

I just saw this outstanding film. I can't decide if it is my favorite film of the year because there were more than a few exceptional films this year (with some yet to be released), but BIRDMAN is right up there near the top. It's one of the most original films I've seen in a long time. Michael Keaton is magnificent!! Edward Norton gives one of his best performances ever! Naomi Watts and Emma Stone are also great. If you love film, you must see BIRDMAN.

Contemporary existential drama about the search for meaning in life. Keaton and Norton are both terrific, as is the unique cinematography (camera always moving), and soundtrack (love the drums!).  No Hollywood ending, multiple Oscar nominations likely.

I enjoyed the exaggerated characters.   I wonder if a black comedy can exist without someone killing themselves.  Suicide isn't necessarily the most awful thing that can happen to a person or to those around them.  For example the emotional abuse these characters dished out to those around them was enough to make this the "black" for me.

This movie is WILDLY entertaining. And if you're at all concerned about cinema in general you need to get out and see it. It's original, creative and just..ALIVE for lack of a better word. Top-notch acting, sure, but the work done by Inarritu as the director and more importantly by Lubezki as cinematographer is absolutely amazing. An ENTIRE movie styled as a SINGLE FREAKING TAKE? Simply awe-inspiring. It's a helluva ride, and I suggest you take it ASAP.
best movie I've ever seen I DONT CARE ANYMORE, MAN IM CALLIN IT NOW
a rather odd....but well acted film.  Overall......Quite Decently Acted....

Brilliantly conceived.  I'd not heard a lot of info and then about 20 minutes in I turned to my wife and said "holy shit, do you see what's going on here?" "  She of course did not but I was blown away by the film technically, by the performances across the board (Michael Keaton might want to start penning his Oscar speech), and even Emma Stone who I normally simply cannot watch on any screen big or small is outstanding.  This film is an accomplishment.  A must see.  You cannot say you miss good movies anymore and then miss this film.  Probably my favorite movie since Inglorious Basterds.  I'm seeing it again this weekend just to look for the cuts.  How fucked up is that.
Great performances especially Keaton and Norton.  Great writing, music and camera work all contribute to a wonderful experience.

All you have heard about Alejandro Gonzales Iñarritu's Birdman or the Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance is true, and them some.

It showcases a career-best performance from Michael Keaton in what many regard as his come-back vehicle (in fact he has never abandoned acting), and I'll tell you why: His electric physicality and the nervousness of his speech delivery made him ideal for comedy back in the 80's, which he took advantage of up until Beetlejuice. But his casting in Tim Burton's Batman was a career turning point that made him a worldwide star for all ages. He would reprised the role in Batman Returns but dropped from the rest of the series, just like Sean Connery left Bond's franchise: to pursue new horizons and go where he had not gone before.

None of his efforts after Batman proved as successful as the superhero series (which is still the rule in Hollywood nowadays) so he slowly vanished from the minds of his audiences, and has been completely unknown to the new ones.

So it's a no-brainer that revered Mexican filmmaker Alejandro González Iñárritu offered him the role of Riggan Thomson, a washed-up Hollywood actor who is about to revive his career by directing, acting and adapting Raymond Carver's short story What We Talk About When We Talk About Love for Broadway. The role asks for an aging man haunted by his long gone superhero persona and the everyday insecurities of actors confronted with success, recognition and relevance and Keaton brings a helpful baggage to the plate, even if he proclaims this is the most dissimilar character he's ever played.

To read the full review, go to http://www.examiner.com/review/birdman-or-the-unexpected-virtue-of-ignorance-a-best-picture-of-2014-contende?CID=examiner_alerts_article

The bruised ego gets its ultimate critical treatment in Alejandro Iñárritu's latest piece of cinematic art, aptly titled BIRDMAN OR (THE UNEXPECTED VIRTUE OF IGNORANCE); the title, art in itself.  I'm a lover of the theatre, particularly the Broadway stage, so it's no surprise that the film, in all its disturbing glory and darkness, is right up my alley.  There's a lot of substance and subtext to be discovered if one is able to look at the screen long enough to witness the mental horror and anguish that occupies the cast of conceited,  amoral and jaded characters that occupy the stage in an effort to leave a mark with fans and critics alike,  Michael Keaton plays a desperate, washed-up, ex-movie star, most famous for BIRDMAN, his superhero role in a trilogy twenty years back.  Now in a frantic effort to make a legitimate move to save his career he must battle his lifelong demons that have so far plagued his id.  But in mounting a New York play about love as his own labour of love, Keaton's character must also confront and battle the people he loves, those who love him and even those who will do just about anything to stay on top of the game.  It's a game of survival to the bitter end. The Broadway stage comes across as a terminal station in the world of ambition and hope. There's a fiery take-no-prisoners approach found in every person of the theatre, including the crucial, indispensable critic.  That Keaton's BIRDMAN ultimately makes it on stage and then soars only affirms that the theatre, even if magical, is not for the faint of heart and that actors are a messed-up, desperate lot.  It also confirms that Hollywood has served up yet another dark, self-critical portrayal that begs to ask us mere mortals why we become so fascinated with the glamourous world of celebrity if we realize that they are far more troubled than we will ever be.
WTF?!?!  Good actors but WEIRD.

Birdman is shot and edited in such a way that it appears to be a single take throughout 90% of the film. It tells the story of Riggan Thompson (Michael Keaton) a former superstar of a superhero franchise known as Birdman. He has since washed up and is out to prove he was more than just a lycra bird suit and big action scenes. To do this he is writing, directing, producing, and starring in a Broadway adaptation of Raymond Carver's What We Talk About When We Talk About Love. The production hits speedbumps along the way to opening night and Riggan has a series of mental speedbumps as well.

Things I Liked:

Michael Keaton and Edward Norton. These two guys tear it up throughout this movie. There are a lot of great scenes in this movie but there is this one fairly early on where it's just the two of them rehearsing on stage and the moment they let the characters go you suddenly realize that you have gotten drawn in and are glued to the screen. They both deliver monsterous performances and create incredibly interesting and multidimensional characters. Unbelievable.

The Cinematography. There is a reason that Emmanuel Lubezki has two cinematography oscars. He's phenomenal at his job. The movie, like I said, is shot to appear as though it is a single take that flows through space and time. The movie has a beautiful look and uses both intense chaos and absolute stillness to the greatest of effects. The movie uses sets that create the cramped backstage atmosphere of the St. James Theatre and really makes you feel like a fly on the wall because there is no wiggle room to move around these sets.

The Score. The soundtrack to this movie is absolutely perfect. A combination of over the top classical pieces and freestyle jazz drums. The sweeping score moments are mostly to accompany Riggan's high moments and the times when he is truly feeling on top of the world, the drums are to assist with his inner conflict and the conflict of the show as it falls apart at the seams. The score isn't usually something that stands out to me in movies but this one added so much that it is hard to ignore.

Things I Didn't Like:

Nothing Really. I was transfixed by this movie the first time I got out of this. I caught numerous moments and subtle things I missed from the first time. The third time I watched it I was over come with excitement. I haven't found a moment I was taken away, a problem, line readings I didn't like, characters I felt were unnecessary. This movie is an experience that drags you along and you can't let go until those credits roll because you WILL miss something if you aren't paying attention.

Overall. Overall, Birdman was a reminder of how amazing movies can be. It was a reminder that there are still original things that can come out of Hollywood. It was a reminder that actors who you had written off can come back and astound you multiple times. And for me personally, it's an excuse to indulge all of my interests: theatre, film, superheroes, music, etc. It's an experience. And one I am happy to take part in multiple times over.

Ahhhh this was incredible! When a movie makes you go "WTF?!?!" at the end, you know it's great. My favorite parts, of course, were the long takes. It gave the actors a chance to actually ACT, instead of stopping every couple lines to set up a new shot. I probably did the wrong thing in that I tried to count all the times the takes ended (I counted 6 or 7), so that meant I wasn't completely immersed in the world of Birdman, but that's okay. I loved it anyway. And I will be seeing it again.
This film is a masterpiece

Birdman (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance) is a very deep film about a washed up actor who wants to be relevant again. With brilliant performances mainly from Michael Keaton and Emma Stone (his Daughter), Birdman goes where no movie has gone and did I mention it is done one take!!!

The supporting cast was great, I was especially impressed with Zach Galifianakis, he can be taken seriously as a serious actor. I just can't say enough about how good this movie really is.

Is Birdman the best film of the year? Yeah, but that'd be selling it short. A more meaningful accolade would be to recognize that a hundred years from now, film students of the 22nd century will probably be writing dissertations about it. 

I CANNOT overstate how completely floored I am right now. The writing, acting, direction, music, cinematography -- OH GOD, THE CINEMATOGRAPHY -- everything about this movie comes together to tell a riveting, deeply emotional story about self-doubt that is probably more universal than most people would like to admit. The characters are larger than life, but played with such empathy and panache as to make human flaws like self-loathing and narcissism endearing and relatable. 

Every scene, every moment is bursting at the seems with tension and real human drama. Doesn't hurt that the movie is also incredibly funny. You should see this movie ASAP, not so that you can be one of the cool kids, but because the more time you let pass by before seeing it, the more likely it becomes that some schmuck will ruin one or more of the movie's many surprises by giving away spoilers. This is one of the most clever and innovative movies I've ever seen -- an absolute inspiration. A+!!!!!!!!!!!

I don't understand what the big fuss is here.  This movie has great acting, but the funny parts don't connect into anything meaningful, and there's a long part in the middle that just drags.  I was hoping it would do something at the end that would make it all worth it, but it just didn't do it for me.

I left this film to almost last before the Oscars because I didn't think it would appeal to me. Definitely not for a mainstream audience. They'll just think it's weird and hate it, will not get the complexities and deeper meaning. I LOVED it! A great director (Amores Perros, Babel). As far out as this may appear at times, the realism of an aging actor/father/husband, integrity of a man is captured perfectly by Keaton and the writing. This couldn't have worked without his appeal. Excellent casting all around especially Zach Galifianakis. Music great, shots of NYC great! Music bits great.

Saw it last night - wow - what performances. I feel like I was dragged voluntarily thru the seediest back alleys of NYC's theatre district & viewed the darkest interiors of some really profound but troubled souls with brutal honesty at the core. Keaton was perfect. Norton was perfect. Stone was perfect. My only disappointment at all was that Norton's character disappeared toward the end - I wanted much more of him. One of the best films of 2014. Great acting and very topical which is its absolute strength for watchign it now but also it's crux with eventual age. Though Michael Keaton is phenomenal, the real standout is Edward Norton who better win best supporting actor for this. While the  film is all about it's meta element, I love how it pays homage to film history itself, with scenes evoking Felini's 8 1/2 and even a nod to Mulholland Dr. Recomended, especially for those who wonder what has happened to Keaton since Birdman. I mean Batman.

I walked into this expecting the cinematography to be too sweet to take in. I didn't realize this was going to be structured to be a single-take film which explains a lot of the wide angle shots and intense close-ups. 
The story is a great concept. I enjoy dual story telling with the play and the deconstruction of Michael Keaton's purpose in life. 
Some of the acting from Emma Stone and Ed Norton is absolutely astounding. The assertion of Emma Stone's individuality to Keaton is a very memorable moment and definitely a demo reel piece for anyone to accomplish. My problem with the film is the writing. The usage of foreshadowing is too much where you know exactly what will happen with the film after the first 40 minutes. Scenes that should have had more suspense were ruined due to the over use of this device.

It's been a long time since I've seen a work of art this innovative, poetic, awe inspiring, ambiguous in interpretation, and masterfully executed.  The camera waltzes through the story with a pace and fluidity that feels like a dazzling magic trick.  The all percussive score is equally remarkable and stirringly effective.  It's the kind of work that can spur artists to think outside of the box and push the envelope with their art.  Utterly impressed would be an understatement.
don't care what anyone says: Edward Norton was the HIGHLIGHT of this movie!!!!!

While Birdman is an art movie and it has some of the typical pretentious elements (literary references, surreal absurdity and complex dialogues) it's not a slow clunker. It's funny and while it can be depressing too, it goes by pretty smoothly.

I truly didn't know what to expect as the trailer is a bit misleading. This is a movie about success and failure. About expectations and reality. Above all, it's a bout perceptions.

Birdman might very well be the best movie I've seen in a few months. That is a tall order since St. Vincent and Nightcrawler are also incredible. 

Don't miss any of them.

Michael Keaton could possibly win his first Oscar for this film. He shines here. It is one of his best. He was overlooked for films such as "Clean and Sober" and "My Life."  It is also hard to watch him here, and not think of "Batman."  Every time they mentioned "Birdman" in the film, I heard in my head, "Batman," instead.  Michael's performance reminded me of Mickey Rourke's performance in "The Wrestler" and Jeff Bridges's performance in "Crazy Heart." All of those films, deals with a star, who has fallen from glory seeking redemption and one last shot to stardom. Keaton's performance here is both hilarious and will make you cry.

The film has a unique style that some audiences might not like. The entire film feels like one big long take without any cuts. The editing here is amazing and should win for Best Editing.  The style in my opinion, grabs the audience into the shoes and the mindset of Keaton's character. Some audiences might not like that, and prefer a straightforward style to tell the story. However, I praise Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu for choosing to do this daring style to tell the story.

The story makes me think of the late George Reeves, of how he didn't want to be typecast as Superman and be viewed as a serious actor.  The film also comments about superhero movies and the public's opinions about them.  The film reminded me of movies like The Wrestler, Black Swan, Crazy Heart, The Artist, The Player, Bullets Over Broadway, and Hollywoodland. The ending seems open-ended and ambiguous that will definitely keep the audience talking after the film is done.

Besides Keaton, Ed Norton, the former Incredible Hulk, is very good here and a great foil and antagonist to Keaton. He is so over the top, it is hilarious.  He should get a nomination for Supporting Actor.  Emma Stone, Gwen Stacy of Spiderman, is also really good as Keaton's daughter. Her scenes with Keaton reminded me of the scenes in The Wrestler between Mickey Rourke and Evan Rachel Wood. I would love to see Stone get nomination for Supporting Actress for the film. Naomi Watts, Zach Galifianakis, Amy Ryan, and Andrea Riseborough provide solid supporting work here.

I definitely recommend this film and I hope that Michael Keaton finally gets nominated and wins a best actor Oscar for the film. He deserves it.
Frenetic. Strange. Good.
inventive, amusing, startling and a great ride!

While watching Birdman, I had a feeling that made me angry. The feeling of not being able to comment, yell, or express any kind of excitement about what was happening on the screen, because I was watching it in a public place, and it would have been inappropriate. Yes, Birdman was that great. 
Starting with the bewildering cinematography by Emmanuel Lubezki (who else?). Thanks to his amazing work, Birdman looks like ONE continuous shot, and that's beyond genius.
The cast left me speechless. Michael Keaton's performance as the washed-up blockbuster actor was incredible. Through his performance we see a character unable to connect with his present self by not forgetting his past. Nostalgia, desperation, feelings of being forgotten, and the ridiculousness of his acts, were all conveyed by his amazing performance. I'm expecting him to be the next Best Actor Oscar winner. Edward Norton also gave an amazing performance, which is really great because the last memorable performance he gave was in American History X in 1998. Emma Stone and Naomi Watts are amazing as well. Basically, I want to see all of them nominated.
Birdman is one of my favorite films of the year so far, and I'm so happy that it was directed by Alejandro GonzÃ¡lez IÃ±Ã¡rritu, because he keeps surprising me with every movie he makes. Amores Perros, 21 Grams, Babel, and Biutiful are all amazing in their own ways. Birdman is no exception; it is originality, uniqueness, spectacle, and awesomeness all packed in the same film. Expect it to be a strong contender for the Oscars this year.

In a glorious mish-mash that results in a kind of "American Beauty" retelling mixed with elements of "Synecdoche New York," Alejandro Gonzalez Innaritu's masterfully shot and edited masterpiece, "Birdman," sprawls across every color on the spectrum of human emotion and absolutely wows with a career-changing performance from Michael Keaton.

This one is a movie lovers movie. The camerawork starts out in an arthouse style to set the mood of a Hollywood celebrity looking for credibility as an actor. You see bad acting and the drama unfold in a way that, while not surprising, has an affect on the set of a play they are trying to perform. Many movies about the industry sort of go self important and just when this movie begins to have that feeling, the tone and feel of the movie changes and you find yourself inside the mind of of someone about to crack under the pressure and strain of his family, money and career. At the end, the line between acting and reality is gone and concludes in a very whimsical way.  Great movie lovers movie, probably worth the price admission for the rest...

"Popularity is the slutty little cousin of prestige "
A delightful piece of cinematographic art, Birdman is a polarizing movie one would either love or hate. Or pretend to like it due to the overall hype surrounding it, even if he/she cannot get.  An emotional exploration zigzagging between sharp humor and hard-to-chew drama this is a magnificent philosophic and existential story. A personal journey of a troubled character, this delivery becomes an experience which the audience gladly shares and enjoys.
The story is about an age-ing actor who has never found his right place on the screen. Riggan (Michael Keaton), famous for his Birdman superhero roles, has always aspired to prove himself on Broadway. In a final grasp to set, to direct and to act in his own Broadway "baby" he risks everything he has gained throughout his acting career: financial assets, image and family. As he struggles with the preparations for the premiere and the co-operation with his team, he needs to fight countless concept battles with his talented but disgusting , alcohol-addicted on stage partner Mike (Edward Norton), to build-up a bridge to his somehow estranged daughter and to face the biggest challenge of his life: himself.
Loud, bold and hugely ambitious, every detail in Alejandro González Iñárritu's story is provocative and superb. It is as if the story develops on the edge of a sharp razor and might crash and disappoint in every moment. None of this happens and the audience remains mesmerized throughout every single battle of Riggan with his internal demons, with his fears, unfulfilled dreams; with his family, stage partners and critics. Below the heavily philosophical and existential content, there is an underlying hint (or actually a criticism) towards the current state of film-making and acting, but few would note this in the movie simply because everyone would find its own part that impresses him/her most.  Iñárritu's delivery contains something special and personal for everyone. You could find a line, a monologue or a dialogue that would touch you, provoke you and stun you. Sometimes it comes out of nowhere, just like the ruthless, realistic and eye-opening monologue Riggan's daughter (Emma Stone) when she quarrels with her father over a cigarette of weed. Or the Edward Norton's one-liner: ""Popularity is the slutty little cousin of prestige ".
On top of the delightful content, Birdman pleases with its brilliant technical presentation, including 8th Cinematography nomination for Emmanuel Lubezki and why not a second Oscar, and spectacularly long and continuous camera takes. These single takes require getting the best of your actors and director  Iñárritu has definitely managed to squeeze out every single drop of talent from his cast. There is hardly anyone that could match Michael Keaton's performance for the Best Male Act at the Oscars this year. Complex, emotional, disturbed and simply astonishing, Michael Keaton delivers a lifetime performance. Even the impressive Edward Norton, who seems to dominate with his presence in the beginning of the movie, is outshined by Norton as Riggan. In the end, one would wonder whether Keaton is the reason for Birdman being such a delight!
In conclusion, Birdman is a must see delivery! Even if it fails at the Oscars it has already become a contemporary classic that would be mentioned as a benchmark for remarkable film-making and acting by many. It is true that all the hype surrounding it has attracted many mainstream viewers, who blink at the final credits and wonder what is so special about this movie. So it must be also said that Birdman is not an experience for everyone, just for those who perceive film-making, cinematographic experience and exquisite acting as something intimate.

How do you even begin to discuss a film like this? For starters, I've heard many use the term "tour de force," when referring to this majestic piece of cinema. I guess that's about as appropriate as you can get. In fact, BIRDMAN or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance), is the very damn definition of a tour de force. The movie is an exhilarating leap forward from an already impressive disposition for director Alejandro González Iñárritu and his star, Michael Keaton. The film follows Riggan Thomson, an actor struggling to shake off the identity of the superhero he played twenty years ago (sound familiar?), as he attempts to rejuvenate his career through directing, writing, and starring in his own stage adaptation of a Raymond Carver short story. Thomson must eventually face the fact that he lives in a world where audiences only make you a star if you have the most YouTube views, the most Twitter followers, or, maybe, if you sign your soul away to some big-business comic book production company, such as Marvel (cough cough, Robert Downey Jr., cough cough). The journey leading to opening night is a fantastical one, lucidly exhibiting Riggan's struggle with not only his ego, but his family, his crumbling career, and his telepathic abilities (yeah, you heard me correctly). We never get a concrete response from the director whether some of the more supernatural elements of the film are real or imaginary, as we only receive contradicting clues along the way, but what's it matter anyway? Whether Riggan does in fact possess divine abilities is hardly at stake. The parallel is clear - Riggan's powers correlate strongly with what the film does best: parading, comprehensively, the indisputable superpowers of its cast and crew members; Keaton giving an Oscar-worthy execution of acting; its cinematographer, Emmanuel Lubezki, whose love of the long-take is ever so present here (and never has been more effective); and its director. Birdman is brilliant on an astounding number of levels. It's layered, complexly and intimately, with so many in-jokes and small nudges. Not only is it a technical showcase, much like last year's Gravity (also shot by Lubezki), but in contrast, it actually features a meaty, ultra-meta story, with some truly remarkable, mostly haunting, performances along the way. But, what am I saying? These sentences I'm spewing out are all just labels... Labels, labels, labels. All I can say is, go see this damn movie.

A really visceral and interesting work of art. This film was, without a doubt, some hardcore oscar-bait; however, unlike some other films of 2014 (eg. Foxcatcher) it wasn't strictly limited to just enticing the Academy. Birdman is an experience in the truest sense of the word. Whether it be the stellar performances or absolutely astonishing cinematography, the film always has something going for it in every scene. The symbolism is countless, and the whole "what is real acting" is a bit heavy-handed. But, the movie succeeds on its devotion to showcasing the mind of Riggan and his downward spiral down a path of mental instability that starts to make the audience even question what is reality and what is imagination. This dichotomy pervades through the plot in such a seamless matter that everything somehow culminates into this fantastically surreal dark comedy. 

I truly did enjoy this film much more than I expected. The incessant jazz score in the background is so subtly perfect that you almost just get lost in the rhythm. On face value though, I still 100% believe that Boyhood should've won Best Picture, but I really don't have a problem with Birdman snatching it away... it is too good of a film to knock. Great job.
Amazing - one the most amazing films I've seen in sometime and the best from Innarritu since Amores Perros.
This movie was amazing.  Michael Keaton will be an Oscar candidate, Ed Norton as well.   The "on-going" filming style really worked.  See it for that alone.   5 stars

I put off this post because I didn't want to write it in the middle of a blogging marathon. Since it was just a unique and incredible film (in the running for my fave of the year), I wanted to do it justice with a clear and awake head, so I thought I could find that time within the couple of days that my marathons were auto-posting. Oops.

Birdman or The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance, centers around Michael Keaton as Riggan Thompson. Back in the day, Riggan led the popular Birdman franchise. He eventually gave up the role, and his career spiraled ever since. In a last ditch effort to get his life and career on track, he's eyeing Broadway. The film begins with the night before the first preview of the show which he has written, directed, and stars in and leads up to the hopeful opening night. Besides the usual drama that comes along with opening a show (difficult actors, budget constraints, short timelines, etc), he's got his own personal demons to wrestle with, most of which are manifest by the voice of Birdman that is always in his head.

I don't know if I can even count all the reasons I loved this movie. There was just so much that felt like it was a present just for me. I'll be honest. This one is kinda weird. Okay, very weird. Not everyone will get it. God knows there's a lot that I had to shrug off and just go with. But if you can suspend disbelief for two hours and let the Birdman fly, it's well worth it.

I started to write down "first thing that's jumping out at me" but then three thoughts hit me at once and I couldn't decide which to start with. Umm, okay, the theatre part of everything. I loe theatre. I've been involved in many shows and seen countless others. I make trips down to NYC every so often and see as much Broadway as I can, to the point where I know midtown NYC better than a good friend who lives in the city. So of course it was great to be able to follow the action within a Broadway show, getting to see behind the scenes and how some of the last minute drama that I'm all to familiar with plays out. There's one detail about it that got me excited beyond all reason. The real life Broadway theater they used is the St James. That's where American Idiot played. I was there 9 times for that show. I wrote my name on the lobby wall (it was a thing for Idiot). I recognized all of the sights outside when we viewed the street, and I relished each shot of backstage, getting to see where all the magic of my obsession came together. If there was any venue I would have wanted to see that way, this would have been it.

As we trekked thru the theater and the nearby city, there was some incredible cinematography at play. Think about any movie you watch. How many times do you see cuts? Prolly every few seconds or so (less if it's a Michael Bay flick). You cut from one side of the conversation to another. You cut between scenes. You cut and pick up when someone changes locations. Not so in Birdman. The idea was to make it all seem like one long dream-like shot. There was about ten minutes between each cut, and the ones that were there were masked to create a flow. The effect was unreal. Each piece had to be precisely choreographed so that entrances matched with the long tracking shots down twisty corridors. Then you had to hope that no one messed up their lines, or it would have had to start all over. 

But oh, these actors were up to the task, leading some of the SERIOUS Oscar buzz (some are predicting as many as 10 nods total) for this film. I'll just make a blanket statement about the difficulty with the long shots that I just mentioned. Clearly, they all kept up. Michael Keaton had the role of a lifetime. Of course, everyone is drawing the Batman/Birdman connection, but aside from that, Keaton claims Riggan Thompson is the farthest removed from himself of any character he's ever played. Currently, he is the man to beat this year, and its not hard to see why. 

And as a front runner in the supporting category, we've got my boy Edward Norton. To be honest, in the past couple years, his status as my fave actor was starting to fade. Not that I had anyone to replace him (Tom Hanks? Christian Bale? Channing Tatum?), but it had been so long since the days where his films allowed him performances that floored me. Birdman brought it all back. As Mike Shriner, the last minute replacement actor brought in just in time for the first preview, Norton gets to shine in a number of ways. He's got some dramatic moments, as you find out some of the inner turmoil he goes thru, but he also has some great comedic moments. Shriner's antics know no bounds, and Norton relishes in the chance to play them up. We've only seen Norton do comedy a couple times before (Death to Smoochy, Keeping the Faith), but he excels at it, and I wish he'd do more. And getting a chance to combine both ends of the spectrum of his immense skills is such a treat. Of course, any time his name is mentioned even remotely close to Oscar, I'm in his corner. I really hope this is his year. He shoulda had it 15 years ago for American History X. Birdman shows off an even more versatile and nuanced performance.

Emma Stone is also garnering some supporting buzz as Riggan's daughter Sam, currently hired as his assistant to keep her out of trouble and in recovery. She still manages to find some trouble. A much darker turn than we've ever really seen from her, but with that same spark of mischief in those big eyes. Another worth mentioning is Zach Galifianakis. Usually, I can only take so much of his awkward comedy. Turns out, he doesn't need to hide behind it. He had a few moments of frantic energy, but didn't cross into that awkward territory he's known for. I loved seeing him in a serious role, and really want to see more of that. Huh, it's the inverse of Norton's situation. Cool. Other notable names: Naomi Watts, Merritt Weaver, Amy Ryan, and prolly others that may mean more to you than me. I was describing this movie to someone, and as I usually do, I lead with the cast. Their reaction was something like "What?! How have I not heard of this movie! I love all those people and I don't even care what it's about I have to see it!" Yes. Yes you do have to see this.

-----Birdman is one of those rare films that has been able to both excite and frustrate me. On the whole it is an absolute brilliant film, and one that I loved. But it also employs such obtuse and occasionally pretentious symbolism that you almost lose the film at times. If not for these indulgences Birdman just might have been perfect. Still, being near perfect makes it one of the best and most interesting films I've seen in a while. Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu has directed a film that is technically engaging, funny, energetic, poignant, and filled with universally outstanding performances. I highly recommend it.  
-----The film takes place almost entirely in the St. James theatre on Broadway. Here Riggan Thompson has written, directed, and is starring in a theatrical adaptation of Raymond Carver's What We Talk About When We Talk About Love. Riggan, played by Michael Keaton, is a washed-up Hollywood actor famous for having starred in the Birdman superhero films twenty years previously. Two decades on he is desperate to re-start his career with his Broadway show. The show is a few days from opening night, and before it opens Riggan must deal with an antagonistic actor, hateful critics, public ridicule, his fractured private life, and his own crushing self-doubts. Meanwhile all of his insecurities and doubts literally speak to him in the voice of Birdman, and he may or may nor have telekinetic powers. In the end Riggan may pay for his newfound success with his sanity. 
-----The performances in Birdman are universally brilliant, especially from Michael Keaton, Edward Norton, and Emma Stone. Riggan Thompson is a man terrified of being irrelevant, and torn between his desire to be famous and loved and his desire to be truly artistically fulfilled. It's one of the best roles Keaton has ever had, and he wonderfully leads the ensemble cast. The best, however, is Edward Norton, who gives the best performance I've seen all year. He plays Mike Shiner, clearly the best actor in the show. But while he achieves perfect truth onstage, he is incapable of being honest offstage. Antagonizing everyone around him and just being a terrible human being, Mike is an obnoxious character, and Edward Norton plays him perfectly. Then there's Emma Stone who plays Sam, Riggan's daughter, and the only person Mike acts honestly with. Emma Stone plays off Norton as well as he does off her, and their scens are among the highlights of the film. Though Michael Keaton is the clear lead, he backed up every step of the way by the entire supporting ensemble. 
-----Birdman gives us a unique look into the world of Broadway theatre. The film is presented in one massve  tracking shot that winds through the hallways and rooms of the St James. This gives a bold and kinetic view into the lives of these various characters as they attempt to put on this play. The script is witty, insightful, and full of clever dialogue. Which is why it so frustrating when, in the third act, the film starts to be so overtly symbolic and metaphorical that it threatens to derail the momentum gathered by the first hour and a half of the film. As of now I have seen Birdman twice and I am still unable to figure out the underlying meaning, if there is any, of these surreal moments. Perhaps the problem lies with me instead of the film, but these moments, more than anything else, are what hold the film back for me.  
-----Birdman is the best film I've seen this year, despite these frustrations. It asks many interesting questions about the nature of fame versus prestige, and the balance between being a celebrity and being an actor. Through its ensemble of interesting characters it tackles the nature of why we do art, and this exploration is ultimately a joyful one. I rarely have so much fun at the cinema.

A well-written movie, with superb acting and phenomenal directing will usually get 4 and a half stars from me.  To get 5, it needs to be that one element more special than just a fantastic movie.  It has to be unique or a different perspective on a previously tackled subject.  "Birdman"  (or "The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance") fits that description and gets 5 stars only because it cannot get more.  Every movie starts with a story.  The story portrayed here is flawless.  It is a brilliant story written in such a dark, nonsensical way, yet anchored with so much dialogue that 2 hours zooms by as the viewer tries hard to absorb it.  It's the kind of story that leaves you talking about it, reading more about it and wanting to watch it again just to be sure you got it all.  In that sense, it was perfect.  To execute all of that dialogue, the casting and acting had to be perfect, and I see no way it could have been done more perfectly.  The attraction to the initial construct of the story centers around a seemingly washed-up actor who, 20 years removed from his heyday, is seeking to be both respected as an actor and appreciated by the fans who left him long ago.  However, as all good stories will include, the irony is, the meat of the story is not truly about that at all. Sure, it is peripherally, but the point of the film is about so much more than that.  So, on the surface, getting Michael Keaton to play a role that is meant to lure audiences in thinking that the comparison to Michael's character, Riggin, and Michael himself is what the movie is about, but instead the audiences will be fed so much more.  And to do that not only takes excellent writing, but also solid casting and acting.  "Birdman" also perfectly does this.  Since the majority of the film is about the pretension of acting as a whole, both in celebrity-driven Hollywood as well as the self-importance of the Broadway theater scene, it was vital to cast actors who have done both and can seriously, yet ironically, play those kinds of characters.  Emma Stone and the brilliant Edward Norton solidify the execution of this story in a way that makes it so fun to absorb the deluge of dialogue in this 2-hour film.  That brings us to directing.  The gasoline in this machine, which relies heavily on how the acting carries out the dialogue and story, is rooted strongly in how the camera and direction guide the audience cinematically through it.  The dizzying, sometimes frantic, pace of the camera work and the perception of a 2-hour single-shot film, is the main reason the acting and script is able to be absorbed by the audience.  The chemistry of all of these elements are done so perfectly, that 4.5 stars was an easy award.  What put "Birdman" over the top, however, is the sheer absurdity of its subject matter.  The film is so schizophrenic, yet has to be in order to be coherent.  It's a dark comedy.  It's a drama.  It's an exquisite study into the minds of the type of people who become actors, why they get sucked into the field, what tortures them throughout their careers and, in the end, how they wrestle with the drama that has to be created in their own lives to even continue on such a seemingly-futile balance of integrity and popularity.  The definition of success as an actor is almost completely blurred.  Then to attempt to blend any success in that craft with success in real life is just impossible.  "Birdman" is such a farce, yet brilliantly constructed as an almost educational analysis of the industry that one walks out of the film simply amazed and nearly breathless trying to comprehend what had just been witnessed.  "Birdman" is what filmmaking is all about and what is so rarely seen.  It will be taught in universities for years.  It deserves Oscar recognition for directing, best acting, best supporting acting and screenplay.  It's just that good.

It's Hollywood satire. It's tragicomedy. It's art turned inside out. It's character study. It's a giant inside joke. It's a reflection on meaning, parenthood, popularity, love, relationship and truth. But - most amazingly - it is exceptionally good at being all those things. Birdman is different than anything Inarritu has done before, and in a good way. Brilliantly conceived, brilliantly shot, brilliantly scored, brilliantly acted...just plain brilliant.

Without fail 1-2 times a year I get suckered in by a PR campaign and this year it is "Birdman The Unexpected Virtue Of Ignorance" being the full title but being known as "Birdman".  The film is being herald as a movie making technical feat, acting at its best, plus definite Oscar nominations for Michael Keaton and Edward Norton in some of the lesser media oversell. I bought in to it!

Keaton is a one time movie star who became famous playing the superhero Birdman who decides to come to Broadway in a play he has written, is producing, directing and is starring in for a comeback. Playing opposite is another film star (Naomi Watts) making her Broadway debut and Mike Shiner (Norton) a method actor who believes you use a real gun in a scene when he is going to be shot and drinking real gin on stage. Also involved is Laura (Andrea Riseborough), Keaton's sometime lover, his daughter Sam, (Emma Stone) just recently out of rehab being her Dad's assistant, his ex-wife Sylvia (Amy Ryan) and his attorney Zach Galifianakis.

It has been described as a comedy/drama, a first rate back stage story but regarding the former I laughed once and as far as the latter comes nowhere near "All About Eve". There is one scene far fetched scene where The New York Times fictional critic, played by Lindsay Duncan, tells Keaton she will destroy his play, and him, for having the nerve to come to Broadway for his comeback.

Yes Keaton does a good job with what has to work with, Norton has some good moments but it is Emma Stone who makes the strongest impression.

Director Alejandro G. Inarritu, who co-wrote the film with Nicolas Giacobone, Alexander Dinelaris and Armando Bo, also produced it. His gimmick, working with his cinematographer Emmanuel Lubezki, making it seem like the movie, even though taking place over a few days, was filmed in one continuous take and is very successful at it. The music, mainly drumming by Antonio Sanchez, at times is affecting but most of the time annoying.

I may wind up in the minority, and Keaton and Norton may get the Oscar nominations that are being talked about, but as a comedy or a drama or a satire "Birdman" doesn't rate a worth seeing from me.
One of the most interesting movies this year, and one of the best. Michael Keaton is absolutely amazing. Edward Norton is phenomenal. Just a great movie.
