The Mexican director Alejandro González Iñárritu has been making feature films since the year 2000, when his masterful triptych "Amores Perros" was released. Scripted by Guillermo Arriaga (who turned director, himself, in 2008, with the depressingly mediocre "The Burning Plain"), that movie followed three separate stories in Mexico City - all involving, in some way, dogs - as they intersected and diverged over the course of many months. Before turning to full-length films, González Iñárritu had, like David Fincher before him, for years honed his craft on commercials, and his cinematic confidence as he juggled the many different threads of "Amores Perros" was a marvel to behold. What especially impressed was the fact that he wasn't all flash - con brio, e non con braggadocio - and that the stories had narrative weight and consequence.

What followed were films equally as confident and similarly masterful - at least in terms of their mise-en-scène - but much less meaningful. Both "21 Grams" and "Babel" - written by Arriaga, as well - allowed González Iñárritu to continue to explore his love of multiple overlapping stories and fluid chronology, but when they reached their respective conclusions they revealed not much more than a naked emperor, fascinating as their cinematic trappings may have been. "Biutiful," his next film, was made after he and Arriaga had a falling out, and it eschewed the focus on multiple protagonists to give us a hard look at one man (Javier Bardem) dying of cancer. An even bleaker movie than González Iñárritu's earlier films, it featured a powerful central performance and much more straightforward camera and editing work than we had grown accustomed to. It was nice to see the director trying something new. Still, dark despair does not always equal profundity, and the film, though effective in certain scenes, managed to leave me cold in the face of death.

And now we have something new: a comedy (though a bleak one). Fresh as that might sound to aficionados of González Iñárritu's work, what's even more innovative is how he has transformed his earlier technique of layering multiple narratives and shifting chronologies into a seemingly linear story that looks like a single unbroken camera take (that is, without edits). From the time we first meet our hero, Riggan Thompson - played by Michael Keaton (in top form and much better served here than by "RoboCop") - the camera, though extremely restless, never cuts. Or so it seems. González Iñárritu and his cinematographer, Emmanuel Lubezki (an Oscar-winner for "Gravity" and heretofore the main cinematographer for another Mexican director, Alfonso Cuarón) have carefully crafted the film to look that way, though in actuality it was not shot as a single take. And if that were all this movie were - an example of bravura filmmaking and choreography - then it would fascinate, for sure, but remain a meaningless magic trick. Instead, this technique is an integral part of the story, since it brings us into the visceral feverish madness of the lead character by bending time and perspective (González Iñárritu's usual obsessions)

Riggan Thompson is a washed-up former action star, best known for his work in a series of superhero films (the Birdman of the title, which somewhat resemble the "Batman" films that Keaton, himself, once starred in). In an effort to rehabilitate his reputation, he has written (and is now directing and starring in), a Broadway play based on the writer Raymond Carver's short story anthology "What We Talk About When We Talk About Love." Rehearsals are not going well. After a stage light falls on his male co-star, he is forced to bring on board an obnoxious New York thespian, Mike Shiner (a very funny Edward Norton, seen earlier this year in "The Grand Budapest Hotel"), whose volatility proves a dangerous addition to the production. Along for the ride is a cast of very fine actors, all at the top of their game: Emma Stone ("Magic in the Moonlight") as Riggan's daughter; Zach Galifianakis ("The Hangover") as his nervous lawyer and friend; Naomi Watts ("St. Vincent") as his female co-star; Andrea Riseborough ("Oblivion") as his girlfriend (and other co-star); Amy Ryan ("Win Win") as his ex-wife; and Lindsay Duncan ("Le Weekend") as a nasty theater critic. All serve as both obstacles and opportunities in the way of Riggan's success, and companions on his slide towards insanity.

The film is a wonderful meditation on the nature of art, its intersection with commerce, and how the search for validation - for admiration - through the creative process is no substitute for real human connections. As Riggan's mind slowly disintegrates and the boundary between his alter ego and real self becomes indistinct, we see how the desperate need for love can destroy us if we can only take and not give. As the movie's opening title card - a Carver poem, "Late Fragment," from  "A New Path to the Waterfall" - proclaims:
	"And did you get what you wanted from this life, even so?
	I did.
	And what did you want?
	To call myself beloved, to feel myself beloved on the earth."
Did I mention that the film is also extremely funny? Never has madness been this entertaining.

There are no cuts, no edits, as you continue to track all the actors from day to night and back to day. Editing is little rough, but the camerawork is superb and so is the performances. Keaton delivers one of his best and honest performances, and I wont be surprised if he gets an oscar nom. Definitly worth a look.

Plain and simple... Birdman is one of best films I've seen of the past decade.  It may even be a "perfect" film, if there is such a thing.  Michael Keaton is spectacularly brilliant as the lead character.  The supporting cast is so phenomenal, no praise is enough for each of them.  Every actor plays every available note with such deft craft; they'll no doubt be fighting each other come Oscar time.  As if this isn't enough to make a mad dash to see this film, even more impressive is the director's hand, as it screams with the genius of Alejandro G. Inarritu.  Perhaps not since Kubrik have we seen such a visionary as Inarritu.  He unveils for us a next level of storytelling within the medium as he wrings out every element of filmmaking.  Go see how and why film is, or can be art of the highest order.  Sadly perhaps, only in the hands of brilliant artists... such as the collaborative of Birdman.

Birdman is one of the most unconventional, bizarre, and enigmatic films of the year. It's also one of the best. Emmanuel Lubezki's trademark style is enhanced, and the cinematography is filmed in such a way that it appears to be a single-continuous shot. Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu's innovation direction brings out the best in the magnificent cast. Edward Norton is fantastic, Emma Stone is vivacious, even Zach Galifianakis has a commendable screen prescience. But most of all, Michael Keaton makes a legendary comeback. He is truly outstanding, and gives a no holds barred performance. Birdman's sly commentary on the psychological meltdown of a famed actor is devious in the execution. It offers so many perspectives on the lives of various "entertainers" and is a technical showcase. By the end of the journey, you will learn the 'unexpected virtue of ignorance'.
One of the most impressive movies I have seen to date. My he more I thought about it the greater the movie was. There is no flaw to this movie for me. I had a smile on my face the hole time.

A narcissistic and apparently delusional Academy fell for this hot mess of a film. That doesn't mean anyone else should.

On its own merits this is a 2.5 star film. However, because it won Best Picture, it must be judged in comparison to the other nominated films. And in that comparison it falls pathetically short. This disaster of a movie beating the exhilarating film Whiplash is akin to the crimes perpetrated by the Academy when they awarded Best Picture to Going My Way over Double Indemnity, The Best Years of Our Lives over It's A Wonderful Life, or Annie Hall over Star Wars. Perhaps half of the Best Picture winners over the years have been inferior to another nominated or un-nominated film from that year but most of the winners have something to commend them.

Birdman is plagued with overacting, a ridiculous plot, unlikeable characters, an intrusive and repetitive drum score, and expository dialogue much more suited to a play (most of the film takes place offstage or backstage).

Even if you make it a habit to catch all Best Picture nominees or winners, give yourself a pass and skip this one.

This is an interesting movie, but I'm not nearly as excited about it as the critics. The subject matter, the egos of actors, is a bit trivial in my opinion and has been done to death elsewhere, if not as stylistically. Michael Keaton is wonderful and should receive award nominations. But my friend and I left feeling a bit let down. While there are really interesting aspects of this movie it does not really say much in the end. I don't want to discourage anyone from seeing it, it has enough going that it's worth you time and money, just don't expect the overwhelming experience the critics seem to be having.

Birdman is a densely layered comedy that is open to numerous interpretations. It's a dissertation on acting vs. celebrity. It's a rumination on show business and the fleeting nature of fame. And it' a satire on the acting profession. Regarding that last one, this is a pretty savage portrait on the existence of an actor. There is an element of fantasy to this too. Michael Keaton as Riggan has a constant interior monologue in the guise of his alter ego Birdman. These Shakespearean soliloquies add to the experimental feel of the spectacle. The drama opens with him meditating, seated in the lotus position, floating in midair. Later he's moving objects with his mind. The drum heavy score by jazz artist Antonio Sanchez, accentuates many scenes with a thudding percussion beat. The stylish flourishes are to subvert reality. It adds to the manic tension that continues all the way to the ending. It's one of those head scratchers that leaves the audience with a big question instead of closure. That's ok because with Birdman it's about the journey. The chronicle takes the viewer on a wildly inventive and smartly written ride. Hold on tight because once it starts, it doesn't stop.

fastfilmreviews.com

Big Al's Movie Review:  Birdman

After portraying a popular superhero on the big screen, a has-been actor must overcome personal issues, egotistical castmates and naysayers while putting on a Broadway play in the hope of rekindling his career. 

Birdman is a performer's paradise, artistically exposing the rift between Broadway and Hollywood. Masterful camerawork mixed with great editing give this film the appearance of rarely being cut; as if it were shot in one long take. Michael Keaton is impressive in a role that echoes his own career, previously starring as the first big screen Caped Crusader, while Edward Norton shows off his usual A-game talent. 

I think Uncle Oscar will be very kind to Birdman. 

Grade:  A
You can't mistake an original...

Birdman is almost indescribable, featuring some of the best performances all year and an unmistakable visual flair. Birdman is truly remarkable filmmaking and deserves every ounce of recognition it receives.

A supremely creative and inventive undertaking, "Birdman" is rightly deserving of all the acclaim it has received and will surely continue to receive. Michael Keaton is fantastic as a washed up actor desperately staging a comeback while his personal life falls
apart. Although Batman comparisons are inevitable, and adds to the moviegiers' enjoyment of the role,  it doesn't detract from Keaton's performance. It should be noted, however, that both director and actor say that Batman had no impact on casting or Keaton's own performance.
     Another highlight of the film is Edward Norton's return to form after a too long departure into commercial roles. As an acclaimed and arrogant stage actor who hates Hollywood he gives a performance that is on par with the talent and range he showed in his early roles.
    As a whole this is a thoroughly enjoyable film with enough humor, industry jabs, and great performances to satisfy any movie fan.

This is one bizarre movie, shot as one continuous take. It's... an experience to be sure.

The one continuous take thing does feel a tad gimmicky. There's no real reason the story has to be told that way, but it doesn't bring the film down or distract too needlessly. The whole film moves along so seamlessly that you barely notice it. Kudos to the editor. They must have had one nightmarish job making it flow together so well.

Our lead is Michael Keaton and getting him to play an actor famous for playing a superhero is just genius casting. Oh, and he also gives a great performance as well, battling with the other actors, himself, and his superhero alter-ego. It's a darn good performance.


The rest of the cast performs admirably as well. Naomi Watts, Emma Stone, and Andrea Riesborough are all given moments to shine, and all three nail them. However, Edward Norton stands head and shoulders above the rest as an actor who demands hyper-realistic sets and props. He gives the film's best performance. Yes, even better than Keaton.

Most of the flaws with the film are somewhat nitpicky. The drumming used as the score can get a bit irksome, and the vague ending could rub some people the wrong way. However, it works, the performances are great, and  it's a darn tricky technical achievement successfully pulled off. It's worth checking out.

"Birdman or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance)" is a movie that will stay with you long after you've left the theater. (Or turned off your bluray player.) It'll linger in your head - like a hovering bird, man. It's the closest you'll come to watching a stage play on a movie screen. (More on that later.)
In the film, Michael Keaton stars as Riggan Thomson, a once iconic movie star who portrayed the world's biggest superhero, Birdman (in three films), on the big screen. Now he's a washed up actor who is desperately trying to reclaim his elite status in the acting world by staging a play based on the Raymond Carver short story, "What We Talk About When We Talk About Love." But don't you dare try to make a connection between Keaton and Thomson because, according to Keaton, he is nothing like Thomson (despite the two having donned a cape and cowl at the heyday of their careers). In a recent Entertainment Weekly interview, Keaton said: "In terms of the parallels, I've never related less to a character than Riggan." Regardless. Audiences are going to find it hard to separate Keaton and Thomson. Is that a bad thing? I don't think so. Let's say the role of Thomson went to someone who has never starred in a superhero movie (I know, there seem to be so few actors left who haven't starred in a superhero movie, and the film reminds us of that fact) - it wouldn't be as believable, would it? Keaton's past adds great depths to the role, and director Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu knew that from the beginning. (His disdain for superhero movies is also pretty evident throughout the film.) 
When we first meet Thomson, he's seen sitting cross-legged (in his underwear), levitating above the ground. Is this for real, or is this just an illusion? It's hard to know. He also appears to have the ability to control objects with his mind (a la Magento). It's the night before the first preview of his debut in the theater, and tensions are rising high for everyone involved. His daughter, played by Emma Stone (who was in the reboot of Spider-Man, remember), is his assistant, but she's not really keen on trying to calm him down (and she's just been released from rehab). He sees one of his co-stars as an absolute train-wreck, and the only way to get rid of him is to (seemingly) use his telekinetic powers to knock him out with a stage light. But this leaves a gaping hole in the cast. Enter Mike Shiner, played by Edward Norton (who was in "The Incredible Hulk," remember). Mike Shiner is one of the great names in theater - his acting method is "pure" and "real" (unlike his real-life self). He already knows all of the lines because he's been sleeping with one of the female leads, played by Naomi Watts (who was in "Tank Girl," remember). He seems to be the perfect fit. Until he decides to drink real alcohol while on the stage, belittle Thomson in a high-profile newspaper interview, and suggest that Thomson use a real gun in the final scene instead of a cap-gun. 
Discover the rest of the plot for yourselves. 
"Birdman" delves deep into the mind - and psyche - of Riggan Thomson. His real struggle isn't the stage, or his attempt at a comeback, or his damaged relationships (with his daughter, his ex-wife, his girlfriend), or his past. His real struggle is within himself. He will never be able to succeed because he won't let himself. But is this inner-struggle about Thomson's "art life" or is it a struggle with his "true life"? Or is it both? Throughout the film he is taunted by his alter-ego (which happens to take the form - and voice - of The Birdman). What's curious is that most of the time The Birdman is mocking Thomson and those around him, but sometimes The Birdman cheers him on. It's almost as if The Birdman represents both Thomson's id and ego (or super-ego, anyway).  
This is a film that would have attracted directors like Billy Wilder, I suspect. And, no doubt, Alfred Hitchcock. The humor, the inner-turmoil, the fantastical - all things Wilder and long-time collaborator I. A. L. Diamond would have salivated at the chance to write about. Certainly, Hitchcock's "Rope" served as inspiration for the (seemingly) seamless one-long-take the film utilizes. Let's talk about this for a moment. Think about what this can do for viewers. If you're watching a movie directed by, let's say, Michael Bay, you're likely to find numerous quick cuts and edits throughout the movie (more when it's an action scene). Does this heighten the action/suspense, or does it become more of a nuisance for the audience? You decide. But think about this. If you're watching a film, like "Birdman," that is almost entirely comprised of one single take, would you be more aware of the fact that you're watching a movie, or would you almost forget your watching a movie and, instead, become immersed in the movie (as if you're watching a live play on the stage)? For me, it's the latter. The camera zooms down hallways, and bursts out of windows. And I suspect cinematographer Emmanuel Lubezki will score an Oscar nomination for his work. (I also suspect Keaton, Norton and Stone will be recognized with nominations.)
A final thought to consider: Is it possible that the entire film plays out in the mind of Riggan Thomson? Perhaps the playhouse represents his mind. Most of the action takes place within the playhouse (or the bar down the block). It's almost as if Thomson has locked these actors, stagehands, and family members inside the playhouse so he can try to "direct" them as he sees fit.

Will be compared to "Black Swan", and, as much as I like that film - this is superior. This film is a result of great direction, writing, acting, cinematography and editing working together so seamlessly. Funny and often touching - Theatre goers and film lovers should appreciate this.

October 17, 2014 (Limited)

There is a scene late in "Batman Returns," which was Michael Keaton's last superhero film, when Batman glides over Gotham City. Director Tim Burton employed a God's eye view as the Caped Crusader rises from the bottom of the frame and crosses over the top in perfect form. Alejandro González Iñárritu presents a similar shot in "Birdman Or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance)" when Keaton, playing a has-been Hollywood actor whose claim to fame was a superhero not unlike Batman, imagines himself flying over New York City. 

It's safe to assume the similarity between Burton's shot and Iñárritu's is no coincidence. Keaton was cast in the lead role of "Birdman" for a reason, not least because his post-"Batman" career may partly mirror that of the character he plays. 

But the idea that the two have anything in common fortunately only adds to the appeal of Iñárritu's film; it doesn't determine it. "Birdman" would be just as sad, humorous and lively without the audience knowing Keaton once played a superhero himself. His character and performance, and the film as a whole, are engaging regardless.

Keaton plays Riggan Thompson, who identifies himself as an actor but whom critics label a celebrity. Riggan once played the title character in a superhero franchise called "Birdman," which was a huge hit, but now, years later, he finds himself struggling to do something (and be someone) that matters. He explains this is why he turned down "Birdman 4." 

To reinvigorate his career, Riggan is funding, directing and starring in a stage adaptation of Raymond Carver's "What We Talk About When We Talk About Love" on Broadway. "Birdman" functions not only as a character study of Riggan, who's desperate to reassemble the shattered pieces of his current life, but as an ensemble and often zany comedy about a play that seems destined to fail.

Neither one of these premises is particularly groundbreaking. There have already been movies about once-famous Hollywood actors who now feel they've drifted into obscurity ("Sunset Boulevard",  "Somewhere"), and about the behind-the-scenes shenanigans of a tumultuous stage production ("Topsy-Turvy," "Shakespeare in Love"). These recycled setups are perhaps what hold "Birdman" back from total greatness, but together they still make for an engrossing and thoroughly enjoyable experience. 

Much of this is owed to Iñárritu's technique of making it seem like the entire film was shot in one take, which raises the energy and tension levels and we get the sense something or someone is always about to burst. Whether or not something actually does, I'll let you discover, but this approach keeps us on edge and we instantly get caught up in the characters and their absurd situations. 
And speaking of the characters, they are inhabited by a team of enthusiastic actors who seemed to know they were making something special. They include Zach Galifianakis as Riggan's producer and best friend who will tell the star just about anything to ensure the show goes on and they recoup at least some of their investment; Edward Norton as a talented but egotistical thespian who thinks he can come along and steal the spotlight, not to mention Riggan's daughter/assistant, who's just completed a stint in rehab. She's played by Emma Stone and it's clear the source of her emotional problems goes beyond drugs. There's also Andrea Riseborough and Naomi Watts as the two actresses in Riggan's play, whose collective frustration and lack of faith in Riggan, or men in general, leads them to explore alternative options.

The camera playfully follows each of these pieces of work into every nook and cranny of the theater as the cast and crew prepare for the play's upcoming previews. All the while, we wonder whether an uptight theater critic's (Lindsey Duncan) preemptive scathing review will cause the show to sink or swim. Or perhaps fly is the better word, since Riggan seems to possess the same powers as Birdman, who, oddly enough, speaks in the same low, bass tone as Batman and constantly eggs Riggan on. The movie wisely never substantiates Riggan's potential schizophrenia or his superhuman abilities like levitations and telekinesis.

Overall, "Birdman" may not surprise us with its narrative trajectory, but that hardly makes it any less of a pleasure. On the surface, it's rhythmic and infectiously funny, and on a deeper level, we really come to care about Riggan, and not just because he's pathetic, but also because we see he genuinely wants to do right for his daughter, the other players, and himself. We're naturally inclined to root for him and although this may be a familiar story of redemption, it's still a moving one. 

It does help that Keaton once played Batman, but I think he'd be just as effective in this role even if he hadn't. He shares a scene late in the film with Amy Ryan, who plays Riggan's ex-wife, that's so strong and nuanced, it reminds us of Keaton's range as an actor. If he receives an Oscar nomination, this scene will be why he wins. 

I'm honestly surprised it took Hollywood this long to make a modern film that centers on a washed-up actor known for playing a superhero. "Birdman" is well aware of the current times and the prolificacy of the superhero genre, going so far as to make snide comments about Robert Downey Jr. as Iron Man. It knows that actors who play such larger-than-life figures are often doomed to be typecast and thought of as nothing else. "Birdman" runs with this notion and makes it both fun and dramatic, reminding us that humans are indeed mutable creatures, capable of reinventing and redefining ourselves. This is not a novel message, and it's one Hollywood delivers more often than not, but it still helps to hear it.

There's drums, "Birdman" stomps across the screen. There's a quick flash of a beach with jellyfish, a meteor plummeting to Earth, then there's Michael Keaton; floating in mid-air Indian style. After these first few minutes of Alejandro G. IÃ±Ã¡rritu's "Birdman" went by, so many thoughts flew through my brain that I started to smile trying to figure things out. Without doing much, "Birdman" gives you a lot to think about just in the first couple of minutes. What does this mean? Why did this happen? 

How bizarre, how strange, how weird, how curious, how unbelievably intriguing? After Keaton leaves his dressing room, the camera follows him, and doesn't stop. It moves to other people, follows their lives, their thoughts, then comes back. I cannot get over how innovative and intriguing this film is. Along with this brilliant camerawork, the film has a fantastic script; sharp, funny, and even satirical. I smiled the whole time while watching this film. 

"Birdman" is the story of a man who used to play an iconic superhero in the movies, who's now haunted by these memories in his own mind, who tries to make it on Broadway. The movie is a trip through the lives of our main character, Riggan (the guy who played Birdman) and the others surrounding him. It reminded me of a Tarantino movie in a way, because of the level of ambition in the script, and the long, but masterful, meaningful scenes.

"Birdman" is the best film of the year. It stands out, it's on a completely different level of filmmaking.

I loved every minute of BIRDMAN, but I'm certain that in a week it will have slid completely out of mind. It's a fine addition to the genre of backstage comedy. It's more cheerful than anything I've seen from Iñárritu. It's art-positive. The performances are terrific. I've never thought of Keaton as a serious actor but his performance here changed my mind entirely about that. Norton is better than I've seen him a long time. The problem is that there is absolutely nothing new here. The relationships studied by the film, the characters examined, the questions of artistic integrity and selling out, have all been been done and done and done.

The best release of the year - Keaton is perfect questioning his future and legacy, Norton outstanding as a prima donna, and the screenplay builds dramatic tension.  Nuanced story with unpredictable outcomes holds attention to the end.

Edward Norton should win an Oscar for his performance.  

The movie is about a man's need to feel beloved.  Finding Hollywood popularity unsatisfying Riggan tries "legitimate theater" for affection expressed as accolade.  He co-stars with Mike (Ed Norton) who can act with emotional vulnerability on the stage but lacks the ability for emotional connection in life.  Riggan's daughter has lived without the feeling of being beloved and has given up on it's pursuit.  One character seeks motherhood for the feeling of love.  Another a career on broadway.  throughout the film is Riggan's internal voice asserting Riggan's greatness; he is worthy of being loved.  A superhero battling the main characters own self-doubt and contrary evidence.  But where can one feel that he/she is really loved: popularity, significance, family, career?  

The film is a masterpiece of film making.  In addition to the directing and cinematography other have mentioned i'll add the music.  The sequence of Riggan flying adds doubt about whether this is real or imagined even as the strings soar, for example.  

a great movie.  highly recommend.

Birdman is one of the most bold and unique films to come along in awhile, stitched together to look like everything takes place in one continuous shot. Cinematographer Emmanuel Lubezki is the easy MVP, as the shots he pulls off are unbelievable, and Alejandro Gonzalez Iñárritu rises to the challenge with his best film since his early days. Unsurprisingly, his version of a comedy is also bleak and depressing, although with an energy and life his work has never had before. The cast is very good as well, with Michael Keaton and Edward Norton outstanding in roles that hit home to their real life careers. There are so many interesting things going on that even in its weaker moments Birdman is still a sight to take in.

A strong cast make this otherwise slow paced black comedy an interesting piece of work. The dialogue adds interest and layers to the film, and these layers are more fascinating the more you peel. Unfortunately for me, the film is too slow, even with the stylish setting, it gets tiring on the eyes and it lost me for a little. The crescendo really saves it for me that once again showcases the interesting premise and character that is Riggan. The contrast between Riggan and Mike is also fascinating as one tries to live on the stage, and the other one could only survive anywhere but the stage.
"You're not an actor. You're a celebrity." Absolutely and utterly fantastic.

The most interesting film I have seen in a long time. I'm so proud of what one of my favorite mexican directors, Alejandro Gonzalez IÃ±arritu, has accomplished. I love the camera technique as well as the background music not to mention the great acting. Highly recommended.

For more reviews, visit www.bemovieseemovie.com.

Bill Murray never quite gets his due from audiences unless he's in a comedy. That hasn't stopped Murray from being great in a number of dramatic films, Lost in Translation and Groundhog Day being at the top of the list. St. Vincent isn't going to end up on Bill Murray's greatest hits, but the "comedian" elevates a standard screenplay with sound acting chops. Plus he does a little dance number.

Maggie (Melissa McCarthy) and her son Oliver (Jaeden Lieberher) are forced to uproot and move to Brooklyn. Unfortunately, they move next door to curmudgeonly Vincent (Bill Murray), who is having his share of life problems as well. Because of her long work hours, Maggie reluctantly pays Vincent to watch Oliver after school. The two form an unlikely friendship, will Murray's life skills teaching Oliver how to grow up and fend for himself.

Theodore Melfi wrote this script and directed the movie himself. The story means well, but doesn't really establish itself as anything other than an "old coot and innocent kid bond" story. Crotchetiness and naivete are established early. Does the kid need help standing up for himself and does the old man have some tips? Does the old man's past with a foreign woman (Naomi Watts) cause a severe plot shift? Is an oft mentioned absentee character going to show up in the third act? Does the old man have a secret soft side? Is there a big reconciliation after a split of the friendship? If you've EVER seen a movie, you'll know what the answers to these questions are.

Despite the overt manipulation, Bill Murray is here to pick up the slack. Murray's jovial side is in evidence even during the early scenes, when horrible choices are consistently thrust upon him. The scenes with him and your Jaeden are cute and fun. Murray's presence elevates Melissa McCarthy's performance, especially when she's backed into a corner by Vincent. Murray's chops are tested in the third act, where a contrived event forces him really sell a believable state for his character. When the climactic event happens, I was only rooting for the obvious because of how well Bill Murray sold the old man to me.

It makes me a little sad to think Peter Venkman himself is now forced to take old man roles. However, Bill Murray's years of development give me hope that some long overdue awards could be in his future. St. Vincent could be the start of that; Academy Voters, look past the fact that this movie is cloying and give Murray a nod. You owe him for Lost in Translation.
Good, very good - but not great. Technical mastery, satirical flair, but lacking in depth to match.
So much to like about this movie. It's shot tight. Audience is "in" the scene. You're right there. Fantastic performances all around. Definitely worth watching. Original, beautiful, wonderful.

One of the most original films I've seen in a long while, really amazing on a lot of levels. A lot of people probably won't "get it" because it's not conventional. Awesome cast, highly recommend for those with an open mind for something different.
In spite of a flawed ending the movie is one of the most thoughtful and interesting you will see this year.

A brilliantly fascinating picture until its ending. A tour de force in contemporary philosophical existentialism draped in cinematic art. May be the ending is brilliant too, but it needs a second viewing to establish this. Killer acting with notable Oscar nomination for Michael Keaton and Edward Norton. The cinematography feels like you just can't get enough no matter how much more you see. I haven't had the urge to see a film again so soon after I've just seen it. The drum score performer has a cameo that makes you want to pick up sticks and loose your neighbors.
Awesomely amazing film. Go see it with your friends. You'd need to talk it over after.

had no expectations going into this movie - saw it on a private screening at fox studios - great movie - love the long sequences which i can appreciate technically.  the story has a gripping suspenseful mood the whole movie and you never really knew where it took you next.  the ending was just spectacular even if it doesn't give you closure.

I don't know why people are saying that this is Michael Keaton's comeback. The man has been working for decades. Yes, maybe not in lead roles, but the man finds work. BIRDMAN is a satire on Keaton's career as he plays a washed-up actor whose biggest role was playing the superhero Birdman 20 years earlier. He stages a comeback by putting on a play on Broadway. Sound familiar to one of Keaton's roles as a certain Dark Knight? Keaton is at his manic best as an actor who is stressed out about the show while hearing his Birdman alter ego act as his conscience. The supporting cast is top notch, with Edward Norton playing a over-the-top version of himself and Emma Stone as Keaton's recovering addict daughter. Both actors, along with Keaton should deserve some love come awards season. Director Alejandro González Iñárritu shoots the movie with handheld cameras and what seems to be one, long continuous shot, which is done seamlessly and something that makes this film unique. This takes filmmaking to a whole new level. Because of this type of storytelling, more praise should be given to the cast a crew for pulling such a difficult task. BIRDMAN is quirky, funny, out of control, and bizarre. You really never know what is reality and what is fantasy in this film, and even the end will be up to interpretation. Either way, this isn't Michael Keaton's comeback. This is his statement.

Grade: A

An audacious black comedy that speaks to our notions of what we believe constitutes love and admiration and what really matters in the end. Despite some occasional lapses in the writing and some periodic pacing issues in the first half-hour, the film delivers on all other fronts, especially its biting humor, intriguing visuals and stellar performances by Michael Keaton, Edward Norton and Emma Stone. This is definitely not for everyone, but for those seeking a film that will make them laugh -- and think -- this is a terrific offering on both fronts.
Just a great film Keaton is excellent, Norton is excellent, shot in a cool way where everything runs kind of runs together.  A couple weird scenes but besides that worth watching.

Bravura filmmaking and a wonderful cast, excluding star Michael Keaton who simply can't pull this off, BIRDMAN is ultimately banal, self-indulgent claptrap signifying nothing but everything it purports to criticize.

This boring story was a huge disappointment for me. I was yawning and fidgeting during most of it, waiting for something or someone to be interested in. Edward Norton did provide that interest during his few great moments on screen, but there just wasn't enough of him. And while the camerawork was technically interesting and impressive, it lacked emotional engagement most of the time because it was too self-aware and took aware from the characters. I found myself repeatedly thinking about the camera and the behind the scenes of how they executed the camerawork. As a moviegoing experience, Birdman was a big, overrated letdown for me.
Original and creative, this film is what deserves to be called art. I don't think they could have made a better movie, even if they tried. It's simple, yet very effective.

THE WINDBAG BENEATH HIS CGI WINGS - Ok, my too-clever-by-half title is misleading, as it would appear I didn't like the film.  The opposite is true.  I just couldn't resist.  Sure BIRDMAN is a talky film, but it's the most cinematic expression of live theater I've ever seen.  Many have attempted to adapt a play to film with diminishing results, often falling prey to too much talk, too static presentation, or worse, falsely "opening up" the piece by simply setting some scenes outside. Director Alejandro González Iñárritu (BABEL, 21 GRAMS, AMORES PERROS) along with his co-screenwriters, Nicolas Giacobone, Alexander Dinelaris and Armando Bo have created an all-out war between Hollywood and Broadway with BIRDMAN.  

Starring Michael Keaton in the role of a lifetime, his Riggan Thomson is a character seemingly modeled after his own experiences - a once-A-list Superhero star who turns down a sequel and years later mounts a Broadway show to reignite his stalled career.  Bristling with a tortured ego, nervous energy, desperation, and a wellspring of hidden talents, Riggan stalks the theatre in a constant search for sparring partners.  

Presented as almost one seemingly continuous shot, this backstage dramedy gives its audience the thrill of live performance while constantly keeping things visually exciting.  Can we just name Emmanuel Lubezki  (GRAVITY, CHILDREN OF MEN ) the greatest living cinematographer and call it a day?  This isn't the first film to attempt this, with Alfred Hitchcock's ROPE and Alexander Sokurov's RUSSIAN ARK being two notable examples, but the way this film plays with time transitions and reveals is breathtaking.  Furthermore, this shooting style allows this stellar cast to truly live with their characters, and the payoff is explosive.  

Emma Stone has never been better as Riggan's fresh out of rehab daughter/personal assistant.  She may be wounded, but she's nobody's fool.  Her self-possession here is a joy to watch, and in one bruising scene, she lets out a spectacular fury that should be a required audition monologue for aspiring actors.  Zach Galifianakis plays against type as Riggan's stressed out manager/lawyer and shows great, straightforward vulnerability.  Naomi Watts is edgy and hilarious as Riggan's co-star, especially in a great scene she shares with Andrea Riseborough, who after a string of dramatic roles shows she excels at comedy.  Amy Ryan is pitch perfect as Riggan's ex and Lindsay Duncan has a great, bile-filled speech as the all-powerful theatre critic who's gunning for our star.  But let's face it, Keaton's triumph here aside, everyone will be talking about Edward Norton's incredible turn as Mike Shiner, perhaps the world's most difficult actor.   A last minute replacement in the stage show, Shiner challenges everybody and everything when he isn't trying to fuck them.  He comes across as exactly what you would expect it to be like to work with Norton, and the results are so specific, so gloriously detailed, and so damn entertaining, you just can't wait to see what he'll do next.  

BIRDMAN takes you on an actor's journey to stay relevant, to literally and figuratively face his demons, to experience real performance vs. the soul-sucking idiocy that can be blockbuster films.  Keaton dares to be an indulgent, raging narcissist here, yet miraculously manages to make Riggan a thrillingly entertaining figure throughout.  

If I have to quibble a little, it's with the monotonous, percussive score by Martin Hernandez.  The incessant jazz drumming got old really fast yet kept up its paces throughout the entire running time.  Every so often an orchestral score would take over, and its melodies would be sweet relief from the unbearable pretensions of the rest.  There were times when the camera would glide by an actual drummer, which quite possibly made my eyes roll into the back of my head.  Tune out the drums and you've got an original, funny, heartbreaking film.  It's a minor misfire in a dazzling piece of cinema.  Audiences who grow tired of talk get their big special effects moments here and there, making BIRDMAN the thinking person's superhero play.  I'd say that's worth a refreshing standing ovation.
A strange, artistic dark comedy with exceptional performances by the cast.

One of the best movies of 2014.  Every actor an performance was remarkable.  Long scenes without a cut, so the actors truly had to give a strong performance without the tricks of editing and camera techniques.  Cinematography was remarkable, Academy Award level, and often, was as an additional character in the movie.
This is a great movie. It's worth watching twice. Be sure to watch this one.

The whole film appears to be shot in one continuous take which is executed superbly. The performances by Keaton, Norton and Stone are also brilliant making Birdman a truly unique and unforgettable movie.

A career best performance by michael Keaton in this fresh movie that in its relation rarely comes along. The performances by everyone are top class from the supporting cast including Edward Norton and career defining performances by Emma stone and Zach galifinakis. Birdman is truly one if a kind and no surprise from the rave reviews by critics this film will have a good response at the oscars
Certainly lived up to the hype.

a little light on plot, but it more than makes up for it in style and performance. The stars really delivered, and the shooting style was so unique and kinetic that I've rarely if ever seen anything quite like it.

Wonderfully acted, wonderfully shot, and overall wonderfully crafted. While there are a couple of small things that keep it from being a straight up masterpiece of satire and pitch black comedy, Birdman is an amazing experience. Michael Keaton is fantastic, and hopefully there's and Oscar win in the future. He deserves it.
Awesome movie! Great story line.
This movie is beyond brilliant.  The cinematography was amazing,  it was so well acted, and the story was unique and a pleasure to be a lady of (in so much as watching it anyway).
Brilliant, snappy, edgy.  Great performances by Edward Norton and Michael Keane.  A must see

Pleasantly unpleasant. Every character has a serious flaw, which makes it unbelievably relatable to the everyday person. Not my favorite movie of the year, but can definitely see why it won best picture.

Birdman is a film for the ages, a film that takes risks and comes out of nowhere and takes advantage of every second it has to surprise you from the outstanding directorial work to the wonderful screenplay to the brilliant performances (Michael Keaton in particular brings a character to life with such volatile realism, it should go down as one of the greatest performances of all time) as well as the stunningly ambitious cinematography; Birdman soars as not only the best film of the year but also one of the best, most ambitious, most unique films made of modern day, truly brilliant; In conclusion, Michael Keaton has staged the comeback of the century in the best film of 2014
fantastic. best movie of the year.
Keaton is Oscar worthy
Birdman soars onto the screen in spectacular fashion due to its intriguing story,humor,and impressive cast
Birdman is a novel and innovative piece of filmmaking. Great acting, editing and music.

Taking a very risky chance, director Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu directs "Birdman" all in one seamless take (so to speak) and I have to say, it pays off better than I'm sure he could have ever dreamed. Flawlessly shot, brilliantly acted, and perfectly directed, "Birdman" is a once in a year/decade film. Michael Keaton, Edward Norton, and even Emma Stone are perfect in their roles, kind of playing off their real life selves and playing at the fact that Hollywood Blockbusters have the ability to create washed up actors if they are not ready to leave the fame and fortune. With very clever and quick writing, you honestly feel like you are floating along with these actors as they crack jokes, get pissed off at each other, or are just having a natural conversation. There is truly something remarkable about this filmmaking choice, and after the films final events, the film feels like even more of a punch to the gut for Hollywood. Brutal, hilarious, and almost beautiful at times, "Birdman" is one of the best films of 2014!
By unmeasurable numbers "Birdman" claims victory over its competition (of 2014) and as a movie-going experience it's an immensely satisfying trip that leaves the viewer mesmerized and in awe.
Tremendous performances from a stellar cast and one of the more unique films of the year.  Also one of the best films of 2014.  See it.

A giant wink and nod to the super hero film craze and the actors involved in it, this is unlike any movie I've seen in a good, long time. The way it manages to balance humor, drama and psychological depth is genuinely masterful. The way it employs the use of long takes and extended cuts to create a genuinely immersive experience that you can get lost in. On top of all of this, the performances involved, particularly Edward Norton and Emma Stone, may turn out to be career defining. It will be interesting to see how awards season treats this one.

This is one of those extraordinary film that comes along every once in a while, defying classification and making a mockery of formula. It is meta, bizarre and completely enthralling - you  definitely haven't seen anything like this before. Technically outstanding and brilliantly acted, this is a visionary work of art from Alejandro Inarritu, and I can't wait to see what he does next.
oh, I'm gonna say, recommended.

The only rational character in the movie is Riggen's druggie daughter...but tuning out on drugs is the only way to deal with the fucks in this movie. Deeply unpleasant. If that's what you like, that's perverse but go for it here. Btw I can't stand Michael Keaton, I hated him as Batman.

The style of filming can be quite jarring, claustrophobic and confusing to start, but as you get into the film it comes into its own and you feel the beauty of it. The meta commentary on the film industry feels a little unnecessarily pretentious but the comedy is good. The complexity of the story is at times rewarding and at times a little dragging. Overall however, the combination of tremendous acting and ingenious camerawork make this engrossing and breathless. Oh and the score is just ballistic. Absolutely ballistic.

Alejandro Inarritu continues to raise the bar in his canon of films that focus on the human condition with a supernatural twist as he did with Biutiful and 21 Grams. Birdman is the ultimate film nerd's film as Inarritu manages to create a mesmerizing homage to the auteurs of the past; take the excess and surreal nature of Fellini's 8 1/2, the improvisation and layered characters from Altman's films mixed with the philosophical and supernatural style of Wim Wenders' Wings of Desire, put it in a blender and drink it all up. If there was an Olympic competition for cinematography, Emmanuel Lubezki would reign supreme as his work on the stedicam is fluid and balletic just like his previous work with Alfonso Cuaron. With an incredible cast and a visionary filmmaker at the helm, Birdman stands out as a raw, original, and powerful work of art.
Very happy for Michael Keaton , great to see him back in the spotlight. ...This was a wild ride it has Oscar written all over it .....for many performances ........
One of the most bizarre films I've seen in a while.

All I can really say about this film is what I took away from it. For me, it was about how, in life, we do everything we can to make ourselves believe we are controlling our surroundings and what's happening to us. When really all we are doing is affecting the outcome, but not controlling it. Everything that happens to us is not up to us, but we can reclaim what we can of ourselves and go forward with a new attitude.

This is what Michael Keaton's character does in the film. We see things happening as he sees them. And as the film's subtitle suggests, the virtue of his ignorance is his only way to relate to his surroundings, and the world, and his inner voice is the only thing keeping him from going over the edge, until he does.

On other notes, Edward Norton is absolutely hilarious as the over the top method theater actor. Apart from opening and closing segments of the film, it's made to look like it's all one shot, which obviously it's not but for movie people it's fun to try and see where they actually cut.

I feel like more and more we live in a world where things aren't interesting unless they're meta. If that's true, this is one for the books.
Wow. Daring, dazzling filmmaking. One of the best movies this year by far.

To make this entire film one shot is an amazing achievement in cinematography  and editing. The script is hilarious at times, and amazingly serious at other times. The acting is amazing. Emma Stone and Edward Norton are both amazing in it, but it is Michael Keaton who makes the movie. He is able to go from being calm and easy going to being completely mad seconds later.

This is one bizarre, bombastic, brilliant film. It skewers pretty much all things entertainment: superhero movies, egocentric actors, actors' insecurities and motivations, Method, Broadway, Broadway critics, all manner of side effects of being in the business (absentee parents, neurotic kids...) - and yet, it is curiously uplifting and frequently its blackest of black humor is gut-wrenchingly hilarious.

Keaton is superb - not just because he did a couple of Batman movies in the eighties, but because he's a great actor in a role that allows him to be one without being precious, or cautious.
Great script, great cast. But what I appreciated the most....one long take shot almost in the whole movie, very excellent directing and camera work.
Sooo bizarre. Loved Edward Norton.
Loud. and bad.  I wish I could get back the two hours. I was hoping the main character would kill himself so the movie would end.  Even Emma Stone was bad.
Subversively funny, caustic, bittersweet.  Original and creative.
Superbly paced, acted and darkly comic - Birdman is one of the best movies I've seen this year.

The story starts out a little slow, but once it gets going, it is an absolutely thrilling satire on the human condition - the need to be "relevant," in a society with ever-shrinking attention spans where a new "flash in the pan" seems to be created daily. Michael Keaton turns in a brutally honest performance, although I'm sure that aspects of his own life and career went into his portrayal of Riggan Thomson. Edward Norton also turns in a strong performance, and I have no doubt that these two actors will be up for Oscars next year.

I could go on and on writing superlatives about this movie. I loved this movie, you should go see it now! After you've seen it we should get coffee, a drink, dinner, whatever and spend hours talking about Birdman. Go. Now.
PodrÃ­a escribir superlativos sobre esta peli durante horas. Me fascinÃ³ Birdman, corre a verla ya, despuÃ©s nos tomamos un cafÃ©, una copa, cena y nos pasamos horas hablando sobre esta peli. Ve. Hoy.
For all that it has in great performances, Birdman falls down in substance and considered choices of direction. Unfortunately.

What a dumb movie.  Not so bad as just BORING.  A total waste of time.  I can't understand anyone giving this train wreck of a film a positive review!  No redeeming qualities at all - even Ed Norton couldn't save this thing.

This film is hard to describe, its basically about Michael Keaton (as a former movie superhero) trying to reinvent his career by staging a broadway play... The actors, most notably Keaton and Edward Norton, are terrific as we get more into the craft of acting as we have in film in awhile..  The movie is also cinematically great, with terrific tracking shots through the backstage corridors of the theater and some swooping aerials as well. This film is not for everyone, and you really cant trust Keaton's perspective on much of the action as he seems to be losing his mind...but I thoroughly enjoyed it.

Not only is the film funny and visually marvelous, but it delivers a powerful metaphor about the nature of celebrity overshadowing actors' true selves, skewering Hollywood, Broadway, and critics, all in one (incredibly meta) fell swoop.

A high speed view into the life of an aging actor/celebrity.  The ensemble cast is great creating side stories that are compelling in their own right.  Michael Keaton shows that he has acting chops beyond his role as Batman - perfecting casting! Oscar worthy
Despite the movie leaving me wondering about whether he had powers or not because of the ending, this was a delightful movie with some wonderful humor.

Birdman is a solid comedic masterpiece with great cinematic style, an interesting score, hilarious dialogue and amazing performances from Micheal Keaton and especially Edward Norton. The film also has a great message on film critics, duality, and what's a persons purpose
Is in life and it's crafted beautifully. Amazing film, needs to be watched and analyzed.  I love Birdman 9.7/10

God, everything about this movie shines (except a few elements that are uncharacteristically exasperating). The look, the feel, the sound, and the style of Birdman will stay with you for a while; it is something special. A great film by any measure.
It was so compelling to watch. Michael Keaton  all the way. He played a manic schizophrenic actor that was trying to restart his career.  It's a trip to watch.
Wow what a great movie! Keaton nailed it and Emma was fabulous. Great story, sparkling photography. We need more of this in the theaters!
Really different but outstanding insight and acting

On the surface there's a sense of petty egotism to the Michael Keaton character's motivations, of feeling more important and entitled than those around him. I myself felt this tied into a more universal theme though, one of a man trying to control his legacy and his impact on the world around him, make his time on earth mean something if only just to him. There's a blurring of the line between fantasy and reality on a couple levels, perhaps meant as a commentary on how the former can impact the latter. In the role of an obsessive, self important actor, Ed Norton personifies a certain kind of personality to comedic extremes, someone focused on his work to where hostility and aggression become totally impersonal tools of the trade. Emma Stone's cynical blogger rang as a touch two dimensional, but at the same time there was a humanity to how her upbringing pushed her in this direction. Other thematic focuses seemed to be on a sort of a pull between devotion to one's art, and the personal havoc in wreaked on ones life, and the conflict between Keaton and Norton does seem to bring up whether a work is a product of the director or a collaborative effort. 

Stylistically there was a kind of 70s movie inspired tone mixed with modern surrealism. I'm not exactly sure on what cutting the film to look like a single continuous shot was meant to achieve, perhaps to create a sense of the elements of the characters' lives and fantasies blending together. At any rate, it meshed well with the style of the movie. In some ways, it felt like some of the cynicism running through the film was an excuse for covering up insecurities about the screenplay, that cliches could be evoked "ironically" to avoid accountability.

Definitely an odd arthouse movie, and not one I would watch over and over. But the acting - superb. The directing - great. And the steadicam operator deserves a few medals for the steadiness during extremely long takes that went up and down stairs, through tight corridors, and with many obstacles.
Terrific acting and great story development.  Surreal at times, all too real at others, results in an Oscar-worthy film.
A real dive off the deep end. Loved it.

Thoughts include that I am not a fan of jazz music... Although as a soundtrack, it does denote a particular insanity that speaks to this movie.  I also felt the confirmation to an appreciation of dark comedic crazy, and I can live in that idea easily, New York is of course a glorious embrace of setting and flavour to host such a piece of work; and the contributions from Edward Norton (who knows and articulates the walk of sexy terror in comedy) Emma Stone and Michael Keaton were each raw, available and gross to the point we may have been watching a new level of human sickness best not witnessed.  It's entertaining, but I'm not sure it's healthy.
What's not to love about a film that takes on topics like schizophrenia, narcissism, and the nature of art? It's engrossing, fascinating, and freakishly well acted.

A surreal masterpiece of directing, acting, cinematography,  score and camera work! The supporting cast is awesome, each deserving award buzz! Micheal Keaton, one of our most under rated actors, gives an intense, funny and heartbreaking performance! The tracking shots of back stage equal that of the club, kitchen sequence in 'Good Fellas!'
Oh the irony of reviewing this film, but it's too good to not to talk about it. Birdman pushes every boundaries in every aspect of filmmaking. It's beautiful. I wanna cry.
Really good, Michael Keaton is the star but Edward Norton very good.

"Let me tell you something" GO SEE THIS MOVIE! Michael Keaton and Emma Stone give the best performances of their careers! A Great story with great acting by the entire cast. This movie will leave u feeling like a bird...man, soaring high into the clouds.
What a self indulgent piece of crap!

Potentially the best film of the year, its vulgarity and unfocused telling of different characters (Edward Norton's important character suddenly disappears from the film's final act) keeps me from granting a full five out of five stars. The film's usage of continuous camera shooting is reminiscent of a play, in that there are no edits in a play, and in that a play gives the viewer a sense of real time and believability and being in the present. I would say the technical aspects of the film are six stars out of five, but the narrative serves as simply a worthy companion, instead of a grand compliment which betters the film as a whole. Michael Keaton was great, but I don't think it will restart his career; he's just too unorthodox for his talent to translate to other movies.
Impressive filming, well acted, great writing,
asking for a review before I have view the app is not going to solicit a good response.
I thought the performances were great. I wasn't crazy about the storyline.
rich, textured, smart, fresh.
The most unique masterpiece in film in our bland modern culture.
Definitely one of the best movies of the year. Keaton is an Oscar nominated for sure.
Don't have much to say other than: Bravo!

In a hundred years, people will look back and rate this classic as a great example of America cinema, in the same realm of "Citizen Kane", "Casablanca" and other masterpieces. This is the kind of experience that you have very rarely in theaters these days, when a masterful Mexican director is able to take out the best of great artists and build something magical, revolutionary and unforgettable.

There's so much to admire in this dark fable, from the brilliant acting of Keaton and the rest of the cast, to the mesmerizing long shots -- a dazzling display of cinematic choreography.  Those are what made the film worth watching, but ultimately I'm just not a big fan of dark, surrealistic tragedies; and even the occasional humorous, playful touches couldn't break through how unlikeable (and self-absorbed) almost all of the characters were.  A cautionary tale about the dangers of life as an actor, perhaps?
I thought it was great, but it's very very "arty". You may hate it if you don't like abstract weird stuff and annoying drum scores.
A metafictional biography of Michael Keaton, modern art and commerce.
Brilliant, genius, and inspired!

Visually, this movie was great, and I wouldn't be surprised if either the Director or the Cinematographer receives some sort of an Award Nomination for their creative camera direction and the sometimes random, but pleasing, visuals. One of the very few films where you have Batman, The Hulk, and Gwen Stacy all share the same screen together...hahaa. This by far is Michael Keaton's best work he has ever done (yep, and as much as I loved him in Beetlejuice, this exceeds that) and both him and Edward Norton will most likely have front row seats at the Academy Awards next year with this film. One of the best films I've seen all year!
Good performance by Michael Keaton.  A bit odd movie but entertaining.

If you are a fan of performances and originality in filmmaking, then Birdman is right up your alley. It really is like nothing you've ever seen. I though it was fantastic! Has to be a virtual lock to win best cinematography next week. As good as Michael Keaton is, Edward Norton is better; and that's saying a lot because Keaton is superb. I waited a week to write this and I'm glad, because it has sunk in and Birdman is remarkable. See it.
Alejandro González Iñárritu has outdone himself, Keatons best performance....

Birdman is an odd, hilarious film that takes filmmaking to the next level, the direction is perfect, the cinematography looks gorgeous, Keaton's performance was outstanding, Norton's performance as well, the script makes sense and is perfect that it's impossible to look for a flaw, because it doesn't have any, overall it is a well directed, beautifully shot, with a flawless script that is smartly written and outstanding performances.
Interesting. Different. Good acting. Was pleasantly surprised to also have Emma Stone, Zach Galafanakis, and Edward Norton in it.

I really wanted to like this, I think Michael Keaton is great in dramas, My Life is one of my favorite movies, but this film is just pretentious tricks so the director can show the audience how wonderful he is.

Aktorska ekstraklasa w "jednym uj?ciu" tragi(bardziej)Komicznej metafory "wielkiego" ?wiata dzisiejszej kultury, sztuki, s?awy, blockbusterów, tweetów i ca?ej reszty. Birdman is nothing short of brilliance. It's darkly humorous, sharp, and all too honest. Michael Keaton - who needs to win an Oscar for this role - plays a washed up actor who was the star of a Batman-esque franchise called Birdman (which, in the film, ended with Birdman 3 in 1992, and was never remade or revisited by Hollywood). To resurrect his career, he mounts a play based on the work of Raymond Carver. Every shot, every action, and every prop was intentional, the acting is raw, and the film has a lot to say about celebrity, acting, theater, Hollywood, superhero franchises, and self-worth. It's a gorgeous film, shot entirely as one long continuous shot, with an ending open to interpretation. Emma Stone - who typically plays comedy - is the one performer who stands out for being very serious, including one scene where she also earned her Oscar nod for her incredible work. And Edward Norton, a notoriously difficult actor to work with, plays an actor...who is difficult to work with. But his motivations are so beautifully fleshed out, he too needed a nod. Truly one of the best films of 2014.

May just be the most original and well-written movie of the year. Inarritu creates a masterpiece that is as hilarious as it is thought-provoking. Keaton seems as if he were born to play this insightful role of a former superhero-actor, who is desperate to feel relevant. There is also fantastic supporting performances from Stone, Norton, and Watts. But the film itself has ingenious commentary about how everyone yearns to have purpose in the world and what people find entertaining in this day and age. And it is shot perfectly, with immaculate cinematography.

The best picture winner of 2014, once again I'm here to tell you if it was a well deserved win. I'm here to say, yes absolutely. This film winning best picture makes me happy, because it's different. It's not a conventional Oscar movie, as in not about someone in history or events that happened in the past. It was an original movie that won, and that doesn't happen that often. 
 As for the actual movie, it's fantastic. Alejandro Gonzales Inarritu crushed it. For the story of the movie, it's about an aging actor named Riggan, played by Michael Keaton, who did superhero movies. He did sequels of the superhero Birdman, and he was then not respected as an actor so he decides to make a play, he writes, directs, and stars in his own play. Riggan is doing this to show everyone who he is and what he can do, that he deserves their resepect. There are many different characters that are, weird, for the most part. There is the producer of the play named Jake, played by Zach Galifianakis. Mike, played by Edward Norton, an actor that is loved by critics joins the play.  I mean, this is a fantastic cast, Emma Stone plays Riggan's daughter, and Naomi Watts plays another actress in the play, which is in a relationship with Mike.  All the performances are great, but there are two stand outs in which I want to mention. First is Michael Keaton, this is his greatest performance of his career. He really becomes the character, Michael Keaton is a recognizable person but I didn't see him, I saw his character. Another performance which I would like to point out is Zach Galifianakis, it was surprising that he could pull this off. I've only seen him in comedic roles where he just does the same thing over and over, but this performance was different it was real. He plays more of a serious role, and he's great in it, he holds his own with all these other great actors. In my opinion, Zach Galifianakis, in this film, was the most surprising performance of 2014. I believe Zach's performance was great because he was under a great director. Alejandro G. Inarritu was fantastic behind the camera. If he can make Zach Galifianakis give a good performance, I wonder what he can't do. 
Speaking of being behind the camera, the cinematography is amazing. You probably already know by now, but the whole thing looks like one tracking shot. It's virtually impossible to detect the cuts, I couldn't detect them. A very well deserved award for the cinematography, I applaud Emmanuel Lubezki. And while we are on the subject of technical achievements, the score...is alright. Look, I didn't love it like other people do, but I like it, I like how it fits with the story. The score, in my opinion, is the weakest part of the film. I'm not saying the score was bad, not even close; it's just as creative and imaginative as the film itself.  But if that's my only complaint, that I didn't like the score that much, then it shows you how amazing this movie is.

Here we are in 2014.  For whatever reason, being meta is incredibly popular in mainstream film right now.  Plenty of movies are acting self-aware these days and it is actually coming up on the point of feeling cheap rather than interesting or at the very least a fun novelty.  Some movies have handled this trend well, such as "22 Jump Street" and "They Came Together," and some have merely exploited it for no real benefit, like "This is the End."  Here we have "Bridman," a film that comes as close to being meta as humanly possible without ever actually saying it out loud.  Michael Keaton plays former Hollywood superstar, Riggan Thomson, who made billions in the early 90's as the popular superhero Birdman and now, many years later, is trying to reinvent himself as a serious actor, and no one seems to care (an obvious metaphor for Keaton's own "Batman" career).  Even beyond that, the movie is still very "inside Hollywood," and by the end of the film everything that was charming about being meta has worn out its welcome.
 
"Birdman" boasts such a strong first half that you may leave the theater wondering what happened to it during the second.  Nothing happened to it, and that's the film's biggest problem: the first half is virtually identical to the second half.  The film falls into a repetition as we watch these characters struggle to open a play adapted by Thomson from Raymond Carver, but the first half really is a marvelous piece of cinema.  Keaton gives off a phenomenal performance that can be appreciated by all and good for him because he deserves to have another performance to be remembered by under his belt.  He is the heart and soul of this film and in classic Keaton form, is able to bring the audience from laughter to anger in just a few seconds.
 
The other two most notable performances come from Edward Norton and Emma Stone.  Norton (who possibly needed a good role even more than Keaton) does his absolute best to bring the character of Mike to life.  There are scenes here where we are instantly reminded of why Norton was once one of the top actors in the business before burning too many bridges, and oddly enough, his best work is done in the scenes where he gets to relax and just be a real person but at times tries a little too hard during the scenes where he gets to be the eccentric stage actor he's playing.  It might be a bit of his own fault but I do put some of the blame on the uneven writing of his character.  Even so, I was thrilled to see Norton doing some solid acting in a good movie again.  And Emma Stone brings as much complexity as she can to the character, Sam, Riggan's fresh-out-of-rehab daughter.
 
Despite the serious nature of the film, all of the actors appear to be having a good time with it and really hit the audience hard with the comedic moments.  In order to give off the vibe like we're watching a play on screen, the film is shot as if it is all done in one continuous take which really makes you appreciate the performances and how difficult it is to time the scenes but during some back and forth dialogue scenes you may find yourself wishing that the camera would just cut back and forth between the two actors speaking to each other rather than moving back and forth or just cutting some speaking characters out of the shot altogether.
 
While the film is only two hours, it feels much longer near the end because of the repetition.  I began to ask myself, "how many more rehearsals and previews do we need to watch?  When is it going to be opening night?"  We see Riggan's tension and neuroses build higher and higher with every rehearsal and we go deep into his mind as we see him imagining he actually has superpowers, and we also get to hear his inner monologue narrated not quite by himself but his alter-ego Birdman, a constant reminder of mistakes and failures of his life and career.
 
Of course "Birdman" is pretentious and a bit repetitive but it is also strangely lots of fun.  Everyone does the best job they can and perhaps with a different director, would have been the perfect piece of abstract yet mainstream film that everyone so desperately wants this to be.  If anything, "Birdman" starts a conversation and for that I can do nothing but recommend it.

I've never seen another movie like it. After it was over I just wanted to watch it again, not just because it was good, but because there was simply so much of it.

During a time when even blockbusters try to mix heavy themes with spectacle, it's refreshing to watch a movie that actually treats both aspects with a certain amount of intelligence and wit that rewards multiple viewings. 

The themes of Birdman run the gamut: depression, parent-child relationships, reality and performance, and maybe most poignantly, identity in the modern world. The spectacle comes in the form of the camera work and a grounded use of special effects. The scenes have a crisp visual fidelity reminiscent of car commercials.

Sometimes it was honestly hard to follow along, but it was never not rewarding throughout. As unabashedly current as this movie is, I hope it ages better than the character that the camera so often dizzily zooms around.

Looks great, less filling.  Inarritu is a world class filmmaker with "Amores Perros", "21 Grams," "Babel," "Biutiful," and now "Birdman," which is his most ambitious film to date.  His skill with actors, camerawork and the technical aspects of production always makes his films worth seeing.  But often he uses gimmicks like the nonlinear style of "21 Grams," crosscutting across the world in "Babel" or the shock effects of the dogfight and car crash in "Amores Perros."  The problem with "Birdman" is that he introduces so many things that are very visual, but just don't pay off in the story - the lesbian seduction, the moving objects, the levitation, the superhero narrator conscience, just to name a few in the first 20 minutes alone, that never satisfactorily develop and conclude in the film.

The film tries to be many things, but never really accomplishes any of them.  It's about celebrity and fame, madness in the theater, a self centered actor who screws up the lives around him, a satire of empty entertainment vs. real meaning in art.  Like the visual gimmicks, it introduces all these themes, then never follows through, so you are left with cool visual imagery, but no satisfactory insight or resolution about any of the ideas.

Michael Keaton has the role of a lifetime here and will certain get nominations and even awards.  The other cast support him very well, especially Edward Norton, Naomi Watts and Emma Stone.  The film is reminiscent of "The Fisher King," but unlike that memorable Robin Williams-Jeff Bridges masterpiece, also about madness and celebrity in New York, "Birdman" lacks the central script working on all the levels the film aspires to be on.

Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu's ("Babel" and "Amores Perros") films, although frequently critically acclaimed, often get pegged as being downbeat and gloomy. So, it's a genuine surprise to many that his latest, the wondrous "Birdman (or the Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance)," is such a witty, often hilarious and even moving film.

There's been a lot of talk about Michael Keaton's comeback in the movie as Riggan Thompson, a washed up Hollywood star known mostly for his role as the film's titular superhero who is staging a resurgence by putting on a theatrical production of Raymond Carver's "What We Talk About When We Talk About Love" on Broadway. And, for sure, the role is Keaton's juiciest in some time. As Riggan, he is able to dig into a character who is equally flawed, poignant, goofy and, at times, borderline delirious. And Inarritu complements his character's moments of frustration and anguish with magical realist flights of fancy that would have made Gabriel Garcia Marquez proud.

But although Keaton is great in the movie, there's enough praise to go around for the entire cast, which includes a very solid Naomi Watts as a Broadway first timer, Emma Stone in her best performance to date as Riggan's ex-drug addict daughter who also works as her father's assistant, a very restrained Zach Galifianakis as Riggan's manager and friend and Amy Ryan as the former star's ex-wife.

Edward Norton nearly steals the show as Mike Shiner, the prima donna Broadway star whom Riggan calls in at the last moment to act in the play after a colleague is seriously injured by a falling stage light. Norton's always been a fine actor, but who knew how funny he could be? Shiner is a handful, trashing the stage's props during a preview show and then later taking a sex scene a little too far with a fellow actor.

One of the elements of the film that has drawn much attention is the way that Inarritu makes it appear as if the entire movie were one continuous shot. Obviously, it's not and the filmmaker employs some techniques similar to those of Alfred Hitchcock's "Rope." But the picture always feels as if it is in motion, following one character down a hallway, only to take up with another heading a different direction. Rather than feeling gimmicky, the technique creates the tension involved in a Broadway production's final hours before it is unveiled to the public.

Another aspect of "Birdman" that makes it unique is how it plays upon its actors' real lives to comment on their characters in the film. Keaton, as we all know, shot to fame playing a superhero and Inarritu's film is a comeback for him, much as the Carver play is for Riggan. And Norton has been known - on occasion - to be a high strung collaborator, although I'd be willing to bet his obnoxious Shiner is exaggerated for the sake of hilarity.

"Birdman" is, of course, also about the artistic process and the film's final frames struck a similar note to the finale of Darren Aronofsky's "Black Swan," although Inarritu's picture ends on a more hopeful - rather than bleak - note. This has been a year for great final shots - "Boyhood," "Under the Skin" and "The Immigrant" come to mind - and "Birdman" has a pretty terrific one as well.

This is a thematically rich and extremely entertaining film with some pointed commentary on the process of making art as well as the modern methods of making it accessible to the public. Everything from YouTube, Twitter and Facebook to smart phones and comic book movies come under fire. This is one of the year's best.
