I honestly didn't know what to expect with a cast like this, and the rumor of a non-stop camera take. First of all, the cast made this film come to life. From the quick little comedic bits of Zach Galifianakis's hilarious supporting role to the believable daughter role created ever-so-brilliantly by Emma Stone, this film delivers the perfect amount of comedy, drama, action, and even tragedy. But the true highlights of this film are from the two leading men, Michael Keaton and Edward Norton. Norton creates a character that the audience just loves to hate, and then loves to love at the end. A supporting actor nomination and even win are VERY likely for him. As for Keaton, I have never seen an actor as dedicated or believable as he in this film. He truly comes to life in this film and in my mind, deserves the Oscar right now...why wait till Spring?! There are plenty of films about "washed up actors" or "wannabe stars," but Keaton takes it to the next level, bringing tears, laughs, and emotion to the audience in the most believable way. Believability, in my mind, is vital, and Keaton nails it to the bone. Aside from the acting, the cinematography that Birdman offers, as well as the (less than) five minutes of special effects, are truly breathtaking. For those of you who don't know, the entire film is done in ONE take, even transitioning from night to day, without cutting the camera ONCE. Seeing the camera seamlessly transition between scenes makes the whole thing seem real and like you're literally walking through the hallways and backstage of the St. James theatre. Everything about the writing, cinematography, and acting, make Birdman a must see, and create a LEGEND out of Michael Keaton. Watch out for this film come Oscar time, for you'll see it on the list in MANY places.
genius. captivating from start to finish. only weak scene is the truth or dare one

Birdman, written and directed by Alajandro Gonzales Iruitu(probably butchered that but oh well), and stars Michael Keaton, Edward Norton, Emma Stone, Amy Ryan and Zach Galifanakas. Birdman tells the tale of a man who once played a famed superhero back in his early days of acting. Now he must battle his alter ego(Birdman) in order to premiere his play on broadway so he can back into the world. One of the biggest complements I can give to this movie is the directing by iruitu, his choice of making it look all like one shot is genius. The acting was also spot on everyone gave great performances, but the p that stands out most is Keaton, he will and should win the best actor Oscar I'm not just saying that because of everyone else but because of how much effort he put in to this role. Norton also gave a great performance as Keatons co-star in his play, Emma stone also great I mean really what isn't there to love about Emma stone.....whoa got off track there for a minute. The music as well is great not as good as interstellar though but its still good though, also the cineamatography in this movie holy cow this movie looked beautiful from start to finish. Now your all probably saying to yourselves hey man you just love it because everyone else loved it, go watch Boyhood its a far superior film then this and to that I say no, I like this movie because it was original anyone could direct a movie for twelve years and get an Oscar nod, but for someone who made a beautiful movie like this and shot it the way he did deserves best picture and director. One final thing there's a scene in this movie where Keaton is in a bar and he's talking to a critic and the critic says she's going to give it a bad review even though she had yet to see the play, now I'm guilty of this I have criticised a film before I saw it but that's beside the point Keaton exerted so much heart and passion and energy into that scene and I thought to myself, yeah give this man the Oscar. My final grade for this movie is an A+, go check it out now if its playing in a theater near you its worth your time!!!!

The movie is successful in making it feel like a theatrical performance, something bold and daring in its own right. It also serves as a reminder as to what our current Hollywood mindset does to us when it comes to the art of performance. The acting is superb, however, some of the best characters have plot devices left unfinished, and that's probably my biggest set back. But it's mostly a funny, spirited, dark, clever, and insightful tale about a man struggling to become himself and struggling to accept the things that make us human.

A daring film by Alejandro GonzÃ¡lez IÃ±Ã¡rrituÂ with an even more daring performance by Michael Keaton. Some films are great cause they show restraint and a minimalist design...Birdman is not that type of film. Director Alejandro González Iñárritu has thrown in everything plus the kitchen sink for his latest picture, a visual-feast and poetic satire that's as thorough as it is ambitious. Shooting the film in the appearance of a single long-take (with the most subtle of cuts), Birdman's cinematic flourish actually accentuates it's themes regarding artistry, as it makes the film carry the look of a play, only wistfully projected through the world of cinema. Iñárritu also comments on virtually every spectrum of the entertainment world here (criticism, budgetary-concerns, low-brow vs. high-brow), yet the movie never feels messy, and wraps it all together in a truly sublime and uplifting fashion. Carried by a wide-range of familiar actors (many of whom are gloriously breaking their type-cast here), the film remains highly accessible and entertaining even when most cerebral, and in many ways it resembles the perfect comic-book film that Hollywood has tried so long to film. An ensemble dramedy masterpiece, that can join the likes of Boogie Nights and Pulp Fiction as an instant classic!

I swear if this movie is not nominated for Best Picture in the Oscars, I am going to kill myself.

The movie's plot relies on character development and they did a good job doing that. The movie's plot also relies on social commentary about Hollywood which they were on point about it especially about "washed up" actors trying to be relevant again as well as the "snobby critics" which was my favorite scene in the entire movie.

I don't usually comment on musical scores in this movie but I cannot ignore the score in this movie because it was really good. The use of the drums in this movie as a score is perfectly used considering the intense tone of the movie.

The direction from Alejandro González Iñárritu in this movie is amazing. Not to forget that this movie excel the "shot in one take" style of filming very well. It feels like they really shot the movie in one take thanks to clever editing skills.

Birdman could be an Oscar winner next year thanks to its brilliant cast performance especially from Michael Keaton, Edward Norton and Emma Stone as well as great character development, on-point social commentary about Hollywood, really good musical score, amazing direction from Alejandro González Iñárritu and its well-done "shot in one take" filming style.

The surprise film at the LFF this year truly surprises. After correctly guessing what it will be, I was not prepared for the visual/cerebral assault that took place in the next 2 hours. For anyone who has ever bemoaned the homogeneity and predictability of modern cinema, Birdman is the answer. A film showcasing a revitalised Michael Keaton (aided also by an amazing supporting cast from Norton to Stone to even Galifianakas, who normally can be quite grating) throwing everything he's got on the screen, losing oneself to a role so selflessly without reservation or vanity that it would be a crime not to give him a nod come Oscars time.  But this is also the director's film. Inarritu has made a slightly surreal film about a Hollywood actor trying to find legitimacy in a self-financed Broadway play, blurring the lines between reality and fantasy to great (narrative and visual) effect, he ingeniously decided to emulates the fluidity and flow of a theatrical play with one seemingly continuous tracking shot that is literally breathtakingly intense and so fluid that it glides non-stop for the duration of the film from beginning to (almost the) end. Lubezki, after his stunning work on Gravity is behind the camera again gunning for a 2nd consecutive Oscar with the help of some seamless editing, intelligent and unobtrusive use of CGI and a pulsating percussive soundtrack that literally drove the film ever onwards. The film is exhausting to watch but you cannot take your eyes off of it until the very last enigmatic scene that leaves you pondering what it all means. Thought-provoking and unique, this is a rare experience that I expect people will talk about for a long time to come.

The more I think about this film as time goes, the more I really appreciate this films message. Starting with the great story of an actor who played a superhero in the late 1980s to the early 1990s after becoming a household name, Birdman. The movie centralizes on the actor named Riggan, who is played by Micheal Keaton on trying to change his image to reflect not how people see him but how he sees himself as well as struggling with his confidence. The movies narrative is straight forward but its delivery is truly stunning mostly due to the cinematography, by making all the scenes look like one shot. That being said what it shows are standout performances from the cast, especially from Keaton. Now there are arguements being made about how this movie is pretty much his life, I would say it is very similar but not entirely accurate. The movie focuses more on the psyche of actors and actresses for the same reason Keaton's character Riggan are working towards. Some of the characters we sympathize with in terms of their mental well being, some of characters we disregard for their actions or for why they act but this is definitely Riggans story of a person who questions his actions to hopefully deal with his demons. He is consistently having a hard time to keep his demons at bay while also dealing with his family (mostly his daughter played by Emma Stone) and the play. The movie really punches the audience in the face regarding how movies are just being cash grab blockbusters and not a lot of creatively is being put into the movies. It really hits audiences and critics on the idea that they demand a lot from actors but are never satisfied. It also depicts the perspective that everyone just labels everything and doesn't think about the creative process it took to make a play or film. The message only strengthens the movie story giving it a greater impact to where we get a greater sense of reliability between Riggan and the viewer. I suppose with Michael leading this story it certainly does help the film have a genuine approach and I can understand the arguments being made. Choosing Michael Keaton as the lead role was a phenomenal choice, as I can't see how it would have worked with any other actor, especially with the realism. Overall this movie has a great message and its story is really spot on. A well deserved praise is due for Micheal Keaton as he was able to show weakness and humility throughout the films narrative as well as captivating an actors integrity making it feel like a unique experience. Come Oscar season I wouldn't mind if it won at all.

Birdman: How did we end up here?

As if I needed more reasons to want to love Michael Keaton as a performer, director Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu has given the actor a fantastic role that puts him back in the spotlight, in a film that puts heavy emphasis on what it is to mean something to many, only to want to redefine one's self.  That is just one of the many ideas that Birdman tackles, as the film plays as a very entertaining dissection of Hollywood, Broadway, and the notion of fame in our modern culture.  Additionally, Inarritu was far from content with treating this project as a simple satirical exercise, so the film is made to show us the weeks that go by in this story within nearly one long take.  This shot is of course many shots carefully stitched together, but the screenplay is also a careful assemblage of ideas, themes, and great moments for all the actors to shine.  This makes Birdman an ambitious and unpredictable ball of energy that just so happens to be a spectacular film to watch.

Like most people I know, my interest in Birdman came from the obvious parallels between Michael Keaton's real career and that of the character he is playing. In Birdman Keaton plays Riggan Thomson. A Hollywood actor who's last great role was in the 1990's when he stared as the title character in Birdman 3. Keaton of course will always be most well known for playing Batman in the first two (serious) Batman films. But that's where the comparisons between Keaton and Riggan Thomson stop. Keaton's real life persona, and Riggan Thomson's couldn't be any further from each other, and the plot of the film is definitely nothing like what you would see in a summer superhero block buster. All of which is good news for the audience.

The film is mostly about the fate of a play Riggan has adapted, is directing, and starring in-this of course rubs some Broadway diehards the wrong way, such as Edward Norton's character, a beloved Broadway actor named Mike Shiner, and a New York Times critic played by Lindsay Duncan-but it's also about the insatiable attention artists crave, and what lengths they're willing to go to get it; to stay relevant in today's lightning speed culture. The film hits all the right beats, but it delivers them in that strange way that only an independent film can dare to do. Now don't let that last statement turn you off, this isn't a head scratching movie (well, except for maybe the ending), it is grounded in a realism that's sorely missing from the majority of todays films, and is a welcome addition to Keaton's filmography.

I may not be able to explain it, but gods, it was brilliant. Birdman is at once an indictment of a movie culture that gives us nothing but franchise superheroes and ever louder CGI explosions... AND an indictment of actors and artists who think they're oh so above donning a latex suit and making a hundred million on opening weekend. The film is a technical masterpiece, put together as one long tracking shot over nearly two hours, and the director never clues you in on exactly what is in Michael Keaton's head and what's not in this play within a play... but this is also an utterly brilliant piece of acting from a guy who once donned a latex suit for Batman in the late 80s. It piles the bravery of showing aging human bodies in all their ugliness in brutal reality on top of what can only be fantasy and pretension, in ever-arching circles of self-awareness while ultimately closing its eyes and letting us fly away from it.

"Why don't I have any self-respect?" "You're an actress, honey." Those are just two lines from this excellent, weird, funny movie. Sometimes you don't know if what you're seeing is the "real" part of the story or something in the mind of Michael Keaton's character, Riggan, the actor and director of a new play on Broadway, but it's all engrossing and I couldn't look away. I honestly cared for this character. He's half insane with a voice in his head that sounds like his low self-esteem while he goes tries to weather the storm of producing his play, dealing with a disappointed daughter, a crazy actor, relationships with two women, and a theatre critic who hates him. It's definitely one of the best films I've seen in a long time.

If this isn't the most unique and meta film made in the last decade, then I don't know what is. Practically shot in one entire cut/take, "Birdman" is impressive on that front alone. However, its raw and unabashed look at modern Hollywood, theatre, popularity, vitality, and criticism makes me want it to win Best Picture all the more.
Bravura performances and camerawork.

Birdman is a searing indictment of fame, both of those who mindlessly chase after it, and the audience that feeds the machines of it. In a superb performance, Michael Keaton plays an actor trapped by his own ego, unable to maintain a stable life offstage. Emma Stone turns in a wonderful performance as his daughter, who was cast aside her entire life and is one of the few people in the actor's life that is willing to offer him a modicum of truth. The entire cast provides a delightful chorus to Keaton's impending insanity, and Innaritu masterfully weaves his camera through the madness.

Michael Keaton is a force of nature in Alejandro Iñárritu's Birdman, a breathtakingly brilliant meta-commentary on acting, theatre, celebrities, film franchises, criticism, individuality, self-worth, and more. Every aspect of Birdman works excellently, from its technically outstanding camera work to Antonio Sanchez's gleefully kinetic score. Basically, what I'm saying is this: if you are interested in film, theatre, or brilliant acting, watch Birdman.

96% Birdman is certainly one of the primary Oscar Challengers this year. With an incredible Directorial effort by Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu and a great Cinematography makes this movie what it really is. With an amazing cast, starring the Career Role for Michael Keaton, a Mind Blowing performance by Edward Norton, the Career Defining Acting by Emma Stone, and other great jobs by Zack Galifianakis and Naomi Watts (Who seems to be everywhere these days). Birdman makes an unlikely Oscar Plot about an old Actor who once was a Popular Superhero Character, act in a play to get his career back on track, into a fantastic movie and one of the best you will see this year.

Deserves to be on the list of top technical achievements in film history for filming several long elaborate takes and combining them to seem like one continuous shot. It also has some great performances not surprisingly from Edward Norton and Emma stone. I still don't care much for Michael Keaton what can i say. This drama comedy lampoons not only the current state of superhero obsessed Hollywood but also the snobbish Broadway scene. Birdmans strength, being one of the most topical movie you will ever see is also its weakness. The current state of all the things it criticizes well have changed in 5 or 10 years making this film far from timeless. It also playes way more to hollywood or theater insiders which might be a good way to win an Best picture Oscar but is relevant to a very very small percentage of the population. Enjoy it for the film making skill and performances but don't expect to watch this in the future and have it have any meaning.

I bet whatever money I have in my wallet that this will be the movie of the year according to the Academy. Guaranteed. 
While it's not my type of film, the Academy will surely drool with excitement over it. It has everything, artistic expression, fantastic actors and acting, stunning cinematography and out-of-style camera work. The fact that the movie is shot in NYC by a foreign director presenting a messed up life of a struggling Broadway actor is practically licking balls of the Academy. 
Yes, Boyhood was filmed over 12 years. Yes, The Grand Budapest Hotel was phenomenal. But Birdman will take the best picture Oscar home this year.

Edward Norton acted the best as usual, he was hilarious, and Emma Stone did wonderfully. Michael Keaton and Naomi Watts overacted, while Zach G was a joke in the role, he should stick to comedy. Not really recommended but Michael Keaton and the movie could be up for Oscars. Just don't know what to do with Broadway Actors in movies playing Broadway Actors. 2/18 update - after seeing all other Oscar nominees, Birdman is a strong contender for both Best Picture and Best Actor.

"How did we end up here? This place is horrible. It smells like balls."
In case you are wondering, this is not a superhero movie.
Birdman is a black comedy about Riggan Thomson (Keaton, the best performance in years), a washed-up actor who played a superhero in blockbuster movies, trying to make his comeback by writing, directing, and starring in a theatrical adaptation of Raymond Carver's "What We Talk About When We Talk About Love". He is so desperate to prove that he's an artist and that he can do something other than a superhero character.
The play is produced by his best friend/lawyer Jake (Galifianakis, superb), and stars Riggan's girlfriend Laura, first-time-Broadway-actress Lesley (Watts, great), and Mike Shiner (Norton, terrific as always), an actor who is notorious for being difficult to work with. There's only a few days left until the opening, and Riggan is on the verge of nervous breakdown.
Oh, he also tries to rekindle his relationship with his daughter Sam (Emma Stone, her most outstanding performance ever), a recovering drug addict who works as Riggan's assistant, AND he has to deal with Birdman, his alter ego that keeps whispering in his mind. His ego is so big and it's killing himself.
It's a huge leap forward for writer-director Alejandro González Iñárritu, the mastermind behind 21 Grams (2003) and Babel (2006). Who would've thought that he could make a showbiz satire? The idea is so ambitious and full of creativity, the story is compelling, and the jokes are laugh-out-loud funny. It's a crowd-pleaser in the best way possible.
By far the most extraordinary aspects of this film is the visuals. The entire film looks like it's shot in one continuous long take. The cinematographer Emmanuel Lubezki (an Oscar winner for Gravity (2013)) keeps improving himself. His work is always magnificent and breathtaking. The dude is a real visual artist.
All of the performances are near-perfection. Michael Keaton knows exactly what he's doing. The actor himself was once popular as Bruce Wayne/Batman in Tim Burton's Dark Knight flicks, but hasn't done anything memorable ever since. Well, this will surely put him back on the map and he will be nominated for Best Actor at the Oscars. Edward Norton, who is a difficult actor to work with in real life, gives another award-caliber work as Mike, the volatile actor who drives Riggan banana. Emma Stone is an eye-opener as Riggan's daughter Sam, Zach Galifianakis is damn good as Jake, and Naomi Watts is solid as always
But still, the biggest achievement of Birdman is the way it presents itself. The movie knows it's taking the risk and how ambitious it is. You can feel it saying "Come at me, bro!" Iñárritu is a risk-taker but also a visionary director. Haters can piss off. If you are a true movie lover, buy a ticket and jump right in. And you won't regret it.

The technical aspects of the direction were intriguing. The actors masterfully captured the pretentious egos of the characters. The story never told the audience where it was going, was entirely strange, but thoroughly rewarding. I "Label" it awesome, amazing, one of the best of the year...  it was really good. "Caw."

Michael Keaton is great as always.  It's finally nice to see Him getting the recognition as a leading man that he has missed for so long.  And this is easily my favorite performance by Edward Norton in more than a decade.  Not to say that the rest of the cast isn't noteworthy.  They all are.  But it's the two I mentioned that realy steal the show on camera. 
   Off camera on the other hand this movie is flawlessly directed and shot.  About 95% of the movie is made to look like one take and they do an amazing job of convincing the audience of it.  The music is unique and fitting.  And I thought the visual effects, for a film of this sized budget, were great.
   My only disappointment overall with the movie is that although it has stuck in my mind for a few days now.  It didn't impact me as much emotionally as I was hoping/expecting it to.  Given it's amazing reaction by the critics and audiences alike.  But it is an amazingly well made film with great performances that deserve to be honored come awards season.

a tour de force of genius and brilliance
director Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu has crafted a great return to fame for Michael Keaton which also plays as a mirror image of the actor's real career and persona
Keaton played another superhero back in his day and he has been out of it for a long while, here he has the chance to make a career comeback by putting on a play of his own
yet the voice inside his head being the character of Birdman makes him unsure of whether to continue the broadway profession or act in another movie again to have the public love him
the film is expertly shot being one single take without any cuts moving from place to place, you even wonder how did they get some of these shots??? they look fantastic
the rest of the actors from Emma Stone to Edward Norton are pure gold trying to tell Keaton's character what the art of theater is these days and how the show runs; there's also a fascinating analyzation about the celebrity culture (how once-famous actors can fall from grace and become washed up and forgotten about), the power and influence of social media from Twitter to Youtube to Facebook, and attacking what critics criticize even though its their job 
the psychological battle is also very nifty using the persona of Keaton's alter ego and visualizing the once-greatness he had on the world and what it could still mean for him
it's funny, sincere, influential, and culturally relevant
one of the year's finest films

A cinematic masterpiece. Plain and simple. This is a film with purpose in its steps, and a big brain (that of brilliant co-writer and director Alejandro Inarritu) on its shoulders.

This is a story about knowing yourself, and never yearning to please those who don't determine the next step. There's subtlety, subtext, and nuance in every character. We pull from every single one. Amy Ryan's pent up frustration; Emma Stone's dissatisfaction with herself, projected onto those around her; Edward Norton's want to be the three-dimensional person he is on stage in the real world; Naomi Watts' misplaced want for recognition and affirmation.

Thank you, Mr. Inarritu. This is the type of film that is going to spur on a whole new generation of creative minds to make original films.

Serving as Michael Keaton's Academy Award nominated comeback film, Birdman (or the Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance) was too critically acclaimed to miss.

To say that I went into Birdman with high expectations is an understatement. With all its critical acclaim, I hoped that it would be a revolutionary experience. I definitely set my sights a bit high, but there is no doubt that Birdman is a brilliant film which really messed with my head.
Birdman is a massive rush. The story in the film deals with so many themes in a confronting manner, ranging from dealing with deteriorating mental health so a sense of inferiority in the world and determination to stand up and make a change against the nihilism. The film jumps right into the material and in no time is able to establish the atmosphere as being intense and striking. This combines with the fast pace of the film to create a mesmerizing rush of an experience, for better and for worse. The hard hitting nature of the subject matter combined with the rapid pace of Birdman is sure to strike viewers, but it can also be overwhelming at times. While Birdman gives time for the subject matter to transition in, it jumps straight into the mood of the film and stays consistent with it to the end of the film. It is a very faced paced experience which can be overwhelming because at some times it rushes through scenes mercilessly. It doesn't leave any of the story out, but the manic energy in Birdman may weigh down on the viewers at points in the film. But while I felt this for moments of the film, as a whole, the experience of the feature was brilliant.
There were some moments when I was watching Birdman that I got so lost in the film that 10 minutes later I would stop and realize that I was sitting in a cinema. To be sucked into a film like that is an amazing thing, and for Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu to achieve that is amazing. Despite his films being rather popular, I have always had mixed to negative feelings about his works. After seeing Birdman, I have no doubt that he is a brilliant filmmaker. Birdman is a new high point for his career, a new standard of filmmaking which is just not something that anyone who likes movies can ever miss. The way that he contains the story even though it is such a psychotic one is very challenging to achieve, but he manages to do it. I just could not believe how much the film sucked me in because it is one that is so simple in story and yet so complicated in themes while maintaining certain stylistic elements of a stage production like the one that is chronicled in the story. There is a lot to take in from the film, and the extent that the viewer's brain can honestly fit in will determine how much they enjoy the film. I honestly feel that I walked away from Birdman with my brain having expanded because the images of the film still cloud my vision today. After seeing Birdman, there were times where the voice in my head actually made me feel like there was a a superhero alter ego of mine waiting behind me. That just goes to show how much Birdman can confront its viewers and strike them with relevance to their lives in any sort of way. There are a lot of things in Birdman that protagonist Riggan Thompson experiences that viewers will be able to connect to on some level which is what establishes him as a brilliantly likable protagonist and the hero that the story truly needs. The screenplay for Birdman is packed with all kinds of interesting characters and situations without ever seeming the slightest bit derivative or predictable.
In terms of technical characteristics, the cinematography in the film is particularly amazing. With its constant movements, it makes things seem like Birdman is shot in one continuous scene. With Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu choreographing the scenes to be long and filming them all in with the most time he can, Birdman is actually composed of only a few separate scenes if you look really closely. If you go out of your way to try and find the moments in the film where it is edited you may spo9t it, but if you just watch the film without trying to note that it is easy to miss because the execution is amazing. The cinematography in the film is consistent and takes a very claustrophobic angle during some of its most dramatic scenes to get up close and personal with the dramatic nature of the situations. It can sometimes feel like a bit close, but that really projects every little detail about the physical characteristics of the cast members, so it is clearly a major frontrunner for the Academy Award for Best Cinematography. It also manages to capture the sights of the nice scenery and well placed production design which all manages to contribute to giving the film a sense of genuine feel for its intended setting. The small touch of visual effects is nice as well. The cinematography in the film really elevates the experience that little bit further, and so Birdman is an insightful and stylish affair.
And with so much success built around them, the cast in Birdman give it their all and do nothing short of amazing efforts.
I have respected Michael Keaton for a long time as he was always my favourite Batman aside from Adam West, so when I heard that Birdman featured a performance from him that later became nominated for an Academy Award I was overwhelmed with joy that the world was once again appreciating the talents that I have admired for so long. On the surface he is the perfect fit for the role of a once legendary star who portrayed a superhero as he played Bruce Wayne / Batman in Tim Burton's Batman films of 1989 and 1992. But much deeper down, he is perfect for the part because in the 25 years since he first donned Batman's armour, his career has faded. I never stopped liking him though, and so seeing him fly in Birdman pleases me on a very personal level. But the fact is that his performance is the greatest he has ever given, a second coming for the actor who is now in his 60's. You wouldn't be able to tell it from the film because his age does not stand in his way. His performance transcends age, he does not seem the least bit frail and has more energy in him than any other cast member. Coming back to reality and realising that he was a 63 year old actor was actually a shock because although I knew it for long, being reminded of that after seeing Birdman was quite surprising. Michael Keaton grasps the heroic flight of his superhero character Birdman and puts all the passion in the world into the role, grasping it with a mean tenacity which captures some startling moments of affecting emotional drama and others which are generally hilarious. He never misses his mark for a second and is able to hold the screen the entire time whenever he is on it by pulling his soul out and showing it for everyone. His performance is raw with shocking strength, and arguably one of the greatest performances of 2014. Michael Keaton turns Birdman from the tale of redemption into a real life story of redemption by bringing attention to his career which has laid dormant for way too long, and to see the actor who once played the titular character from Beetlejuice delivering the number one performance worthy of the Academy Award for Best Actor. 
Edward Norton just blew me away in Birdman. The once legendary actor who has scored Two Academy Award nominations in his career delivers his finest performance in years for Birdman, a performance which is undoubtedly worthy of its Academy Award nomination. His role fits him because it fits the profile that people give of him as a control freak while also reinvigorating his status as a legandary actor by giving him the deep and complex but egotistical character of Mike Shiner. He remembers his lines seamlessly well and is able to vary in dramatic strength incredibly well when the situations demand it from him. He goes through moments of being so into character that it is infuriating but he also has the ability to touch audiences, and his tense chemistry with Michael Keaton is a brutal battle for the spotlight in which the winner is constantly varying while his interactions with Emma Stone are far more gentle. Edward Norton is a brilliant actor and we all know that, but Birdman demands the most out of him since his debut performance in Primal Fear, and he takes his talents one step further to ensure that he is clearly a viable asset to the film's success.
Emma Stone delivers her finest performance to date. While still maintaining the status of a young and innocent girl, Emma Stone uses all the skills she has spent years progressing in since she first came to prominence in 2006's Superbad to deliver a performance of exceptional theatrical talent. Her character is not given as much depth as the others, but she remains incredible based on the chemistry that she shares with Michael Keaton and Edward Norton. She is up front and brutal in some of her scenes with Michael Keaton and is able to deliver her lines with their comedic or dramatic nature all without flinching, being mercilessly dramatic without stepping into melodrama. She really puts herself out there in a very bold performance which is so admirable for her, and it is the endeavour of her career. As a person who has been watching Emma Stone since her career first took off, seeing her reach the heights she does in Birdman is a wonderful thing to experience. Emma Stone breaks new ground in Birdman, and it is beautiful to behold.
Zach Galifiniakis is also brilliant in Birdman. The actor mostly known for his work in the Hangover trilogy delivers a brilliant supporting effort in Zach Galifiniakis which shows him working with subtle humour and hard hitting drama which he manages to work out easily. He is funny, but I expected that. What I was surprised by was the level of dramatic depth he was able to reach and his astounding chemistry with Michael Keaton. His brief appearance in Birdman shows him pushing all his emotions into the part and coming out shining. Birdman left me encouraged to hope Zach Galifiniakis would tackle more dramatic material in the future and confident that he would be able to succeed at doing it, so Birdman also gives his career a step forward.
Amy Ryan, Naomi Watts and Lindsay Duncan also bring strength to their appearances.

So although Birdman can be an overwhelming film, the pure brilliance in Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu's directorial style and handling of the material mixed with revolutionary performances from Michael Keaton and Edward Norton makes it one of the finest films of 2014 and a sure frontrunner for the Academy Award for Best Actor.
Such a marvelous experience to behold the technical achievements as well as the best performance I've seen from Michael Keaton. Norton, Stone, and Galifianakis were outstanding as well.
I expected a good film with Michael Keaton, Edward Norton, and Emma Stone, and  Naomi Watts, but this film was beyond what I expected.  I look forward to seeing this film several times.

A frustratingly accurate portrayal of performers, "the biz", and art in the face of today's blockbuster and internet culture. That said, I don't recommend it for anyone that has never performed, or at least known an actor or performer. Without that experience, the merits of the film's commentary can become lost. "Birdman" is a film unlike most films seen this year, and that is one of the biggest compliments to give to this masterfully crafted work-of-art that inserts humorous jabs and commentary on today's "superhero" culture. 

The film, with the insert of a jazz-like drum beat, flows and moves at a perfect pace with near-perfect construction by masterclass director Alejandro González Iñárritu. What Iñárritu does with this film enhances the experience from being a superhero-spoof, to an Award-worthy comedy that inserts elements of fierce drama and insanity. Filmed as if it were one continuous take, "Birdman" propels the audience into a frenzy of insane and delusional scenarios, as if we are main character Riggan who goes off-and-on the break of pure insanity.

I laughed, a lot, and was genuinely rooting for this struggling actor to make the comeback he truly deserves. Michael Keaton provides a career-revival performance that is placing him on my top list (as of now) for best actor because he just hits a homerun! The rest of cast, including Emma Stone and Edward Norton, deliver outstanding performances as well. The whole cast, just great, great, great!

I must say, this film is not for everyone. It is weird, style and substance, but I found myself connecting with the film on a deeper level than expected. I loved the characters, loved the commentary, and freaking loved the style. 

"Birdman" is not the best film of year, but it is an engrossing, engaging, and an extraordinary film that balances the drama and comedy so well. Filled with wonderful performances, brilliant imagery, and is simply a film that proudly stands as the most unique film experience of the year.
Not only is the narrative incredible from opening to close, but the camera work is so well done that I dare say it would be impossible to not be completely engrossed for the entire runtime.

To criticize this film - positively or negatively - is to give added voice to the prevalent theme of Birdman. Why do we criticize others? What are the consequences of those critiques? What kind of critics are we to ourselves? These are the kinds of questions that Birdman raises to it's audience. It's a juicy look at the inner workings of the performance industry and it displays the brazen stereotypes that come with it but with a deeper look into what creates those stereotypes. Emma Stone just might've earned a best supporting actress nod with her angry monologue directed towards her father (Keaton). And speaking of Mr. Keaton; unabashed, surreal, real, and arguably his best work. I loved watching him jump to and fro emotionally and physically. Edward Norton tap danced beautifully around every character in Birdman bringing out the best and the worst in them. Great acting and beautiful long shots that probably was the catalyst for the great acting. Such a lovely piece of cinema, right there, ahuh.
I absolutely loved this. Keaton was epic. Heavy on metaphor, and a very unique way to tell a story. It's magical, funny, heart wrenching,  and sometimes frustrating to watch.
Birdman is a movie about movies, shot beautifully, and has some groundbreaking performances.
Perfection. Adored every frame. Keaton is breathtaking. A remarkable achievement in magical realism. Thought provoking, artfully made, and just a great great film.
The performances are top notch in this movie.  The story however bored me and had to many things going on that served absolutely no purpose.

I had heard this movie was good, amazing in fact, but I wasn't convinced it wasn't hyperbole. It never failed to deliver! Every aspect of this film is impressive. From the technical requirements of shooting to make the film seem like one to shot, to the incredible performances given by Norton, Stone and especially Keaton it never stops surprising and rewarding you for watching. The exploration of family, love and regret is complimented by the themes of identity, sacrifice and celebrity vs  reverence. The similarities between  Keaton's and Riggan's careers only add another layer to this already we'll put together and crafted script. Add to that the exploration of the relationship between Hollywood and Broadway, and the prejudices both have for one another and you have a highly entertaining, thought provoking, moving hilarious film. If you a fan of great film making you have to see this movie.

Using a bit of movie magic, the film is made to appear entirely in one continuous shot.  It was quite unsettling since film cuts and fades are usually quite evident, occuring every minute or so. For example, the camera "followed" every character down every hallway which provides a sense of realism and a feeling that you're standing there with them as part of the crew, but also a quick route to motion sickness. The technical achievement in this film is undoubtedly great, but it's not as enjoyable for the viewer. Another example is that without cuts, when two people are talking the camera spends the entire time focused on just one person and you miss the other's reactions. 

Anyway, the story itself is fine, but didn't grip me the way I wanted it to. Keaton and Norton were excellent and backed up by nice work from Stone and the rest.  Perhaps the blame for my dissatisfaction is on its artsy directing style. Let's put it this way, if French New Wave is recognized by jump cuts, this is the furthest on the other side of spectrum.

A good film? Yes! A film I want to watch again? Probably not.

In general, I try to know as little as possible about a film before screening it. If I've done a good job, I won't even know who is starring in the film or anything about its plot. When I screened Birdman or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance) all I knew going in was that it starred Michael Keaton and apparently that the movie had been shot entirely in one take. Seeing Keaton interested me, because other than a fairly meaty role in the RoboCop reboot earlier this year and few supporting roles over the last several years, we haven't see much of him, and definitely not as a leading man. But let's be honest, the real draw to this movie is the manner in which it was filmed; if the filmmaking team really pulled off a complete movie in one take, that is a movie worth seeing. But more on that later.

Now, with my butt firmly in the seat, I was ready for anything. From the opening scene with Keaton, it is obvious that we are in for a unique vision. The elevator pitch of movie goes something like this: washed-up Hollywood action star tries to gain some artistic street cred by moving to New York City and starring in a broadway show that is adapted, produced, and directed by him; along the way, he deals with a myriad of problems ranging from financial to personal to professional. The onscreen development of these issues and how he attempts to address them are the crux of this entertaining and engaging story. However, like most films worth watching, that is not really what this film is about.

Birdman isn't really so much a story to be heard, but a work of art to be experienced. Mexican born director Alejandro González Iñárritu (Babel, 21 Grams, Biutiful) attempts to push the boundaries of convention; metaphorically, as part of the story and literally through the way film was conceived and executed on a practical and technical level, as one "continuous" shot. To be clear, the film was not actually shot in one sitting. The filmmakers employed a number of techniques (including computer generated effects) to create the illusion of a single continuous tracking shot, but for at least the first quarter of the film, I was fooled, and for its entirely, I was hooked. In the vast majority of movies out there, editors cut back and forth often. Sometimes the cuts are integral to the plot or artistry of the work, but just as often they are there to cover flubs in performances, to fix issues that occurred on set, or to cover up the fact that a scene was too long and stretches of dialogue needed to be tighten up. Because of this, I sometimes find myself not paying as close attention as I could be to what I'm watching or, just as often, oddly placed cuts distract me and take me out of the moment. This is not possible with Birdman. The continuous, nonstop nature of the movie makes you afraid to blink or look away, even for a second, for fear of missing out on something crucial. There is no such thing as "b-roll" in this movie - every frame is important and shouldn't be missed.

Iñárritu is not the only director to attempt to make a movie in the continuous style. In 1948, Alfred Hitchcock attempted the same thing with Rope, starring Jimmy Stewart. While Rope is one of the more interesting in Hitchcock's catalogue of films, the uninterrupted filming technique was not nearly as effective then as is here. Rope is a claustrophobic feeling that is more akin to the filming of a stage play than an typical big screen film. Birdman, however, despite taking place on stage and backstage at a Broadway theater, is a film that thrives on the big screen and succeeds in all the ways that Hitchcock didn't or couldn't (due to technological restrictions) when he made Rope.

While the film achieves much from a technical perspective, it would have all been for naught had he not entrusted his script to the talented actors and charged them with bringing the characters to life. There isn't a false note among the cast, which includes in addition to Keaton, Emma Stone, Zach Galifianakis, and Edward Norton, all of whom give career-defining performances. However, the real credit must be given, once again, to Iñárritu. The kind of vision and bravely that it takes to make and succeed at making what must be called an experimental art film is something that we see very rarely from even the most lauded American directors. I honestly hope the film succeeds at the box office this weekend and during awards season next year to encourage more of this kind of bravery, something the industry desperately needs.

A technical marvel, Birdman is a satirical and oddball look at a washed-out actor's attempt at staging a comeback via a Broadway play. 

Auteur Inarritu's ambitious attempts at making a genre-defying film is largely successful, layering the story with many dichotomies.

But Birdman isn't just a showcase for his directing prowess, but also one for the actors and cinematographer. Keaton gives his career best, strongly complemented by the thespian chops of a talented ensemble - Edward Norton, Emma Stone and Naomi Watts. But it's the spectacular cinematography (seamless tracking and dolly shots) that steals the show.

Is this film Oscar bait? Absolutely, should it or does that take anything away from this film? Absolutely not. This is the type of film that one waits for all year and it embodies the true art of film. This is a masterpiece from beginning to end and from the opening scene you are enthralled with this story and not for one second can u take your eyes away from the screen. From its extremely strong plot and its intriguing social narrative about Hollywood and the state of movie making today. Also the way this movie is shot truly is a sight to see and a true achievement in cinema. From about two minutes in to the last 2 minutes of the film it is made to look like it never cuts and it is just one long shot. This was masterfully done by Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu and puts him seriously in contention for an Oscar this year. Above all of this one really keeps this story so entertaining and this film so great is the remarkable performances from all the actors involved. Michael Keaton gives maybe the performance of his career and will likely win him and Oscar. Emma Stone gives a very powerful performance along with Naomi Watts. In my personal opinion though Ed Norton has the strongest performance in this movie and steals every scene he is a part of.  Another surprise performance in this film though is Zach Galifianakis who goes a turn for the dramatic and gives the best performance of his career. The only real complaint I have about this film is that the end left me a little cold and I think that it should have ended a little earlier than it did. Other than that I do not have anything bad to say about this movie it is a great film that I can honestly say is an experience and an experience worth having in the theater at that. 4.5/5

Time is not kind. Time is the one thing we can't seem to make more of and yet the only thing, when it really comes down to it, that we could ever hope to gain. Birdman is about the moments in life when it really comes down to it. When everything in life seems so fleeting, materialistic or fake and we have a second of clarity that defines what is really important to us, what makes this existence worth enduring and even why we want to exist in the first place. Birdman is a character study wrapped in social commentary about the current state of cinema as well as a love letter written in blood to the idea of legacy. There are millions of avenues one could run down when it comes to telling a story about the basic experience of being human and those moments that define who we are, who we become or who we want to be despite our actions. Director Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu (21 Grams, Babel) is interested in the moments that make up a personality and the effect or contribution that personality has on society, but he also wants to make a few other notions clear in the process. The guy hates comic book movies, clearly, or at least hates that they have become the cornerstone of the modern cinematic experience. It is hard to find fault in this opinion with as strong a case as his film makes, but then again this can all be perceived as pretentious and taking things too seriously since most comic book films have no intentions other than being escapism for the masses. As much as Birdman incorporates the world of super heroes and comic book movies into its structure to make a larger point the film is ultimately about the difference in love and admiration and how the quest to feel "special" will likely only leave you empty if you disregard those closest to you for personal gain and have no one to celebrate with when that gain puts you at the top of the mountain. Needless to say, there is a lot going on in Birdman. Both on the screen in front of you and as larger analogies Inarritu's film has a lot on its mind and is primarily so successful because it is so capable of conveying this multitude of thoughts and ideas in an entertaining and insightful manner.

Birdman is a good film that's undeniable. right from the start it feels like a piece of cinema that has been conceived as a whole and done with passion from the whole cast and crew. The Story is told in an interesting narrative way, the camera follows the main character and seems to never rest, always wondering everywhere , sticking to the characters, giving an impression of being part of it, being there and being the witness of this whole farce about life, celebrity, theater and countless other subjects of our actual society. The director has clearly a define vision of what he wants out of his team and get it readily and religiously accomplished. This is a concept film and you will either be transported by the whole piece or left out, but I must confess I have a hard time to see how anyone would dislike such a film... but tastes are different and I could see how some people would feel lost by the camera work for example who gives such a frenzy and erratic pace to the film. I can't praise enough the technician here, the lights, the costumes, the make up and the actors are all superb. A.G. Iñárritu is a terrific director and with this Birdman he confirms all the good we could think of him. One can only hope such director will continue to entertain us with challenging pieces such as this film. Great work, great film and great experience at the movies.

Talk about a comeback movie! Not only does Michael Keaton give one of the best performances of 2014, but also one of the best performances of his entire career. Like the rest of the cast (including a surprisingly straight and sympathetic performance from Zach Galafianakis), Keaton's character combined with the impressive one-shot camera tricks feels so real; bitter and frustrated of feeling invisible despite trying again and again to be remembered more than one role while feeling pitiful and desperate of retaining what once was through achieving art rather than selling his soul to another blockbuster franchise. The film has many great themes of feeling worthless, people either being too caught up with the latest trends rather or being too stigmatizing of the "Birdman" persona to give him a fair chance (thought to be fair while vague labeling and bias is a bad way too critique movies I wouldn't exactly say the majority of movie critics are necessarily "out to get" certain filmmakers), and stress getting the best of your relationships witg loved ones (though I'm not sure if the hypocrisy of Keaton's character continuing to drink his life away and even trying a joint of Emma Stoned (I'm sorry I had to) was intentionally hypocritical, him trying to make a better outcome for her than how he's turned out, or neither). "Birdman" is like the lemon meringue pie of 2014 movies; an intriguingly sour reality frosted with sweet comedic moments on the top. Easily one of the best movies of 2014.

The performance by Edward Norton and Emma Stone are worth seeing just by themselves. The way the director filmed it by making it look like almost one continuous shot takes this film to another level. Don't go in expecting another high action superhero story and it won't disappoint you.
Great acting, great camera work, and great movie!

From the perfect performances of Michael Keaton and Edward Norton, to the sublime direction (utilizing single takes that last upwards of 20 minutes), every element of this film harmonizes magnificently. This is filmmaking at its most audacious.

It is kind of hard to explain what makes Birdman so special. You will either love it or you will hate it, and I think a lot of that has to do with how much you can relate to the lead character who is struggling to find himself. The film is shot so that nearly the entire movie looks like a single take. This could prove divisive, as audiences who are not used to long takes may feel that the film drags, as there are no quick cuts to break up the dialogue. Not only that, but some viewers may find it hard to follow, as you are dropped in the middle of the situation, without much context and a bevy of characters thrown at you. These are all just more reasons to love it though. The director isn't there to hold your hand. The film feels raw and rather profound. It doesn't use cinematic norms to ease audiences into situations and that is for the better. I can highly recommend this film to those who are looking for something different, something that deserves the attention of film critics and audiences alike. Some may not like it, but I was both highly entertained and intellectually stimulated. 4.5 out of 5 stars.
Not perfect, but one cannot deny what an engrossing experience this film is.
Terrific performances, interesting direction, but what the hell was happening in the actual movie?? I have not much of an idea.

There are a plethora of movies that come out each year that you adore, but there are only a few that you admire.  It's rare that a film both audacious and outrageous can hit the mainstream with arty enthusiasm, but "Birdman" has conspicuously done it.  It's a comeback story.  It's a game changer for a bevy of its actors.  It has the daring of "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?" or "A Woman Under the Influence." I may not have loved it with my entirety, but "Birdman" contains those rare juices that can only be found in the vintage days of pioneering filmmaking.
	Riggan Thomson (Michael Keaton) was a huge actor 20 years ago, but these days, he's carrying the weight of a has-been.  Like Keaton, Riggan was the star of a huge superhero franchise, the Birdman series (meta enough for you yet?).  But after turning town another unnecessary sequel, Riggan hasn't found another role that has given him as much notability or respect.
	Now middle-aged and balding, he's decided to reinvent his lagging career by adapting and starring in Raymond Carver's "What We Talk About When We Talk About Love" on the daunting Broadway stage.  But the production is plagued with difficulties.  Riggan's daughter (Emma Stone), who works as his assistant, is fresh from rehab and close to destroying her life once again; one of the actors (Edward Norton), who is extremely Method and without modesty, causes disastrous previews; but worst of all, Riggan is slightly schizophrenic, taunted by the voices of his past.
	There's a theater critic (Lindsay Duncan) in the film who is serpent-like and acidic in her speech; she later describes Riggan's play as having a sort of "hyper-realism".  "Birdman" is filmed as though it were shot in one extreme take, one that fancies close-ups and uncomfortable angles.  It heightens the tragicomic values the film portrays, and that "hyper-realism" becomes a truth.  "Birdman" manages to feel both theatrical and mold-on-the-ceiling authentic.
	Stylistically, it's a very challenging film to embrace with a whole heart.  Its cinematography is so specific and so bold that it sometimes distracts from the dialogue, as we are forced to adjust to a lens we so rarely see in the movies.  Movies hardly ever, if ever, choose to photograph a film with "Birdman"'s take-it-or-leave-it one-shot valor.  If it isn't always successful, it's consistently interesting, and frequently takes the wickedness of the film to entirely new levels.  Its accompanying, brilliant soundtrack, which mostly consists of flashy, jazzy drum beats, matches the whiplashed unpredictably the film flaunts.  
	Iñárritu's direction is unflinching, everlastingly inventive and risk-taking.  If he, along with the cinematography and score, aren't nominated for Oscars, they will surely be robbed.  Certainly, there isn't anything beautiful or lavish about the film (like many of the other potential nominees), but the distinct, harsh landscape is jaggedly excellent. 
	As the film closed and the actors' names flashed across the screen with a Jean-Luc Godard fashion, I couldn't help but feel the tizzy the Academy will be in in a few months.  Keaton has never given a better performance, and no one else this year will either.  Stone smashes the roof off of any preconceived notions about her "type"; so has Galifianakis.  Watts frequently steals scenes and is reminiscent of her powerful characterizations in "Mulholland Dr."  Norton is ruthless yet surprisingly philosophical; Riseborough is a bonfire of energy.  And Ryan, who seems to get crushed under the names of the note-worthy cast, brings a whole new spectrum of light and salvation to Keaton's character.
	Will I see a film this year that deserves as much praise as "Birdman" does? Probably not.  I have yet to see a film so technically terrific or so impactful in its performances.  If only it was a little warmer, a little less stylistically strong.  But it won't matter.  "Birdman" is a blessing in this day in age.

"Birdman is an ambitiously technical achievement by Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu"
Movie Review: Birdman
Date Viewed: November 15 2014
Directed By Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu (Amores perros, Babel and 21 Grams)
Written By Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu, Nicolas Giacobone, Alexander Dinelaris, Jr. and Armando Bo
Starring: Michael Keaton, Zach Galifianakis, 
Edward Norton, Andrea Riseborough, Emma Stone, Naomi Watts, Amy Ryan, Merritt Wever, Lindsay Duncan, Natalie Gold, Jeremy Shamos and Frank Ridley.

The one movie that might win the Best Picture Oscar next February has arrived. "Birdman" is way different from many of the movies I've seen this year. It's a black comedy about a washed-up actor who is trying to make a comeback by writing, directing and starring in a play that is based on a Raymond Carver short story. The main gimmick of "Birdman" is that you get the feeling that you are watching a two-hour film shot in one continuous take. Our main character of "Birdman" is played by Michael Keaton in the performance of his career.

"Birdman" or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance) is about a washed-up actor named Riggan Thomson (Keaton) who used to play an iconic superhero named Birdman in three blockbuster movies. More than 20 years after he left his multi-billion-dollar franchise, Riggan vows to make a comeback by writing, directing and starring in a play. What is it? It's an adaptation of Raymond Carver's short story "What We Talk About When We Talk About Love". The play stars Riggan, a capricious Broadway actor named Mike Shiner (Edward Norton), a first-time actress named Lesley (Naomi Watts) and Riggan's girlfriend, Laura (Andrea Riseborough).

Riggan's daughter, Sam (Emma Stone) serves as his assistant and the play is produced by Riggan's best friend, Jake (Zach Galifianakis) who is also his lawyer. Sam just got out of rehab for drug addiction and she has an emotional confrontation with his father. She tells him that he, like the rest of the world, don't matter. Riggan soon reads the early reviews and they are scathing but it does nothing to stop him from making his play a success. From time to time, Riggan hears a voice in his head, it's the voice of Birdman either mocking him or bolstering his image.

"Birdman" is an ambitiously technical achievement by Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu. He previously made "21 Grams" and "Babel", both movies had interweaving plot lines and characters who were surrounded by the consequences of tragedy. With his new film, he seems to be having fun with his Hollywood satire. Keaton (who previously played Batman in two movies) gives a terrific performance as a failing actor who used to play an iconic superhero. Edward Norton gives his best performance in years as the brilliant but sometimes crazy Shiner and Emma Stone is outstanding as Riggan's daughter. Zach Galifianakis who gets stuck in the middle of this madness gives a strong supporting performance as Riggan's best friend and manager and Naomi Watts is also very good as a first-time actress.

Inarritu has made a challenging high-wire act and the result is one of the best movies of 2014. I see the flood of Oscar nominations already for "Birdman" especially a nomination for Michael Keaton in the role of a lifetime.
Great script.  Great acting.  Great directing.  This is just a fantastic looking film.

Presented with exquisite direction that is as glamorous and colorful as it is gritty and seedy, and showcasing terrific career high points for the cast, most notably the triumphant Michael Keaton, the ambitious bit enlightening Birdman truly soars.

The setting was perfect, had just written one important entrance examination and needed a refreshing cinematic experience in the evening. A dark comedy, what can be better than that? A lot has been said about the movie, it clinched the titles of best feature & best director at Academy Awards as well so I will keep it short. Birdman is the story of falling down in an infinite abyss of darkness. It hurts so much that at one point you just want to put a barrier on your way and crash into it. Keaton's outstanding approach to the main character puts everything else away, he was simply brilliant! Supporting cast including Edward Norton, Zach Galifianakis, Emma Stone, Lindsay Duncan, Andrea Riseborough, Amy Ryan and Naomi Watts were more than good in their respective roles. Cinematography is another point where Birdman excelled, the jerky handheld shots captured the finer nuances of the tumultuousness of main characters with grandeur. An excellent work of cinema, most recommended and worthy of all the awards it had won and more!
Beautifully directed, brilliantly acted, and delightfully weird, yet funny.

O EU - Quem você quer ser?

Birdman o incrível super-herói que já teve seus anos de fama e sucesso encontra-se agora substituído pelos heróis da Marvel; Riggan (Michael Keaton) foi o homem- pássaro, porém seu momento de enorme poder acabou e atualmente ele está falido e luta para sua nova produção, uma inovadora peça de tetro seja seu triunfo novamente. 

O elenco da peça tem sérios problemas e conflitos logo no começo do filme quando acidentalmente ou não eles perdem um ator e assim nas pressas tiveram que encontrar um substituto , Mike (Edward Norton) que acabará causando mais problemas em parte por uma ereção acidental em uma cena com Lesley (Noami Watts); Riggan tem nos seus pensamentos, uma voz que o desafia e questiona, que faz a pergunta do quem sou eu, mas não é só essa voz que atormenta o antigo super-herói, o roteiro do filme é tão brilhante, criativo e esperto que acaba por si só criando varias situações desse questionamento, Alejandro González Iñárritu apresenta seu melhor trabalho como um afiado diretor e roteirista. 

Emma Stone interpreta Sam, a filha de Riggan em uma atuação impressionante, mas quem realmente rouba a cena é Edward Norton com sua terrifica performance e ele, o genial Michael Keaton o único Birdman, que nos presenteia com a melhor interpretação da sua carreira, tecnicamente o filme é impecável a cinematografia não deixa nenhum espaço em branco até os minutos finais do filme, Birdman ou (A Inesperada Virtude da Ignorância) recebeu merecidas nove indicações ao Oscar, por que realmente é um dos melhores filmes de 2014, é Surrealístico, porém real, não estou me contradizendo, quando você começar a perceber que o filme acabou, algumas perguntas surgiram nos seus pensamentos, te inspirará e certamente fará você rir e refletir sobre quem realmente você é!

For more: http://lfecinema.blogspot.com.br/

A terrific technical film that demands several views to truly appreciate it but after it's initial viewing, I praise the acting, the theatre like feel and tone. The commentary on art, broadway, film industries and critical reception. 

Birdman is a quirky film that features terrific, powerful scenes but it's final moments leaves you empty and bewildered yet serves the point perfectly. It demands your full attention and though it's characters aren't that memorable, nor is the story overall, though very layered and self depicting all round.

It didn't live up to the hype for me personally, the filmmaking is fantastic but the overall package lacked the punches where scenes such as Keaton confronting his critics both literally and metaphorically are the films highlights. 

Oscar worthy performances all round, artistically brilliant but far too between with it's most showy sequences that could have been more used frequently, makes it not live up to the hype for me.

Birdman or The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance is a masterful film directed by Alejandro Gonzalez Iñarritu and brilliantly shot by Emmanuel Lubezki. It is simply one of a kind and one that does simple justice to Michael Keaton who perfectly displayed the Riggan character, and had a tremendous supporting cast by his back.

To start off with I will talk about the cinematography which is absolutely amazing. The film as you may already know or know is portrayed as one long cut instead of multiple cuts. This film I believe deserves the best cinematography Oscar over interstellar even though I really enjoyed that film to. Now to talk about next I have to say not only is the film a great ensemble but almost all of the performances are highlights for the year. It can be laugh out loud witty funny and can be depressing the next this film is easily one of the best of the year and quite possibly the best.
Michael Keaton's acting was a very pleasant surprise as well as Emma stone and Edward Norton along side him in the film. So I wouldn't be surprised to see this film winning some best acting nods at the Oscars. The most pleasant surprise is that this is the best comedy I've seen a long while, it's pretty dark at time but is overall a comedy/drama and it seems to me that these two genres were blended perfectly.In conclusion there isn't anything bad I can think of to say about it. So I call this one of the definite must sees of the year. This film could be enjoyed by almost anyone. If you don't like dark comedies then I guess that would ruin your enjoyment but if you at the very least don't mind a dark comedy then you will most likely enjoy it. I hope you enjoy it to the extent I did and end up not wasting your time like I did. That's all and thanks for reading my review.

A movie starring an actor (Michael Keaton) used to play a superhero (Batman) in movies, about an actor who used to play a superhero in movies, who is now trying to bring a play to Broadway.
