This is why movies, like Birdman, are made. Brilliant on many levels!!
This movie just burned a hole into my soul.

HELL YEAH!!! Michael Keaton is back baby! Not that he ever went away, he's just been quieter than his Batman heyday. Keaton is long been one of my favorites, ever since Beetlejuice and I for one, was excited when he was chosen for Batman. Of course, I was 11 and I didn't read comics book yet. In fact, Michael Keaton's Batman was the birth of my now 26 year love affair with printed word accompanied by pretty pictures. Batman is what Michael will always be known for, Birdman is what he will be remembered for. He better win that Oscar(him or Benedict Cumberbatch or Eddie Redmayne, Damn so many good ones this year!) because he is phenomenal as Riggen Thompson, an aging actor known for playing a superhero on the big screen. Yeah, may not seem like a stretch but is there anyone more perfect? How about if we get a guy who was fired from being a superhero after turning in a pretty good performance as one? Edward Norton, famously replaced as the Hulk(of course he was replaced by Mark Ruffalo so no one complained understandably so) still, he probably deserved another shot. The only reason no one is talking about how good Norton is here, is because how fucking good Keaton is! The very first scene between these two, about 15 -20 minutes in, I knew that I was in for something special. I really want them to work together again. Emma Stone, Naomi Watts, Zach Galifianakis  and Amy Ryan all turn in fine supporting performances as well. By far Alejandro G. Inarritu's finest film and definitely my favorite of his. I counted only 2 cuts. Maybe. Either way, the movie is done in pretty much one shot until it's climatic moment and it is fantastic filmmaking from every one involved. Trust me when I say, it takes an army to get what you see onscreen and this one worked very well together. This is up there with my faves of the year, which if you haven't been keeping track are Guardians, Apes, Imitation Game, John Wick, Fury, Theory Of Everything.

One of the most original movies of the past few years, sometimes hilarious with a melancholy undertone. Multiple Oscar worthy performances, most notably Keaton for his not so subtle faux biopic on his own career. Epic writing, no Hollywood cliche is safe.

I don't know why I loved it, but oh how I loved it. The entire cast is superb, and the Who Can Be More Narcissistic competition between Ed Norton and Michael Keaton's characters was so cringingly, Manhattan neurosis-driven on point. Exceptional.

Birdman est un tour de force visuel. J'ai pris un malin plaisir à entrer sur ce terrain de jeu de Inarritu. Le montage présenté comme un unique plan séquence est tout à fait génial et cré une atmosphère intéressante. L'histoire n'avait peut-être pas la profondeur dont je m'attendais, mais au final j'en suis sortie avec la conviction que j'allais le revoir....
Reality and art declare war on each other. A brilliant piece of film-making. Funny, disturbing, technically excellent and the performances are stunning.

BIRDMAN or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance): A surrealist view of realism; this film is the kind of film that actors, filmmakers, and teachers of film will reference in order to present clear, concise  examples of acting techniques, mis en scene, and forms of film. The pans and tilts of the camera and the impeccable editing that flawlessly transitioned scenes did away with conspicuous cuts.  The lighting and positions of the actors allowed multiple plots and stories to be occurring in one shot.  Beautiful editing.
 The film itself is a look into the lives of people who struggle with identity, with truth; confusing who they are with what they are, or what they were.  Reality is ignored and the self is praised.  By doing this, Alejandro González Iñárritu presents the audience with the fallacies that one encounters by rejecting reality.  But, as the title suggests, ignorance my bypass these fallacies. Ignorance might just be a virtue.

Honestly, this is one of those films that you'll either love or hate.  I wouldn't recommend it to a casual movie goer who's looking for a good movie on a night out.  This is a film for those who like to think and analyze film.

Despite unecessary things like a kiss between two women and a relationship between Stone and Norton, Birdman is another incredible film by Iñárritu. Funny, exciting, with an amazing drum sound on the background and scenes filmed on a single shot. You won't see an original and entertainment movie like that so soon! Besides, it's nice to watch Keaton playing basically himself on screen and giving us a superb performance.
Michael Keaton is awesome.Still wish he did Batman 3.
It's like a Fightclub for your fifties.

Alejandro G. And Lubezki are mexican power! the performance specially Michael Keaton is marvelous , he is back !

This film is original and is also on my top 5 of this year... Don't miss !

This is a film that has gotten so much praise this awards season, and is at the top of most people's top ten films of the year lists. I've been waiting so long to see this movie, that most people have probably seen it by now. Writing a review for this won't be easy. It's one of the most bizarre film's I've seen this year, while also one of the best movies I may have seen in my life. I slept on it, and I think I'm ready now. "Birdman" is directed by Alejandro González Iñárritu and stars an impressive cast including: Michael Keaton, Zach Galifianakis, Edward Norton, Emma Stone, Amy Ryan, and Naomi Watts.

Riggan Thomson (Michael Keaton) is a washed up actor who used to be known as a superhero action star named Birdman. Over the years, his career dwindled, and he is now attempting to direct a play on Broadway. His girlfriend Laura (Riseborough) acts in the play as well, and his daughter Sam (Stone) works as his assistant. During rehearsal, a light falls on one of the actors, and Riggan must find a replacement. He brings in Mike (Norton), a very talented, yet very arrogant actor to replace him. Riggan struggles to validate his life and career, all while Birdman continues to taunt him in his mind.

Michael Keaton received a nomination for Best Actor in this film, and he really did deserve it. While not an earth shattering performance, it is the best of his entire career. The cast assembled here is perfect. Edward Norton gives a great performance, and Emma Stone, wow! I'm not a big fan of her, but she really delivers in this. She defiantly has acting chops and I look forward to see what she does next. The performances are all noteworthy and impressive. Secondly, the script is phenomenal! Every bit of dialogue was clever. It did't even feel like dialogue, it was so natural.

This is an art film. Everything about it screams creativity. The cinematography for one is so inventive. Emmanuel Lubezki shot and edited this film in a way that seems like it's one long take. It's literally one long tracking shot. This helps the film feel more natural. It gives it this seamless feel; it's flowing and relentless. It's probably the most original cinematography I've seen in a while. I also love how the movie stands up against the film industry. It slams mindless big action films like Transformers, and challenges audiences to think. It challenges one to think about movies, about life, and about who you are. If you are a moviegoer. a good person, a bad person, or some film critic, no matter who you are, this film gets in your face and tells you the honest truth. It challenges one to own up to who you are and the mistakes you've made.  

"Birdman" is a movie made up of many factors, and it talks about many different things. It's about your career, it's about love, family, friendship, acting, film-making, film critics, and it's about what it means to be a human being. It touches on so many different emotions; sadness, joy, love, and humor. It's a creative art film and is superb on every level of movie making. I can't think of anything I didn't like about this movie. It's a film that everyone can get something out of, and in my opinion, it's a modern masterpiece.
About ego, fear of being forgotten and fighting with lables attaching to human for whole life.  Fantastic Inarritu directory and Lubezki cinematography.

Birdman is an outstanding movie, with a visually stunning, great production, masterfully directed by Iñarritu and of course excellent performances delivered by the ensemble cast including one of the best (if it's not the best) career performances of Michael Keaton.

Riggan Thomson: I got a chance to do something right.  I gotta take it.

Believe the hype, folks.  Mexican director Alejandro GonzÃ¡lez IÃ±Ã¡rritu faultlessly crafts Birdman, a film that appears as one long tracking shot, using clever filmmaking skills to pull off the remarkable style.  Michael Keaton makes an incredible comeback in a momentous performance that deserves all of the praise and awards that it's sure to garner, but it's Edward Norton who steals the show with a paramount performance that perfectly encapsulates what the actor is really like.  This is an ambitious, breathtaking, and technically impressive work of art. 

Read the whole review at creedsdelight.com

The film opens with a shot of Michael Keaton sitting cross legged in a pair of white underpants, hovering about a metre off the floor. And thus begins an awkward relationship between filmmaker and audience, as difficult as each relationship between the characters of the play. For the film is a play, as the full title of the film (Birdman or The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance) requires us to note, and the theatre within the film represents reality. 

The opening moment of supernatural magic sets the scene for a film about a superhero. A quiet moment of solitude where our protagonist reflects on his condition. It's a standard scene in the genre. Here is one superhero who wonders how he got to this place. A place that smells of balls. What is this place? The Earth or this brick walled room? Or a state of mind? And are we talking about the balls barely concealed by his present attire? Or, metaphorically, the condition of mediocrity?

But that opening moment of wonder that the filmmaker has given us is fake. He isn't asking us, after all, to suspend our disbelief, as is required in viewing action adventures. We don't, at first, have any way of knowing this, since the play of the film is focalised on Thomas Riggan. Did the stage light fall because of his superpowers? Why doubt it, they haven't been called into question. Not yet. 

It isn't until after Mike Shiner tells us "popularity is the slutty little cousin of prestige" that the filmmaker reveals that those powers are the illusion of a fragile mind. A fading mind whose life work has been dedicated to creating popular entertainment for the audiences which, in turn, prefer to escape reality through fantasy than confront the painful truths of life. Admit it, IÃ±Ã¡rritu demands, you were childishly drawn in by the magical fiction. And now we are to feel both wonderment and embarrassment at each delightful instance of fantasy. 

IÃ±Ã¡rritu isn't done mocking us yet. The relationship between daughter, underplayed with poise by Emma Stone, and her father stems from his failings, namely, as she tells us, he wasn't around and then tried to make up for it by trying to make her feel special. A line delivered without melodrama that confronts each member of the audience to reassess the true extent of one's parents' shortcomings. 

On the other hand, IÃ±Ã¡rritu helps us a little, signposting the role of the theatre within the film as the description of some sort of reality. As an aside, who doesn't come away wanting to explore the works of Raymond Carver? The description of a man trying and failing to take his life is echoed in Riggan's story delivered to his ex-wife about his own failed suicide attempt. A story that is both bathetic and ridiculous. IÃ±Ã¡rritu chooses black comedy over slapstick, having his protagonist tell the story, rather than film it. Instead he shows a beautiful shot of the beach with the seagulls pecking at the helpless corpses of the washed up jellyfish. This is a modern film noir. 

I wanted to see something positive in this story, an allegory of how unbearable pain helped ironically to avoid total destruction and led to a new beginning. But no. Riggan heads out to take his life again failing spectacularly and ridiculously. And yet to the immediate onlookers, and those connected through the fantastical nature of a world of social media, his failure is misinterpreted as an act of heroism. In today's currency, heroism is measured in the number of views on YouTube or followers on Twitter. 

Affixed on Riggan's mirror is a small card which says: "a thing is a thing, not what is said of that thing". Riggan lambasts the Times critic for the lazy application of commonplace labels. IÃ±Ã¡rritu urges us to work harder, to think harder.

There is one word to describe this and one word only: masterpiece. This is one of the best movies I've ever seen. I loved everything about it.  This is hands down the best movie of 2014 and Inarritu's best. If you don't see it, it's your loss because you'll be missing out on something special.

A wonderful satire on indie vs blockbuster, the theater business, and the entertainment industry as a whole, Birdman is one of the best movies I've seen this year. This is, without a doubt, the greatest performance of Michael Keaton's career. The cinematography is absolutely beautiful, shot in a way where the entire film looks like it's a single shot. I loved this movie.

I can see why this movie won all the awards, I mean it's just amazing and so unorthodox. The acting and the cast were incredible. the "one shot" aspect was distracting the first watch through. second viewing proved more enjoyable watching a "nobody" risk everything to be a "somebody" again.

In one of the year's best films, one of the year's best ensemble casts takes on one of the year's best screenplays under one of the year's most ambitious directorial projects and one of the year's greatest achievements in cinematography. Birdman is a one-of-a-kind cinematic experience that works in so many ways that it's difficult to comprehend how the team pulled it off so well. Filmed in what is meant to look like pretty much one continuous shot, Birdman is an incredible stunt and change-of-pace for director Alejandro González Iñárritu and the insanely talented cinematographer Emmanuel Lubezki, but what makes it even greater is that it is in no way just a stunt, but a full-fledged story with a screenplay that blends sharp dialogue with big ideas, pulled together by great performances.
	No moviegoing experience is quite the same as Birdman. The single shot gives the film a unique feel that makes it difficult to recall when watching a film has felt this way before. Without relying on any editing, it trashes the conventions of how we see dialogue exchanged, the way we see people navigate a room, and the way we see characters interact with others and their environment. To watch this pulled off so well made me question the necessities of conventional editing and wonder why filmmakers so rarely use this technique of long takes to tell a story. So much could potentially go wrong with the actors having none of it to rely on, especially in sequences where humor is crucial to the story. In such scenes it actually works better than it would with cuts because it feels more raw, less timed, less begging of the audience for laughs, and credit is certainly due to the actors for being able to take advantage of the technique. The style even seems to serve a larger purpose. The film is about a play and the style parallels that of an uncut play, loosening the boundaries between what is on stage and what is off stage. Even the magic of this shot adds to the fantastical elements of the film. On top of it all, Emmanuel Lubezki's camerawork is consistently beautiful and fluid in both motion and composition.
	Birdman wouldn't be the success it is were it not build on top of a great screenplay. The dialogue is, line after line, witty, smart, and purposeful. It's funny when it wants to be, dramatic when it needs to be, and always playful, blending all sorts of tones in between. Never are the important pieces like family struggles forgotten. At its core, it is about the blurred lines between our self and our ego, and it constantly establishes and develops this through several motifs such as art, the celebrity, and even social media. It asks us where we exist.
	Michael Keaton leads the cast with a performance that is both subtle and over-the-top. He never forgets why his character is fighting and nails every bit of comedy, insanity, and humanity. Edward Norton is a total standout who brings a lot of laughs to the film in a dimensional role as a dick. Emma Stone shows a lot of versatility, and Zach Galifianakis and Naomi Watts also have performances worth mentioning. As I said earlier, all actors deserve credit for making the uncut camera style work so well.
	Every element of film is at the highest order here, including the unique drum score from Antonio Sanchez, and it all amounts to one of the most original films of the past few years, or ever. And maybe Bridman is not a perfect movie, but that doesn't stop it from being fantastic (AND FLYING/SOARING HIGH GET IT BECAUSE BIRDMAN). What I might not have mentioned is that it's a whole lot of fun, and it's an experience I want to have again/FLY WITH AGAIN BECAUSE BIRDMAN.
Great acting mostly bolstered by a phenomenal supporting cast; great commentary on culture today led by Keaton's psychotic character teetering on the edge of sanity. An original for sure
Birdman is rich, intelligence top acting from Michael Keaton. very good performance. A (2014)
It takes considerable talent and effort to produce a movie of this ilk that won't immediately harken to other films that succeded in the genre. Birdman is such a movie.

a pitch black comedy film only able to be seen to believe or describe, Birdman is the kind of film that should really wake Hollywood up and make Kenton what he should have been called all along, a respectable actor.

Brilliantly inventive. Unlike any film I've ever seen. Any other year this would have been the best film of the year, but now it gets a close second behind Boyhood. The film should win for Best Actor and Best Cinemotography, and earn a nomination for Best Picture and Best Director

One of the smartest, exceptional, and memorable achievements in cinema that should be remembered for a long time.
Well Done.

A movie about the struggle of being a celebrity versus a real true artist. A commanding performance by Michael Keaton, probably his best since "Beetlejuice". But, in my opinion, it was the Ed Norton show. He is really the performance to watch here. Plus the mastery behind the camera of Mr. González and Mr. Lubezki. They were the super heroes in this film.
A lot of style of substance - but worth a watch. Performances are on the whole very good, but the film is ultimately empty, with an annoying soundtrack.

So this is great.

Very cool, unique movie. It totally deserves all the nominations and awards, as it's well directed, written and acted. The continuous shots were great, and the cinematography was excellent. Keaton, Stone and Norton are all great. In it, Riggan is haunted by the fact he played a superhero called Birdman, and wants to prove he's still relevant by directed and starring in a play. He slowly loses his mind, and Inarritu shows this great by making a claustrophobic movie, with a great score of Drums. Total BS how it wasn't nominated for best score.  The following shots made you feel like you were actually Riggan. The ending is great, and the last half of the movie is far better then the start. It picks up and gets better. I have a feeling this movie will go on to be a classic.
Intimate camerawork, complex yet funny characters and an amazing jazz soundtrack drive this beat poet love letter to acting.

The best picture award movie Birdman is a outstanding movie that is a bit of a return to Michael Keaton. The story is amazing, and the cast are amazing, especially Michael Keaton who I'm glad to see with such success from him that hasn't had much of a comeback, until this. The cinematography by Emmanuel Lubezki is stellar to see from his "one shots" and it can be a game to the viewers about where it goes to the next shot. The way he can shot, can be just like a play which is amazing and fitting to where this plot is going. The character are great, and it has great effects when it gets to the dream sequences. It's interesting, and it's really darkly funny. I actually didn't know how it was going to end which is unpredictable, and it still was interesting when it kept going. Birdman is one of the best movies of 2013 that it's really nice that this won a lot of Academy Awards.

"Your in theater, honey. Don't be self-conscious."

Birdman soars in a new direction, bringing Hollywood along with it. 

Inarritu's film is beautifully filmed, technically ambitious, and hands-down perfect. Philosophical and more relevant than we'd like to think, this is a story of a fading celebrity who lost his soul to blockbuster Hollywood and who tries desperately to redeem himself. On-top of this its a look at Michael Keaton's career (who gave a powerful performance). Somewhere hidden in the middle, this story is also about us (viewers) and how we openly appetize on Hollywood fluff. Throw into this mix an ensemble cast and the outstanding performances each one of them give - and you have one of the best films of 2014 (if not the decade).
Great film, with ambitions failure, regreats and demons

BIRDMAN is most thought provoking, surrealist film to have come out of 2014 that I have seen thus far. It has a great visual style, a fantastic cast giving some of their best performances of their careers, stylish cinematography that feels like the audience is experiencing the film's events, and a smart script. The pacing can be a bit problematic, but the rest of BIRDMAN's magical elements more than make up for it.

This is a one-of-a-kind film in many ways. The execution alone is enough to keep attention, and the score is simple yet beautiful. The performances from Keaton and Norton are exactly what one would expect from actors of that caliber. The supporting cast was great as well, but I really, REALLY didn't like Emma Stone in this movie. Normally she is a solid actress, but her whiny, boring character felt one-dimensional. Overall, this is a movie everybody needs to see as long as you have the right mindset going in.
Great Story, Superior Acting, and Excellent Camera Work "Birdman" is easily the best film of the year. Keaton will defiantly deserves the Oscar

Wow just wow. Possibly could be the best film of the year. Absolutely flawless. Amazing direction, acting and musical score. Keaton, Stone, Norton, and Galifinakis give award worthy performances. Welcome back, Michael Keaton.

There has never been a comparable movie to this one. Completely unique. Brilliant acting, cinematography (watch the long,continuos shots), and direction. Surreal at times so I don't see this having broad appeal but I loved it. It has so many things I love: theater, movie business, celebrities, humor, drama, indie, and superheroes! Simply amazing!

Art imitates life, but life can be jealous of the art it created.  Life says "fuck you" and traps you in the bird's nest, maimed and unable to fly, that is, until you test your wings.

The film is very ambitious, and the director casts a spell of "magic realism" (okay so I copied and pasted this term from another review but it sounded good) that essentially takes the best aspects from both film and theater.  It becomes hypnotizing to the point where it feels as if The Wrestler and Black Swan had an out-of-wedlock baby.  Although the theme has been explored before, I really enjoyed how the introspection and emotion were played out, perfectly portrayed by the cast.  On one layer, you start examining the egoism of human nature in general and how Michael Keaton, one of the most versatile actors decades ago, must have felt when he declined in relevancy.  Another layer back, you start questioning the futility of self-importance altogether. 

Do yourself a favor and experience the spectacle.  Jump, fly, whatever.  Just be sure to paint yourself a nest to land on.

"Birdman" has a whole crew of geniuses, Alejandro G. IÃ±arritu behind the cameras alongside Emmanuel Lubezki who is one of the best cinematographer working today, Crise and Mirrione in the editing room (who have previously worked with IÃ±arritu in Babel), newcomer Antonio Sanchez in the music and Michael Keaton and Edward Norton beating the shit out of each other physically and mentally. "Birdman" mocks modern cinema (and theatre) with smart, entertaining, black humor and sets interesting questions about love and insanity

A treat for everyone that enjoys cinema!!! 
"Birdman" is a brilliant satire, mind blowing experience that is filled with grand performances, Hitchcock-esque camera movements and a brilliant way of storytelling.
Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu has completely reinvented himself and the kind of stories he usually tells, in turn giving us a trip into the creation of an artist and the struggle with exposing such creation to the world, trip that venerates cinema's artistic merits while simultaneously condemning it's contamination through commercialisation.
Every aspect of the film is masterfully crafted and executed. Emmanuel Lubezki's cinematography only exemplifies this.The brilliant choice of always having the camera rolling lets the viewer see what happens before and after any given event.
Inarritu made the choice to give "Birdman" an alternate title.That title is: "The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance." I think that fits perfectly.

An incredible philosophical journey from start to finish, Birdman excels in everything it sets out todo. Featuring stunning performances from Michael Keaton, Edward Norton and my favorite performance from Emma Stone. Birdman takes a long hard look at what modern day Hollywood has become and how far we've fallen in this style over substance day and age. Even going as far as the main character's alter ego stating that people now a days prefer grand explosions and flare over talking. Not many will enjoy this film as it can get very meta and philosophical, those who will enjoy it will absolutely love it. The film is also shot as if it is all one long shot which is a rare and very appealing thing to see. I'd recommend this film to everyone though not all will like it, Birdman is that one film that comes along and shakes the base. I hope more films will take note of this triumph and follow suit.

I have already watched this movie five times. It's cast is amazing, it's story makes you think and come up with your own solution. And the way it's made is something I've never seen before. Just to note when watching, I think it's important to Notice when the first cut in this film takes place.
A lot of good cinematography,performances,directing,and writing that will keep you intrigued.
Acting master class across the board. I expect this to be the 2014 film we look back on in 20 years and still say, holy shit - wtf. I lived to see this.

This is a good movie, not a brilliant one as many have made it seemed. The cast is good but the great performances came from Zach Galifinakis and Naomi Watts but they needed a little more to do to really grab attention for the awards buzz. The buzz is mostly going for Keaton who gave a good performance but by no means an award worthy one, Norton who does a great job and out of the three getting attention is the most deserving, and Stone who I love always but she didn't do anything new to warrant any awards attention really. The more important thing to talk about this movie is the tec aspects like the directing, cinematography, and editing that makes this movie seem like it is shot all in one take but it really isn't. Though at times the camera work got in the way of seeing another character's reaction because you could not cut away or it would ruin the whole stunt, it works for the most part and makes you forget about it after a while. The music is very good especially the flying scene. Some of the more fantasy moments worked at time and others especially towards the end just got crazy for me. The ending starts to get repetitive and I thought this movie lasted a lifetime long but it is only 2 hours so that amazed me. Merritt Wever also has a great little part as the stage manager and Amy Ryan adds some nice moments as Keaton's ex wife. My biggest issue was the writing of the critic character because her purpose was a plot device to bring down Keaton's spirits and in the real world that critic would be fired. Should I be judging logic on this movie? Not really since Keaton channels his Birdman powers throughout but that just really threw me off. But I will say Lindsey Duncan that played the critic did a good job for what she had to work with. It is funny especially Norton's character but I wouldn't say it is the funniest movie of the year. There was an odd sub plot between Norton and Stone that just lost focus for me and just seemed like it happened to piss off Keaton's character but they were nice and sweet moments in a really eccentric movie so I can't really complain too much about them. Overall, I enjoyed the creativity of the movie, the look into the theater world, and the tec work, I liked this but it didn't blow me out of this world.

Insanely well done movie. The entire cast was great. The insanity that Keaton's character plays is unreal. Loved the flow of scene changes and the drum playing to accompany the story was solid. Def a Top 5 movie for me. Not sure if it is the best of the year, but it's way up there.

Rarely does a film come along that  demands a second viewing. Birdman balances the micro and macro of human relationships, ambition, failure, our own bloated egos and the film/theatre industry itself - and it's wonderful.

As a massive fan of Alejandro González Iñárritu's work, my levels of expectation going in were high. They were met! Always so brilliant at analysing character, Inarritu begins our journey with Riggan (An Best Lead Actor Oscar lock for what is a career high performance) the way he means to go on; with a man battling with his inflated ego and self importance in surreal splendor. It doesn't ever let up.

The way almost the entire film is stitched together as one continuous shot helps bridge that gap between theatre and film, and it's visually stunning and impressive. Through this roller-coaster Riggan has to deal with various issues concerning the opening of his play - his last chance to do something with "meaning" - all the while dealing with the almost farcical moral crises of those around him. It's hilarious, engrossing and at times very profound. 

The cast is uniformly brilliant. Keaton will certainly be short-listen come Academy Award season, but don't be surprised if Ed Norton sneaks in there too. He hasn't been this good since Down in the Valley. Everyone gets their chance to shine as we glimpse fleeting moments of utter despair, elation or frustration grasp their characters.

It's a film with great scope and depth.The layered story is captivating, delivered in virtuoso fashion by a master director. Don't be surprised if this is 2015's Best Picture and/or Best Director winner. I haven't been so satisfied by such a beautiful or unique movie in years. It's something of a masterpiece and easily in my top five favourite films of all time.

*Review Pending*

Although it may not be the fully transcendent masterpiece some have made it out to be, BIRDMAN is still clearly one of the best films of 2014, packed full of great performances, sharp, biting writing, and several bravura moments.  On a technical level, the movie is spectacular, with camerawork that is often unbelievably good; there's just something incredibly compelling about extended takes, and the seamless nature of the editing allow the scenes to flow together beautifully and - often - without detectable cuts.  The filmmaking itself would be enough to make BIRDMAN a must-see, but there's even more to it than that.  It's a movie that's equal parts satire, farce, and treatise on fame (or past fame) and the "craft" of acting; the screenplay mines these aspects for all they're worth, but the movie never feels pretentious or weighed down by its thematic concerns.  To put it a different way, it's a film with serious things on its mind that doesn't take itself (too) seriously; there's a lightness of touch on display.  The movie's also interesting in the way it presents its (very heightened) look at the pressures of mounting a big time, serious Broadway play.  Michael Keaton is - justifiably - the man of the hour, here, and it's a remarkable performance, one where he metaphorically leaves it all on the field.  It feels like a hungry performance, and I mean that in the best way possible; it's some of the best work he's ever done.  He's surrounded by a fantastic ensemble (all the cast members seem to be having a ton of fun, perhaps energized by the long takes), particularly Edward Norton - in a delightful skewering of the cliched persona of the "Broadway actor" - and Emma Stone, who is perhaps the strongest she's ever been, displaying outward cynicism and fire, but also a slightly more soulful inner life which is eventually coaxed to the surface.  The more ambiguous nature of some of the goings-on might not work for some people, but overall I found BIRDMAN to be as finely-crafted a work of cinema as I saw in all of 2014.  This is an outstanding movie.

Birdman is a fascinating movie. Even if you don't understand everything about it (like the ending for example), you can still call the movie a masterpiece. I know that because I am one of those people. I'm not going to talk about the ending because I don't fully understand it. To figure that out would require a second watch, and that is not currently possible for me right now. Anyways, nearly everything about this movie is flawless. It's edited to look as if it was done in one shot and that freaking blew my mind. I honestly could not tell where the cuts were. It looked as if the camera never stopped rolling. That in itself is an achievement on its own, but Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu takes it another step. There is actually a point to filming this movie like this. The film is about Michael Keaton's character making a play, so it makes sense to make the movie look and feel like a play. Major props that for that call. The direction is incredible of course. This man managed to make a movie look like one shot. It that isn't freaking awesome, then I don't know what is. Everyone in this movie gives a magnificent performance. Everyone from Michael Keaton, to Emma Stone, to Zach Galifianakis of all people, give Oscar worthy performances. Even the special effects are really well done. There isn't many of them, but the ones that were present were handled with exceptional care and looked very realistic. On top of all that, the film has a script that is both funny and intelligent. It has a lot to say about the state of Hollywood, big blockbuster films, and critics. It's nice to see there was a point to this movie. Last thing is the drum score. Now granted I'm not entirely sure what the point of it was (I have a theory, but I don't feel like talking about it), but it sounded so cool that I had to mention it. Whoever played those drums kicks serious ass. I've named all the positives and I actually have no issues with this film. I cannot recommend this movie more. See it in the theater if you can.
This is one of the most original films I have ever seen!

A wacky, pretentious, beautiful mess of a movie. It's pretty much perfect for the first two-thirds, and kind of amazing in how well it juggles its complex main character with a fully fleshed-out ensemble cast. The uncertainty of the third act is where it threw me off, but it's slowly starting to make sense to me.

Michael Keaton gives his career performance as a former comic book actor tormented by the role that became more famous than he did.  A technical, dialogue driven achievement in indie filmmaking as Inarratu's direction is a consistent following shot with no cuts.  The highlight is undoubtedly Keaton's multi layered performance as Riggin Thomson, a man trying to be admired for something more than a pop culture cesspool by producing, starring, and directing his own broadway play.  A strong ensemble cast adds to Birdman's strength including Ed Norton pretty much playing his own off screen persona and Emma Stone playing Riggin's recovering addict daughter.  Perhaps the most underappreciated performance of the film goes to the wily lawyer Zach Galifinakis bringing forth a performance unexpected from the Hangover star showcasing a different type of humor.  Loaded with dark comedy, amazing dialogue, and innovative direction, Birdman soars with personal interpretation as the third act could be interpreted as either a happy or sad ending depending on one's personal understanding.  Personally, I believe it is a happy ending, but I won't give anything more away.  Fingers crossed for Keaton at the Oscars.  Truly the most honest performance of the year from an actor who undoubtedly relates to being defined by one performance despite a hearty resume of more versatile roles.

Stylistically and performance wise, Birdman is spectacular. It' is meticulously crafted and its characters are honest and real. Where it lacks is in its perhaps purposefully chaotic nature, where it plays out as simply a series of events that seem to mean very little; yet perhaps that is the point. The life of an artist brings loads of criticism and loads of praise, but the praise received is frivolous and vain.
Just try to find the cuts. I dare you.

Long gone are the days of Michael Keaton's Batman stardom.  Hollywood has dramatically changed since then, and Keaton has found himself in a totally different position, replaced by new superstars to take up the superhero and blockbuster roles.  Those days of fame and flowing paychecks have waned for not only the actor but the man who he intimately portrays in this black comedy, Riggan Thomson.  Twenty years since starring in the Birdman franchise (ha, get it?), he has diminished into obscurity-hardly drawing in crowds for barely-constructed Broadway productions.  That inherent feeling of self-importance is killing Riggan, the artist, inside with how far he has faded from the public eye. 

 If there's one thing Birdman's narrative is particularly exceptional at, it's the honest and cynical look at the sheer egoism and narcissism that make up artists/actors.  You always need to feel like you're the highlight of the show-the one that gets the headlines and fan girls.  But when the startling truth of your irrelevance becomes realized, an ego hurt is like a soul penetrated with a keen knife.  Riggan is struggling to finally make that comeback and eventually leave the world with a true legacy.  He desperately wants people to admire him and to remember him as the legend his alter ego-the deep-voiced, snarky Birdman himself-and he think he is.  There's no question that this is one of those films that rely more on its performances than its plot/narrative.  

Consequently, this is where mixed feelings materialize, but Alejandro Iñárritu's latest ambitious picture still boasts an incredible ensemble nonetheless that ranges from the greats like Naomi Watts and Edward Norton to newcomers who're still on the path to prove themselves like Zach Galifianakis and Emma Stone.  Norton seemingly plays a role that also mocks his career and well-known personality.  Whereas Keaton is yearning for admiration and respect here, Norton doesn't give two hoots about audience reception as he focuses more on his utter artistry and method acting ability, despite letting his bossiness and arrogance dominate the backstage production.  Stone plays Riggin's daughter, Sam, who's a recovering drug addict but also frankly exasperated by her father's self-centered tendencies, constantly hanging around the theater with snide remarks.

Birdman is a magnificent cinematic masterpiece! One of the greatest movies I have seen this year! This movie will make you laugh and shocked! Director Alejandro G. Inarritu (21 Grams, Amores Perros, Biutiful, Babel) has made the greatest movie of his whole career. Birdman isn't just hilarious, it also gives actors Michael Keaton, Edward Norton, and Emma Stone the greatest performances of their whole careers.

Michael Keaton (Beetlejuice, Batman) makes an epic comeback performance as he stars as Riggan Thomson, a washed-up actor who used to play a iconic superhero named Birdman, that is now working on a broadway play of an old story called "What We Talk About When We Talk About Love" with the help of his friend Jake, (the funny Zach Galifinakis, The Hangover, Puss In Boots), Riggan is working on this play with a few other broadway actors, Lesley (the beautiful Naomi Watts, King Kong, The Impossible) and Mike Shiner ( the talented Edward Norton, Fight Club, The Incredible Hulk). He also has his daughter Sam, (the brilliant Emma Stone, The Amazing Spider-Man, The Croods) helping with his career. As Riggan works on the play, his voice of his superhero character is inside his head saying his career is ruined and states that he should make a huge comeback. Now Riggan has to battle his own ego to get his family, career, and himself back to the way it all used to be. 

Everything in this movie will blow you away! The cinematography by Emmanuel Lubezki, who won an oscar for his work in Gravity, makes the camera moving so much better in Birdman. The movie is like a broadway play, it's non-stop. The camera makes it like one long movie take. Alejandro G. Inarritu writes this wonderful script with co-writers NicolÃÂ¡s Giacobone, Alexander Dinelaris, Jr., Armando Bo. All four writers have created a memorable script that will be loved by everyone. 

The cast is also marvelous. Keaton is perfection, Norton is awesome, Stone is great, Galifinakis is funny, and Watts is amazing. Other co-stars such as Amy Ryan as Riggan's ex-wife, and Andrea Roughbourgh as one of Riggan's co-stars in the play are also brilliant. 

Birdman or (The Unexpected Virtue Of Ignorance) is a movie you shall never forget! Michael Keaton delivers the greatest performance of his whole career and should get an Oscar nomination for this performance! Edward Norton is perfect as Mike! Emma Stone gives a performance that is worth watching! This movie has a great cast, great cinematography, great screenplay, great acting, great directing, which makes this a great movie! Birdman is a must-see!

There have been films that have made me laugh, cry, feel good, feel bad, or just get angrier then I have ever gotten before. However, every once in a while, there is a film that is more of an "experience" than just a film. Its surreal nature prohibits you from taking your eyes off of the screen because the visuals are so astounding and the story is so intriguing. The film Birdman or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance) has that quality and has become my second favorite film (after Pulp Fiction). In my life, I have never seen a film done so masterfully and with such interesting characters.
 In addition to the characters, the breathtaking cinematography and editing style were seamless. It was difficult to tell how they accomplished certain effects. Even though physically impossible, the film seemed to be filmed in one single shot. There are moments you know they had cut to the next shot, but it is cheated so well that if you weren't paying attention to that aspect of the film, you wouldn't even notice. In the story, there were subtleties that hinted at inside jokes. There is a dig at big budget blockbuster action films, alluding that they are superficial and take attention away from smaller, more ambitious independent films. Also, the obvious parallel that Michael Keaton who played Batman, Edward Norton who played The Incredible Hulk, and Emma Stone who played Spider-Man's girlfriend played their roles in a way that could mirror their own personalities. It is an interesting coincidence that the timeline of the main character's film career matched perfectly with the career of Michael Keaton's Batman films and Edward Norton has a reputation of doing things that his character did while on the sets of certain films. There was so much effort and detail put into each moment of this film so I am surprised it is only in limited release at the moment. Birdman is a modern masterpiece and will be hailed as a classic in the future. If you want a truly unique and amazing film experience, go and see this immediately.

Birdman received critical acclaim and I agree with every positive review ever for this movie. It was named one of the best films of 2014 by organizations including the AFI and the National Board of Review. It was nominated for seven Golden Globe Awards at the 72nd ceremony, including Best Motion Picture - Musical or Comedy, Best Director, Best Score and won for Best Screenplay. Birdman, just as Boyhood (2014), is one of those movies where the audience - depending on their circumstance - simply might not understand why either is lauded as being great, and while it is acceptable, said reason is not one that detracts from the overall filmmaking process that went into both movies, particularly Alejandro González Iñárritu's Birdman. As Birdman says, "Look at these people. Look at their eyes; they're all sparkling. They love this shit. They love blood. They love action. Not this talking, depressing, philosophical bullshit." And Birdman is nothing but a stream of steaming philosophical bullshit made for those that enjoy nothing but to pick at a layered art piece such as this like they would do with a scab.

An exploration of the connection between artists and their ego, Birdman serves as a battleground of themes and ideas from Riggan Thomson's midlife crisis as an actor, whilst striking many facets of performance arts such as the correlation and dichotomy between critics and actors, theatre and cinema, along with the old world attempting to find relevance in a new world. Relevance, in itself, is one of the key underlying and constantly recurring themes throughout Iñárritu's Birdman that is exemplified from the verbal to physical sparring between the characters with existential undertones. Transcending the plane of existence within its weighty script, Riggan and those around him are shown to be struggling to remain relevant in a changing world that has moved past disenfranchised Broadway performances and into billion dollar movie franchises

As a washed out actor who was also the first to don the cape and cowl of Batman in a live-action movie, Keaton's role in Birdman is one of a meta-nature - just as the very meta-premise -, as he plays the near-identical role of Riggan to his strengths and finally finds relevance after a slate of roles which had side-lined the actor's inherent, immense talent. And it doesn't just stop at just Keaton; Norton shines in his portrayal as a hyper-exaggerated version of himself as Mike Shiner, an actor that is too method for his own good and a general pain in the ass for everyone that works with him, as Watts herself finally puts up a decent performance as small as her role is as Riggan's co-star, Lesley. On the younger spectrum of Birdman's talent is the big-eyed Emma Stone, who too, plays a slightly meta-version of herself to adequate perfection as Riggan's daughter, Sam.

While Antonio Sánchez' eclectic use of drums in Birdman's score has shown to be just as divisive as the movie's central narrative - some have gone so far as to calling the near-constant stream of drumming as pompous -, what can't be denied anything but tangible recognition is the surreal direction that Iñárritu takes with his actors and the script, which were further elevated through yet another career high display of aptitude by cinematographer Emmanuel Lubezki.

Known for his notorious skill involving long takes - such as what was seen in Children of Men (2006) -, Lubezki's cinematographical prowess is taken to the absolute extreme, as the latter, Iñárritu and the director's go-to editors - Douglas Crise and Stephen Mirrione - turn Birdman into a beautifully shot and edited movie that comes under the guise as one long continuous take from the baffling opening shot of Riggan floating in mid-air to the equally, yet intentionally baffling ending. Birdman's illusion as one continuous long take from start to finish is less of a gimmick, and more of an extension of the movie's many strengths that effectively pushes the envelope with filmmaking.

''I love it when a plan comes together!''
So do I, Hannibal, so do I, because when it does, it's glorious. And Birdman is truly glorious.

A marvel from both a technical and narrative standpoint, Birdman makes for a proud achievement for writer/director Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu and cinematographer Emmanuel Lubezki, as well as an acting showcase for Michael Keaton and Edward Norton among others.

BIRDMAN is directed by Alejandro Gonzalez Inarrittu and stars Michael Keaton as a former movie superhero who takes it upon himself to direct, write and star in a Broadway play. Joining him are Zack Galifianakis, Naomi Watts, Emma Stone, and Edward Norton who play his agent, fellow cast members, and daughter. My initial thoughts when starting it weren't too great, but I gradually came to appreciate it a little more for its technical achievement and some interesting observations on the lives of actors. Still, in a film about the ego of actors and the importance of artistic expression (among other things), it came off as egotistical and self-important. Without giving away specifics or plot spoilers, I can say that the film is very "meta." Michael Keaton is playing a character who has some similarities, or shares some DNA, with his real-life persona, as does Edward Norton (apparently). Michael Keaton's Riggan Thompson is a former blockbuster movie star who is trying to do something artistic for personal validation, and Edward Norton's Mike Shiner is a method actor who probably takes his job a little too seriously. For me, those two characters (and their interactions) form the central dialogue and message the film is trying to get across. They also had the most interesting dynamic in the story. What I didn't necessarily warm up to was the rather cynical attitude it had towards critics and big-budget filmmaking. And some of the magical realism came off as labored attempts to be clever. Elements that did work a little more include Emmanuel Lubezki's cinematography, giving the film a Malickian feel, and the drum score. Overall, I would say that I appreciated the film for what it is more than actually liking or enjoying it. It has an impeccable technical construction, but a lot of the dialogue and overt messaging felt more like therapy for actors and didn't engage me like a straightforward drama normally would. Even though this is Inarrittu's most playful film yet, it made me long for the emotional manipulation of something like 21 GRAMS. There is a time and place for different kinds of movies, and the way the film takes sides when they both feed into each other was rather disingenuous. I can understand why this film did so well at the Oscars, because Hollywood always likes patting themselves on the back, but it has mixed results as entertainment.

I hate using this word, but Birdman may best be described as "meta." An ironic or maybe just fitting plot for former Batman, Michael Keaton, to take on. Off kilter. Entrancing. Michael Keaton and Edward Norton are at the top of their game. Emma Stone continues to prove why she is an "it" girl in Hollywood right now. We haven't seen half of what she is capable of yet.

This is a film practically made for directors and actors in equal measure. From the dauntingly ambitious task of editing a film to give it the appearance of being a single Steadicam shot to the general cinematic ambiguity, this is clearly a film for creative minds. However, the overwhelming volume of brilliant performances from this top notch cast makes this a must-see for actors.

There's nothing I could say that someone more eloquent than myself hasn't already said so I'll leave it at this: This is a brilliant masterpiece about the line between character and actor, and the masks we wear to hide our true selves from the world. Some of Inarritu's best, even if it does feel more like a Malick picture than an A.G.I. film.

The Golden Globes nominated this film for Best Original Score. I'm surprised that the Oscars did not. The score, consisting exclusively of percussion sounds, fits so well with the fantasy existential satiric film. I work in a theater, so I loved that perhaps 90% of the film takes place onstage and backstage of a Broadway theatre. Things are a bit exagerated, but the actors and crew are pretty true to form. The movie is extremely meta! It borrows its editing style from Hitchcock's Rope. The subtitle"The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance" is the review by the critic who hates Riggan (Keaton). Michael Keaton's previous role as Batman lends an interesting layer to his portraying this character. Art imitates art with all the discussion of the short story adaptation of "What We Talk about When We Talk about Love." The cinematography and way the actors must be in the moment for longer scenes as if they are really performing in theatre is mindbendingly awesome. The whole cast is fantastic. My mind is blown by some trivia I just read on IMDb about how this story parallels Macbeth. This movie will require at least a second viewing.

Birdman has been a very interesting project ever since its inception. Alejandro González Iñárritu is a director best known for grim, joyless and depressing human dramas (Amores Perros, 21 Grams, Biutiful and the incredibly pretentious Babel), so the idea of him directing a surrealistic black comedy about a washed-up actor, best known for playing a superhero a few decades ago, orchestrating a Broadway play to regain his former glory sounded very refreshing. The film also stars Michael Keaton in his first lead role in years, but the most unexpected thing about it is that it's edited to look like a single long take. The end result is nearly worth all the hype. Though the initial premise could result to a clichéd bore, Birdman is a multi-layered, darkly funny and sometimes completely fantastical film that also has satirical ambitions towards themes like celebrity culture, egotism, social media and even superhero movies. Keaton's character, Riggan Thomson, is a very typical Hollywood has-been: no one remembers him for playing anything else than the film's title hero, he desperately wants to prove to be capable of doing something more, and constantly fights with his ego. The role of Birdman even haunts him inside his head, tempting him to take the easy way and just sell out. Most of the film is kind of seen through Riggan's warped perspective; every character from Edward Norton's arrogant but popular method actor to Emma Stone's formerly drug-addicted daughter to Lindsay Duncan's snarky theatre critic is more of a nightmarish product of Riggan's imagination than a real-life figure. Keaton delivers an electrifying performance, and his comeback is the most unforgettable since that of Mickey Rourke's in The Wrestler; Norton is clearly having fun in his outrageous role and does it brilliantly; Stone has never been more intense, and Zach Galifianakis (in a surprising dramatic role), Naomi Watts, Andrea Riseborough and Duncan are no less than fantastic. Emmanuel Lubezki's cinematography, seamlessly edited by Douglas Crise and Stephen Mirrone, is surely going to win him his second consecutive Oscar (previously for Gravity), and Antonio Sánchez's drumming on the background creates an effectively offbeat experience. But Birdman has a similar problem with Biutiful; there are too many underdeveloped elements (like the various romantic relationships and Norton's character) which the film forgets during its third act, when it starts focusing on Riggan alone. It may take a second viewing to fully digest everything contained within it, but for now Birdman is a thoroughly entertaining romp and possibly Iñárritu's finest work to date.

Movies don't get much better than this. A flawless work of art, Birdman showcases incredible camera movement, amazing directing, and wonderful performances especially from Keaton and Norton. The film is hilarious and highly emotional, relavent, and has a deep, surreal, layered story that begs for multiple veiwings, and I can say without a doubt this is one of the best movies ever made. Inarritu really knocked it out of the park.
Was it supposed to be a comedy ?

Finding flaws in 'Birdman' is as easy as digging for the truth in this world. The film speaks to the audience in such a sincere way through the impeccable performance of Keaton and its moving dialogue. A comedy has never been this serious and thoughtful, Inarritu's latest film is among the greatest works of art in the last couple of years.

This is true filmmaking. 
This is true storytelling. 
This....is...true.....art.

One shot, there was one single shot at the end of the film that dropped this movie from great to pretty good. However, there is one consistently great thing about this film: the cast. Birdman takes a while to find its direction and about the midway point it really grabbed me. Unfortunately, there were one or two endings that I would have been really satisfied with but they are followed by more less satisfying endings. Both the score and camera are hit and miss, though the camera work is more often effective than the score. Ultimately, though it hits on some great points, this film is too indecisive with its purpose.

Perfection. Birdman is pure perfection. This has got to be one of the best movies i've ever seen. The performances are explosive, the writing is superb, the direction and cinematography are impeccable, its just a perfect movie.
Birdman's dazzling cinematography, brilliant ensemble cast, and deftly, subtly presented themes make it pure movie magic, and Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu's most impressive work to date
Odd, unsettling, hilarious and trippy. Some of the best work I've seen out of a lot of these actors. And anyone who's worked in the theater will find this extra brilliant.
Fantastic movie, Michael Keaton best movie!
A fantastical cinematic achievement. It's insight is deep as the ocean, the performances are mesmerizing, and the direction is impeccable, but the most impressive part was it's incredible passion.

Well, that was interesting. Even if it doesn't work, Birdman is consistently interesting even if it isn't a masterpiece like some are saying. It's terrifically acted, very confident, very well acted, pretty funny, pretty interesting, and a little messy. Michael Keaton does, however, live up to his own hype for his performance and it's refreshing to see Emma Stone utilize her more sarcastic and realistic persona here; she's really great. I appreciate and enjoy Edward Norton's self-deprecating attitude as his obnoxious character fits in with the film's meta humor. I do feel like they could have done more with their meta tone since there seem to be a few missed opportunities regarding possible jabs at show business. The movie itself is kind of messy, but never distractingly so. GonzÃ¡lez IÃ±Ã¡rritu's direction maintains a lightness about it, and it kind of reminds me of Wes Anderson lite or something specifically in terms of awkward and physical humor. I wouldn't call this one of the best of the year, but it's still really solid regardless. 8.3/10, one thumb up, really good, definitely above average, etc.

Unique, funny, moving, painful, beautiful, and captivating. This movie is like nothing I have seen before in its delivery and wonderfully acted. Buy your ticket, take your seat, and prepare for one wild and memorable ride.
Really enjoyed the general oddness of it all
An interesting film to say the least, that I feel would've hit harder (and arguably more cynically) had it ended 5 minutes earlier, but I suppose its ending leaves it up to interpretation anyways.

Definitely not a movie for everyone, but oh boy i loved it. The single take is so encompassing and well done. The acting is phenomenal across the board. The themes are a bit confusing and can be distracting at times, but this truly surprised and wowed me.
I had very high expectations for this movie and it surpassed them. I watched it twice today and it was even better on the second viewing. Definitely one of the best films I've ever seen.
Brilliant. Enough said.

"Birdman" lives up to the hype. Darkly humorous, perfectly acted and well written. Michael Keaton was born for this role, Edward Norton is spot on as usual, Emma Stone is just adorable, and Zach Galifianakis is stretching his acting wings. Although I didn't get to see this one during in theatrical run I can easily say its my favorite movie of 2014.

Brilliant both technically and dramatically, Iñarritu's first comedy is a trip through the guts of entertainment industry. Refreshing, moving, inspiring, melancholic and fun, moved by a magnificent cinematography and wonderful acting, this film mixes all its different colors into one beautiful story.

Delirante y por momentos surrealista, Alejandro G. Iñárritu consigue una entretenida, experimental y humorística fábula sobre la fama, la celebridad y la creación artística. Además, saca la mejor actuación en la carrera de Michael Keaton a la fecha.

Esto es una comedia, no hay duda, pero negra, tan negra como la noche más oscura. Iñárritu sabe contar sus historias, por más inverosímiles que sean, sabe lo que hace. Punto. Esto es porno para los cinéfilos.
Really good. Very artsy.
Birdman is exquisitely directed, but despite its best efforts to seem profound, it's mostly just boring.
Very well made film, but I personally found it kind of boring.
While it may have too many metaphors to tackle, Birdman is still incredibly ambitious, beautifully shot, amazingly acted, and is simply a film student's wet dream.

A cinematic triumph in every facet of filmmaking!!!  The extra-long wait for this film to make it Down Under has paid off in spades for me.  This is one of those dazzling "insider's" film that's certainly not for everyone -- I loved every second of it!  The single-shot "gimmick" has been done before -- probably, most notably in "Russian Ark" -- however, the illusion of Lubezki's single-shot cinematography is a thing of wonder.  The directorial control of each scene is awesome!  To paraphrase a bit of hyperbolic prose from film critic Rex Reed -- who, by the way, HATED this film! -- if Innaritu doesn't win the director's Oscar, "there is no God"...!  By far and away this is the best ensemble cast of the year.  WOW, everyone deserves some kind of award!!!  There will be no justice if "Birdman's" nest isn't full of golden eggs at the end of Oscar's season....  Truly, the most astoundingly wondrous triumph of the year...!  SEE IT, if you give a damn about films that matter...!  :D
It starts and ends in mid-air.
Thought provoking, mostly. Some funny bits, some poignant bits, but overall, nicely thought provoking.
Technically outstanding, emotionally gripping, and complemented by an ensemble cast in state of grace, Birdman fulfills all the expectations this ambitous Iñarritu film had.

Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu, Emmanuelle Lubezki, Michael Keaton and Edward Norton, are four artists who have outdone anything that they've ever done before in a unforgettably groundbreaking achievement called Birdman.
Good moments in half baked film. B

What an explosive film. "Birdman" is a one of a kind. An absolutely brilliant film that's packed to the gills with originality. Anchored by an exuberant score, brilliant direction, and groundbreaking cinematography. And the performances are all phenomenal. In particular, Michael Keaton and Edward Norton are mind blowing. A film that deserves to be seen by everyone. Definition of a must see. Holy fuck.
A masterpiece. It's about narcissism and the constant need of feeling loved, wanted, praised cherished, special. Beautiful metaphors, great directing, acting and pace.

What an unexpected, weird and amazing film by Director Alejandro González Iñárritu! Beautifully shot, he uses long, sustained shots to follow his characters on and off stage at a Broadway play being but on my an ageing movie star, known for an iconic role as the famous superhero, Birdman. Keaton gives a bravely meta performance that is complimented by amazing acting from Ed Norton, Amy Ryan and Emma Stone! Definitely worth seeing.

I found Birdman engaging due to Michael Keaton's performance. And I appreciate movies where the ending is whatever you want it to be. Still, the movie didn't leave me thinking "that was the Best Picture of the Year!" Whiplash left me with more of that feeling. 
     Michael Keaton deserved Best Actor more than the film deserved Best Picture. There's a lot of hidden clues of what's going on and pretty much figuring out the mind of someone going nuts which yes is brilliant. But I admired all that more than I loved it.
     Keaton didn't play Batman since 1992 and I enjoyed that his character Riggan didn't play Birdman since 1992. And that he was replaced in the 3rd film like Keaton was. Rather than the story being all about him losing his mind; I wanted more scenes poking fun at Batman.

Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu has finally topped his ambitious directoral debut epic Amores Perros with a stellar technical powerhouse fueled by outstanding performances, jaw dropping cinematography with impossibly long shots and an occasionally uproariously funny script layered with incisive Hollywood commentary. Birdman is the kind electrifying art house flick that comes around every once in a while to remind people like me why I keep coming back to the movies week after week.
The rise,fall and renaissance of a superhero movie-star.The one-shot photography of Emmanuel "Chivo" Lubezki is superb

Simply impressive. ´Birdman´ is a satire where the satire is just as much part of the satire as what´s being satirized about. A harsh critique of modern media culture that also attacks the hypocrisy of the indie scene who usually do the attacking. All this backed by iron clad performances, especially Keaton at his best, and mesmerizing direction.

Birdman can not be put into one category, it's a drama, a comedy, a character study, and, at times, even a sci-fi. Featuring great performances all around, especially from Michael Keaton, who should without a doubt win every leading actor award there is, and some magnificent direction, Alejandro Inarritu's exceptionally good movie is hysterical and, in equal measure, powerful; not to mention it's extreme sense of exigency. If Birdman isn't one of the best movies I've seen in a long time, it's certainly one of my favorites.

"Birdman" is a superb black comedy! The script is delightful and witty as he cleverly uses magical realism to near perfect effect as it examines the failure and fulfillment of fictional actor/director. It starts out a little pretentiously, but after the first five minutes or so it becomes quite an extraordinary film. "Birdman" is a washed up actor's struggle with - what we think as - schizophrenia. It really portrays in a clear and concise way, how actors are always falling in and out of the spotlight.
Michael Keaton is borderline miraculous! Loved the rest of the cast too! Clearly Edward Norton hasn't been this good in a movie in a long time. Naomi Watts is also super effective in a smaller role. And Emma Stone - hilarious! The whole cast is pretty damn talented!
What makes this movie so bloody great is the directing and the continuous shot approach. Really good stuff, but clearly not for everyone. Despite some occasional lapses in the writing and some periodic pacing issues in the first half-hour, the film delivers on all other fronts, especially its biting humor, intriguing visuals and stellar performances. The camera work is impressive. It is a must-see. From it's black comedy, to it's choppy drum score, this movie really impressed me.
It's so weird and I adored it! This is a strange and beautiful and unique film. A triumph on every creative level, from casting to execution.

C+
Well acted, funny

This an actors' film in the best sense.  The performances of every actor are magnificent, the dialogue is sharp and witty, and the story features some jarring, and often humorous, visual tangents that reaffirm the film's lofty artistic ambitions.  These things, paired with a one-of-a-kind shooting style, combine to make what is not only the best film of the year, but a new addition to my personal favorites.
there you go you motherfucker!

Highly ambitious and inventive, Birdman is writer/director Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu's most upbeat film by a long shot, examining the highs and lows of pop-culture, stardom, identity, film criticism and the movie biz. Brought to life by Emmanuel Lubezki's flawless cinematography, Antonio Sanchez's excellent jazzy, percussive score and a powerhouse cast, led by Michael Keaton in the best performance of his entire career, Birdman is easily one of the best films of 2014.

Full review at http://silverscreenfanatic.com/2014/11/07/birdman-or-the-unexpected-virtue-of-ignorance/

Original, confused, brilliantly acted, Birdman or The Unexpected virtue of Ignorance is catching in the form of actuation, screenplay really good crafted, and originally, originally perfectly recorded.

This film was a masterpiece. Alejandro G. IÃ±Ã¡rritu and Emmanuel Lubezki deserve all the credit in the world for bringing this style of filmmaking that is rarely seen and creating a film that is sure to be studied in film classes everywhere for years to come. Michael Keaton deserved an Oscar, which he sadly didn't win, and even though I'm not sure the film was that great of an accomplishment to win Best Picture, it most certainly deserved every other Oscar it won. Antonio SÃ¡nchez should have been nominated for an Oscar and also won.
Cinema can be made, and Inarritu has proved it. Birdman exists.
Hand Keaton the Oscar now. Multifaceted performance that only a career as long as his can allow. I've never seen anything quite like this film.
